headline: Your Money;   Finite-Life Realty Trusts
abstract: MANY people remember that real estate investment trusts - abbreviated REIT's and pronounced ''reets'' - received a bad name among individual investors in the mid-1970's. Many such trusts, particularly the mortgage trusts that concentrated on financing existing or developing property, had to borrow at higher interest rates than they earned when the prime lending rate soared. As a result, their share prices plummeted.   Conditions in the industry have changed, and the emphasis now is on equity trusts that own investment-grade income-producing property such as office buildings and shopping centers. But increasing attention is being focused on a version of the trusts called finite-life real estate investment trusts. These are abbreviated FREIT's and pronounced ''freets.''

headline: Oscar Mayer Realigns Its Top Management
abstract: The Oscar Mayer Foods Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Foods Corporation, said it had reorganized its top management to ''handle the rapid expansion and increased complexity of its business.''   James W. McVey, 53, has been named president of the company, which makes frankfurters, bacon and other processed meats and is based in Madison, Wis. He succeeds Jerry M. Hiegel, 58, who remains chairman and chief executive.

headline: PATENTS ;  A Versatile Grill Offered for Campers
abstract: A versatile and portable grill for campers was patented this week.

headline: Magnavox Order
abstract: The Magnavox Government and Industrial Electronics Company, a unit of the North American Philips Corporation, won a $37.6 million Army contract for terminals.

headline: Jacobs Raises Stake in Castle
abstract: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, said yesterday that he had increased his stake in Castle & Cooke Inc. to 13.5 percent, from 12.3 percent of the company's 25.8 million outstanding shares. Mr. Jacobs also said that he had sold his stake in Gulf and Western Industries, though he did not provide any details. He had purchased less than 5 percent of the company last month.

headline: SKY-MARSHAL PLAN DRAWS CRITICISM
abstract: Security experts found little merit yesterday in President Reagan's proposal for expanding the sky marshal force for use on international flights.   A spokesman for the International Air Transport Association, said in in Montreal: ''We're not happy about anybody having guns up in the air. There's a distinct danger to passengers and a bigger danger of damage to the aircraft.'' The association is the industry organization of the world's airlines and has 137 members.

headline: Addendum
abstract: Sports Illustrated is increasing its rate base 3.8 percent, to 2,725,000, with its Sept. 2 issue, and its advertising rates 3.1 percent.

headline: Chicago Railroad
abstract: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company will reduce its work force by about 13 percent, or 1,500 workers, over the next three years, its president, James R. Wolfe, told the company's annual meeting. He said the reduction was part of a program intended to save about $60 million. Mr. Wolfe said the company's second quarter ''should be better than the first,'' when it lost 80 cents a share. He also said the company was considering diversifying outside the rail business because Federal approval of a railroad acquisition would take two years and the company wanted to use its tax-loss carry-forwards more quickly than that.

headline: Metropolitan Museum Offer
abstract: To finance new special exhibition galleries and a new wing for modern art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is offering $45 million of bonds this week through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley.   The bonds, which were issued by the New York State Dormitory Authority on behalf of the museum, carry interest rates ranging from 5.90 percent in 1988 to 8.90 percent in 2000 and 9.20 percent in 2015.   Rated Aa by Moody's and Ax by S.& P., the bonds are a general obligation of the museum and are backed by revenues from its $229 million endowment and regular operations.

headline: DOLLAR EXPECTED TO BE FAIRLY DOCILE
abstract: After half a year of roller-coaster activity, the dollar has calmed.   Economists and traders have been wrong too many times to predict continued stability with any confidence. But many suggest that for the near term, at least, the dollar may remain relatively docile, although somewhat upwardly mobile.   ''It has begun to stabilize a bit,'' said S. Waite Rawls, managing director and head of trading at the First Boston Corporation.

headline: Christians in China Mark Day
abstract: Foreigners took a bus from Peking and celebrated Easter at a sunrise service atop the 2,500-year-old Great Wall today, and thousands of Chinese Christians flocked to churches. Five buses carrying Peking-based diplomats, business people, students and a few tourists left the capital at 4 A.M. for the 90-minute journey to the Great Wall here, where a minister from Hong Kong led a 30-minute service.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: U.S. AND INDIA DOUBTFUL ON ANY ARMS DEAL SOON
abstract: Reagan Administration officials affirmed today that the United States was willing to sell arms to India, but did not expect any transactions soon in view of India's military ties to Moscow.   Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in a meeting with reporters today seemed reluctant to enter into arms accords with the United States. He said that in the past the Americans had linked arms sales to foreign policy considerations and were not reliable suppliers.

headline: 44 FILIPINOS KILLED IN THEATER BLAZE
abstract: A rural audience fled in panic from a fire in a movie house complex in the southern Philippines today, and 44 people, most of them teen-agers, were killed, the police said.   Fifty-three people were injured.   ''Somebody shouted fire and all of a sudden there was confusion - people started rushing to the doors,'' said Jeanette Barja, 13 years old, who was one of 20 people injured seriously enough to be hospitalized. She spoke in a telephone interview from a hospital in Tabaco, 200 miles southeast of Manila.

headline: Nuclear Power Study
abstract: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington said today that President Reagan would join in a ''Cabinet-level review'' of the nuclear power industry in an effort to increase its faltering share of United States energy production.   In a speech to utility executives, Mr. Herrington attacked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and the utilities for ''the public's perception that nuclear power is unsafe, unworkable and too expensive.'' The review of the nuclear power industry is to be conducted by a council of ''selected Cabinet members.''

headline: New Dillon Managing Director
abstract: James W. Stevens, who for the past decade has been involved in investment banking activities at Citicorp, most recently as chairman of its venture capital unit, has been named a managing director at Dillon, Read & Company, the Wall Street firm announced. The appointment is effective today.    In a telephone interview, Mr. Stevens, who is 48, said that he would be combining skills acquired at Citicorp with a corporate finance background he developed at the now-defunct brokerage firm of Laird & Company, where he was executive vice president and director of corporate finance.

headline: Uganda Opposition Deputies Assail Human Rights Abuses
abstract: Uganda's opposition deputies walked out of Parliament today to protest the Government's record on human rights, witnesses said.

headline: Data Bank;   April 28, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: Control Data Has Rating Cut
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday that it had lowered the rating on $2.5 billion of debt of the Commercial Credit Company. It also downgraded the rating on $34 million of Control Data Corporation debt.

headline: DR. KING HONORED BY WIDE PROTESTS
abstract: Protesters around the country yesterday marked the 17th anniversary of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with vigorous demonstrations against racism that included a rally of 4,000 people outside the South African Embassy in Washington and the barricading of a Columbia University building.    At Columbia's campus on Morningside Heights in Manhattan, protesters of racial separation in South Africa wrapped a silver-link chain around the handles of the main door of Hamilton Hall and 250 students massed at the building's steps. Leaders of the group said the students would not leave until Columbia's board of trustees issued a statement that it would divest itself of its $33 million of holdings in companies that do business in South Africa.   Access to the building, which is on the east side of the campus's graceful quadrangle, was possible through a subterranean passageway, but many professors canceled classes in the building. The building, which was occupied by students in a 1968 protest, contains the offices of many of the university's administrators, though many were able to work throughout the demonstration.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 27, 1985:

headline: TWO BOOKS CAST LIGHT ON A DIM SUBJECT
abstract: UNEASY PARTNERSHIP, BY STEPHEN D. COHEN, BALINGER PUBLISHING CO., CAMBRIDGE, MASS. 219 pages TRADE WAR, BY STEVEN SCHOLSSSTEIN, CONGDON & WEED, NEW YORK. 268 pages.   ABOUT a century ago, Japanese people still believed that Americans wore heels on their shoes because, like dogs, their natural heels did not touch the ground. And they understood unmarried American women to be called Joan, while married women are named Joanson.   Citizens of both countries can laugh about that kind of misinformation today. But misinformation of more insidious nature continues to circulate in both countries about the reasons for Japan's trade surpluses. It is more than coincidental that Mr. Schlossstein's book was published in the United States as ''Trade War,'' yet appeared in Japanese under a title that may be loosely rendered as ''It's Not Japan's Fault.''

headline: U.S. Plans Record Financing
abstract: The Treasury yesterday announced plans for a record note and bond financing next week, but the heavy supply was not enough to prevent a modest rise in prices of outstanding Treasury notes and bonds.   Many market participants estimated that lower prices and higher interest rates would eventually be needed to attract investors to the $20.5 billion of new Treasury issues, but they added that the supply of new issues was only one factor among many that will influence interest rates in coming days.   ''The real obstacle facing the market is upcoming economic data, not the Treasury's package,'' said William Sullivan, senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''The market's perception of money supply data and employment statistics later this week will be crucial to determining the rate levels when the new issues are auctioned.''

headline: CBS Defends Independence
abstract: Amid continuing rumors about a possible takeover attempt, Thomas H. Wyman, the chairman and chief executive of CBS Inc., today reasserted his company's intention to remain independent.   ''Over the past several months, we have faced challenges from several parties who would either oversee or overturn the organization which has provided news and information for 58 years,'' Mr. Wyman said, speaking at the company's highly charged annual meeting, where many of the broadcaster's critics spoke out.   ''The integrity of CBS News and the independence of CBS News are inextricably linked,'' he continued. ''Those who seek to gain control of CBS in order to gain control of CBS News threaten that independence and that integrity - and this country.''

headline: Exxon Layoffs
abstract: The Exxon Corporation unit that coordinates the company's international supply and transportation of crude oil will lay off between 25 and 50 employees June 1, according to Thomas Hayes, an Exxon spokesman. Mr. Hayes said the employees work for the Exxon International Company, which has a staff of 500 and is based in Florham Park, N.J. He said the dismissals generally stemmed from the sharp decline in recent years of the volume of crude oil shipped by the company, and specifically from the company's closing of its refinery in Aruba in March.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM PRAVDA INTERVIEW WITH GORBACHEV ON RELATIONS WITH U. S.
abstract: Following are excerpts from the text of a Pravda interview with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, as translated and distributed today by Tass:      There is an acute need of international cooperation in developing dialogue, in searching for realistic solutions that would ease tension in the world and help block the road of the arms race. All states, big and small, should take part in this. Quite understandably, a special role belongs to nuclear powers and first of all to the Soviet Union and the United States of America.   The relations between the U.S.S.R. and the U.S.A. are an exceptionally important factor of international politics. But we are far from looking at the world only through the prism of these relations. We understand what the weight is of other countries in international affairs and take this into consideration when evaluating the general situation in the world.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN MICROWAVE COOKING
abstract: UNTIL recently, microwave ovens were probably the least purchased - and least utilized - major household appliance. They were bulky, tricky to use and feared as a possible source of radiation. Even those few souls who bought microwaves rarely really cooked in them, using them instead to defrost, reheat or prepare frozen dinners in a hurry.

headline: U.S. Trust Plans Appeal
abstract: The U.S. Trust Company of New York said today that it planned to appeal a court ruling this week that the company's bid to open a limited-service bank in Florida was illegal.   ''We don't see this as the last word,'' Rodney Woods, the marketing director for U.S. Trust, said.

headline: Dynamics Pays Fine to Navy
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation, saying it did not want to further damage relations with the Navy, has paid a $676,283 fine to satisfy a finding that it gave illegal gifts to now retired Adm.

headline: 172 ARE WOUNDED
abstract: A car bomb exploded in predominantly Christian East Beirut today, killing at least 50 people and wounding 172, according to radio reports tonight.   The bombing came as fighting between Palestinian guerrillas and Shiite Moslem militiamen continued into a fourth day in the heavily populated southern sections of the city and its suburbs.   Authorities said at least 34 people had been killed and 157 wounded in Palestinian-Shiite battles today. The casualty totals since the fighting started Sunday are believed to have reached at least 155 killed and more than 800 wounded.

headline: TO CANADIANS, SHE STANDS IN FOR MONARCH
abstract: Four times a year, Jeanne Sauve sits down to write what she calls a ''rather personal'' letter to the Queen of England, informing her about the state of affairs in Canada.   ''It's an old tradition which is rather nice,'' Mrs. Sauve said. For in one of those touches that define the difference between Americans and Canadians, Queen Elizabeth II still reigns as Queen of Canada. And Jeanne Sauve, a former journalist and politician, serves as her personal representative.

headline: WIDE STRIKE BRINGS THE SUDAN TO A HALT
abstract: A general strike organized by opponents of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry crippled the Sudan today, forcing the shutdown of businesses, transportation and basic services.   According to reports reaching here, strike leaders vowed to continue until Mr. Nimeiry is driven from office. The President was visiting the United States when the most recent strike began Wednesday.    Mr. Nimeiry, in an interview published today in Saudi Arabia, said that the strike was a ''transient matter'' and that he would still be President when he returns home.

headline: Interest Rates Are Mixed
abstract: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with short-term rates little changed while note and bond yields fell slightly.          By late in the day, prices for outstanding Treasury issues were up as much as 1/4 point for long-term bonds, with the 11 1/4 percent issue due in 2015 offered at 99 1/8, to yield 11.36 percent. As recently as midday on April 4, the 11 1/4 percent bonds were offered at 96 2/32, to yield 11.75 percent.

headline: U.S. 'Friendship Flier' Locked Up in Soviet
abstract: An American who brought his light airplane to Moscow on an officially approved ''friendship flight'' spent his three days here locked in a hotel because he arrived without a visa.   But the flier, Millard Harmon, 59 years old, a retired college administrator from Delmar, N.Y., was all smiles as he passed out ceremonial gifts to his hosts before he left today.

headline: French Bus Wreck Kills One
abstract: A bus carrying 55 supporters of the Bordeaux soccer team went out of control on a sharp turn today and fell onto a ledge in a ravine, killing one person and injuring 17, the police said.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Accounts    * Center, the magazine of Rockefeller Center, to Decker, Decker & Freas.

headline: THE EXECUTIVE CXOMPUTER: PUTTING THE BERNOULLI BOX TO WORK
abstract: FLOPPY disks are portable and easily switched from one computer to another.   They provide inexpensive archival memory as well; the mechanical drives for the disks being relatively low in cost and the floppies themselves downright cheap. Unfortunately, the storage capacity of floppy disks is low, and the time it takes to access data on them begins to seem somewhere just this side of eternity once one's initial enthusiasm for personal computing cools.   Hard disks, on the other hand, offer both quick access and large storage capacity. But they do so at the sacrifice of portability and the addition of considerable cost. They also introduce the factor of sensitivity to such outside influences as shock and dirt particles.

headline: MEAD'S BID FOR CROWN FALLS APART
abstract: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation yesterday thought it had a deal to be sold to the Mead Corporation. Then it tried to make peace with Sir James Goldsmith, the British businessman who has sought control of the company. But it ended the day empty-handed.

headline: IRAN HOSTAGES DESCRIBE THE TRAUMA
abstract: Some of the Americans held hostage for 444 days in Iran said yesterday that while they may have been better prepared than those being held in the current Beirut crisis, there is really no way one can prepare for the fear of the actual event.   ''The factor of fear is common to both situations,'' said Moorhead C. Kennedy Jr., the third-ranking diplomat in the United States Embassy when it was taken over in Teheran. ''But I think its harder for them now.''   Mr. Kennedy, 54 years old, said he and the others taken hostage in Teheran in 1979 had been given a special seminar on terrorism. In that seminar they had been warned of the dangers of being taken hostage and how to handle themselves if they were.

headline: Minstar Extends AMF Tender Bid
abstract: Minstar Inc., which is embroiled in a takeover battle with AMF Inc., said that it had extended the expiration date for its $23-a-share tender offer for 12 million shares, or 43 percent of AMF, to 5 P.M. today. Minstar said the offer was already oversubscribed, noting that about 15.9 million shares have been deposited, including 3.8 million tendered subject to guarantees of delivery.

headline: GREECE URGES AMERICANS TO IGNORE REAGAN'S TRAVEL WARNING
abstract: Greece appealed to Americans today to disregard President Reagan's warnings against travel to this country.   In his news conference Tuesday, Mr. Reagan advised Americans to avoid Athens Airport, from where the hijacked Trans World Airlines plane took off last Friday, until security at the airport was improved. Greece's tourist earnings are a principal source of foreign exchange.   Two senior officials of the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou rejected allegations of lax security procedures, while conceding that official warnings to American travelers were beginning to hurt the tourist industry.

headline: McDonnell, Northrop Suit The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the Northrop Corporation yesterday announced
abstract: a settlement of a 1979 private   antitrust suit over who will   build the F-18 jet fighter for the   export market. Under terms of the settlement, McDonnell Douglas will   pay Northrop $50 million.

headline: Somali Cholera Outbreak Reported to Kill 1,500
abstract: The cholera epidemic that began two weeks ago at a camp for Ethiopian refugees in northwestern Somalia has taken more than 1,500 lives, according to official radio reports.

headline: TEXT OF DECLARATION AT END OF 7-NATION ECONOMIC CONFERENCE
abstract: Following is the text of the joint declaration made public today at the end of the seven-nation economic conference:      [1]  Conscious of the responsibility which we bear, together with other governments, for the future of the world economy and the preservation of natural resources, we, the heads of state or government of seven major industrial nations and the president of the Commission of the European Communities, meeting in Bonn from May 2 to 4, 1985, have discussed the economic outlook, problems and prospects for our countries and the world. [2]  World economic conditions are better than they have been for a considerable time. Since we last met, further progress has been achieved in bringing down inflation and strengthening the basis for growth. The recovery in the industrial countries has begun to spread to the developing world. The debt problems of developing countries, though far from solved, are being flexibly and effectively addressed. [3]  Nevertheless, our countries face still important challenges. Above all, we need:    * To strengthen the ability of our economies to respond to new developments;    * To increase job opportunites;    * To reduce social inequalities;    * To correct persistent economic imbalances;    * To halt protectionism; and

headline: Major Blackout in Chile Attributed to Terrorists
abstract: An explosion in the nation's main power station blacked out 80 percent of Chile Friday night. The Government said today that terrorists opposed to the military Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet were responsible.

headline: Newspaper Ad Bureau Re-Elects All Officers
abstract: Members of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau meeting in Miami Beach yesterday re-elected all of their officers.   W. Thomas Johnson and Frank A. Daniels Jr. will once again serve as chairman and vice chairman, respectively. Mr. Johnson is publisher and chief executive of The Los Angeles Times. Mr. Daniels is president and publisher of The Raleigh News & Observer. Richard E. Diamond, publisher of The Staten Island Advance, the treasurer, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, the secretary and assistant treasurer, were also re-elected.

headline: Iraqi Air Raids Kill 41; Iran Hits Border Towns
abstract: Iraqi warplanes attacked the Kurdish town of Sardasht in northwestern Iran today, and Iran said 41 people were killed and 51 were wounded.   In Baghdad, an Iraqi military spokesman said two air raids on a military camp at Sardasht, 10 miles from the Iraqi border, were among a series of attacks on Iranian towns today, including two raids on Teheran.

headline: ADVERTISING;Gentlemen's Quarterly Names a Publisher
abstract: Jack Kliger must have performed well as West Coast manager of Gentlemen's Quarterly before he quit for another job because S.I. Newhouse Jr., chairman of  Conde Nast Publications, has reached out to grab him for the newly vacant publisher's chair at GQ.         Mr. Kliger, 38 years old, most recently has been associate publisher of California magazine. At GQ, he replaces Steven Florio, who was named publisher of Conde Nast's newly acquired New Yorker.

headline: SHULTZ, IN VIENNA, TALKS TO GROMYKO
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko agreed today to strengthen the framework of Soviet-American relations, even though sharp disagreements remain on arms control and international issues like Central America.   After an unusually long session, a six-hour meeting at the Soviet Embassy here, the two sides seemed to be moving toward an announcement on a meeting later this year between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.      Officials Won't Discuss Topic   At a briefing for reporters, three of the American participants repeatedly refused to comment on any question dealing with a Reagan-Gorbachev meeting. On Monday, Mr. Shultz said that an American invitation for a meeting in Washington was on the table and that it was up to the Soviet Union to respond. Today, the American officials said they could not and would not discuss the matter.

headline: R.J. Reynolds Sees Profit Dilution
abstract: J. Tylee Wilson, the chairman of R.J. Reynolds Industries, said yesterday that there would be some dilution of his company's earnings as a result of its proposed $4.9 billion acquisition of Nabisco Brands Inc., but he declined to elaborate.   Mr. Wilson said any calculation of the dilution would ''simply be speculative'' because the interest and dividend rates on the new preferred stock and debt securities to be issued to pay for the purchase had not yet been fixed.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Allied Corp. said that it agreed to postpone until July 8, from June 28, the purchase of the common stock of Signal Cos. in its tender offer for up to 22 million shares at $45 each. The postponement gives the antitrust division of the Justice Department more time to review the transaction.    * Ansett Transport Industries, the Australian air carrier, said that it would spend $500 million on 12 new Boeing 737-300 twin jets. Ansett is owned jointly by Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd. and Rupert Murdoch's News Corp.

headline: Beber, Silverstein Wins Luxury Car Account
abstract: Beber, Silverstein & Partners Advertising of Miami and New York is going to be the agency for a new British and Japanese motorcar that is to be imported here by the newly formed Austin Rover Car of North America in Miami.   The 1987 models of the luxury line, powered by Honda engines, will first be available here in the fall of 1986.   The Government-owned British car company will have a 49 percent equity in the Miami corporation, but the majority owner will be Norman Braman, who owns 17 automobile dealerships and the Philadelphia Eagles football team.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN UNION STORMS APARTHEID'S BASTIONS
abstract: It was gold that drew whites to war with one another many decades ago on the uplands of the Reef, in the Transvaal region of South Africa.   Now, in these same reaches where Briton once fought Afrikaner for control of Africa's wealthiest mineral deposits, a different war is shaping up, one in which the nation's white mining barons face an emergent and increasingly powerful black mining union.   It is a fight, some people assert, that will be more telling in its impact than the confrontations that have blazed in the black townships since last September, for it has assumed the proportions of a crusade against bastions of apartheid that once helped entrench the power of mineowners.      Paradox for Employers    A paradox is that the employers seem to acknowledge that eventually it will be more fruitful to deal with centralized labor unions, even though those labor organizations have cast themselves as the vanguard of a political struggle against white rule. This struggle, unlike its counterpart among the disaffected youth of the townships, may reinforce its aspirations with the power of economic veto over a critical industry.

headline: SOURCE OF PRIDE NOW A SOURCE OF LIVERPOOL SORROW
abstract: ''You'll Never Walk Alone,'' says the wrought-iron motto over the gates of the Liverpool soccer club. After Brussels, that sense of shared euphoria has been replaced by other emotions: shock, chagrin and anger.   In the pubs and narrow brick homes of a city that has already been brought to its knees by fleeing industries and unemployment, these new emotions are especially hard to bear. For a long time, Liverpudlians have been living on pride.   Their two soccer clubs, Liverpool and Everton, were both champions this year. Everton, the League Cup winner in England, played five matches on the Continent on its way to winning the European Cup Winner's Cup. All went off uneventfully, including the final match in Rotterdam on May 15. #21 Years of Good Behavior As the Liverpool fans set off for Brussels to see their team, the national champions, play the Italian champions, the Juventus team of Turin, for the European Cup on June 5, they took with them a 21-year record of good behavior. Then came the horror of the violence, seen by millions on television, before the match could begin.

headline: 'CHAOTIC' CONDITIONS FEARED AT U.N.'S PARLEY ON WOMEN
abstract: A panel preparing a United Nations-sponsored conference on women's issues completed its work last week, leaving a dispute between representatives of Western and third-world nations undecided. Western diplomats predicted the conference would be ''chaotic'' and ''disastrous.''   Western representatives expressed fears that political issues they consider marginal to improving the worldwide status of women would dominate the proceedings in Nairobi, Kenya, in July. The meeting, similar to two previous gatherings, will mark the end of the United Nations Decade for Women.

headline: COMMERCIALIZING OLYMPIC CHAMPIONS
abstract: UNTIL a few years ago, only Joe Namath, O.J. Simpson and a handful of other athletes commanded the celebrity status to sell products just by saying they used them. But the physical fitness mania sweeping the country has made numerous corporations anxious to include athletics - and thus athletes - in their advertising campaigns. Thus, a growing number of amateur athletes can now be seen hyping McDonald's hamburgers, mugging for Vidal Sassoon's latest styling mousse, and generally plugging products that have little to do with the sport they play.   None of the newcomers are commanding the type of fees that Mr. Namath or other superstars get. But they earn enough to provide lucrative percentages for the agents responsible for honing their images, negotiating their contracts, even managing their finances.   The result is that sports marketing - a somewhat misleading term coined by industry officials to describe a business that promotes individual athletes rather than the sports they play - has, by some estimates, mushroomed into a sophisticated, $10 billion industry.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bloomingdale's said Barry Marchessault had been promoted to senior vice president in its catalogue division.    * Bristol-Myers Co. has elected C. Benjamin Brooks Jr. president of its Clairol division.

headline: ISSUERS DISRUPT TRADING IN MORTGAGE CERTIFICATES
abstract: Trading in $110 million of mortgage pass-through securities was disrupted yesterday, after the three major issuing agencies instructed their transfer agents not to complete trades until disputes surrounding the ownership of the securities have been settled.   The tempest stems from the failures of three government securities dealers since early March - E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., Bevill, Bresler & Schulman, and Parr Securities Corporation. In late March, thrift institutions and municipal governments began filing ''notices of adverse claims'' to protect their interest in mortgage securities that they claim were used as collateral for loans they made to the securities firms.

headline: PURCHASERS' INDEX STAGNANT IN MAY
abstract: After entering the second quarter on a mixed note, the economy turned flat in May, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday.   In its most recent survey of purchasing managers at 250 major industrial companies, the trade association said that new orders, production and inventories fell sharply, while employment continued to be weak and the rate of price decreases slowed.   The group's composite index of indicators, adjusted for seasonal variation, remained unchanged in April and May at 47.3 percent, its lowest level since January 1983 when it was 46.9 percent. It had slipped in February, March and April. A reading below 50 percent indicates that the economy is in decline; anything above means that it is expanding.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *       Advanced Systems Inc., Arlington Heights, Ill., said it intended to make purchases of its common stock and series A $3.50 convertible preferred stock under the 1985 stock purchase plan adopted on Monday.     *       Amoco Production Co., the oil exploration and production unit of Standard Oil Co. (Indiana), said it had signed an oil exploration agreement with the Government of Tanzania.

headline: Security Traders President
abstract: John L. Watson 3d, an executive vice president and director of capital markets at Robinson Humphrey/ American Express Inc., has been selected as the next president of the National Security Traders Association.   Mr. Watson succeeds Morton N. Weiss, 65, who has served as president of the trade association since 1973. Mr. Weiss, who during his tenure has become a well-known spokesman for the securities industry, will continue to serve as a consultant into next year, the traders association said.

headline: Home State Sale Gains
abstract: The Ohio Senate narrowly passed a bill today permitting the use of state funds to complete the sale of the failed Home State Savings Bank to Chemical New York Corporation. Senator David L. Hobson, the Senate sponsor, conceded that the bill stopped short of the $125.2 million Chemical had requested in state funds to help complete the deal. The House cut the state outlay to $92.1 million, and the Senate did not restore the reduction.

headline: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD DOWN 10.7% IN MONTH
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 26.7 million shares, or 10.7 percent, in the month ended April 15, to 223.5 million shares. The record was set last month, when short interest totaled 250.2 million shares. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 202.5 million shares.   In the same period, the short interest on the American Stock Exchange was down 161,427 shares, to 18 million shares.    A short position can result from the sale of borrowed stock in the hope of buying the same issue at a later date and at a lower price to cover the sale.

headline: DEMOCRATIC PARTY'S RESPONSE TO THE TAX PROPOSAL
abstract: Following is a transcript of the response last night by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, to President Reagan's speech, as recorded by The New York Times:   Good evening, I'm Congressman Dan Rostenkowski from Chicago.   Let me read you something that pretty well explains what tax reform is all about, and what Democrats are all about:   ''The continued escape of privileged groups from taxation violates the fundamental democratic principle of fair treatment for all and undermines public confidence in the tax system.''   That was President Harry Truman's message to Congress 35 years ago.   Trying to tax people and businesses fairly. That's been the historic Democratic commitment. Our roots lie with working families all over the country, like the Polish neighborhood where I grew up on the northwest side of Chicago.

headline: I.B.M. Outlook
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation, despite an anticipated pickup in product introduction during the year, will not be ''immune'' to a United States or worldwide economic downturn in 1986, said James J. Forese, vice president and controller. Mr. Forese, responding to questions from securities analysts, said that if a recession struck the United States, ''our growth projections would have to be changed.''

headline: FAILED COAST UNIT GIVEN A MANAGER
abstract: James C. Schmidt, the president and managing officer of the Great American First Savings Bank of San Diego, has 28 years of experience in the thrift industry, and every year of it will probably come in handy during the next few weeks.   In addition to his duties at Great American, Mr. Schmidt will be president and chief executive officer of the Southern California Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board declared that thrift unit insolvent last week, chartered a new institution to assume its assets and liablities and gave Great American a 90-day contract to manage it.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: April 11, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 3 P.M.   Preparatory Committee for 40th Anniversary of U.N. - 10:30 A.M.

headline: More Than 60 Detained In South Korean Protest
abstract: More than 60 students were detained by the police today after demonstrating in support of colleagues who occupied the United States Information Service building last week, dissident sources said.   They said students scattered leaflets and shouted slogans late Wednesday in downtown Seoul, about four blocks from the American library that was occupied for four days.

headline: FRANKFURT BOMBERS NOT KNOWN
abstract: The Frankfurt police said today that they were following several leads in the bombing of the city's international airport but that they still had no indication of who might have set off the explosion.   A Portuguese man and two Australian children were killed when the bomb exploded in a departure lounge Wednesday afternoon, and 42 people were treated for wounds.   The police identified the dead man as Enrique de Araujo, the head of the Portuguese chapter of an anti-Communist organization known as the Collegiate Association for Research of Principles. He was said to have just arrived in Frankfurt from West Berlin, where he had taken part in a protest action against the Berlin wall.

headline: Italian Court Convicts 16 As Sardinian Separatists
abstract: Sixteen people were convicted today of involvement in a plot to make Sardinia independent from Italy.

headline: SHULTZ WARY OF ANTI-APARTHEID MOVES
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz declared today that there should be a national consensus that ''apartheid must go,'' but he said the Reagan Administration continued to oppose any economic sanctions against South Africa.   In a long policy speech timed for the start of Congressional hearings on 20 bills involving South Africa, Mr. Shultz said the measures were ''well intentioned'' but would have the counterproductive effect of reducing American influence on South African policy and would not help South Africa's blacks.   ''The only course consistent with American values is to engage ourselves as a force for constructive, peaceful change,'' he said in a speech to the National Press Club. ''It is not our business to cheer on, from the sidelines, the forces of polarization that could erupt in a race war; it is not our job to exacerbate hardship, which could lead to the same result.''

headline: GANDHI TRIES TO REACH SIKH ACCORD
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi is stepping up the Indian Government's attempt to negotiate with Sikh leaders to avert a confrontation that many fear may occur next weekend.    Sikh leaders have set April 13 as the date for a renewal of agitation if their demands are not met. There is concern that demonstrations and violence may resume in Punjab, the state on the Pakistani border where Sikhs predominate.   A month ago, Mr. Gandhi, in a change of tactics, began making concessions to the Sikhs, freeing eight leaders held in prison since June and directing his aides to make contact with these and other Sikhs.

headline: Criticism Of S.E.C.
abstract: The chairman of a House panel today chastised the Securities and Exchange Commission for not heeding ''red flag'' improprieties by a New Jersey securities firm years before its collapse this April.   Representative Doug Barnard, Democrat of Georgia, chairman of a House Government Operations subcommittee on commerce, told the S.E.C. chairman John S. R. Shad that his agency did not appear to take vigorous action against the Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Asset Management Corporation, despite repeated violations by the firm over the last eight years.

headline: STORAGE'S COMEBACK STRATEGY
abstract: The Storage Technology Corporation, attempting to convince customers that it will emerge from bankruptcy proceedings, yesterday introduced a new high-speed disk drive and said the company would return to profitability by the beginning of next year.   The disk drive, the company's first new product since it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last fall, is intended to match International Business Machines Corporation's new 3380 models, which are high-speed drives used with mainframe computers. The Storage Technology model will be delivered at the end of 1986, company officials said, about a year after I.B.M. begins shipments of its drives.   In an interview in New York yesterday, the company's new management said that the primary importance of the announcement was symbolic. ''Customers are telling us that we have to prove that we are going to be around,'' said Ryal R. Poppa, the corporate turnaround specialist who took over Storage Technology 13 weeks ago. ''We will be around. And now the customer base is beginning to come back, because they want to see us succeed and they want an alternative to I.B.M.''

headline: PATENTS;  A Car Seat for Pets
abstract: Paul R. Rux of Las Vegas, Nev., was granted a patent this week on a pet seat for automobiles. Intended for cats and small dogs, it has a harness and a hinged front wall that will permit various lying, sitting and standing positions for the animal. A drawing in patent 4,512,286 portrays a comfortable-looking dog strapped into the seat.

headline: REAGAN ASSERTS RUSSIAN TROOPS HELP NICARAGUA
abstract: President Reagan said today that the Soviet Union had ''military personnel'' in the battle zones of northern Nicaragua near the Honduran border.     A White House official said later that the Soviet personnel, few in number, had been sighted near Ocotal, where there is a Sandinista military garrison.    Mr. Reagan, speaking in his weekly radio address, said, ''Just this week, we confirmed the presence of Russian military personnel in the battle zones of northern Nicaragua.''        Attacks Democratic Proposal    The President also used the radio address to label a Democratic alternative to his proposal to provide relief aid to the Nicaraguan rebels as a ''shameful surrender'' that would ''hasten the consolidation of Nicaragua as a Communist-terrorist arsenal.''

headline: U. S. POWER IN ASIA HAS GROWN SINCE VIETNAM
abstract: Ten years after the defeat of South Vietnam, there is widespread agreement among policy analysts that the position of the United States in Asia is stronger now than at any time since the end of World War II. In April 1975, it was in shambles.     A decade ago, in victory, North Vietnam looked invincible. Now the economy of united Vietnam is stagnating and Hanoi is mired down in its own ''Vietnam'' in Cambodia.    In the span of 10 years, policy analysts say, Vietnam, the Soviet Union and most Communist movements in Asia tumbled from victory or ascendancy to decline, while the United States moved from defeat to a position of strength.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THURSDAY, MAY 2, 1985        The Economy    The Senate soundly rejected a proposed curtailment of Social Security cost-of-living increases, an important element of the White House budget package. Several Senators said the Social Security amendment could lead to the unraveling of the overall budget package. [Page A1.]  Sentiment for a stiffer minimum tax appears to be growing in Congress. [D25.]

headline: Boston Bank Is Criticized
abstract: Top executives of the Bank of Boston were fiercely criticized at a House hearing today on the bank's failure to adhere to currency trading laws and its dealings with organized crime figures.   ''We've seen massive mismanagement and stupidity,'' said Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Connecticut.

headline: TIGHT BUDGET, EASY MONEY
abstract: How would the Federal Reserve Board -- Washington's most independent economic actor -- react if the Senate and the House manage to reduce the Federal deficit for fiscal 1986 by $25 billion to $35 billion?   Allen Siani, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers, who thinks this scenario is increasingly likely, predicts that the Fed would be forced to offset the restrictive economic impact of such a deficit cut.

headline: LEADING INDICATORS DOWN 0.2%
abstract: The index of leading indicators, the Government's main forecasting gauge, registered a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the first drop this year, the Commerce Department reported today.   Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige called the April leading indicator report ''disappointing'' but insisted that ''several signs point to a pickup in the economy.''   ''Consumer confidence and consumer spending both improved in April and housing starts rose to their highest level in a year,'' he said. ''The catch-up in Federal income tax refunds now in progress should add to consumer demand. These developments will be bolstered by recent declines in interest rates, leading to stronger growth through the rest of the year.''

headline: Lucas, Duralith
abstract: Lucas Industries said Friday that it was offering to acquire the Duralith Corporation of Millville, N.J., for $24 million. The offer, $20 a share, is subject to approval by Duralith shareholders, who are expected to vote within two months. Duralith makes graphic control panel assemblies.

headline: S.E.C. STUDIES PICKENS ON DISCLOSURE TIMING
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether an investor group headed by T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, violated Federal securities laws that govern insider trading, fraud and timely disclosure of takeover plans, Mesa said yesterday. The Pickens group, Mesa Partners II, is currently locked in a takeover battle with the Unocal Corporation for control of the California oil company.   A Federal judge in California said last Thursday that Unocal would ''probably be able to prove at trial'' that the Pickens group had violated the law in February when it said its original holding of Unocal stock was for investment purposes only.   Analysts and securities lawyers said it was still too early to tell if there would be any impact on Mr. Pickens's takeover attempt from either the S.E.C. investigation or further court action stemming from lawsuits filed by Unocal. In active trading yesterday, Unocal's shares gained 62.5 cents, to $46.375.

headline: Comptroller Denies Bids
abstract: The Comptroller of the Currency, C. Todd Conover, has rejected applications from the BankAmerica Corporation and the American Security Corporation to set up ''non-bank'' bank subsidiaries.   A spokesman, Lee Cross, said today that the applications were rejected last week based on confidential information compiled by examiners from the Comptroller's office.

headline: FOREIGNERS FIND TERROR EXEMPTS NO ONE IN BEIRUT
abstract: A week ago, a British professor decided to rush his blond daughter, a student, out of West Beirut after a secretary at the French Embassy was kidnapped.     The secretary's abduction, three days before, deepened the apprehension among Westerners still in Beirut because it showed that foreign women were no longer immune from kidnapping.    The apprehension did not ease after the French secretary, Danielle Perez, was freed. The wife of a French businessman, for instance, dyed her hair jet black so she would not look quite as foreign.         'Scouts' Survey Streets    For many months, Westerners, Eastern bloc nationals and even Arabs, Lebanese and non-Lebanese alike, have lived in constant fear of being kidnapped or killed. Now, after a new wave of abductions of foreigners in the last month, an even more oppressive atmosphere has settled on Beirut.

headline: 16 DISSISDENTS IN SOUTH AFRICA WIN FIGHT FOR BAIL
abstract: Sixteen prominent opponents of the Government won a protracted legal battle today to obtain their release on bail. They are to be tried later this month on charges of high treason.   Defense lawyers, however, said the terms of bail, set by a Supreme Court judge at the equivalent of $85,000 for the group, resembled house arrest, since the dissidents are required to report twice daily to the police, stay away from political gatherings and remain home between 9 P.M. and 6 A.M.   The 16 are all members or supporters of the United Democratic Front, a nonracial opposition alliance that says it has 600 affiliate groups and a following of over 1.5 million. It is the biggest extra-parliamentary opposition organization in the country The dissidents had been refused bail since the police, invoking security laws, began detaining them in October for what is expected to be the biggest political trial in South Africa in a quarter of a century. At one point, the Attorney General of Natal Province issued an order forbidding bail altogether, but a Supreme Court judge overruled it, enabling them to apply for bail again today at the Supreme Court in Pietermaritzburg.

headline: Market Place;   Health Care In Spotlight
abstract: THE announcement on Sunday of plans to   create the nation's largest health care company had Wall Street buzzing yesterday with the possibility of other consolidations that might develop in the $400 billion-a-year industry. The takeover spotlight swung suddenly from the oil and natural gas pipeline industries to health care - the province of hospital beds, disposable syringes and nursing homes.    Triggering this conjecture was the proposed merger of the Hospital Corporation of America, the nation's largest hospital management company, and the American Hospital Supply Corporation, the largest distributor of hospital supplies.   ''The real driving force to this merger is the balance sheet - not the earnings,'' Todd Richter, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company, said yesterday. ''After the merger, the surviving company will have a debt-to-equity ratio of 38 percent to 62 percent. In contrast, by the end of 1985, Hospital Corporation would have had a ratio of 56 percent to 44 percent. Moreover, the combined company will have $1 billion a year in cash flow and this means that Hospital Corporation can accelerate its trend of acquiring not-for-profit hospitals.''

headline: REAGAN'S LISBON NEWS CONFERENCE AND WASHINGTON REMARKS
abstract: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's news conference in Lisbon yesterday, as recorded by The Associated Press, and a transcript of his statement on his arrival in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:   News Conference Well, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to share with you this morning some of the more significant results of this trip and to take a few of your questions before we leave for home.   The journey to Europe has involved many highs and yes, some anguishing moments. It took us to one of Europe's youngest capitals and two of its oldest and to a city which symbolizes the continuing quest for European unity.   At every stop, I emphasized that our European friends could count on the United States to be their partner, to help them grow, to support their democratic aspirations and to stand with them to protect the peace.   We're leaving today with our Atlantic ties strengthened, and we're returning home mission accomplished.

headline: A PUSH FOR PAY-PER-VIEW TV
abstract: The cable television industry feels under siege. It is facing growing competition for viewer attention from the boom in video cassette recorders, and as fewer new cable systems are built, it is having trouble wooing and holding on to new subscribers.   Those problems have cable programming networks seeking another way to attract audiences, and some of them think they have found it in pay-per-view television.   Two cable networks, Showtime/ The Movie Channel and The Playboy Channel, announced plans last week for pay-per-view operations, and a third company, called The Exchange, is developing a similar offering. Pay-per-view allows cable subscribers to pay a small fee to see a specific movie or other special programming. Subscribers can get pay-per-view instead of, or in addition to, the continuous programming they now receive for a monthly fee from so-called pay-cable networks such as Showtime or Time Inc.'s Home Box Office.

headline: LIBERIANS GET SINKING FEELING ABOUT 'DEMOCRACY'
abstract: Less than a year ago, this small West African nation began moving toward political change, and in the view of many citizens it promised to be as refreshing as the Atlantic breezes that curl through the sultry climate. But the great expectations have soured into cynicism.   After four years of military rule, the nation had begun a transition toward elections and a civilian democratic government. Voters overwhelmingly approved a Constitution similar in many ways to that of the United States.

headline: DEAL PROVIDES MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES
abstract: For UAL Inc. the acquisition of the Hertz Corporation is the latest in a series of transactions aimed at making it a more formidable travel company.   UAL officials said that by bringing under one banner United Airlines, Westin Hotels and Hertz, the path had been opened for a number of marketing opportunities that they said would make each component more attractive to customers.   ''There are several aspects of this that, from a marketing standpoint, are very intriguing to us,'' said John R. Zeeman, executive vice president of marketing and planning for United.   ''There are opportunities in the future in automation, our check-in systems. It's possible that one day you might be able to get your seat assignment when you rent a car and never have to come to the ticket counter at the airport,'' he said. ''Things like that are now available to us, but how soon is another question.''

headline: Future Navy Orders Seen for Todd
abstract: The Todd Shipyards Corporation, though it failed to win an important Navy contract for a destroyer, is likely to receive future orders, analysts said today. In the meantime, they added, the Navy was likely to give smaller assignments to Todd to keep its modern shipyard here operating. That yard, Todd's Los Angeles division, is the company's largest.

headline: SWEDISH LEADER FOR 2 DECADES
abstract: Tage F. Erlander, who was Sweden's Prime Minister from 1946 to 1969 and a major architect of its social welfare state, died early yesterday in a hospital in the village of Huddinge, seven miles southwest of Stockholm. He was 84 years old. The cause of his death was not immediately disclosed, but doctors said he was suffering from cardiac insufficiency and minor pneumonia when he entered the hospital June 9.

headline: Offer Is Made For Lee Wards
abstract: A group of investors led by the executive vice president for specialty retailing at General Mills Inc. is seeking to buy Lee Wards Creative Crafts Inc., one of the company's retail chains, and may also seek another of the company's retail divisions.      The investor group is led by   Michael J. Boyle, and includes Allan B. Gilman, the former president of Murjani International, an apparel producer.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: ITT Will Sell 12 Companies The ITT Corporation said
abstract: yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to sell 12 industrial companies for $370 million   to Forstmann Little & Company, an investment banking firm   that specializes in leveraged   buyouts. The proposed sale is part of   ITT's plan, announced Jan. 16,   to shed assets valued at about  $1.7 billion.

headline: Belgium's Singing Nun Is Reported a Suicide
abstract: Jeanine Deckers, the guitar-playing ''Singing Nun'' who won worldwide fame more than 20 years ago with her song ''Dominique,'' committed suicide along with a friend over the weekend at the home they shared, the Belgian news agency reported today.     The former nun was 52 years old.

headline: LAKER TRUST SUIT DEAL IS EXPECTED BY MONDAY
abstract: British Airways and the other 11 defendants in an antitrust suit filed by the liquidator of Laker Airways are optimistic that they will have an out-of-court settlement ready by Monday to present to a United States judge in Washington, a source close to the negotiations said yesterday.   The settlement, which is expected to total about $65 million, would be presented to Judge Harold H. Greene of the United States District Court of the District of Columbia, who has presided over the suit.   According to the source, all the defendants have agreed to the amounts each would pay toward settling with Laker creditors and bankers.

headline: A PROPOSED ANTISPYING LAW PRODUCES AN OUTCRY IN JAPAN
abstract: Japan's governing party, saying that a crackdown on spies is long overdue, has submitted legislation authorizing the death penalty for anyone convicted of espionage that ''severely endangers national security.''   The proposed law has drawn denunciations from opposition parties, human-rights activists and newspapers, and as a result its passage by Parliament this year is highly improbable. Opponents complain that the bill is ambiguously worded, saying it would inhibit the press and interfere with the public's ''right to know.''   ''The Espionage Prevention Bill absolutely must not be passed,'' the newspaper Asahi said in a recent editorial. ''Its contents trample on the spirit of our peace Constitution at its very foundation.''

headline: Officers for 1991 Named In Allied-Signal Merger
abstract: Michael D. Dingman, currently president of Signal Companies Inc., is slated to become chief executive officer in 1991 of the corporation to be formed by the merger of Signal and the Allied Corporation. Mr. Dingman believes that such advance planning, publicly disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday, is basic to the success of the transaction.   ''When you do friendly deals of the magnitude this deal represents, the directors want to make sure you have peace and harmony, to make sure that you have all the hard points covered, not just the price of the stock,'' said Mr. Dingman in a telephone interview from his office in La Jolla, Calif., where Signal is based. The announcement of the long-range management development plans, he added, ''was done to assure that there is an orderly succession and full participation.''

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.      Monday   Construction SpendingApril Tuesday New Car SalesMay Wednesday None Thursday None Friday UnemploymentMay

headline: Deportees from Nigeria Allowed to Cross Benin
abstract: More than 500 illegal aliens expelled from Nigeria crossed the tiny West African country of Benin by road today after the Government let non-Benin nationals cross its eastern border, witnesses said.   A convoy of Togolese and Ghanaians, escorted by the police, left a small frontier post and headed west along the coastal road to Togo, the witnesses said.

headline: DOW UP 5.26 TO 1,301.97 IN PRE-HOLIDAY TRADING
abstract: Stock prices gained slightly yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped back above the 1,300 level. But activity was light as investors made an early getaway for the Memorial Day weekend.   ''Trading began to wind down in the afternoon as is usually the case'' before a holiday, said Larry Wachtel, research director of Prudential-Bache Securities. But he said volume, while lower, was impressive as investors still appeared interested in equities.

headline: Northern Telecom
abstract: Northern Telecom Ltd. announced it had signed a memorandum of understanding with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation to enter into studies leading to a long-term supply contract for Northern Telecom's DMS-10 digital central office switching system. The studies are scheduled to conclude no later than Dec. 31.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Two Notable Changes In the Book Field
abstract: Among the various types of specialty ad agencies are the ones that specialize in books. Generally not an unruly group.    Now they have suddenly come alive to offer up two bits of information, one concerning a new president at Jameson Advertising and the other about a brand new agency in the field called the Mesa Group.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: June 26, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M.   Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Committee Against Apartheid - 10:30 A.M.   Special Committee on Decolonization - 3 P.M.

headline: Cleveland Electric Ratings Lowered
abstract: The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company's debt ratings were lowered yesterday by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.    The rating agencies noted that the utility faced difficulties in building the Perry and Beaver Valley nuclear facilities in Ohio. S.&P. said the problems had been exacerbated by legislative restrictions.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * American Magnetics Corp., a Los Angeles company that makes magnetic stripe products, has elected Marion W. Haun chairman and Verney L. Brown president and chief operating officer.    * Baltimore Gas and Electric Co. has elected to its board Willard Hackerman, president of Whiting-Turner Contracting Co.

headline: DUARTE'S PARTY CLAIMS VICTORY
abstract: President Jose Napoleon Duarte's Christian Democratic Party claimed an upset victory in national elections here today.    President Duarte, speaking in an interview, said he believed his party had won at least 31 seats, giving it a majority in the powerful National Assembly.   The contention was supported by a national exit poll carried out by the Spanish International Television Network. The poll, based on a survey of almost 11,000 voters, indicated that Mr. Duarte's party would win a majority of at least 32 seats in the country's powerful 60-member National Assembly.   The Miami-based network conducted a similar poll after presidential elections here last year that was within four- tenths of one percentage point of the final result. Official returns from the contest for the National Assembly

headline: Complex Suits And Jury Trials
abstract: MARK GELLER has come to understand why many lawyers and judges contend that some suits are too complex for jurors to understand.   As jury foreman in the MCI Communications Corporation's antitrust lawsuit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Mr. Geller sat through seven weeks of testimony that covered such dizzying subjects as real versus operating cash flows, microwave interconnections into the phone system, and a two-inch-thick economic study on the present value of future losses.   ''I'm not a telecommunications expert, and I'm not an economist, but most of the testimony was by economists or telecommunications experts,'' said Mr. Geller, a college administrator. ''It was tough to keep a handle on what they were saying.''

headline: Your Money;   Finite-Life Realty Trusts
abstract: MANY people remember that real estate investment trusts - abbreviated REIT's and pronounced ''reets'' - received a bad name among individual investors in the mid-1970's. Many such trusts, particularly the mortgage trusts that concentrated on financing existing or developing property, had to borrow at higher interest rates than they earned when the prime lending rate soared. As a result, their share prices plummeted.   Conditions in the industry have changed, and the emphasis now is on equity trusts that own investment-grade income-producing property such as office buildings and shopping centers. But increasing attention is being focused on a version of the trusts called finite-life real estate investment trusts. These are abbreviated FREIT's and pronounced ''freets.''

headline: Oscar Mayer Realigns Its Top Management
abstract: The Oscar Mayer Foods Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Foods Corporation, said it had reorganized its top management to ''handle the rapid expansion and increased complexity of its business.''   James W. McVey, 53, has been named president of the company, which makes frankfurters, bacon and other processed meats and is based in Madison, Wis. He succeeds Jerry M. Hiegel, 58, who remains chairman and chief executive.

headline: PATENTS ;  A Versatile Grill Offered for Campers
abstract: A versatile and portable grill for campers was patented this week.

headline: Magnavox Order
abstract: The Magnavox Government and Industrial Electronics Company, a unit of the North American Philips Corporation, won a $37.6 million Army contract for terminals.

headline: Jacobs Raises Stake in Castle
abstract: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, said yesterday that he had increased his stake in Castle & Cooke Inc. to 13.5 percent, from 12.3 percent of the company's 25.8 million outstanding shares. Mr. Jacobs also said that he had sold his stake in Gulf and Western Industries, though he did not provide any details. He had purchased less than 5 percent of the company last month.

headline: SKY-MARSHAL PLAN DRAWS CRITICISM
abstract: Security experts found little merit yesterday in President Reagan's proposal for expanding the sky marshal force for use on international flights.   A spokesman for the International Air Transport Association, said in in Montreal: ''We're not happy about anybody having guns up in the air. There's a distinct danger to passengers and a bigger danger of damage to the aircraft.'' The association is the industry organization of the world's airlines and has 137 members.

headline: Addendum
abstract: Sports Illustrated is increasing its rate base 3.8 percent, to 2,725,000, with its Sept. 2 issue, and its advertising rates 3.1 percent.

headline: Chicago Railroad
abstract: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company will reduce its work force by about 13 percent, or 1,500 workers, over the next three years, its president, James R. Wolfe, told the company's annual meeting. He said the reduction was part of a program intended to save about $60 million. Mr. Wolfe said the company's second quarter ''should be better than the first,'' when it lost 80 cents a share. He also said the company was considering diversifying outside the rail business because Federal approval of a railroad acquisition would take two years and the company wanted to use its tax-loss carry-forwards more quickly than that.

headline: Metropolitan Museum Offer
abstract: To finance new special exhibition galleries and a new wing for modern art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is offering $45 million of bonds this week through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley.   The bonds, which were issued by the New York State Dormitory Authority on behalf of the museum, carry interest rates ranging from 5.90 percent in 1988 to 8.90 percent in 2000 and 9.20 percent in 2015.   Rated Aa by Moody's and Ax by S.& P., the bonds are a general obligation of the museum and are backed by revenues from its $229 million endowment and regular operations.

headline: DOLLAR EXPECTED TO BE FAIRLY DOCILE
abstract: After half a year of roller-coaster activity, the dollar has calmed.   Economists and traders have been wrong too many times to predict continued stability with any confidence. But many suggest that for the near term, at least, the dollar may remain relatively docile, although somewhat upwardly mobile.   ''It has begun to stabilize a bit,'' said S. Waite Rawls, managing director and head of trading at the First Boston Corporation.

headline: U.N. Aide Denies Food For Ethiopia Is Missing
abstract: The United Nations official in charge of emergency aid operations in Ethiopia said today that virtually all of the food sent to this country had been accounted for.

headline: Fall in World Birth Rate Since 1983 Is Reported
abstract: The world's birth rate has fallen from 29 to 27 births per 1,000 people since 1983, largely because of sharp curbs on China's population growth, a private population study group has reported.

headline: Modest Hope for Soviet Trade Talks
abstract: The United States Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, opens two days of talks with senior Soviet trade officials Monday, in the first such top-level trade encounter in seven years.   The meetings are not expected to produce any spectacular results, according to diplomatic sources here. But in resuming the dormant Joint Commercial Commission, of which Mr. Baldrige and the Soviet Minister of Foreign Trade, Nikolai S. Patolichev, are co-chairman, the two sides appear to be signaling a readiness to revive the commercial contacts battered by several years of embargoes, political tensions and recriminations.

headline: ATHENS DISCLOSES A HIJACKER DEAL
abstract: The Greek Government today gave in to the demands of hijackers of an American airliner and freed an associate who had been in Greek custody in exchange for the release of eight Greek passengers.   The Government said 45 others were also released by the hijackers in Algiers today. It said that it had obtained the release of all 53 in exchange for the hijacking accomplice after he had been flown to Algiers. The announcement did not specify the identities or nationalities of the 45 who were not Greek citizens. Officials in Algeria said that early today 2 hostages were freed, followed by another release of 49 people. It was not clear why the numbers did not agree.

headline: LATE MARCH CAR SALES ROSE 6.9%
abstract: Sales of new domestically made cars rose moderately throughout March, gaining 6.9 percent in the last 10 days of the month from the 1984 period, the major manufacturers said today.   ''This was pretty much in line with what we're looking for,'' said Jean- Claude Gruet, a securities analyst who covers the auto industry for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''The 10 days came in a little lower than the numbers we've seen in the last 8 to 10 weeks, but it is still in the expected range.''    In the period, which had 9 selling days this year and 10 last year, the companies sold a total of 301,496 cars, or 33,500 a day.    For all of March, sales rose 5.6 percent, to 768,927 units, bringing the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate to 8.4 million.

headline: Unocal Hearing In Delaware Court
abstract: A Delaware Supreme Court panel heard two hours of arguments today and promised a decision Friday on an attempt by the Unocal Corporation to exclude T. Boone Pickens and his partners from the company's repurchase of 29 percent of its stock at a premium price.

headline: Aetna Files Stock Offering The Aetna Life and Casualty
abstract: Company, the largest shareholder insurance company in   the country, filed a registration   statement yesterday with the   Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of 6 million   shares of common stock,   through underwriters led by   Morgan Stanley & Company.  The offering comes at a time   when profits of insurance companies have been hard-hit by   losses in the property and casualty insurance business, where   premiums have not equaled insurance claims.

headline: Agency Seeking Its 'Face'
abstract: THE name of the agency is not   Janklow & Bender, Janklow/   Bender or Janklow-Bender. It's JanklowBender. Nice and cozy, for a reason.    ''The reason,'' explained David Bender, 34 years old, ''is that while there are a lot of partnerships out there, this team is unique - two partners, one marketing and one creative - but overstepping into one another's areas and both being integral parts.''

headline: STORAGE REPORTS '84 LOSSES
abstract: The Storage Technology Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy protection last October, said yesterday that it lost more than half a billion dollars in 1984.    The loss, which included $279 million in write-offs and a re-valuation of inventory, was the first concrete measure of how deeply the company had fallen victim to its own mistakes and tough competition from the International Business Machines Corporation.    The net loss for the fourth quarter, including the write-downs, was $419.2 million, compared with a loss of $7.8 million the previous year. Revenues were $151.9 million, compared with $226.9 million in the comparable 1983 period.

headline: Peru, Avoiding Vote Runoff, Proclaims Its President-Elect
abstract: Alan Garcia Perez, a Social Democrat, was proclaimed President-elect of Peru today by the Electoral Board after the board accepted a decision by the Marxist candidate, Alfonso Barrantes Lingan, not to contest a runoff.   Mr. Garcia, the candidate of the left centrist American Popular Revolutionar Alliance, got the most votes in last month's general election but failed to get the outright majority needed to avoid a second round.   Mr. Garcia won 45.7 percent of the votes in the April 14 election. Mr. Barrantes, the candidate of the United Left Alliance, took 21.3 percent in the first round of voting for a successor to President Fernando Belaunde Terry.

headline: ADVERTISING ;Miller May Replace L"owenbr"au Agency
abstract: The Miller Brewing Company confirmed yesterday that it would be looking over  a number of agencies as a possible replacement for Backer & Spielvogel on the creative part of the L"owenbr"au beer account.

headline: AGENDA AND DISPUTE
abstract: A major conference on human rights opened here today with delegates from 35 countries still unable to agree on a final agenda for the six-week session.   The diplomats worked through the night until 8 A.M. to try to resolve the differences between East and West over how to conduct the conference. It is being held to examine the progress made on human rights in the 10 years since the issue was embodied in the Helsinki accords.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Pickens Bid To Continue
abstract: T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company. will continue to seek proxies from shareholders of the Unocal Corporation to have Unocal's meeting adjourned another 60 days, even though a Federal judge on Friday postponed the meeting until May 13, an executive close to Mr. Pickens said yesterday.         Originally, the Unocal meeting was scheduled for today and a cash tender offer that would have given control of the company to an investor group led by Mr. Pickens was set to expire May 3. Judge A. Wallace Tashima ruled in Los Angeles on Friday that the Pickens group should extend its tender offer until May 17 and the Unocal meeting should be postponed until May 13.

headline: ROBINS SETS UP DALKON SHIELD PAYMENTS FUND
abstract: The A. H. Robins Company, a Richmond pharmaceutical concern, said yesterday that it had set aside $615 million to settle legal claims from thousands of women who used its Dalkon Shield birth control device.   The reserve fund is by far the biggest provision of its kind in a product liability case, lawyers said.    ''Clearly it is the biggest medical device product-reserve ever set up,'' said Dale Larson, a partner in the law firm of Robins, Zelle, Larson & Kaplan in Minneapolis, which specializes in product liability cases. ''It is also undoubtedly one of the largest product reserves set up in any category.''

headline: Kuwaiti Flies to Saudi Arabia
abstract: The Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who narrowly escaped a suicide car-bomb attack 11 days ago, left for Saudi Arabia tonight to visit Moslem holy places in Mecca and Medina, officials said.

headline: BellSouth-I.B.M
abstract: The BellSouth Corporation's Advanced Systems Inc. subsidiary said it had agreed to market in nine Southeastern states products made by the International Business Machines Corporation. BellSouth said it would sell I.B.M. System/36 products as an authorized value-added remarketer and I.B.M. Personal Computers as an authorized value-added dealer for a variety of voice and data applications. A similar agreement with the Digital Equipment Corporation was announced earlier this year.

headline: Reynolds Metals
abstract: The Reynolds Metals Company said it would temporarily idle 49,000 tons of primary aluminum capacity and temporarily lay off 250 workers associated with the cutback. It said a potline at Troutdale, Ore., that produces 25,000 tons a year would be halted this weekend as well as a line at Longview, Wash., that produces 24,000 tons a year. After the cutbacks, Reynolds said, it would be operating at 65 percent of its consolidated primary aluminum capacity.

headline: Stake in Asarco
abstract: The Australian investor Robert Holmes a Court has increased his stake in Asarco Inc. to 9.9 percent of the New York-based minerals concern's shares outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Holmes a Court said that between Monday and Thursday he bought 305,400 Asarco common shares for prices ranging from $23.50 to $24.25 a share, or a total of $7.3 million. In previous S.E.C. filings, Mr. Holmes a Court said his purchases of Asarco shares were for investment purposes only.

headline: HONG KONG ADJUSTS TO TRADE RULE
abstract: Hong Kong apparel makers are examining a number of alternatives to adjust to a tighter textile import rule imposed during the past year by the United States.   The so-called country-of-origin rule was designed to close gaps in the Multifiber Arrangement, an international treaty governing more than 80 percent of the world's trade in cotton, wool and synthetic fibers. The change aims to prevent a country that had already filled its export quotas, such as China, from shipping goods through another country with unfilled quotas, such as Hong Kong.   Under the rule, which was promulgated in August but did not become final until April 4, the United States will consider the exporting country to be the one in which the last ''substantial'' transformation of apparel made in more than one country takes place.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;30,000 Rioters Set Fire To an Indian Slum
abstract: The police opened fire today on 30,000 rioters who had set fire to a slum colony in the western state of Gujarat during protests against a Government affirmative action policy. The policy reserves a quota of Government jobs and university placements for disadvantaged castes and classes.         The Press Trust of India, a news agency, said at least 200 huts were destroyed and four people injured in the slum, which is in the city of Surat.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA ALLOWS MULTIRACIAL PARTIES
abstract: The South African Government announced today that it had decided to abolish a 17-year-old law prohibiting multiracial political parties.   The announcement followed a decision last month to repeal laws forbidding marriage and sexual relations between whites and nonwhites.   The move today, repealing the Prohibition of Political Interference Act, means that political groups whose membership was hitherto restricted to one race may now recruit supporters from other races.

headline: WHITE-COLLAR CRIME: BOOMING AGAIN
abstract: THE business news lately has been reading like a drawn-out Hollywood script of corruption: Old line manufacturers exposed cheating the Pentagon. Venerable banks caught laundering money.
