A securities firm found fraudulently kiting checks. Once-respected businessmen and former government officials indicted - and jailed - for insider trading and fraud.   A corporate crime wave appears to be exploding across the nation. Not since the mid-1970's, when a series of foreign corporate bribes and illegal political contributions shocked the body politic, have there been so many deep gashes in corporate America's moral armor. The general public seems certain of the reason:There's only a fine line between business executive and crook, they say (see accompanying story). But academics, executives and government officials are still trying to figure out what, exactly, is going on orhow to stop it.   ''These are the kinds of crimes that clearly involve a matter of choice,'' said D. Lowell Jensen, Deputy Attorney General of the United States. ''These are cold, calculated crimes. It's not as though these are crimes of passion.''

headline: Minstar Notes To Yield 14.95%
abstract: Minstar Inc., a holding company engaged in moving, warehousing and boat manufacturing, is offering $300 million of 14 7/8 percent senior subordinated notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.604, to yield 14.95 percent, through Drexel Burnham Lambert as sole underwriter. The size of the financing was increased from $100 million.   The notes were assigned a specualtive grade rating of B-3 by Moody's.

headline: People
abstract: Peter Finn has been named chairman of Bozell & Jacobs/Southwest in Dallas and Dennis McClain has joined the agency as president.   * Andre Morkel has been appointed senior vice president and co-creative director of Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle.   * Robert L. Edgell, vice chairman of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, has been elected chairman of American Business Press Inc., an association of specialized business publications.

headline: Product Liability
abstract: To the Editor:     Stuart Taylor's article, ''Product Liability: The New Morass'' (March 10) cast me in the role of defender of the current system.

headline: OHIO THRIFT UNIT'S SALE IS SET BACK
abstract: The Ohio Senate defeated on a tie vote of 16 to 16 today a measure that would allow the sale of the failed Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati to the Chemical New York Corporation. The measure had been approved in the House earlier in the day by a vote of 63 to 25.   Sponsors said the defeat did not necessarily mean the bill was dead, because under Senate rules a motion to reconsider can be made within two legislative days.

headline: Emhart Group
abstract: The Emhart Corporation said it would sell its Hill Store Equipment Group to the Jepson Corporation's Emerson Quiet-Kool affiliate for $60 million. Emhart said it expected to close the deal later this month. Hill manufactures store fixtures in the United States and Canada.

headline: CARBIDE OFFERS $5 MILLION IN AID FOR INDIA VICTIMS
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday offered to provide $5 million in emergency aid to victims of the Dec. 3 pesticide leak at its plant in Bhopal, India. The Indian Embassy in Washington said it had no comment on whether the Government of India would accept the offer.    Union Carbide's offer came two days after Federal District Judge John F. Keenan suggested at a pre- trial hearing in Manhattan that the company should immediately provide $5 million to $10 million for the Bhopal victims as a matter of ''fundamental human decency.'' Such a payment, he said, could be made without admitting liability.

headline: 6 BUSINESS CHIEFS ENDORSE TAX PLAN
abstract: Six chief executive officers, specially selected to be the first business leaders to testify before Congress on President Reagan's tax revision proposal, endorsed the plan today and said it would benefit not only their companies but the economy as a whole.   ''I am here today to tell you that the mainstream of American business is on your side,'' said John M. Richman of Dart & Kraft, the first of the corporate officers to testify before the House Ways and Means Committee. ''We, too, want tax reform.'' Mr. Richman and the five other executives, who were selected by the committee because of their support for the Reagan plan, represent the kinds of companies - food, retailing and household products - that can take relatively little advantage of tax preferences allowed under current law and thus pay high taxes now. Most such companies would be helped significantly by the President's plan to reduce the corporate tax rate to 33 percent from 46 percent.

headline: Home Group's Stock Distribution
abstract: The City Investing Company, the manufacturing, services and financial concern that is in the midst of liquidation, said its board of directors had decided to distribute all the common stock of the Home Group Inc., the parent of the Home Insurance Company and a City Investing unit, to City's shareholders.

headline: Apple Is Closing San Jose Unit
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. has decided to close its disk-drive manufacturing operations in San Jose and has laid off 80 employees who worked there, a company spokesman said today. The 80 employees had been making hard disk drives for the now discontinued Lisa computer, and had been scheduled to produce a future hard disk drive for the Macintosh, as well as an electronic filing system, known as a file server.

headline: Stocks Gain as Interest Rates Fall
abstract: Helped by a buying spree in the final hour of trading, Wall Street stretched its winning streak to six consecutive sessions as stock prices rose in response to declining interest rates.    Traders said the improvement might have come sooner in the day except that two brokerages, Paine Webber Inc. and Salomon Brothers Inc., were engaged in large stock- selling programs into the afternoon.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was down to nearly 1,257 in early afternoon, finished at 1,269.55, for a 2.77-point gain.

headline: UNITED'S STRATEGY QUESTIONED
abstract: United Airlines dazzled the airline world with its agreement last month to acquire the Pacific division of Pan American World Airways. Hardly was the ink dry before it announced an ambitious restructuring of its pension fund assets that will provide nearly $1 billion to finance corporate expansion. And then, after finally fighting through a costly pilots' strike, this week it announced the purchase of the Hertz Corporation, a company that many saw as a natural extension of the company's travel business.   To many outsiders, those moves seemed to represent the imaginative expansion of a company that is already the country's biggest airline. But to some in the business, they suggested that the company might be placing the wrong bet, putting it in danger of being overtaken in the skies by another major carrier, American Airlines. While United has been engaged in its diverse expansion moves, American has been busy lining up new aircraft and generally consolidating its position as a domestic airline.   Such concerns are not without merit. Even Richard J. Ferris, the chairman, president and chief executive of UAL Inc., which owns United Airlines, acknowledges the importance of a solid and expanding domestic system. He has said that the airline was ''adding all the lift it could digest'' and has promised further expansion. ''We will be adding to our domestic fleet,'' he said.

headline: Goldome Buys Bankers' Funding
abstract: The Goldome Realty Credit Corporation, a subsidiary of the Goldome Savings Bank, said that it had purchased the Bankers' Funding Corporation from the American National Bank unit of the Central Pacific Corporation.

headline: PATENTS;  Detecting Cancer
abstract: A common garden slug, limax flavus, is the source of a new and potentially powerful cancer-detecting chemical patented this week by Ronald L. Miller, a biochemist at the Medical University of South Carolina in Charleston. The chemical, called a lectin, reacts strongly with sialic acid, which is believed to exist in large quantities in the blood serum of cancer patients. Patent No. 4,520,111 is assigned to the Research Corporation, a nonprofit foundation with offices in New York and Tucson, Ariz., which is offering licenses.

headline: Bride's Publisher
abstract: Elliot Marion has been named publisher of Bride's magazine, a Conde Nast publication, succeeding G. Thomas Grenier, who is leaving to pursue other interests. Mr. Marion, 60 years old, joined Conde Nast in 1962, serving as advertising director for Bride's, and then as beauty advertising manager for Glamour. Most recently, he was advertising director for Mademoiselle.

headline: Economic Scene;   Refiners' Bid For Protection
abstract: EIGHT years ago the United States imported 8.8 million barrels of oil a day, about 48 percent of its total needs. Alarmed by such heavy dependence on foreign suppliers, President Jimmy Carter started a program of price decontrol and other steps that he said would guarantee that the 1977 import level would never be exceeded.   Higher prices, combined with recession, worked to produce a spectacular decline - far steeper and faster than anyone expected. This year imports are running at well under 4 million barrels a day and few people worry any longer about America's energy security. The Reagan Administration, in fact, now proposes to save money by suspending further purchases for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve - a stockpile of oil intended to be drawn upon in an emergency.

headline: PATENTS;  ROOT CANAL IMPLANT
abstract: A root canal implant and a method of its insertion in a tooth were patented this week by Dr. Richard J. Pitz of New York and Ezekiel J. Jacob, operator of a Brooklyn laboratory that makes medical plastics.

headline: AS POLES RECALL WAR'S SUFFERING, GOVERNMENT STRESSES SOVIET AID
abstract: The Polish Government marked the 40th anniversary of the end of the war in Europe today by stressing the Soviet role in the defeat of the Nazis.   Many ordinary Poles privately recalled the enormous suffering, sacrifice and losses of their own nation, both during and after the conflict.   After weeks of art shows, television discussions and movie festivals, all emphasizing the Soviet leadership in the victory, the celebration here culminated in a modest parade of troops bearing only sidearms and sabers. It was watched by a crowd of invited guests with tickets.

headline: 11 Campers Killed in France
abstract: A concrete wall collapsed onto a crowded Mediterranean seaside campsite today, crushing and killing 11 campers, five of them children, the police said. Six others were seriously injured when the 90-foot hillside support wall suddenly gave way early this morning while most of the campers were sleeping. The police said heavy rain had apparently eroded the wall's foundations.

headline: HOME BANKING: EDGING IN THE DOOR
abstract: KENNETH FRIEDMAN, president of a New York computer service company, was on the phone negotiating a lease for a new car when the leasing company told him his checking account balance was far lower than he had indicated on the application. Immediately, Mr. Friedman went to his I.B.M. PC, called up Pronto, Chemical Bank's computerized home banking system, and within minutes was back on the phone with his balance.   ''Can you imagine the feeling of control in being able to do that?'' he said. ''I was not only able to tell them they were wrong, but I gave them my exact balance, down to the penny.''

headline: SAUDIS TIGHTEN BELT, A NOTCH
abstract: There is one thing that the royal family, Saudi officials and foreign investors agree on: The boom days in Saudi Arabia are gone.    ''The era of 'easy come, easy go,' is over,'' said Prince Muqrin bin Abdul- Aziz, Governor of Hail Province. ''People will have to earn their livings now.''   Determined to adjust to the reality of a three-year-old recession, the Saudi Government is retrenching. Large-scale projects involving both Saudi and foreign contractors have been shelved, delayed, scaled back or put out again for rebids. Payments to some contractors have been withheld. At the regular breakfast of an American businessmen's group in Riyadh, the chitchat over scrambled eggs and French toast was about who is not getting paid these days.

headline: Ferraro's Bill
abstract: To the Editor:   In her letter published May 5, Geraldine Ferraro cavalierly dismisses the concerns expressed by many practitioners regarding a provision of her sponsored Retirement Equity Act, which grants rights previously contractually waived.   Occasionally, in the case of late-life marriages, a prenuptual agreement is entered into under which each spouse waives claim to certain property rights, including pension benefits.

headline: GANDHI AND SRI LANKA LEADER PLAN A JOINT BANGLADESH VISIT
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India and President J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka will travel together to Bangladesh to express sympathy for the victims of the recent cyclone disaster there, an Indian spokesman said today.   The spokesman said the joint trip was scheduled for Sunday, after the two leaders hold talks about the conflict in Sri Lanka between the Government and Tamil separatists.   Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Jayewardene, who will fly over the devastated Ganges delta with President H. M. Ershad of Bangladesh, are making the trip to show ''South Asian solidarity,'' the spokesman added.

headline: Basques Suspected in Blast
abstract: A bomb exploded today near a beachfront hotel outside Valencia, and the police said it may have been part of an anti-tourism campaign by Basque separatist guerrillas. No one was hurt, and there was no damage. The police said warnings had been received by telephone before the blast.

headline: SEOUL PROTESTERS LEAVE U.S. OFFICE
abstract: South Korean students today ended a four-day occupation of a United States Goverment office, leaving voluntarily without receiving the American apology that they had demanded.   At 12:04 P.M. the steel door grate of the United State Information Service Building opened, and the students appeared, carrying a handmade South Korean flag, linking arms and chanting ''Down with Chun Doo Hwan,'' South Korea's President. They had been demanding that the United States apologize for what they viewed as its complicity in its suppression of the May 1980 Kwangju uprising, in which about 200 people were killed and thousands injured.

headline: Offer for Gump's
abstract: Campbell & Company, a New York venture capital company, said it had formed an investor group that is proposing to buy the Gump's stores in San Francisco, a four-store home furnishings and catalogue business.

headline: Airplane Smoke
abstract: To the Editor:   Trans World Airlines may tout its new special chair in the business seating sections of its planes (''TWA Takes a $5 Million Seat Overseas,'' April 14) but it will never increase the use of first-class or business-class sections until they are off-limits to smokers.

headline: Brussels Bomb Damages Office of Company
abstract: A bomb damaged the offices of a West German electronics company today, 20 hours after a bomb caused a fire at the office of the North Atlantic Assembly, an advisory body to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

headline: U.S. HALVES QUOTA FOR SOVIET FISHING
abstract: The Secretary of Commerce, Malcolm Baldrige, announced today that the amount of fish the Soviet Union may catch in United States waters would be cut by at least half because of Soviet violation of an international whaling agreement.   According to the Commerce Department, Soviet whalers exceeded their allowable quota of 1,941 minke whales from waters around Antartica by about 500. The quota is set by the International Whaling Commission.

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET OPEN TALKS ON AFGHANISTAN ISSUE
abstract: The United States and the Soviet Union opened talks here today on Afghanistan, the latest in a series of discussions on regional issues.   The talks may continue into Wednesday, a State Department official said.   ''I don't think we are expecting a great deal, but we are going to listen very carefully for not only what they say but any possible nuances,'' he said.

headline: Company Fitness Programs
abstract: HEALTH care has become a growth industry, and joggers and bicyclists are everywhere. When trends such as these converge, interesting job vistas can be spotted - in this case in fitness programs for company employees, sometimes known as ''wellness'' programs.   At a Princeton University seminar on the impact of biotechnolgy last weekend, Norman C. Fost, a physician and associate professor at the University of Wisconsin, made this statement, ''Health care has little to do with health.''   He meant that health depends on factors outside the doctor's aegis -genetic traits, environment, nutrition, exercise and other personal aspects of life that differ widely among individuals.

headline: Goldsmith Begins Soliciting Proxies
abstract: In his battle to acquire the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, Sir James Goldsmith began soliciting proxies, urging shareholders to press the board of the forest-products company to rescind a defensive measure adopted last August.    His letter to shareholders followed a ruling Friday by a Federal judge in Nevada ordering Crown Zellerbach to delay its annual meeting by two weeks, to May 23.

headline: Trading in Options on O-T-C Stocks Begins on 4 Exchanges
abstract: Trading in options on over-the-counter stocks began today at the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the New York, American and Pacific stock exchanges.   Exchange officials said that there would be great competition because many of the options would be traded on more than one exchange. Today also marked the first time that the New York Stock Exchange has conducted trading in stock options.   The American Stock Exchange took the early lead in the trading. In trading options on Apple Computer Inc. stock, the O-T-C option with the largest volume today, the Amex traded 8,052 option contracts and the Chicago Board Options Exchange traded 1,372.

headline: Khomeini Said to Shift Gulf War Tactics
abstract: In a major strategy change, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has ordered Iranian forces to use ''defensive'' guerrilla tactics in the war with Iraq, an Iranian official says.   Ali Reza Afshar, chief of staff of Iran's Revolutionary Guards, said, referring to the Ayatollah, ''The Imam has issued an overall order for a defensive holy war,'' a switch from the major offensives that have prevailed since 1982.

headline: LEUCADIA PLAN FOR INTERGROUP
abstract: THE Leucadia National Corporation's well-chronicled success in profiting from its pursuit of the Avco Corporation earlier this year brought the little-known investment company a fortune but too little fame, analysts believe, to make it an instant force in the high-pressure field of corporate takeovers.   Now the company, a descendant of the Talcott National Corporation, which was once controlled by Michele Sindona, the convicted Italian financier, has set its sights on restructuring National Intergroup Inc., and analysts are wondering if Leucadia has the clout to accomplish its plan.   ''The biggest thing about it,'' remarked Peter L. Anker of the First Boston Corporation, ''is the size of the ads.'' Full-page advertisements in some newspapers last week proposed a recapitalization of National Intergroup that would include the spinoff of its First Nationwide Financial Corporation.

headline: Volatile Day for CBS Stock
abstract: CBS stock rose $3.25, to $103.75, in brisk trading yesterday after bouncing between a low for the day of $100.50 and a high of $107. Volume was slightly less than 700,000 shares.

headline: G.O.P. SENATORS ASK CURBS ON PRETORIA
abstract: Key Senate Republicans broke with the Reagan Administration strategy on South Africa today and proposed economic sanctions against the Pretoria Government within two years unless it reverses its apartheid policy.   The bill was introduced by Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and other Republican leaders.

headline: Rate Hopes Send Dow Up by 10.86, to 1,300.96
abstract: The stock market scored its first advance in a week yesterday as investors, once again convinced that interest rates would move lower, scrambled to buy recently devalued equities.   The Dow Jones industrial average gained 10.86 points, inching its way over the 1,300 pyschological barrier by closing at 1,300.96.   The closely watched Dow, which tracks the performance of 30 high-capitalization stocks, had fallen in the previous three sessions, including a 16.02-point drop on Thursday. For the week, the Dow lost 15.46 points.

headline: CUBA EXPANDING ACTIVITY IN AFRICAN NATIONS
abstract: Despite persistent objections from the United States Government, Cuba is expanding its activities in Africa, and Cuban officials say it is unlikely that their combat troops in Angola will be leaving in the near future.   According to Giraldo Mazola, the Deputy Foreign Minister for Africa and Asia, Cuba has technical and medical teams in 15 African countries and is negotiating to send specialists in agriculture and public health to a 16th, Burkina Faso.   United States officials say Cuba has up to 30,000 troops in Angola and about 5,000 in Ethiopia. There are also Cuban advisers with the Polisario guerrillas fighting Moroccan troops in the Western Sahara.

headline: VACANCY SIGNS
abstract: The recent New York hotel strike is not the only problem for the $40 billion lodging industry. Another is the construction of new hotels nationwide is running at a 13-year high -- twice the growth rate of demand for rooms, according to Daniel R. Lee, senior analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: LARGE CLAIM SEEN FROM PLANE CRASH
abstract: The crash of the Air-India airplane off the Irish coast on Sunday could result in the largest property insurance claim in aviation history, insurance experts said yesterday.   So-called hull insurance on the value of the Boeing 747 aircraft and equipment amounted to about $100 million, according to Terry Titron, former chairman of the Lloyd's of London Aviation Underwriters Association. In addition, liability claims by dependents and estates of the 329 passengers and crew members are expected to increase that amount substantially.

headline: A SONG PLUGGER'S BIGGEST PLAY: HIS RETURN AS BOSS
abstract: WHETHER it's ''Everything She Wants'' by Wham! or George Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' or Elvis Presley crooning ''Love Me Tender,'' it's all music to Freddy Bienstock's ears.   What accounts for Mr. Bienstock's catholic tastes is simple self-interest: Since early this year, he has been the chief executive officer and a sizable shareholder of Chappell & Company, the world's largest music publisher. Chappell has 31 companies in 23 countries and holds the copyright on 400,000 titles, including the works of Gershwin, Presley and the popular British group Wham!   For years, Chappell had been owned by Polygram, a major recording company that is itself owned by Philips of the Netherlands and Siemens of West Germany. Last year Polygram put Chappell up for sale, and Mr. Bienstock, a veteran music publisher, and a group of other investors acquired it in a $100 million deal. ''I didn't think we had much of a chance when we started,'' he said of their bid for the company, ''but I can't resist a challenge.''

headline: TAIWAN CONVICTS 2 IN U. S. KILLING
abstract: A civilian court convicted two reputed gangsters today of planning and carrying out the murder of a Chinese-American writer last year in California. They were sentenced to life in prison.    The defendants, reputed leaders of the Bamboo Union, the country's biggest crime syndicate, were tried by three judges in a Taipei district court for the killing of Henry Liu. Mr. Liu, who wrote a critical biography of President Chiang Ching-kuo, was shot three times in the garage of his home in Daly City, Calif., last Oct. 15.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Slogan for WNEW
abstract: Radio station WNEW, on the AM dial, is going to start promoting itself as the station that is ''Blessed With America's Best,'' in advertising that will appear on television and posters. The ''best'' are the likes of Frank Sinatra and Louis Armstrong, who show up in the commercials, as do such station personalities as Ted Brown and Alison Steele, and George Shearing, who has a live Sunday night show. The advertising was created by Holland & Callaway and has the distinctive look of something that might show up on MTV, except that that would obviously be the wrong age bracket.

headline: MARCOS SAYS HE MIGHT ASK FOR ALLIED TROOPS
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the Philippines might have to call for military help from its allies to fight Communist rebels.   ''If the integration of aid and foreign-trained troops is so massive that it is the equivalent to outright attack,'' he said in a statement, ''then we may have to ask for the help of allied troops as provided for in the mutual defense pact.''   The presidential palace made his statement public after published reports of an interview that quoted him as saying he might ask the United States to send in combat troops if the Communist insurgency got out of control.

headline: VENTURE CAPITALISM FOR THE 'LITTLE GUY'
abstract: MIDDLE income investors who have seen their portfolios languish these last few years must look with envy on the financial exploits of such venture capitalists as Arthur Rock. Mr. Rock's instinct for spotting high-tech winners such as Apple Computer and Intel has netted him returns that on occasion run hundreds of times his original investment. By contrast, the Dow Jones industrial average, despite its recent record-breaking surge, is only modestly above its June 1983 level of 1,280.   Until recently, the venture capital game has been largely reserved for huge financial institutions or multimillionaires such as Mr. Rock. Increasingly, however, smaller investors are joining in. For only about $3, for instance, individuals can purchase a share in the Biotech Capital Corporation, one of a number of publicly traded venture capital funds. For $5,000, investors can share in venture capital partnerships run by such financial supermarkets as Merrill Lynch or Prudential-Bache.

headline: O'NEILL CALLS PLAN RUSE: REPUBLICANS OPTIMISTIC
abstract: Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, today called President Reagan's new proposal to aid the Nicaraguan rebels a ''dirty trick'' that would be rejected by Congress, but some Republicans expressed cautious optimism that the proposal would sway enough swing votes on Capitol Hill to win the day for the Reagan Administration.   While the Democrats were denouncing Mr. Reagan's plan in unusually harsh terms, and predicting its failure, they also expressed worry and admiration for the President's proven ability to lobby lawmakers and push his program through Congress.    ''I don't think the funds are going to be released,'' said Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Democratic whip. ''But it's going to be a very close vote, and I don't ever want to be accused of underestimating the President.''   The Senate is scheduled to vote on the proposal April 23, and the House is likely to vote about a week later. Mr. Reagan is expected to mount a major campaign for his proposal over the next several weeks.

headline: Treasury Securities Mixed
abstract: Interest rates on Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with rates rising for Treasury bills due in less than a year but falling slightly for longer-term notes and bonds.   All of the improvement in the Treasury note and bond market came late in the day, lifting the price of the bellwether 11 1/4 percent issue due in 2015 to 107 5/8, up more than 3/4 point to yield 10.41 percent. Among shorter maturities, the 9 7/8 percent notes due in 1990 were offered at 100 26/32, up about 1/4 point to yield 9.65 percent and the 9 1/8 percent issue due in two years was offered at 100 5/8, up 2/32, to yield 8.77 percent.   A plan by United Airlines to capture the excess funds in its employee pension plan and use the rest of the funds to buy annuities might help the bond market, analysts said, because similar plans by other companies have involved sizable bond purchases.

headline: NO U.N. TRIP FOR GORBACHEV
abstract: A United States official here confirmed today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev had decided against attending the United Nations General Assembly this fall.   The official made the comment after Armand Hammer, the industrialist, told reporters earlier this week that he had been advised of the Kremlin's decision by Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet Ambassador to Washington.

headline: CUBANS LEAVING, NICARAGUAN SAYS
abstract: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has said that the Government will soon carry out its pledges to send 100 Cuban advisers home and to free a number of people held on charges of subversion.   Mr. Ortega promised in February that he would send home 100 Cubans, and on Wednesday he said they will leave May 2. He said the ambassadors of the regional bloc known as the Contadora Group - Panama, Mexico, Venezuela and Colombia - would be invited to the departure ceremony.

headline: WIND POWER SHIFTS INTO HIGH GEAR
abstract: SUMMER has arrived, and high up in California's exotically named mountain passes - Altamont, Tehachapi and San Gorgonio - the wind is blowing. It funnels down through mountain canyons and activates thousands of windmills.   Nearly all of them have been erected since 1981. And they are humming with power - so much that some energy experts say that wind farming may soon be a multibillion-dollar business.

headline: INTERVIEW WITH PERES ON U.S. NEWS PROGRAM
abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview with Prime Minister Shimon Peres on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' as recorded by The New York Times:   Q. Your Government has announced the release of 31 of the Lebanese Shiites. There are 766 there. Why not release them all?   A. We did release the 31 in accordance, first of all, with the laws of our country. Every detainee has the right to appeal to a special committee and if the committee decides to release them so we do.

headline: Herbalife Sets More Layoffs
abstract: Herbalife International, a diet-product and nutritional supplement sales company, has laid off 573 employees at its headquarters here and at its nine distribution centers around the country.

headline: Polish Students Protest Effort to Curb Autonomy
abstract: Hundreds of students at Warsaw University staged a protest rally today against plans by the Communist authorities' to limit student self-government and to exert more official control over courses and teaching methods.

headline: FAN VIOLENCE HAUNTS ENGLISH SOCCER TEAMS
abstract: Fan violence at soccer games has haunted English teams this season.   A boy was crushed to death in Birmingham, hundreds of fans and police have been injured, and the police in York confiscated knives, razor blades, a spike, and chains.   Last week, in sentencing 25 Cambridge United fans to prison, a judge condemned ''an evil, wicked vortex of violence,'' in which one fan last year had his throat cut with a broken milk bottle and a policeman was kicked in the back as he tried to ward off 30 youths from an unconscious Chelsea supporter.   Fans, the Government, and the police have felt for months that something must be done. One of the recommendations here had been to fence off soccer fields from spectators who have invaded the playing field to attack other fans and the police. The Bradford fire on May 11, in which 53 fans were killed and 200 injured, raised serious questions about this approach. Far more people would have died, it was agreed afterwards, if most of the crowd had not been able to escape onto the field.

headline: ECONOMIC GROWTH FELL TO 1.3% RATE IN FIRST '85 PERIOD
abstract: The economy slowed sharply to a weak 1.3 percent annual growth rate in the first three months of the year, the Commerce Department reported today.    That was the smallest growth since the recovery began in late 1982 and was far below the 4.3 percent rate of the final 1984 quarter.    According to most economists, the report dashed hopes that the United States could achieve the Reagan Administration's 3.9 percent growth target for 1985. One of the implications is an adverse effect on the Federal budget deficit because lower economic activity, among other things, implies lower incomes, profits and Treasury revenues.

headline: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: Where Safety is Taken Seriously;   SURVEY FINDS SECURITY AT AIRPORTS USUALLY SERIOUS, SOMETIMES NOT
abstract: Airport security varies widely around the world, but a review of procedures shows that in general those practiced in developing countries tend to be lax while those in North America and the Communist bloc tend to be stringent.   In Europe, the review shows, the major airports usually follow a high standard of security. A notable exception is Athens, where hijackers last week seized a T.W.A. plane, some of whose passengers are still held hostage in Beirut, Lebanon.   The review was conducted by correspondents for The New York Times and supplemented by interviews with State Department officials and representatives of the International Air Transport Association and the International Federation of Airline Pilots Association. Officials of the Federal Aviation Administration and the Central Intelligence Agency declined to be interviewed.

headline: 2 Offerings Made By Florida Utility
abstract: In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Florida Power and Light Company offered a total of $74.13 million of pollution control revenue bonds for two borrowers - St. Lucie County and the Dade County Industrial Development Authority.    The St. Lucie offering consists of $61.2 million of 35-year bonds maturing April 1, 2020.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Amoco Oil Co. said that its previously announced spinoff of its money-losing minerals business would take effect July 1 and that shareholders would receive 1 share of common stock in the new Cyprus Minerals Co. for every 10 shares of Amoco held as of June 19.    * Dow Chemical Co. said it had agreed to purchase the Minneapolis-based Filmtec Corp. for about $75 million, or $21.75 for each of Filmtec's 3.45 million shares.

headline: LEVERAGE, AND PRIDE OF OWNERSHIP
abstract: THE allure of real estate as a personal investment arises basically from the wonders of leverage.   Put down $20,000, borrow $80,000 and buy a property for $100,000. Wait five years and sell the property for, say, $150,000. Repay the lender the amount still owed, about $78,000. Then pocket the remaining $72,000 or use it as the 20 percent down payment on a property worth $360,000.

headline: THE 8 ACCUSED OF A PLOT AGAINST THE POPE
abstract: Mehmet Ali Agca The Turk who shot and seriously wounded the Pope on May 13, 1981 . . . Was captured in St. Peter's Square immediately after the shooting . . . Sentenced to life imprisonment by an Italian court in July 1981 . . . Case against the other defendants is based almost entirely on his testimony . . . Appearing at the trial mainly as a witness, but the indictment charges him with helping to smuggle into Italy the Browning pistol used to shoot the Pope . . . 27 years old.      Sergei Ivanov Antonov   Rome station chief of Balkanair at the time of the shooting . . . Arrested in Rome on Nov. 25, 1982, on charges of complicity in the papal shooting . . . Accused of helping Mr. Agca to plan the shooting, driving him to St. Peter's Square and waiting in a nearby street to drive Mr. Agca to safety if he escaped . . . 37 years old . . . Has repeatedly denied any involvement.      Musa Serdar Celebi   A prominent member of the Turkish terrorist organization Gray Wolves . . . 33 years old . . . Accused of being the contact between Mr. Agca and the purported mastermind of the plot in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia . . . Was arrested in West Germany and extradited to Italy.

headline: SSC&B: Lintas Fills Key Posts
abstract: Spencer Plavoukos, newly arrived at the top of SSC&B: Lintas USA with the title of chairman and chief executive, has in turn raised two associates to new heights.   Frank DeVito, imported only recently from Young & Rubicam to be head creative person, has additionally been named president.

headline: PORTUGUESE COALITION BREAKS UP
abstract: Portugal's Social Democratic Party told its Socialist partners in the Government today that it was withdrawing from the two-year-old coalition, a Socialist Party spokesman said.   The decision, which was personally conveyed to the Socialist Prime Minister, Mario Soares, by the Social Democratic leader, Anibal Cavaco Silva, came in the aftermath of a bitter policy dispute between the two parties.

headline: T. W. A. Cuts Loss; Lockheed Up 23.5%
abstract: Trans World Airlines, benefiting from an extraordinary gain, yesterday reported a smaller loss in the first quarter.   The airline posted a deficit of $74.3 million, compared with a loss of $87.3 million in the first quarter last year. The earnings for the latest quarter were after an extraordinary gain of $11.7 million from an exchange of stock for debt.

headline: FREED PASSENGER RECOUNTS BEATING
abstract: An Australian girl freed by the hijackers of a T.W.A. jet described today how the gunmen assaulted an American serviceman before killing him, kicking him over and over until ''they had broken all his ribs.''   Ruth Henderson, 16 years old, said she was sitting next to the serviceman Friday night when the hijackers ''dragged him out of his seat, tied his hands and then beat him up.   ''I watched as they kicked him in the head. They kicked him in the face and knee caps and kept kicking him until they had broken all his ribs.

headline: Thrift Unit Accord
abstract: After six years of litigation, the Home Owners Federal Savings and Loan Association has agreed to pay more than $600,000 to 1,200 home mortgage borrowers whose interest rates were raised. The settlement also means the mortgage rates will drop to their original levels, which averaged 6 percent, for about 650 borrowers whose mortgages are still in force. ''The bank still believes it had the right to raise the mortgage rates to an average of 9 percent in 1979 under the agreements,'' Lenore S. Treiman, first vice president at Home Owners, said.

headline: Analysts Skeptical
abstract: Oil industry analysts in the United States expressed doubts yesterday that OPEC would be able to keep world oil prices from falling.   Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass., said that ''there's no question that several OPEC members are feeling tremendous pressure from the markets to match non-OPEC countries' discounts and price cuts.''

headline: ANOTHER DAY OF WORK IS DONATED IN SOVIET
abstract: Millions of workers across the Soviet Union donated a day of work to the Government today to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the surrender of Nazi Germany in World War II.

headline: MOBIL PLANS TO DIVEST WARD UNIT
abstract: The Mobil Corporation, acknowledging the failure of an expensive effort to diversify outside the energy area nine years ago, said today that it would divest itself of its retail subsidiary, Montgomery Ward & Company.   Ward, a venerable name in American retailing, is the nation's sixth-largest merchandising chain and third-largest catalogue house. But it has been a big disappointment to Mobil.   In 1976, Mobil bought Marcor Inc., the holding company for Ward and the Container Corporation of America, for $1.7 billion. Since then, the oil company has plowed another $600 million into Ward. $500 Million Write-Off Mobil said it would take an after-tax write-off of $500 million this year to ''reshape'' the retailer. The company said its goal was to create a Ward that could ''operate as an independent, free-standing, profitable retail company without Mobil ownership or financial guarantees.'' Last year, Mobil earned $1.27 billion.

headline: Boar's Head On Guard
abstract: According to the creative high command at Altschiller Reitzfeld Solin, its client of seven years, Boar's Head Provisions of Brooklyn, maker of premium-priced cold cuts, is troubled by a number of unscrupulous deli operators in New York.   The operators are said to be playing the old switch-the-ham caper on customers who ask for Boar's Head.

headline: Common Market Leader Attacks U.S. and Reagan
abstract: The European Economic Community Commissioner, Claude Cheysson, accused the United States today of developing imperialist attitudes and President Reagan of being tactless in relations with Western allies.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 26, 1985        Companies    I.B.M. is taking a stake in MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance company. The move, seen as the computer giant's strongest challenge yet to A.T.&T., is expected to further narrow the number of companies in the turbulent long-distance market. It is also seen as critical to I.B.M.'s strategy of building a huge infrastructure that can exchange data, voice communications and pictures among computer systems. In the deal, I.B.M. will buy the part of the Satellite Business Systems telecommunications company that it does not already own and will then turn over S.B.S.'s assets to MCI in exchange for an initial 18 percent share of MCI. [Page A1.]  MCI has found a partner with the money and the technological clout it needs to compete with A.T.&T. [D1.]    American Express announced the resignation of Sanford I. Weill as president, after months of rumors that he was dissatisfied. His successor is Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the head of the travel services unit. [D1.]  The company also announced a partial divestiture of its Fireman's Fund insurance unit, a division that Mr. Weill had tried to acquire through a leveraged buyout. [D5.]

headline: Holiday Inns to Expand
abstract: Holiday Inns Inc., the United States-based hotel chain, announced plans today to open as many as 26 more hotels in Britain at a total cost of about $200 million. The new hotels will average 120 rooms and form part of a big European expansion program, Sigi Bergmann, the company's European managing director, said.

headline: ECONOMIC INDEX OFF IN NEW SIGN OF A SLOWDOWN
abstract: The Government's main index for predicting changes in economic trends registered a small but unexpected decline in March of two-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.   Analysts described the fall in the index of leading indicators as somewhat disconcerting after other recent reports of meager economic growth in the first quarter and an upturn in inflation.   The department also said the United States trade deficit in March was $11.1 billion, or 3.5 percent less than in February. The improvement was less than many economists expected. [Page D5.]  Another report said that factory orders fell nine-tenths of 1 percent and that the durable goods component plummeted 3 percent, not 2.3 percent, as first reported last week. [Page D19.]  Bigger Drop Probable The report on factory orders meant that the composite index of leading indicators would probably be revised to show a drop greater than two-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: Data General Net Falls
abstract: The Data General Corporation, a minicomputer maker based in Westboro, Mass., yesterday reported a 36 percent drop in second-quarter earnings and said it would close domestic plants for two weeks this year. Net income fell to $9.1 million, or 34 cents a share, from $14.2 million, or 55 cents a share, a year before. Revenues rose 16.9 percent, to $320.2 million, from $273.9 million.

headline: IN SAUDI OASIS OF CALM, SOME SEE SEEDS OF UNREST
abstract: When Saudi officials are asked if their kingdom is stable, they answer that Saudi Arabia has little violent crime, no suicide bombers and a royal family close to the people.   ''Whenever I come here, I feel a total sense of peace and security,'' Samir S. Shihabi, the Saudi delegate to the United Nations, said on a recent visit home. ''I feel as if I'm protected from the world outside.''   By all indications, the desert kingdom is stable, according to Saudi officials, Western and Asian diplomats and foreign businessmen. But there are tensions within the society that threaten to disrupt the tranquillity in the years to come.

headline: CANDID BRITISH FOREIGN SECRETARY
abstract: Lord George-Brown, a former Foreign Secretary and one of Britain's most colorful political figures in the 1960's, died Sunday. He was 70 years old.   Lord George-Brown was named George Alfred Brown at birth, but never used the middle name and inserted the hyphen when he was made a baron. He died of complications from surgery to correct severe internal hemorrhaging, said his brother, Ronald Brown. The surgery was performed last week at a hospital near his home in Cornwall.

headline: ADVERTISING ;Hilton Switch
abstract: Hilton International, which is in the hotel business but largely outside this country, has switched its $3.5 million account to Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle from Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, a subsidiary of the JWT Group.

headline: Real Estate;   Law Firm As a Buyer, Not Renter
abstract: CONSTRUCTION crews worked through the Father's Day weekend to finish up in time for the official opening last night of the 275,000-square-foot building at 100 Maiden Lane. The property had been purchased and was renovated by the 193-year-old law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, which occupies 155,000 square feet and plans to lease the rest to other law firms.   Grant B. Hering, managing partner for Cadwalader, said this is believed to be the first time in New York City that a major law firm has chosen ownership over renting. In recent years, doctors and medical groups have begun to switch from renting to owning their offices, and several medical condominium office buildings have opened. Lawyers, however, have resisted the trend so far.

headline: Kaiser Aluminum To Sell Subsidiary
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell the Kaiser International Corporation, a subsidiary, and two fertilizer plants to an investment group headed by Thomas K. Singer, president of Kaiser International. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: A-Test Is Laid to Israel And South Africa
abstract: South Africa and Israel conducted a joint nuclear weapons test in 1979, a private lobbying group said today, and a member of Congress called for a new investigation of the report.   The report, by the Washington Office on Africa, said the Carter Administration suppressed information about the atomic test because the test was politically inconvenient and potentially embarrassing.

headline: NOVELL INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: FUROR IN ISRAEL
abstract: Many of Israel's top experts on terrorism say they believe the prisoner exchange carried out Monday was a blunder that has dealt long-lasting damage to Israeli strategy on counterterrorism.  The experts, including scholars and former intelligence officials, contend that the decision by the Government to trade 1,150 Palestinians for 3 Israeli soldiers has negated Israeli assertions that it will never negotiate with terrorists. They also contend that it will, in the long run, encourage Arabs to risk attacking Israeli targets.  The first casualties of the exchange, the experts say, were Israel's moral arguments in the fight against terrorism.  ''I am disgusted,'' said Shlomo Gazit, a former Chief of Military Intelligence and one of Israel's top counterterror strategists.

headline: Economic Scene;   Examining G.N.P. Vigor
abstract: THE just-released ''flash'' report of the gross national product, showing that the economy has moved up at a 3.1 percent annual rate in the second quarter, said to the markets that there is life in the expansion yet.   ''The surprise in the new figures,'' said Robert Ortner, chief economist of the Commerce Department, ''was on the upside.'' Most market analysts and economists had been expecting real G.N.P. to come in at a rate closer to that of the first quarter, which the Commerce Department revised downward to a mere three-tenths of 1 percent - next to nothing.   The flash report is really a projection for the quarter as a whole, based on preliminary data for April and part of May, and will undergo three later revisions. On balance, however, Mr. Ortner finds the first G.N.P. report ''reasonable.''

headline: STORER SETS A PARTIAL BUYBACK
abstract: Rejecting a $1.6 billion leveraged buyout offer as inadequate, Storer Communications yesterday proposed a substantial change in its capital structure. It would repurchase six million of its shares, or slightly more than a third of the company, for cash and debt valued at $100 a share.    The proposal is seen by Wall Street analysts as an attempt to head off a proxy fight at the annual meeting next month, when a dissident group headed by Coniston Partners has vowed to take control of the company.   But Augustus K. Oliver, a general partner with Coniston, said that the recapitalization proposal was inadequate and that his group would continue with its plans to seize control of the cable operator.

headline: Retrenchments Set By Intel and Gould
abstract: In separate developments reflecting difficulties in the semiconductor industry, the Intel Corporation said yesterday that it would lay off about 950 employees and Gould Inc. said that it would take a $150 million write-off in the second quarter.   Intel, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., said that besides laying off about 4 percent of its work force, it would take ''other measures'' to reduce costs. It also said it would close by the end of the year its silicon wafer fabrication plant in Santa Clara, its smallest and oldest such operation.

headline: A System to Verify TV Ad Performances
abstract: Here comes another electronic system for verifying the performance of TV commercials.

headline: British Immigration Law Found Sexually Biased
abstract: The European Court of Human Rights today found the British Government guilty of sex discrimination in immigration laws that permit men who are legally settled to bring their wives to Britain but do not permit women residents to bring their husbands.   The ruling could affect as many as 2,000 couples a year, according to the Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants, which helped to bring the case before the court in Strasbourg, France.   A spokesman for the British Government said today that it would abide by the court's decision.

headline: 60 Soldiers Leave Grenada; Last of U.S. Invasion Force
abstract: The United States has withdrawn its last invasion troops from this Caribbean island, ending its nearly 20-month presence with a ceremony at the Point Salines International Airport.   Sixty soldiers of the 82d Airborne Division handed over their Grenadian flag Tuesday to Police Commissioner Russel Toppin and boarded a C-130 transport plane for the flight to Fort Bragg, N.C.   The 60 American soldiers were part of a team of 250 military policemen, medics and communications experts stationed here since the last combat troops withdrew in December 1983.

headline: A Bind for the Fed
abstract: The March trade figures, which will be announced in Washington on Tuesday, are likely to continue the familiar saga of huge merchandise imports and anemic exports for the United States.   Raymond T. Dalio, president of Bridgewater Associates, an economic consulting firm, predicts a merchandise trade deficit of over $12 billion for March, a bit higher than February's $11.5 billion.   But more worrisome, said Mr. Dalio, is a link between the trade deficit and possible moves by the Federal Reserve Board to take the economy out of the doldrums. ''What makes the rising merchandise trade deficit particularly disturbing,'' he said, ''is that the inflow of less- expensive foreign goods is encouraging consumers to take on enormous installment debt burdens.''

headline: Baldrige's China Pledge
abstract: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that China and America ''have  great potential together'' and promised to help accelerate Western screening procedures for United States high-technology equipment destined for China.         He made the pledge in a toast at a welcoming banquet given by Zheng Tuobin, minister of foreign economic relations and trade.

headline: SALVADOR DEFENSE LAWYER CHARGES COVER-UP IN SLAYING OF U.S. NUNS
abstract: A lawyer who defended a Salvadoran national guardsman convicted of murdering four American churchwomen said yesterday that he had been forced to take part in a ''conspiracy'' aimed at preventing higher-ranking military officers from being implicated in the case.   The lawyer, Salvador Antonio Ibarra, said that another defense lawyer had pressed him not to contradict a statement that ''the possibility of a cover-up had been thoroughly investigated'' and rejected. Mr. Ibarra said that declaration was ''an outright lie'' and added that he was specifically warned not to pursue the case on his own.   After it became clear he would not cooperate fully in the plan, Mr. Ibarra said in an interview, he was abducted by Salvadoran security forces, held prisoner at National Guard headquarters and tortured. The objective, he said, was to get him off the case, either by killing him or forcing him to flee the country.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Harsco Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $100 million of debt securities.    * Intel Corp. announced plans to file for an offering of an undetermined number of units consisting of zero coupon notes due in 1995 and 10-year warrants to purchase capital shares at $40 a share.    * Pitney Bowes Credit Corp. has filed for a shelf offering of up to $250 million of debt securities. Common Stock

headline: REAGAN TO VISIT GERMAN GRAVES
abstract: The White House announced today that President Reagan planned to lay a wreath next month at a cemetery for German soldiers who fought Americans and other Allied troops in World War II.    Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said the visit by Mr. Reagan to the Bitburg German military cemetery was in line with the theme of reconciliation Mr. Reagan plans to seek during his European trip from April 30 to May 10. A part of the trip coincides with the 40th anniversary of the German surrender to the Allies.   Mr. Reagan has already drawn criticism from Jewish groups for his decision not to visit the Dachau concentration camp in Germany. The disclosure today of the cemetery visit stirred a new burst of critical remarks.

headline: BRITISH REPORT I.R.A. PLAN TO BOMB RESORTS
abstract: Scotland Yard said tonight that it had uncovered a plot by the Irish Republican Army to plant bombs at 12 English seaside resorts this summer.   Twelve people have been detained under Britain's antiterrorism law in an operation that began with the arrest of five people in Glasgow on Saturday.   One is thought to be a man, identified as Roy Walsh, whom the police have been seeking for questioning in connection with the bombing of the Grand Hotel in Brighton last September. Five people were killed in the bombing and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher narrowly escaped death.

headline: THE NIGERIAN EXODUS: OLD RIVALRIES EMERGE
abstract: Thousands of Ghanaians expelled from Nigeria are coming home to a country that is of two minds about their return. They face an economic landscape offering the most fragile hope that they may not have to leave again in search of the good life.   On the one hand, many Ghanaians who stayed resent the 300,000 or so compatriots who took their quest for riches elsewhere, as their country struggled toward economic recovery. But their disdain for those returning has been somewhat tempered by what they consider the inhumane treatment the illegal workers have received at the hands of the Nigerian Government.

headline: Court Backs Broad Stock-Sale View
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal securities laws applied to stock sales that resulted in the transfer of ownership or control of a business.   In two 8-to-1 decisions, the Court endorsed the long-held position of the Securities and Exchange Commission that the antifraud provisions of the securities laws protected the purchasers of stock regardless of the underlying ''economic reality'' of the transaction.   The Court rejected the so-called sale of business doctrine, a judicially created exemption to the securities laws that had been adopted by a number of lower Federal courts, although not by Congress. Under this doctrine, a sale of stock resulting in the transfer of control of a business is viewed as a commercial or entrepreneurial venture, and not a typical ''passive'' investment of the sort that the securities laws were intended to cover.

headline: United Cable Plan
abstract: The United Cable Television Corporation said that it had started a tender offer to buy back about 16.5 percent of its stock for $40 a share, or a total of $80 million. The company said it wanted to buy a maximum of two million of its 12.1 million shares outstanding because it was an ''attractive investment.'' The shares will be purchased with the proceeds of a $100 million debt issue.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Condition of Neves Called 'Very Grave'
abstract: A hospital official said today that President-elect Tancredo Neves, weakened by 6 operations in 25 days and suffering from severe breathing problems, was in ''very grave condition with his life in danger.''

headline: BONN SAYS REAGAN MAY BROADEN VISIT
abstract: The West German Government indicated today that consideration was being given to broadening President Reagan's program during his visit next month to permit him to pay tribute to Jewish victims of the Third Reich.         The disclosure last week that Mr. Reagan's program called for a wreath- laying ceremony at a German war cemetery - without a gesture to the six million  Jews who died at the hands of the Nazis - has touched off protests in West Germany and in the United States.

headline: PRODUCER PRICES UP BY 0.2%
abstract: Producer prices for finished goods rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in March - the first increase of the year - as gains in a grab bag of items such as furniture and baby clothes offset declines in gasoline and food, the Labor Department reported today.   Inflation at the wholesale level has gone up just three-tenths of 1 percent in the last 12 months, the smallest gain in 20 years. Analysts predicted the good news would continue as Americans reaped the benefits of a strong dollar and oversupplies of oil and food.   The March increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index followed a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in February and no change in January.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, MAY 24, 1985        The Economy    The House approved a 1986 Government budget that would reduce the projected deficit by $56 billion. Over three years, the plan would cut projected deficits by $259 billion. The House and the Senate each have now approved 1986 budgets that are almost the same size. But they are poles apart on the politically sensitive issues of the military budget and Social Security, setting the stage for what could be a tough conference to work out differences. [Page A1.]

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: April 2, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Outer Space Legal Subcommittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad hoc committee on Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad hoc committee on Charter of Economic Rights and Duties of States - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: G. M. to Close Major Foundry PONTIAC, Mich., April 10
abstract: The General Motors   Corporation, citing excess capacity, said that it would shut   its engine-block foundry in   Pontiac, the second closing of a   major G.M. foundry. Production will be cut in the summer   of 1986 and will end the next   year, affecting about 1,800   blue-collar and 200 management workers.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Key Ohio Banker Is Critical of Chase
abstract: Julien L. McCall spent 21 years as a New York City banker. But Mr. McCall, who is now chairman and chief executive of the National City Corporation, Ohio's largest bank holding company, does not approve of the way at least one Big Apple-based bank is trying to do business.   Last week Mr. McCall called a news conference to protest a plan presented by the Chase Manhattan Corporation to purchase savings and loan associations hurt by the E.S.M. Government Securities scandal and convert them into commercial banks.

headline: CARTER SEES HOPE FOR MIDEAST PEACE
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter said yesterday that new peace negotiations in the Middle East could be built on the ''tremendous amount of common ground'' in positions already held by Israel, some Arab governments and the Palestinians.     But Mr. Carter said his successor, President Reagan, had failed to recognize or to exploit those possibilities and to apply ''consistent and persistent effort'' to foster new talks between Israel and its neighbors.   The former President, speaking in an interview in New York, where he was promoting a new book that outlines his views on the Middle East, also made these points:      - Mr. Reagan's proposal to develop a space-based defense against ballistic missiles was probably ''doomed to failure'' on the grounds of technical infeasibility and cost. He called the ''Star Wars'' plan an ''insuperable obstacle'' to achieving an arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union.

headline: GETTING MERRILL LYNCH MOVING AGAIN
abstract: THERE is no other firm in the world quite like    Merrill Lynch & Company. It is the giant of the   brokerage industry, from New York to London to Tokyo. In the United States, Merrill's brokerage offices have been known for decades in nearly every hamlet in the land - about 90 percent of all Americans live within 20 miles of a Merrill branch. More recently, the firm has elbowed its way into the upper echelons of investment banking, becoming a major force in the world of high-stakes corporate finance.    But the giant is faltering. Its 1984 financial results were dismal. Merrill earned $95 million, compared with $230 million the year before - on revenues in the same $6 billion range. Its pre-tax profit margin was a slim 1.2 percent, and its 4.8 percent return on equity was far below the industry norm.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed six senior vice presidents: Lynn R. Anderson, Mary B. Maguire, Chris J. Matlon, Fraser P. Seitel, Jeffrey A. Sell and Philip L. Toia.

headline: PARTI QUEBECOIS IS DEFEATED IN 4 BY-ELECTIONS
abstract: Quebec's governing party, the Parti Quebecois, lost four by-elections today to the opposition Liberal Party and had its majority in the provincial legislature reduced to a single vote.   The Liberals won by a 3-to-2 margin or better in all four districts.   One of those elected was Robert Bourassa, the Liberal leader, who was ousted as Premier in 1976 when the Parti Quebecois, led by Rene Levesque, came to power.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Chief Is Appointed At Louisiana Utility
abstract: James M. Henderson, chairman and chief executive of the Central Louisiana Electric Company since July 1983, has retired because of ill health, the utility announced.    Mr. Henderson, who is 62 years old, will be succeeded as chief executive by William F. Terbot, 48, who has been president and chief operating officer. Mr. Terbot will retain the title of president.

headline: REAGAN VISIT AIDS PREMIER IN LISBON
abstract: The greatest immediate beneficiary of President Reagan's just-completed visit to Portugal as the guest of President Antonio Ramalho Eanes has been the President's archrival, Prime Minister Mario Soares, according to Portuguese political commentators.   The Prime Minister runs the Government, but the President has veto powers and tremendous moral weight as chief of state, making both men powerful. And they dislike each other.   It was the Prime Minister's residence where Mr. Reagan paid a call, the commentators noted, and it was pictures of a grinning Mr. Soares side by side with Mr. Reagan that dominated newspaper front pages.

headline: International Paper Plans Cuts
abstract: The International Paper Company said it had adopted a voluntary early retirement plan under which 1,000 of its 10,500 management workers would be eligible for retirement. The company added that it planned to reduce the size of its work force by an unspecified percentage following a review that would be completed by the end of the summer.

headline: MAJOR SHIFTS AT INTERGROUP
abstract: National Intergroup Inc. has made major personnel changes in its aluminum subsidiary following an investigation into unauthorized metals contracts that scuttled a merger with the Bergen Brunswig Corporation.

headline: ISRAEL IS SAID TO SEEK A DEAL WITH SHIITE MILITIA ON SOUTH LEBANON
abstract: Israel would, in effect, be prepared to give up the security zone it plans to establish in southern Lebanon for an informal agreement with Lebanon's Shiite Amal militia to keep the area quiet, senior Israeli military sources said today.    ''We would be prepared to trade the security zone for a deal with the Shiites,'' said a senior military source directly involved in policy making on Lebanon. ''We would like them to know that we mean business. Though we know that Amal could not, even if it wanted, fully guarantee security in the area, we believe they could do so to a large degree. We regard them as an address we can deal with, and we are not looking for any formal arrangements.''

headline: PROFITS WEAKENED IN QUARTER
abstract: Buffeted by the strong dollar and an economic slowdown, corporate profits in  the first quarter were disappointingly low, according to economists.         ''Corporate profits were generally disappointing to Wall Street, and most businesses expected better performance in the first quarter than they experienced,'' said David A. Levy of Levy Economic Forecasts in Chappaqua, N.Y.

headline: New Chief Named For Josephson Unit
abstract: Josephson International Inc. said yesterday that William M. Lendman had been named president and chief executive of Herzfeld & Stern Inc., the investment bank and brokerage subsidiary that has been losing money steadily since Josephson bought it in January 1984.   Mr. Lendman, who most recently served as chairman of Glasrock Home Health Care, an American subsidiary of Britain's BOC Group P.L.C., succeeds Alvin H. Schulman and P. Thomas Cohen, who since October have been serving as co-chief executive officers.   Mr. Schulman, 54 years old, has served as chairman of Herzfeld's management policy committee since July and became co-chief executive in October. He will return full time to his duties as president of Josephson, the company said.

headline: Johnson's French Deal
abstract: The French sugar and paper group Beghin-Say is forming a company with Johnson & Johnson to market pharmaceutical products and toiletries in France, Beghin-Say's president, Jean-Marc Vernes, said today. The new company, to be called Beghin-Say Johnson & Johnson, will be exclusively a sales and marketing operation for selected products made by the two companies.

headline: IN GENEVA TODAY, AMERICANS AGAIN FACE TOUGH BARGAINERS
abstract: Thirty-five years ago, an American diplomat who had spent three years at the United Nations together with Andrei A. Gromyko decided that a heart-to-heart talk might break through a deadlock that had persisted between them.   Taking aside the man who was to become the Soviet Foreign Minister, the American, Frederick Osborn, spoke of his sincere desire to find a solution, and said he was sure Mr. Gromyko also believed in his sincerity.   After looking quietly at him for a moment, Mr. Gromyko replied, ''Mr. Osborn, you may be sincere, but governments are never sincere.''   In the arms talks that resume Thursday in Geneva, Americans are dealing with some of the hardest bargainers, an unsentimental breed of men who honor strength and in whose language the word ''compromise'' carries overtones of capitulation.   A body of literature on Russian negotiating techniques that dates back to the early 18th-century days of Peter the Great - when a delegation smashed its hosts' furniture to demonstrate its independence - reads like a cautionary tale against those who hope sincerity and reasonableness will bring accords.

headline: People
abstract: *       Douglas Longmire has joined Brouillard Communications, a division of J. Walter Thompson, as senior vice president and account director.     *       Robert P. Ballerini has been named executive vice president of Kornhauser & Calene.

headline: Earnings Off For Brokers
abstract: The average retail stockbroker earned about $64,000 last year, a drop of more than 22 percent from the nearly $83,000 earned in 1983, the Securities Industry Association reported yesterday.   The decline, which stemmed from a lower level of trading volume last year, came about despite an increase in ''payout'' - the percentage of the commission dollar that firms pay to their brokers.

headline: TAX EXPERTS URGE CAUTION BY INVESTORS
abstract: Tax experts are cautioning individuals against rushing into investment deals after President Reagan unveils the Administration's tax revision plan on Tuesday.   They are particularly concerned that many investors will race to lock in tax deductions by pouring money into certain investments before the tax benefits are taken away by Congress.   Part of the fear among tax accountants is that promoters of tax shelters and other tax-oriented investment deals will use the opportunity to bring out a flood of programs, many of which will be of questionable economic merit.      'A Lot of Bad Deals'   ''There's going to be a lot of bad deals around,'' said Arthur S. Hoffman, a tax partner at the accounting firm of Oppenheim, Appel, Dixon & Company. ''If there is this window of opportunity prior to a new law coming into effect, investors are going to have to be very wary and on the outlook for quality. They're going to be induced to do it in haste and that is most unfortunate,'' he added. ''But the investor has to overcome the attraction of the tax break and take a close look at the quality of that investment.''

headline: BUSINESS FORUM;  DON'T RUSH TO REGULATE REPO MARKET
abstract: ; Ralph F. Peters is chairman of the Discount Corporation of New York, a primary government securities firm.   THE recent failures of E.S.M.  Government Securities Inc.,  which provoked the subsequent run on Ohio's privately insured savings institutions, and Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc. have prompted calls for Federal regulation of all government securities dealers. While some regulation of unsupervised dealers may be needed, new rules should be enacted with care and not based on any of the misconceptions about the government securities market that are so abundant today.  One misconception is that, short of comprehensive regulation, investors have no reliable way of distinguishing reputable government securities dealers from the unscrupulous. Even comprehensive regulation is no guarantee of reputable behavior and cannot replace an investor's careful credit inquiries. Moreover, investors already have an extremely reliable source of information about certain government securities dealers - the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: FLASH FIRE KILLS 40 IN BRITISH STADIUM
abstract: Forty people were reported killed today when a flash fire swept through a wooden grandstand at a soccer match in the northern English city of Bradford.   Forty-three other people, most of them elderly, were hospitalized with serious injuries, and more than 100 others were treated for burns and shock.   Millions who were watching the match on television saw the blaze and watched as the police and spectators tried to save a middle-aged man who walked from the grandstand engulfed in flames.      Some Officers Weep   Later, the police superintendent said, some of his officers cried.

headline: Tiger to Nominate Steinberg to Board
abstract: Tiger International, a diversified transportation company, said today that its board had agreed to nominate Saul P. Steinberg, the New York financier, and an associate for election to the board at the company's annual meeting May 23.   Mr. Steinberg's Reliance Financial Corporation is Tiger's largest shareholder, with 3.9 million shares, or 17.8 percent of the total outstanding.

headline: BAKER, AT HEARING, FINDS MIXED MOOD
abstract: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d won promises of bipartisan cooperation today as he appeared at the opening Congressional hearing on President Reagan's tax plan. Sharp questioning from members of the House Ways and Means Committee, however, foreshadowed months of negotiations over some elements of the proposal.   Almost all the Representatives took issue with one aspect or another of the sweeping Administration proposal to redesign the Federal income tax system, but nobody disputed Mr. Baker's declaration that ''there is a clear and compelling need for reform.''   ''He has struck a populist chord,'' the committee chairman, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, said of the President. ''We need tax reform. The country needs tax reform.''

headline: Thailand Is Seeking a Place To Move 50,000 Cambodians
abstract: After a series of meetings this week, Thai officials and international aid organizations are still searching for a place to move more than 50,000 civilian followers of a Cambodian guerrilla army.

headline: FRONTIER CUTBACKS
abstract: Frontier Holdings Inc. said it was cutting its Denver-based work force of 366 by about 50 management and non-contract personnel and about 10 clerical workers in a move to become more cost effective.

headline: Cyclone Death Toll Climbs
abstract: The bodies of three more victims of last month's cyclone have been found, bringing the total recovered to 2,540, the authorities said today. Some 4,882 are officially listed as missing from the storm on the Bay of Bengal on May 24 to 25.

headline: A GRIM NIGHT AT A HOSPITAL ON THE IRISH COAST
abstract: The bodies of passengers and crew members from Air-India Flight 182 began arriving here early Sunday afternoon in a wave of helicopters. By the time the 25th settled onto the damp airport tarmac a little after 10:30 P.M., a routine had been established.   One by one, on stretchers and covered by blankets, the victims were carried by young Irish Army soldiers to a one-story building beside the airport, identified by sex by the Irish police and placed in drab green military trucks for the 30-minute ride to Cork County Regional Hospital.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Associated Dry Goods Corp. is offering $100 million of 10 7/8 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 100 through Goldman, Sachs; the notes are rated A-2/A+.    * Atlas Van Lines has filed an offering of 50,000 units, each consisting of three warrants, senior sinking fund notes due in 1993 and subordinated sinking fund notes due in 1994, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: MGM Hotels And Insurers
abstract: MGM Grand Hotels Inc. said yesterday it had reached an agreement settling disputes with Frank B. Hall & Company, its retroactive insurance carriers and the Del E. Webb Corporation and its insurance carriers. The disputes followed MGM Grand's 1983 settlement of liability claims stemming from a fire at the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas in 1980.

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC.

headline: ANOTHER SEVEN AMERICANS HELD HOSTAGE IN LEBANON
abstract: In addition to the 39 Americans - 36 passengers and 3 crew members - from the hijacked Trans World Airlines plane, there are seven other Americans being held hostage in Lebanon.   Those seven were kidnapped at different times in the last 15 months. They are believed to be held by militants, and their whereabouts is not known. There has been no indication that they would be released if the T.W.A. hostages are freed.

headline: LEBANON MILITIA BRIEFLY DETAINS FRENCH COLONEL
abstract: The Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army seized a French Army colonel who was negotiating for the release of 21 kidnapped Finnish United Nations soldiers today, but it later released him unharmed, a United Nations spokesman said.   Political sources in Israel said the French Government had put heavy pressure on the Israeli Foreign Ministry to obtain the colonel's release.   Meanwhile, Israeli security sources said Gen. Antoine Lahd, the Christian commander of the South Lebanon Army, had told his Israeli Army advisers that he would resign if Israel tried to force him to release the Finnish soldiers without the return of 11 of his men whom his group says the Finns handed over to the Shiite Amal militia Friday.      Israelis Support General    Israeli leaders indicated in public, and even more strongly in private, that they were backing General Lahd in his conflict with the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon, or Unifil, because they believed the force had acted wrongly by turning over South Lebanon Army members to Amal. Unifil says the men defected.

headline: Jacobs Group Adds To Castle Holding
abstract: A group of companies controlled by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis-based investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its stake in Castle & Cooke to 3.63 million common shares, or 14.1 percent of the total outstanding.   Mr. Jacobs, who is president and chief executive of Minstar Inc., reiterated that he was planning to vote his shares against the company's proposed merger with Flexi-Van Inc. The date of the Castle & Cooke shareholders meeting to vote on the merger has not been set. Between April 17 and May 15, Mr. Jacobs bought 565,400 of the food production company's shares.

headline: U.S. BIDS LATIN NATIONS LURE PRIVATE CAPITAL
abstract: Reagan Administration officials called on Latin American governments today to speed change in economic policies to attract more private capital as the way to guarantee future stability and ease the debt crisis.   David C. Mulford, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, warned at a daylong conference at the State Department that the region's capital needs would not be met either by more foreign aid or greater United States absorption of Latin exports.   Without ''fundamental'' changes, the region faces a new debt ''storm,'' he told the Council of the Americas, a group of 150 business leaders from the Americas who meet in Washington for a day every year to discuss Western Hemisphere problems.

headline: DIRECT VOTE FOR PRESIDENT RESTORED IN BRAZIL
abstract: Seven weeks after the military left power, the Brazilian Congress approved a constitutional amendment on Wednesday restoring a system of direct presidential elections eliminated at the time of the 1964 military coup.
