Early elections are not expected because the new President, Jose Sarney, who was chosen as Vice President by a 686-member Electoral College in January, has said that he plans to serve a four-year term as President.   But the Government-backed amendment, while setting no date for elections, may forestall leftist efforts to see Mr. Sarney replaced by a popularly elected President before 1989.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Adac Laboratories, San Jose, Calif., maker of medical imaging products, has named Johan F. Blokker president and chief executive officer.

headline: Iran Says It Launched 'Massive Attack' on Iraq
abstract: Iran said it bombarded Iraqi territory today in ''a massive attack'' in retaliation for Iraqi air raids, and Iraq said its warplanes raided targets in five Iranian towns.   The Iranian press agency, monitored in London, said reports from the war front indicated that ''flames and smoke from burning oil tankers and ammunition dumps could be seen for hours.''

headline: BONN PRAISES PRESIDENT ON HIS CEMETARY VISIT
abstract: West German officials expressed satisfaction today at President Reagan's apparent determination to hold to his plans to lay a wreath at a German military cemetery during a visit next month.    The officials also said Chancellor Helmut Kohl had no inhibitions about Mr. Reagan's new plan to include a visit to a former Nazi concentration camp in his itinerary.   ''Our Chancellor has no problems with going to a KZ,'' one of Mr. Kohl's aides said, employing the German initials for concentration camp. On Tuesday, the Bonn Government made public excerpts from a letter addressed to Mr. Reagan in which the Chancellor recalled that he had originally suggested a visit to a camp.

headline: SALVADORAN REBELS, IN NEW TACTICS, ARE KIDNAPPING OR KILLING MAYORS
abstract: In a sharp shift in tactics, leftist guerrillas have killed 2 newly elected mayors, kidnapped 8 others and burned 32 mayors' offices in recent weeks, according to a Salvadoran Army spokesman and Government officials.   The campaign, waged by the Marxist People's Revolutionary Army factions of the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, has spread fear among towns in rebel areas in eastern El Salvador. It is the first time the guerrillas have attacked a series of local government officials in areas of rebel operations.   The guerrilla radio, Venceremos, announced today that the People's Revolutionary Army had begun to seize mayors because it considers them to be part of ''counterinsurgency plans financed and advised by the United States.''

headline: BEIRUT RESIGNATION RESCINDED
abstract: Prime Minister Rashid Karami of Lebanon withdrew his Cabinet's resignation today after a two-day conference of top Lebanese Moslem leaders held here under Syrian sponsorship, the Syrian Vice President said.   Mr.Karami, 63 years old, a Sunni Moslem, submitted the resignation last Wednesday to protest a battle for control of West Beirut in which Shiite and Druse militiamen defeated the Sunni Moslem's Mourabitoun faction for control of the Lebanese capital's Moslem sector.

headline: President Resigns At City Investing
abstract: As the process of liquidating the company continues apace, Peter C.R. Huang, president and chief operating officer of the City Investing Company since 1979, has quietly resigned.   The company acknowledged the departure yesterday, saying in a press release that Marshall Manley, 44 years old, an attorney who was recently elected chairman of the Home Insurance Company, City's largest subsidiary, had been named to replace Mr. Huang.   City Investing said that Mr. Huang, whose last day at the company was on Monday, intended to pursue ''personal interests.''

headline: U. S. Denies China Got Pledge on Atom Ships
abstract: The Reagan Administration today denied China's assertion that it had received assurances that visiting United States Navy ships would not be carrying nuclear arms.   ''We have given no assurances to the Chinese, as reported in the press, that the proposed U.S. ship visit to China would be by non-nuclear armed vessels,'' the State Department spokesman, Edward P. Djerejian, said.

headline: People
abstract: * Craige D. Johnson has been named chief executive officer for the Marschalk Co., Houston.

headline: Mild Dip Seen By Economists
abstract: Growing Federal budget deficits and a soaring trade imbalance will send the United States into a mild recession next year, the National Association of Business Economists said today.   The group said 58 percent of those responding to a survey believed the United States would suffer a mild recession next year.

headline: Reagan Voices Desire For Spin on Autobahn
abstract: President Reagan, in a chat with a West German reporter, said he would like to get behind the wheel of a car and race down an autobahn, or superhighway, a Hamburg newspaper reported today.

headline: FUR SALES BOOM-AND SO DO IMPORTS
abstract: FOR the fur industry, the last few    years have been a prolonged   round of the old ''good news/bad news'' game.    The good news is that sales are up in every sector of the market, from dyed rabbit coats selling for a few hundred dollars to Russian sable coats retailing for $100,000, as more and more secretaries and middle-income women find it financially possible and morally acceptable to buy themselves furs. Moreover, the social disapproval once garnered by anyone wearing animal pelts is now felt only by those wearing the skins of endangered species. ''Wearing a farm-bred fur has become as socially innocuous as eating a hamburger at McDonald's,'' said fur industry analyst Edward B. Keaney of Burns, Pauli & Company in St. Louis.    This year, retail fur sales in the United States are expected to total more than $1.5 billion, up nearly 50 percent from 1981, and more than three times the total in 1974. First- time fur buyers are younger than ever - about 26 years old - compared to an average of about 40 in the early 1970's. For producers and retailers that means greater potential for more sales now, and trade-ups to higher-priced furs as the population ages.

headline: POPE LEADS GOOD FRIDAY SERVICES
abstract: Pope John Paul II carried a wooden cross tonight in a torchlight procession commemorating the final agonies of Jesus on Good Friday.   The procession ended a day of ceremonies, including a three-hour observance of the Passion of Jesus at St. Peter's Basilica.

headline: U.S. IS REPORTED TO BE WEIGHING SHIITE OFFER ON MOVING HOSTAGES
abstract: The United States was reported today to be exploring the possibility of taking advantage of an offer by Nabih Berri, the Shiite leader, to move the American hostages to a Western embassy in Beirut or to a third country such as Syria.   Such a move, a Reagan Administration official said, could be the first step toward resolving the crisis, if it was followed promptly by an Israeli decision to free 735 detainees whose release has been the main condition set by the hijackers for freeing the Americans.   In Israel, a special meeting of top Cabinet members stirred speculation that Mr. Berri's offer was being discussed. [Page A10.]  U.S. Insists on Separate Acts The United States, however, is determined not to yield to hijackers' demands and appears to be striving to assure that the release of the hostages and the release of the detainees in Israel would be seen as entirely independent steps.

headline: GOLDSMITH INCREASES CROWN STAKE
abstract: Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier who has battled with the management of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation, said late yesterday that he had increased his holdings to slightly more than 20 percent of Crown, thereby placing into effect the company's anti-takeover provisions.   Sir James's action came after Crown ignored a threat issued by Sir James on Monday that if it did not rescind the so-called poison pill measures, he would go ahead and force them into effect.   ''We took the action we said we would take,'' Sir James said in a statement. ''We understand the Crown Zellerbach board, for its own reasons, failed to redeem the poison pill.''

headline: Big Board Union Protest
abstract: About 100 clerical workers from the New York Stock Exchange demonstrated after the close of trading yesterday against automation that they say threatens their jobs. The employees are members of Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employees International Union, which has threatened to go on strike soon if its demands are not met.

headline: THE SHORT SELLERS HANG ON, NERVOUSLY
abstract: THE stock market's relative strength over the last year has pained short sellers, speculators who sell borrowed stock hoping to buy it back later at a lower price, and a profit. As prices have risen, losses have widened for these bears.   Some of the ''shorts'' have scrambled to close out positions, while others have hung on doggedly, praying for a break in prices. But if prices stay firm, or head up, a classic squeeze may develop: As short sellers rush to close their losing and dangerous positions - theoretically there is no ''upside'' limit on potential losses - their buying lifts prices, making escape even costlier. That happened in the fall of 1978 in the gambling stocks. A squeeze on short sellers in Resorts International then led to a spectacular blow off, as the stock price leaped in a few months from about $20 to $210.   More modest squeezes foiled bears early this year in issues such as Valero Energy, which had been touted as a candidate for distress but enjoyed an abrupt recovery. Its stock recently sold near $13, more than double its January low. One short seller who finally bailed out lamented: ''I saw a $60,000 profit turn into a $20,000 loss.''

headline: Falkland Airport to Open
abstract: A new $342 million airport will open this weekend on the Falkland Islands, giving Britain for the first time the ability to fly reinforcements into the disputed South Atlantic colony on short notice, the Government said today. Officials noted that a state of hostility still officially existed between Britain and Argentina, which claims the islands and seized them briefly in 1982 before being expelled by a British task force.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: June 10, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Institute for Training and Research meeting of presidents of General Assembly - 3 P.M.   Industrial Development Organization meeting on Conversion to Specialized Agency - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: ZELLERBACH REJECTS GOLDSMITH'S OFFER
abstract: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said yesterday that its board of directors had rejected a $42.50-a-share tender offer made Wednesday by Sir James Goldsmith, but added that the board said it would consider offers for $60 or more, including any from Sir James.     Sir James, the British financier who holds an 8.5 percent stake in the company, was also rebuffed on his request that the company rescind its anti-takeover provisions, a condition on which his offer had been based. .    The board, which announced its position a day after its special meeting, said the fact that Sir James's offer included that proviso demonstrated that the anti-takeover measures ''do in fact serve their purpose of enabling the board to protect the shareholders and strengthening the ability of the board to negotiate on behalf of the shareholders.''         Boesky Stake    Meanwhile, Ivan F. Boesky, the multimilionaire Wall Street arbitrager, stated in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had acquired 7.4 percent of Crown Zellerbach's shares for investment purposes.

headline: U.S. AND CHINA SEEK ACCORD ON PLANNED PORT CALL
abstract: The United States and China are engaged in ''delicate negotiations'' to decide whether Navy ships will pay a planned port call at Shanghai next week, a State Department official said today.   The talks, being held in Peking, have been going on since China said last month that the United States had pledged not to include ships carrying nuclear weapons. The United States denied that such assurances had been given, and the talks have not produced an accord on what should be said.   The issue is deemed so important by the United States that a State Department official said today that the port call by three destroyers might have to be postponed if no accord can be worked out in the next few days.

headline: Peachtree Sold
abstract: Management Science America Inc. said it had sold Peachtree Software Inc., the last of its microcomputer software units, to the Intelligent Systems Corporation. M.S.A. said the purchase was for cash and notes, but it did not disclose the sale's terms. It also said it had retained certain Peachtree equipment as well as the rights to distribute certain Peachtree software. M.S.A. is a leading provider of software for large-scale mainframe computers manufactured by the International Business Machines Corporation, and its $5.5 million acquisition of Peachtree in 1981 was its most notable effort to penetrate the microcomputer software arena. Intelligent Systems, based in Norcross, Ga., makes add-on products for personal computers and color graphics display terminals.

headline: REDRESSING THE HILLS: NEPAL IS NURTURING ITS TREES
abstract: After 10 years of losing ground in its battle against environmental destruction, this Himalayan kingdom is turning to new approaches in a desperate effort to prevent its hills and forests from turning into vast barren deserts.   Environmental experts say Nepal, a country with some of the world's most breathtaking scenery, is threatened with calamity unless it can reverse a trend that has left it with only 10 million forested acres today, compared with 16 million acres two decades ago.   Some experts project that at the current rate, all forests will disappear within 25 years. Even tourists are affected by the problem. Hikers and trekkers in the Mount Everest region are now required by the Government to take along kerosene for fuel, since the region has been largely denuded of trees.

headline: Godspeed Returns to Sea
abstract: The Godspeed, a replica 17th-century sailing ship retracing the route taken in 1607 to Jamestown, Va., returned to sea today after rough English Channel waters forced her ashore for 24 hours.

headline: Bevill Sale To Siebert Is Reported
abstract: The receiver for Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc., the New Jersey-based securities group closed earlier this month, said yesterday that he had agreed in principle to sell the firm's discount brokerage business to Muriel Siebert & Company.   The terms of the sale, though, remain in flux. Muriel Siebert, the firm's chairman, said yesterday that she had just received figures for the gross commissions of Bevill, Bresler's discount business in April, and they were only one-fifth the level of March, much less than she had expected.

headline: Power Agency Refunds '81 Bonds
abstract: The Northern Municipal Power Agency, based in Minnesota, is offering $222.7 million of electric revenue bonds to refund bonds sold in 1981 when it paid interest rates as high as 11 7/8 percent.   Underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company tentatively offered the bonds with maximum yields of 9.348 percent for 9 1/4 percent bonds due in 2015 at a price of 99 1/4, and 9.179 percent for 9 1/8 percent bonds due in 2005 at a price of 99 1/2.

headline: ENVER HOXHA, MASTERMIND OF ALBANIA'S ISOLATION
abstract: Enver Hoxha, the Albanian leader, who died in Tirana yesterday, kept his isolated mountain country rigidly cordoned off for four decades.     Historically preyed on since Greek and Roman times, Albania maintained its independence under his defiantly Stalinist leadership. But his policies also left Albania with few friends abroad as his Government broke with a succession of more powerful foreign benefactors and protectors.   Mr. Hoxha derived his absolute powers at home from his positions as First Secretary of the Albanian Workers (Communist) Party and Commander in Chief of the armed forces.    ''Let everyone understand clearly, the walls of our fortress are of unshakeable granite rock,'' he wrote in one of the many volumes of memoirs, some containing reminiscences of Stalin, that he penned over the years. More than 40 volumes of speeches and reminiscences by Mr. Hoxha were published.

headline: U.S. Planning No Yen Bonds
abstract: David C. Mulford, an Assistant Treasury Secretary, said today that the United States was not considering issuing any bonds denominated in Japanese yen.   At a news conference, he denied an article in a Japanese financial newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, which said the Treasury had approached Japan's Finance Ministry with a plan to float such bonds, to mature in 10 years, for the equivalent of $1 billion.   Mr. Mulford, in Tokyo for a currency meeting, added that the Treasury was not planning any non-dollar borrowing.

headline: Europe Is Split On 'Star Wars'
abstract: EUROPEAN business executives are in a quandary about the wisdom of President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' research program and proposals for Europe to join in. Many think the program will have a major impact on the development of a wide range of key communications and materials technologies, but they are deeply split over whether Europe stands to gain or lose by participating.   The divisions were evident in Munich last week, where the Geneva-based Institute for Research and Information on Multinationals and The Financial Times conducted the most recent of a string of conferences catering to the fears in Europe about its lagging performance in comparison with the United States and Japan in developing new industries based on modern technology.   The views expressed there and elsewhere in the Star Wars debate reflect broad concerns about European technology development. The most important is the hobbling effect in many fields of the lack of a true common market in Europe.

headline: Interest Rates Rise In Profit Taking
abstract: Reversing course, interest rates jumped yesterday as traders took profits following the recent exuberant rally.   They were motivated, analysts said, by a feeling that the Government's ''flash'' gross national product report for the second quarter, to be released this morning, will show stronger growth than earlier forecasted.   Both short- and longer-term rates rose as bond prices slipped for the first time this week. Long-term bonds fell just over 1 point in price, or $10 for each $1,000 face value.

headline: FEBRUARY INVENTORIES ROSE 0.4%
abstract: Business inventories increased four- tenths of 1 percent in February, twice the gain in sales during the month, the Commerce Department reported today.   Analysts said the disparity could be an indication that businesses are having trouble working down excess stockpiles, a problem that could translate into weak production and employment gains in coming months.   The inventory-to-sales ratio for the month moved up a scant 0.01, to 1.38. That meant that it would take 1.38 months for stockpiles of existing products to be depleted at the February sales rate.

headline: WHY TELEVISION'S BUSINESS PROGRAMS HAVEN'T TURNED A PROFIT
abstract: ANYONE waiting for a lunchtime partner at New York's ''21''   Club can use the time to check on stock prices. The prestigious restaurant's lobby television is generally tuned to the Financial News Network, and patrons can often be found staring as an anchor gives the latest business news. Across the bottom of the screen: a slightly dizzying, nonstop stream of ticker tape.   At different times of day, the screen could just as easily be turned to ''Business Times,'' ''Moneyline,'' ''The Wall Street Journal Report'' or a myriad of other business programs. Indeed, if the sheer number of entrants into the arena of televised business news were an indication, business programming would be the hottest money-maker around.

headline: ADVERTISING;AC&R Campaigning For Quality Care Inc.
abstract: Quality Care Inc., which provides a variety of in-home health care services through a national network of 165 offices, has gone to AC&R Advertising to see what advertising can do.         For the company, which is based in Rockville Centre, L.I., the agency is testing television and newspaper advertising in New Orleans; Columbia, S.C., and the Flint/Saginaw/Bay City, Mich., markets. According to the agency, a Ted Bates subsidiary, ''It's going great.''

headline: BANKAMERICA EXPECTS A BREAK-EVEN QUARTER
abstract: In another stunning report of mounting loan losses, the BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it expected its operating results to ''be near the break-even point in the second quarter.''   Samuel H. Armacost, president and chief executive, said in a telephone interview that it was too early to determine whether the banking company, the nation's second largest after Citicorp, would report a loss for the quarter. He also said that the company's dividend policy would be reviewed.   Analysts were surprised by the news. Most had been predicting that BankAmerica would earn $100 million or more for the quarter, and some said that until recently the bank had been encouraging such projections. BankAmerica stock dropped $2 yesterday, to close at $19.75, as the most active stock on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Capital Holding Corp., a stockholder-owned life insurance organization, filed for $250 million of debt securities, which may be sold directly, or through underwriters including Goldman, Sachs & Co.     *       Chrysler Financial Corp.  is issuing $300 million of 11 1/2 percent notes, with final maturity in 1997, priced at 99 1/2 to yield 11.70 percent for the first three years, through Salomon Brothers Inc.     *       Citicorp sold $100 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 8.784 percent, down from 8.833 last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 8.984 percent, down from 9.160.     *       Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.  auctioned $200 million of 15- year, 12 percent mortgage pacticipation certificates at an average price of 98 3/4, to yield 11.95 percent.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Basix Corp. is offering $30 million of 8 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2005 at a price of 100 through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as sole underwriter.    * Borg-Warner Acceptance Corp. plans to offer from time to time $75 million of notes with maturities ranging from nine months to 10 years.

headline: Bank Change Approved
abstract: The Comptroller of the Currency has approved an Atlanta telecommunications company's application to buy a Florida bank and turn it into a limited-service bank. The Comptroller's office said that the law governing bank ownership changes is specific and gives the agency no grounds for rejecting Continental Telecom Inc.'s purchase of the Southern National Bank of Pompano Beach, Fla., despite a Federal court order against approving further charters for such operations.

headline: TV Plans to Present Visit to Bitburg Live
abstract: The four major television networks plan live coverage of President Reagan's visit to the Bitburg military cemetery in West Germany on Sunday.   ABC News, CBS News and the Cable News Network have scheduled telecasts that are expected to last about 30 minutes, starting at about 8:30 A.M., Eastern daylight time.

headline: Advertising ;   Campaign For Sports Illustrated
abstract: SPORTS ILLUSTRATED, now in its 31st year, is about to embark on its first image advertising campaign aimed at beefing up both circulation and advertising.    In the print phase of the campaign at least, the effectiveness of the effort will depend on some of the great photography taken from the last 18 months of the Time Inc. magazine. James Goode is the art director and John Gruen the copywriter.

headline: PRETORIA CANCELS SETTLEMENT PLAN
abstract: The authorities have announced what appears to be a reprieve for an estimated 700,000 blacks living in 52 townships once threatened by forced uprooting to tribal homelands.   Under the plans of traditional apartheid, the townships were to be moved because they lay on the outskirts of white cities within 30 miles of a homeland boundary.   Sam J. de Beer, Deputy Minister of Cooperation, Development and Education - a portfolio affecting millions of black people - said in Cape Town today that the removals were never really practicable and that the Government was merely facing reality in cancelling the policy. All new development in the 52 townships had previously been frozen for two decades. But Mr. De Beer last week announced an end to the freeze.

headline: REAGAN AIDE SAYS AN AGENDA MUST PRECEDE SUMMIT TALKS
abstract: The White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, said today that the groundwork and an agenda would have to be complete before President Reagan would meet with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the new Soviet leader.     In laying out what amounted to the conditions that the Russians would have to meet before talks could be held, the White House appeared today to be moving away from its recent suggestions that a meeting should take place as quickly as possible, even with no prearranged agenda.   Mr. Regan, echoing comments made Monday by State Department officials, told reporters that President Reagan was against ''just having meetings for meetings' sake.''    ''We think that it would be a big letdown,'' Mr. Regan said, ''not only for Americans, but for the rest of the world, if the two leaders were to meet and accomplish nothing.''    The President appeared last month to have been moving away from his long-held insistence on firm ground rules for a summit meeting when he sent Mr. Gorbachev a letter proposing a meeting.

headline: DIGITAL'S INCOME SLIPS 10% IN QUARTER
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation, suffering from a declining demand for minicomputers that has afflicted the entire industry, said yesterday that net income for its fiscal third quarter slipped 10 percent, to $91.7 million.    Meanwhile, two of the stars of the personal computer business, the Lotus Development Corporation and the Compaq Computer Corporation, reported sharply higher earnings and revenues.    Analysts were particularly impressed with the results for Compaq, a maker of I.B.M.-compatible computers, which has continued to surge ahead despite a steep industry downturn. The earnings announcements came a week before Compaq was expected to announce two new products, a desktop and a portable machine to compete directly with the International Business Machines Corporation's still-troubled PC-AT.

headline: INTEREST RATES MOVE HIGHER
abstract: The credit markets struggled through a slow session yesterday and interest rates edged higher, as most investors cautiously waited on the sidelines in advance of a heavy schedule of Treasury security offerings set for the next three days.   The apprehensive conditions yesterday were in line with the market's turn for the worse at the end of last week. The bullish glow that had lifted the market and sent yields skidding faded when the Government reported that the economy was growing more vigorously in the second quarter than many had been forecasting. The market was also hurt by the Federal Reserve's report that the money supply has been growing far faster than its hoped-for expansion rate.

headline: Ad Council Chairman
abstract: James H. Rosenfield, senior executive vice president of the CBS Broadcast Group, has been elected chairman of the Advertising Council, which since World War II has united the media, ad agencies and advertisers as the advertising industry's public service contribution. He is the first TV network executive to hold the post.

headline: THE BIG WINNERS ON TAXES
abstract: Amid the loud outcries from smokestack industries, high-tax states and other special interests that stand to be hurt by President Reagan's tax revision plan, Wall Street analysts and tax specialists have been scouting the economic terrain to pin down those who stand to benefit handsomely under the plan.   The list of winners is long and ranges from a substantial cross-section of corporate America to low-tax states spanning the Sun Belt, and from sole proprietors and professionals at the top of the income spectrum to individuals living below the poverty line.   Although lobbyists for special interests fighting to knock down provisions of the Reagan plan are currently the most visible on Capitol Hill, prospective winners are forming coalitions to rally support for it.   For instance, a coalition of 17 major companies and industry groups - ranging from the International Business Machines Corporation and the General Foods Corporation to the National Retail Merchants Association and the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors - has pledged to work for passage of the plan.

headline: Rio Grande Industries Offer
abstract: Rio Grande Industries, a Denver-based railroad holding company whose principal property is the Denver & Rio Grande Western Railroad Company, yesterday offered $180 million of debt securities through Morgan Stanley & Company as sole underwriter.   The issue includes $100 million of 13 5/8 percent senior subordinated notes due 1995 at a price of 100, and $80 million of 14 3/8 percent of subordinated debentures due 2005 priced at 100.

headline: Computer Memories
abstract: Abraham Brand, president and co-founder of Computer Memories Inc. in Chatsworth, Calif., resigned on May 23, according to the company. Gary Streuter, who joined the company as executive vice president seven months ago, was appointed president on the day of Mr. Brand's resignation, Irwin Rubin, chairman and chief executive, said. Mr. Streuter previously worked for Altos Computer Systems in San Jose, Calif.

headline: SUDAN'S PRESIDENT IS OUSTED IN COUP BY MILITARY CHIEF
abstract: The 15-year-old Government of the Sudan was overthrown today in a military coup led by the Defense Minister, according to statements by the new Government.     The takeover came after more than a week of demonstrations and strikes touched off by increased food prices and growing disaffection with President Gaafar al-Nimeiry's Government. It occurred while Mr. Nimeiry, a 55- year-old army officer regarded as pro- Western, was out of the country. He arrived in Egypt today after more than a week in the United States.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Action Graphics Inc., a graphic arts supplier based in Hackensack, N.J., has appointed Allen J. Merganthaler executive vice president.         * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, announced that John M. Galvin has resigned as senior vice president.

headline: No Curbs, Honduras Says
abstract: Foreign Minister Edgardo Paz Barnica, who headed the Honduran delegation here this week, says his country does not plan to restrict the activities of anti-Sandinista rebels operating from camps on the border with Nicaragua.   While the Administration was trying to convince Congress to approve the aid to the rebels last month, officials repeatedly warned that one likely consequence of a failure to renew it would be that Honduras would end its tacit support for the rebels.   But in an interview this week, Mr. Paz Barnica and Col. Efrain Gonzalez Munoz, chairman of the Honduran Joint Chiefs of Staff, chastised Congress for its vote and said Honduras planned no action to curtail rebel activities.

headline: First Pennsylvania Buys Warrants
abstract: The First Pennsylvania Corporation said it had reacquired the last of some 20 million stock warrants once held by the Federal Government, effectively completing a $1.5 billion rescue plan.   First Pennsylvania said it had reacquired the last F.D.I.C.-held warrants, which gave the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation the right to buy First Pennsylvania stock, with $30.1 million generated through a recent public stock offering. The announcement came on the fifth anniversary of the start of what was then the largest Federal rescue plan in United States banking history.

headline: CBS FILES 2D PETITION ON TURNER
abstract: CBS Inc., in an extensively detailed presentation to the Federal Communications Commission yesterday, again charged that a proposed $5.4 billion takeover by Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcast entrepreneur, would financially cripple a combined company, throwing the future of CBS into jeopardy.   The document, the second that CBS has filed with the F.C.C. on the matter, presented a financial picture that differed starkly from the optimistic outlook that the Turner Broadcasting System offered in its June 18 petition.   The latest analysis especially challenged Mr. Turner's projections that CBS would remain the dominant network, both in ratings and advertising, after a takeover.   Because of the differences, CBS asked the five-member commission to hold evidenciary hearings on the transfer of licenses. Such proceedings, which can take months, are not usually held.

headline: Chevron Waiting
abstract: The Chevron Corporation has not received any firm purchase offers for its 60 percent interest in Gulf Canada Ltd., but efforts to sell the holding are continuing, said Gulf Canada's president, S. Keith McWalter. Chevron acquired the Gulf Canada interest this year, and it assured the Canadian Government that the holding would be offered first to Canadian concerns until April 30.

headline: 8 WELLS FARGO UNITS CLOSING WORLDWIDE
abstract: Wells Fargo Bank, the nation's 13th-largest bank, said today that it would close its London branch, a key New York office and six smaller offices throughout the world in an effort to streamline operations.   The move, part of a continuing campaign by the bank to concentrate on its home market in the Western United States, leaves Wells Fargo in the unusual situation for a major bank of not having any branches in Europe.   ''We're probably the largest bank that will not have a presence in Europe,'' said Lewis W. Coleman, executive vice president.

headline: Selling Conrail
abstract: The Administration's proposal to sell the Government's 85 percent interest in Conrail to the Norfolk Southern Corporation may be in for a harder look by Congress in light of a counteroffer from a group of 25 investors.   After speeding through legislation earlier this spring that would allow the Government's stock to be sold for $1.2 billion, the Senate Commerce Committee announced late last month that it had scheduled June 12 hearings on the counteroffer, organized by Morgan Stanley & Company, with the CSX Corporation as a major player.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: MONDAY, APRIL 8, 1985        Companies         Mesa Partners is seeking control of Unocal.  Mesa, an investment group controlled by T. Boone Pickens, is offering $54 a share for 64 million shares. Combined with the 23.7 million shares it already has, the group would have 51 percent of Unocal's shares outstanding if its bid is successful. (Page D1.)

headline: ISRAELIS SAY NOT ALL 766 PRISONERS ARE SHIITES
abstract: Israel said today that of the 766 detainees whose release the Beirut hijackers are demanding, only 570 are Shiite Moslems.   The Defense Ministry, issuing a full accounting of the prisoners in Atlit prison, said of the rest that 147 are Palestinians and 49 are others who include Druse, Christians and Sunni Moslems.   A Defense Ministry spokesman, Nachman Shai, said that of the 766, more than 400 had been arrested for taking a direct part in ''terrorist activities.''

headline: Sale Seen Near For Us Magazine
abstract: A partnership of Rolling Stone magazine and the Telepictures Corporation is close to completing a deal to buy Us magazine, Jann Wenner, Rolling Stone's editor and publisher, said yesterday. Us is owned by McFadden Holdings Inc. and the Warner Publishing division of Warner Communications Inc. Mr. Wenner, who declined to disclose the price being discussed, said plans are for Rolling Stone and Telepictures to form a separate company to operate Us.

headline: TRAVELING FOR BUSINESS AND PLEASURE
abstract: LAST winter, a veterinarian fled his Long Island office for a week-long seminar in Acapulco, Mexico, sponsored by the New Jersey Veterinary Medical Association. He spent his mornings in lectures on hematology and clinical pathology, but during the afternoons he went deep-sea fishing, played golf and did some sightseeing.   Uncle Sam picked up part of the tab for the veterinarian's trip - and for the excursions of countless others who are lucky enough to be able to combine business and pleasure travel. And this tax break seems likely to continue: Despite sharp limits on deductions for business travel contained in the original Treasury proposals, President Reagan's new tax plan would impose few new restrictions on tax-deductible travel.

headline: BAXTER PUTS PRESSURE ON AMERICAN
abstract: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. intensified pressure yesterday on the American Hospital Supply Corporation to reconsider its merger proposal by guaranteeing that all shares would be exchanged for either $50 in cash or an equivalent amount of stock.   In rejecting Baxter's $3.7 billion offer on Tuesday, American Hospital had focused on the uncertain value of the stock portion of the offer. Meeting that objection, Baxter's revised offer yesterday provided that American Hospital shareholders would receive Baxter common stock, preferred stock or a combination that both companies' investment advisers would agree was worth $50 a share.   But American Hospital evidently was not appeased. In a statement issued late yesterday, Karl D. Bays, American Hospital's chairman, said that while the revised offer would be reviewed, ''no one should assume that any transaction will result with Baxter.''

headline: T.W.A. PUT UP FOR SALE BY BOARD
abstract: The directors of Trans World Airlines voted unanimously yesterday to put the airline up for sale.   The action came after a Federal judge decided earlier in the day not to block an $18-a-share offer from Carl C. Icahn, who already owns 25 percent of the airline's stock.   The board instructed the airline's management and its financial adviser, Salomon Brothers Inc., to pursue alternatives that would give shareholders ''an opportunity to participate in a transaction superior to the Icahn proposal.'' The board added that any arrangement should be in the ''best interests of T.W.A.'s employees, the communities it serves and the traveling public.''

headline: Perkins Interest
abstract: Donald N. Smith, who resigned as president and chief executive of Diversifoods Inc. in January, said that he had signed a letter of intent to acquire an 80 percent interest in Perkins Restaurants Inc., a subsidiary of Holiday Inns Inc. The Memphis-based lodging company will retain a minority interest.

headline: SIHANOUK URGES THE U.S. TO HELP SET UP COALITION
abstract: Prince Norodom Sihanouk appealed to the United States today to use its ''great influence and prestige'' to help Cambodia establish a coalition government of Communists and non-Communists under international guarantees.   He spoke in an interview at his residence outside the North Korean capital, where he has made his home for several months each year since the 1970 coup in Cambodia that overthrew him and installed a pro-United States Government under Gen. Lon Nol.   The Prince, ruler of Cambodia for nearly 30 years before the coup, suggested that creation of such a coalition government could grow out of a new Geneva conference on the six-year-old conflict in Cambodia, which is between Vietnam and the rebel forces opposing Hanoi's occupation.      'More Important Than Dollars'   ''For our people, there is something more important than dollars and weapons, and it is diplomacy,'' the Prince said. ''The United States should use its very great influence and prestige and put them at the disposal of the Cambodian people.

headline: PARTNERSHIP: OWNERSHIP WITHOUT PAIN
abstract: TO many people, real estate is an attractive investment because they can see it, even kick it. But few people have the time or expertise to be a developer or landlord. The solution often lies in real-estate partnerships, which have become extraordi-narily popular in recent years. A partnership lets an investor own a share of a real-estate project without the headaches of building and managing it. And the returns can be attractive, as they come in three forms: tax breaks, income from rentals and appreciation in property value.   ''Individuals across the board are beginning to look at real estate partnerships - from the people looking to put $2,000 into an Individual Retirement Account to the heavy hitters looking at private placement tax shelters,'' said Charles R. Harmon, a financial planner in Newton, Mass.   Typically, a real-estate partnership - like an oil and gas, equipment-leasing or cable-television partnership - is composed of a general partner, who oversees the program, and limited partners, who put up most of the money. The money is used to buy or build a project; for a real-estate partnership, that is typically an office building, apartment complex, shopping center or hotel, and the investors share in any profits.

headline: A System to Improve Nuclear Safeguards
abstract: Nuclear power plants have protective systems that can shut down the reactor in an emergency.

headline: 2 Banks Cut Prime Rate; Bonds Rise
abstract: Two major New York banks, Citibank and Chase Manhattan, said late yesterday that they would cut their prime lending rates by half a point, to 10 percent, effective Monday.   The announcements followed a statement from the Federal Reserve that it had lowered its discount rate to 7 1/2 percent. That news prompted an 11th-hour rally in bond prices.

headline: SPAIN ARRESTS DOZENS AS VIOLENCE FLARES DURING NATIONWIDE STRIKE
abstract: Dozens of people were arrested today as much of Spanish industry and transportation was shut down by a one-day general strike called by Communist-led unions.   It was the first national strike in Spain since free elections were held in 1977 after the death of Franco. Most of the arrests came in clashes between picketers and the police.

headline: An Exchange President Gets Top Provigo Posts
abstract: Provigo Inc., Canada's second-largest food distributor, said yesterday that Pierre Lortie, president of the Montreal Exchange, had been named chairman and chief executive officer.   Mr. Lortie, who is 38, succeeds Antoine Turmel, who is retiring. Mr. Turmel, 67, helped start the company in 1969, when his own company, Denault Ltd., was merged with J.L. Lamontaigne Inc., and Couvrette & Provost, two other Quebec food wholesaling concerns, to form Provigo.   Mr. Lortie has been president of the Montreal Exchange since June 1981. During his tenure there, the stock exchange has grown in terms of volume and the number of companies listed. The Toronto Exchange remains Canada's largest, however.

headline: U.S. Falloff Welcomed In Europe
abstract: Figures released Thursday showing a sharp first-quarter slowdown in United States economic growth are being widely welcomed in Europe.    The figures are part of a Commerce Department report that said the United States economy was growing at a slight 1.3 percent annual rate in the first quarter.    The Europeans see two primary benefits: the continuing strong sales of European and Japanese goods to the United States and the possibility that the Federal Reserve and other major central banks may ease interest rates, giving a further lift to economic activity in Europe.

headline: U.S. PROPOSES REVISION OF GAS PIPELINE RULES
abstract: The Government today proposed a sweeping revision of its regulation of natural gas pipelines that officials said would cut prices for consumers by removing barriers to competition.   The plan, approved by a 5-to-0 vote of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, was described by one commissioner as an industry Magna Carta and by another commission official as the most important change since a 1954 Supreme Court decision that extended Federal natural gas price controls back to the wellhead.   ''Our goal is simple: To secure for American consumers the full benefits of competition in natural gas markets,'' the commission chairman, Raymond J. O'Connor, declared.   The plan would broaden access to pipelines by both producers and consumers, would allow pipelines to ''buy out'' unfavorable supply contracts with producers and would encourage pipelines to serve new markets at their own risk.

headline: FIRE IN CLINIC KILLS 79 IN BUENOS AIRES
abstract: A fire at a psychiatric hospital here killed 79 people and injured 247 Friday night, and today Government officials questioned two representatives of the institution, the police said.   The fire at the St. Emilienne Neuro-Psychiatric Institute began at 9 P.M. and quickly engulfed the modern six-story building in smoke and flames, witnesses said. The police said 410 patients were registered at the hospital. Officials said they did not know how many staff members were on duty.

headline: Brazil Links Shoes to Debt
abstract: Brazil's Minister of External Relations, Olavo E. Setubal, told the United States on Friday that a curtailment of shoe imports, as recommended by the International Trade Commission, could make it ''increasingly difficult'' for Brazil to pay the interest on its $100 billion of foreign debt.   Mr. Setubal said that he was stressing the importance of trade for financing interest payments in talks with officials on a three-day visit to Washington.

headline: ISRAELIS APPEAR ANGERED BY SUBTLE U.S. PRESSURE
abstract: Israeli leaders, angered by what they perceive to be subtle American public pressures to give in to the hijackers, affirmed today that they would make no concessions unless asked to do so officially by the United States.   The Israelis say that while they are pleased with the tough line taken by President Reagan, they are disturbed by public opinion polls, editorials and reports from their embassy and from Israeli correspondents suggesting that Americans are beginning to blame Israel from prolonging the crisis.   As a result, the Israelis seemed to be digging in their heels, saying that they would not release the 766 detainees, mainly Shiites, in exchange for the hostages in Beirut unless the United States, as one official put it, ''asks us officially to cave in to the terrorists.''      Tinge of Anger in Israeli Voices    Israeli officials made it clear that they had no intention of taking the United States off the hook by releasing the detainees on their own. If the United States wanted to give in, it would have to address Israel directly, and only then would Israel consider the matter, the officials said, often with a tinge of anger in their voices.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: May 8, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee (Subcommittee on Petitions and Information Assistance) - 3 P.M.

headline: U.S. Says 2 at Hutton Led Fraud
abstract: The Justice Department said today that two individuals were responsible ''in a criminal sense'' for practices by E.F. Hutton & Company that led to 2,000 felony counts of fraud against the company, but it said neither person was a ''high-level executive.'' They were not identified.  Stephen S. Trott, an Assistant Attorney General, made the remarks in a letter sent to Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, a Missouri Democrat, who along with 14 of his Democratic colleagues had questioned the Justice Department's failure to prosecute any individuals in the company.

headline: Anti-Government Priests On Rise, Warsaw Says
abstract: The Communist authorities said today that the number of anti-Government priests had grown since the slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest, and they appealed to Roman Catholic Church leaders to prevent unrest.

headline: Holiday Inns Net Rises
abstract: Holiday Inns Inc. today reported first- quarter earnings of $33.7 million, or $1.08 a share, up 29.6 percent, from $26 million, or 69 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the first quarter was $428.3 million, up 6.4 percent, from $402.5 million. ''We are especially encouraged by the increase in operating income from our hotel and hotel-casino divisions,'' said Michael D. Rose, the company's chief executive.

headline: WARREN ANDERSON: A PUBLIC CRISIS, A PERSONAL ORDEAL
abstract: WARREN M. ANDERSON, the chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, has not taken his wife Lillian out to dinner much in the past five months. ''I kind of felt that if somebody caught me laughing over in the corner over something,'' he said, ''they might not think it was appropriate.''   To be sure, since Dec. 3, when a chemical accident at a Union Carbide plant killed more than 2,000 people and injured thousands more in Bhopal, India, the 63-year-old Mr. Anderson has not felt much like laughing anyway. ''It must be like when someone loses a son or a daughter,'' he said. ''You wake up in the morning thinking, can it possibly have occurred? And then you know it has and you know it's something you're going to have to struggle with for a long time.''   The public ordeal of the Union Carbide Corporation since the Bhopal tragedy has been well-chronicled. The huge chemical concern has seen its stock plummet, its financial health challenged by multibillion-dollar lawsuits and the pace of its strategic acquisitions slow due to problems in raising cash.

headline: Market Place ;   Electric Utility Stocks Backed
abstract: FOR weeks, the broad stock market averages   have been under pressure, reflecting basic investor uncertainty over corporate earnings, interest rates and the course of the economy. But electric utility stocks have begun to shine again.    On Tuesday, the Dow Jones utility average finished at 154.54, its highest level since November 1965. Yesterday, it closed at 153.83, down 0.30.   The recent appeal in utility stocks stems in part from their relatively high yields. Also this is a conservative group, somewhat like the food issues, that tends to do relatively well when the market goes on the defensive.

headline: REFINERS' PROBLEMS LIE IN U.S. MARKET
abstract: FOUR years ago, at a time of rising oil prices, United States oil company executives cheered when President Reagan removed the last vestiges of Federal control over domestic oil prices. Texaco's chairman, John K. McKinley, praised Mr. Reagan for his ''overall reliance on the free market mechanism.''   Today, floundering in a sea of oil, buffeted by foreign competition, and faced with further drops in oil prices, many oil company executives are looking to the Government for protection from the ''free-market mechanism.'' Thus, a few months ago, Mr. McKinley told Texaco's stockholders that ''serious injury to both the economy and national security'' caused by rising gasoline and other petroleum product imports could only be avoided by Federal intervention.

headline: Arco Unit Deal
abstract: The Arco Oil and Gas Company, an Atlantic Richfield Company unit, said it would pay $300 million for interest in 56,000 acres of east Texas oil and gas properties owned by Henderson Clay Products Inc., of Henderson, Tex.

headline: Variety of Bonds In Texas Offering
abstract: The Austin, Tex., Housing Finance Corporation is offering $47.3 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. The bonds, insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association, are rated Aaa by Moody's and AAA by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Finding A Niche In Music
abstract: MUSIC students for years have trudged a tough road to find jobs in their field. One popular side street has been teaching in schools or universities.   Robert Freeman, director of the Eastman School of Music, part of the University of Rochester, reported last year that 1 percent of Eastman's graduates were active as concert artists or opera singers, 15 percent were orchestral players, 35 percent held jobs as school music teachers, 40 percent were college-level teachers and 5 percent had jobs in the music world as orchestra managers, recording engineers, film score composers, critics working for newspapers or magazines or administrators and advisers for foundations or arts councils. This left 4 percent of the music majors working in fields outside music.

headline: Eastern Vote Held On Merger Curbs
abstract: Frank Borman, chairman of Eastern Airlines, said at the company's annual meeting that a preliminary count indicated that shareholders had rejected proposed anti-takeover measures. The meeting, however, was adjourned until Monday to give shareholders more time to vote. Mr. Borman said that he did not expect any bids for the airline, and added that the company's debt of more than $2 billion would serve as adequate protection from an unwanted buyer.

headline: LESTER CROWN BLAMES THE SYSTEM
abstract: A BLACK limousine pulled up at the curb of the General Dynamics Corporation's suburban Washington office one day last week. A tall, trim man who had recently turned 60 emerged and took the elevator to Suite 1000, a warren of offices devoted to advancing the government interests of one of the world's most powerful arms manufacturers.   Though some senior General Dynamics officials have become familiar faces in the news during the past year of turmoil for the company, this man -even his name - has remained virtually unknown except to serious students of the case. He is Lester Crown, a company director whose 8.9 million shares of General Dynamics make him the company's biggest shareholder and who is playing an increasingly important role in shaping company strategy.   As the son of Henry Crown, the legendary Chicago financier who once bought the Empire State Building with borrowed funds and sold it for a $32 million profit, Lester Crown has gradually inherited much of his father's weight on General Dynamics' board. And in the past few months his role has expanded as his 89-year-old father's has diminished: While he does not have a hand in the day-to-day running of the company, Lester Crown is, by all accounts, deeply involved in major decisions. Recently, for example, he played a key role in choosing a successor to the company's beleaguered chief executive, David Lewis.

headline: Intergroup Lowers Net
abstract: National Intergroup Inc. said today that its 1984 profit was nearly $39 million less than originally stated, leaving the diversified manufacturer with net income of $13.7 million. The change follows the recent disclosure that the domestic trading operation of its subsidiary, the National Aluminum Corporation, had agreed to buy large amounts of aluminum ingot in long-term contracts. Intergroup said an investigation of the matter had begun.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $302.1 million, to $213.75 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: SYRIA FINDS IT ALSO LACKS KEY TO LEBANESE PEACE
abstract: Syria's efforts to impose its own order on Lebanon have bogged down in that country's intractable feuds, according to diplomats and Lebanese, Palestinian and Syrian sources here and in Beirut.   There is little prospect, these sources say, that President Hafez al-Assad will send Syrian troops into Beirut anytime soon to put an end to the fighting, the latest in a decade of civil war.   And negotiations conducted by Vice President Abdul Halim Khaddam and various factions have been suspended.   The Lebanese Druse leader, Walid Jumblat, who had been attempting to mediate an end to the most serious of the current clashes, the war between Shiite fighters and Palestinian guerrillas holed up in refugee settlements on Beirut's southern fringe, has not been seen here for days. Nabih Berri, head of the Shiite Amal militia, who was supposed to meet with Mr. Khaddam last week, has yet to show up.

headline: ENSERCH TO WRITE DOWN ASSETS BY $225 MILLION
abstract: Hard hit by falling oil and gas prices, the Enserch Corporation said yesterday that it would write down its assets by about $225 million before taxes in the second quarter.   The company said the write-down would be partly offset by an $85 million after-tax gain from the public sale of about 15 percent of Enserch Exploration Partners Ltd., a limited partnership formed in April.   Still, some analysts believed that the write-down would result in a second-quarter loss for the Dallas-based energy company.

headline: An English-Language Hispanic Supplement
abstract: An English-language Sunday newspaper supplement for Hispanic readers is scheduled to make its debut in a dozen general circulation United States newspapers on Sept. 8.   To be called Vista, The Hispanic Magazine, it has the backing of a number of extremely knowledgeable people, and its board and investor list includes Morton Frank, former publisher of the Family Weekly supplement; Warren Reynolds, former publisher of Parade, the largest supplement; Ignacio Lozano Jr., publisher of La Opinion of Los Angeles; Fortuna Calvo-Roth, former editor of Vision magazine, and Jerry Apodaca, who was Governor of New Mexico.

headline: Navy Lists General Dynamics' Gifts to Rickover
abstract: The Navy released today a detailed accounting of more than $67,628 in gifts given by the General Dynamics Corporation to Adm. Hyman Rickover over 16 years.   The list of gifts, which Admiral Rickover received from 1961 to 1977 while he - as the Navy's director of nuclear submarines - oversaw billions of dollars of construction at General Dynamics' Electric Boat division, was disclosed in the investigative report of the Navy's Ad Hoc Gratuities Board.   Based on the board's findings, Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. fined General Dynamics $676,283 on May 21 and censured the admiral, who retired in 1981. Mr. Lehman said then that many of the gifts had been ''suggested, encouraged and even demanded'' by Admiral Rickover. On Monday the Navy announced that the company had agreed to pay the penalty.

headline: ANTITRUST'S LOOSER GUIDELINES;  REAGAN'S HANDS-OFF POLICY IS WORKING
abstract: FOR years, Government authorities saw corporate mergers and joint ventures as an economic toxic substance, tolerable in small doses but hazardous to our economic health in larger ones. The Government routinely attacked mergers between companies with small market shares,and a sympathetic Supreme Court admitted that its hostility toward mergers was based not so much on economic concerns as an overriding fear of excessive economic concentration.  This pproach toward mergers and joint ventures was bad law and bad economics - a self imposed handicap that we cannot afford in this era of intense international competition. Fortunatey, it has been repudiated in the last four years. Under current Justice Department guidelines, the government will challenge a merger only when it is likelly to lessen competition and cost consumers money.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 22, 1985:

headline: SHORT-TERM RATES DECLINE MODESTLY
abstract: Short-term interest rates declined modestly yesterday but not enough to prevent an increase in note and bond yields.   The impetus for lower short-term rates was a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in the industrial production index for April. This was seen as fresh evidence that the economy is weak and needs to be stimulated by an easier Federal Reserve monetary policy. Despite the hopes for a near-term drop in interest rates, however, many economists remain concerned that a rebound in the economy will bring higher rates before year-end.

headline: U.S. ENVOY FAILS TO SECURE TALKS FOR MIDDLE EAST
abstract: The State Department said today that a high-level American official on a two-week trip to the Middle East had failed to get an agreement for direct talks between Israel and Jordan.   Despite the continuing deadlock, the department announced that Secretary of State George P. Shultz would add Egypt and Jordan to his trip to Israel, which begins on May 9.   Some State Department aides had previously said Mr. Shultz would go to Cairo and Amman only if the American official, Richard W. Murphy Jr., the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, made significant progress in his advance mission, which is nearly completed.

headline: City Housing Bond Offering
abstract: The New York City Housing Development Corporation is offering $120 million of bonds to finance multifamily housing projects in Battery Park City.   Underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs offered the bonds with yields ranging from 5.10 percent in 1986 to 7 percent in 1990, 8.10 percent in 1995 and 9.20 percent in 2002.

headline: Suit by E.S.M. Trustee
abstract: The court-appointed trustee for E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. of Fort Lauderdale filed suit yesterday in Federal bankruptcy court against the American Savings and Loan Association of Miami in an attempt to recover some $45 million  American managed to withdraw before E.S.M.'s collapse.         The E.S.M. trustee, Thomas Tew, had earlier this month indicated his intention to sue American Savings, contending that the savings and loan had an improper advantage over other creditors in withdrawing the funds because of its  close ties with E.S.M.

headline: Norfolk Rail Agreements
abstract: The Norfolk Southern Corporation, seeking to quell opposition to its bid to buy the Government-controlled Consolidated Rail Corporation, said today that it had offered to enter into agreements with several smaller, regional railroads guaranteeing them access to major traffic transfer points in the proposed merged railroad.   Norfolk Southern is also offering the smaller lines joint rates for shippers whose goods must also move over the merged railroad's routes.

headline: FRANCE ADOPTING NEW VOTING PLAN
abstract: The French Government today announced a new system of voting for parliamentary elections next year that, if current trends persist, would both strengthen the Socialists and increase the representation of far-right and far-left parties.   The new system, which was adopted in principle by Government ministers this morning, will do away with the two-stage, winner-take-all elections for Parliament that have been in existence since 1958. It will replace them by a single-vote proportional system in which seats in Parliament will be distributed to parties roughly according to their percentage of the total vote.   The most conspicuous and controversial element in the new system is that it virtually guarantees a significant bloc of seats in the Parliament that will be elected a year from now for the National Front, the highly nationalistic, anti-immigration rightist party led by Jean-Marie Le Pen. The National Front holds no parliamentary seats now.

headline: MESSGAES AND EXCERPTS FROM NEWS CONFERENCE: 'PUT ASIDE FEAR, ANGER AND INSULT' TO RECTIFY WRONGS, THE HOSTAGES URGE
abstract: Following are excerpts from statements yesterday by American hostages from the hijacked Trans World Airlines jetliner, as provided by ABC News. The first five statements were delivered in tape recordings, and the subsequent statements were made in a news conference in Beirut, Lebanon.   Following are excerpts from statements yesterday by American hostages from the hijacked Trans World Airlines jetliner, as provided by ABC News. The first five statement were delivered in tape recordings, and the subsequent statements were made in a news conference in Beirut, Lebanon.   PALMER. My name is John Palmer. I'd like to say hi to my family, that I am fine. I received my medication. I'm looking forward to being home soon. Thank you.

headline: FORD HANGS ON AILING ARGEnTINA
abstract: As one of the oldest operating American companies in Argentina, and the only remaining United States auto maker here, Ford Motor Argentina S.A. has always been a hallmark of stability in the difficult Argentine economy. But, inflation, labor troubles, financing costs and the market's unpredictability have shaken its standing as the industry leader.   After months of speculation in the local press that the home office would impose mass dismissals and close plants, a new president, Robert Sparvero, was named to lead the troubled company out of its slump.   The 45-year-old American, who formerly directed product strategy and commercial operations in Ford's Latin American division, replaced Juan Maria Courard three months ago. Mr. Courard retired, and is now a consultant to the company.

headline: Big Banks Join Prime Rate Cut
abstract: Major banks across the country yesterday announced reductions in their prime rate to 10 percent from 10 1/2 percent.

headline: SLAIN MAN'S BODY SENT TO SPAIN FOR IDENTIFICTION
abstract: The body of the passenger from the hijacked airliner who was killed Saturday in Beirut arrived tonight at an American air force base near here, American officials said.   Spokesmen for the American Embassy and Torrejon Air Force Base said the body had been transferred to the base's morgue, where specialists were taking fingerprints, X-raying teeth and making other checks in an attempt to establish the man's identity.   The body had no papers, making identification a puzzle that will likely require work through the night and into Monday, an embassy source said. Specialists here and in the United States are searching for clues from the body and medical records of the many passengers in a long-distance matching operation, he said.

headline: MANILA PLAINCLOTHES UNIT IS FOCUS OF A FUROR AFTER KILLING 14
abstract: A plainclothes Government force has killed at least 14 criminal suspects in the last week, setting off a sharp debate between authorities who say the force  is effective in fighting crime and critics who charge that it disregards civil rights.         The police say the special force, which was activated May 4, is needed to combat rising urban crime in Manila. But human rights advocates and others say the officers, who are called ''secret marshals,'' have scant regard for due process and could be used against opponents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

headline: GORBACHEV LEADS FORMAL RENEWAL OF WARSAW PACT
abstract: The Soviet Union and its Eastern bloc allies today formally extended the Warsaw Pact for 20 years in a ceremony presided over by Mikhail S. Gorbachev on his first visit abroad as Soviet leader.   Mr. Gorbachev and the leaders of the seven nations in the Soviet-led military bloc agreed at a two-hour meeting to renew the 30-year-old pact, whose expiration date was May 15.   Polish television coverage of the signing ceremony focused largely on Mr. Gorbachev, who was shown being greeted with some deference by the older men who are the party leaders of the other member nations - Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Rumania.      Gorbachev's Tone Is Muted    In marked contrast to a speech in Moscow three days ago, in which he said Washington was not seeking an agreement in the Geneva arms talks, Mr. Gorbachev toned down his characterizations of the United States in his remarks today. Instead he stressed Soviet proposals for mutual nuclear rollbacks, which he said could only follow the abandonment of United States plans for deploying weapons in space.

headline: CURBS GIVE WAY TO WELCOME FOR MULTINATIONAL COMPANIES
abstract: Just a decade ago, multinational companies were widely viewed as a scourge of the third world. Alarmed by the companies' intrusions into local politics and overwhelmed by their economic might, many countries nationalized foreign holdings or placed tight restrictions on new investments.   But today, from China to Algeria, from Australia to Nicaragua, foreign multinationals are finding warm welcomes almost everywhere. Eagerly sought for the capital, technology and jobs they provide, the companies are being courted by developing and industrial countries alike.   ''We feel that it is better to have partners than creditors,'' Francisco Swett, Ecuador's Finance Minister, said in a telephone interview. ''I can say that with full authority, having just refinanced our foreign debt.''

headline: FIRE ALTERING THE EVOLUTION OF DARWIN'S ISLES
abstract: A fire that has been charring Isabela Island for the last month has made life precarious for nesting birds, giant tortoises and other forms of wildlife unique to the Galapagos Islands. But for some of the human residents of this Ecuadorean archipelago, the blaze has created a modest boom.   Firefighting experts, pilots, scientists, journalists, volunteers, yachtsmen and tourists have been flocking to the Pacific islands, some to help put out the fire, some to observe the proceedings, others merely to savor the excitement. But whatever their reasons for coming, they have been spending money, and the results are visible in this dusty little fishing village.        Big Fire on Isabela Island    Sooner or later, nearly everyone who visits the Galapagos Islands ends up here, at least for a few days. Puerto Ayora on Santa Cruz Island is not the archipelago's capital town - Baquerizo Moreno on San Cristobal Island has that distinction - nor does it command a view of the big fire on Isabela, which lies 60 miles to the west. But Puerto Ayora is where one finds soft beds, cold beer and good talk, not to mention tame tortoises, Darwin's finches and iguanas.

headline: Columbia Gas
abstract: Columbia Gas System Inc. said that its major gas pipeline company had reduced its natural gas prices 11.5 percent, retroactive to April 1.

headline: Eastern Hails Union Vote
abstract: Eastern Airlines said today that it was out of danger of falling into technical default on its $2.5 billion debt now that members of the machinists' union had approved a revised three-year labor contract.   ''I think if there's a crucial vote, this is the one,'' Glenn H. Parsons, an Eastern spokesman, said of Thursday's approval by a nearly 2-to-1 margin.

headline: BURROUGHS AND SPERRY IN TALKS
abstract: The Burroughs Corporation and the Sperry Corporation said yesterday that they had begun merger talks that if successful would create the world's second-largest computer company.   Burroughs, based in Detroit, and Sperry, with headquarters in New York, issued a one-sentence statement saying they were engaged in ''negotiations with respect to a common stock merger.'' The companies declined to elaborate.   Investment banking sources, however, said that the negotiations revolved around a takeover of Sperry by Burroughs. According to these sources, Sperry investors would receive just over one Burroughs share and around $10 in cash for each Sperry share they hold. Those terms would value Sperry at more than $3.74 billion.

headline: HIJACKERS RELEASE OVER 60 FROM JET IN ALGIERS AIRPORT
abstract: The hijackers who forced a Trans World Airlines jet to make a terror-filled journey back and forth across the Mediterranean released more than 60 passengers and crew members in Algiers yesterday and 3 more today, but they set an ominous new deadline for those still held hostage.   Passengers were freed in three groups yesterday and one group early today. All those still held hostage on the plane were believed to be American men, but it was not clear how many there were.   Some reports said as many as 46 passengers and the 3 cockpit crew members were being held as the plane remained on the ground in Algiers this morning. But the official Algerian press agency quoted Algerian officials as saying only 38 hostages remained aboard the plane today, and there were reports that several men had disappeared after being singled out by the hijackers when the plane was in Beirut.

headline: Informatics Vote
abstract: The Informatics General Corporation said a preliminary count of votes submitted at the annual meeting showed that shareholders had rejected its two anti-takeover proposals. The software company said shareholders did re-elect the two directors nominated by the company. Informatics has been engaged in a proxy contest with Sterling Software Inc., a Dallas-based company that owns 9.3 percent of Informatics' stock.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Ames Department Stores Inc., Rocky Hill, Conn., said it had received 2,958,133 G.C. Murphy Co. common shares in response to its tender offer at $48 a share, and the offer had been extended until May 29.    * American Airlines said that on Aug. 1 it would begin daily airline service between Dallas/Fort Worth and Richmond, Va., and Norfolk, Va.

headline: WHITE HOUSE TELLS NICARAGUA TO STOP 'AGGRESSIVE' MOVES
abstract: The White House condemned Nicaragua today for what it called ''increased aggressive behavior'' against neighboring Honduras and Costa Rica.   ''The U.S. strongly condemns these actions and calls upon the Government of Nicaragua to halt immediately any further military operations against its neighbors,'' said Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman.   At another point, Mr. Speakes said, ''We're seriously concerned at signs of increased aggressive behavior by the Government of Nicaragua against its neighbors.''

headline: Solidarity Activists' Trial Called a 'Political Farce'
abstract: A defense lawyer denounced the trial of three prominent Solidarity activists today as a ''political farce'' after a tense courtroom session that included a weapons search of everyone in the room.

headline: Product Introductions
abstract: New products in the package goods area reached all-time heights last month, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News newsletter, which spotted 235 of them, up from 226 in May 1984 and from the paltry 183 in April of this year.

headline: Peru Arrests 2,000 After a Bombing Wave
abstract: The police said today that they had arrested about 2,000 people in a search for Maoist guerrillas who mounted an urban offensive over the weekend.

headline: UTAH POWER SALE
abstract: The Utah Power and Light Company said it had agreed to sell one-fourth of its Hunter 3 generating unit to Nevada Power for $135.3 million. According to the terms of the agreement, Nevada will begin receiving a 100-megawatt share of the 400-megawatt unit's output on Jan. 1, 1988. Nevada Power agreed to pay one-fourth of the costs and improvements at the plant, the statement said.

headline: 2 Officers to Head Lyon When It Goes Private
abstract: Lyon Metal Products Inc., which has been fending off takeover attempts for much of the last year, yesterday named two executives who will run the company after a plan to take Lyon private is successfully completed.   Lyon, which is based in Aurora, Ill., said that R. Peter Washington, who two weeks ago was named interim chairman, had been named to the additional post of chief executive. In addition, Lyon said its board had elected Bruce K. Chamberlain, currently vice president of operations, to the posts of president and chief operating officer.

headline: SHIITE CONFIRMS SEPARATION OF 'ZIONIST' PLANE HOSTAGES
abstract: A senior aide to Nabih Berri, the Shiite leader, said today that six to ten hostages were taken off the Trans World Airlines plane early Saturday because the hijackers suspected them of having ''Zionist connections.''   The statement, by Akef Haidar, who heads the politburo of Mr. Berri's Amal militia, was the first confirmation from a Shiite official that people with Jewish-sounding names were taken from the plane after it made its second stop here, on returning from Algiers.   On Sunday, after the third landing in Beirut, the rest of the 37 passengers were taken off the plane on Mr. Berri's instructions and were hidden away in the city's southern Shiite suburbs.   Mr. Berri has agreed to negotiate on behalf of the hijackers and supports their demand that Israel exchange 766 detainees for the American hostages.

headline: JOHANNESBURG BOMB BLAST WOUNDS 10
abstract: A bomb exploded in the offices of a South African Army medical unit here today, wounding at least 10 people.   There was no immediate word on who planted the bomb, which went off in a high-rise building in central Johannesburg. In the past, the main rebel organization, the African National Congress, based in Zambia, has taken responsibility for such explosions.

headline: U.S. CAR SALES UP 18.2% IN MID-MAY
abstract: A fresh round of buying incentives lifted sales of new American-made automobiles 18.2 percent in the May 11-20 period, the manufacturers reported today.   Sales of light trucks jumped 37.4 percent.   The incentives - in the form of below-market-rate financing - were introduced early in the month, but began to show results in mid-May. A sales analyst for the Ford Motor Company suggested that last week's reduction in the prime interest rate, and the subsequent rally in the stock market, helped renew consumer confidence.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: ''It happened so quick I couldn't do anything but run. All of a sudden it just exploded around me - the car, the gas tank and everything.

headline: CHANGE IN FLOATING CURRENCY RATE SETUP BARRED
abstract: The United States and 10 other wealthy nations today announced modest revisions of the world's monetary system.   In a meeting here, top monetary officials rejected proposals to change the floating exchange rate system. Instead, they called for an increased examination of each other's economic policies as a way to insure overall currency stability. This way, the officials said in a communique, governments would have a better idea of how their domestic policies affected other countries.

headline: HOW HUTTON SCHEME WORKED
abstract: Back in December 1981, John McMurtrie, president of the Northern Central Bank in Williamsport, Pa., had no reason to be suspicious of as prestigious a customer as E.F. Hutton & Company - that is, not until he looked hard at the bank account maintained by the local Hutton branch.   Then he discovered that Northern Central had, for months, been bilked by a corporate check-kiting scheme that sucked millions of dollars out its coffers before payment from checks deposited in the Hutton account had been made.   ''We were losing our shirts on their business,'' Mr. McMurtrie recalled. ''We told them, 'We cannot live with this,' but they decided to withdraw their account.''   Mr. McMurtrie's bank was by no means the only victim, as evidenced by the criminal charges and penalties that Hutton agreed to several weeks ago. After one of the largest criminal investigations the Federal Government has ever conducted, the Justice Department concluded that the huge brokerage house had worked its scheme on some 400 banks between July 1980 and February 1982.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 8, 1985:

headline: WHY NABISCO IS ATTRACTIVE
abstract: Through a combination of aggressive marketing and strong brand names like Ritz, Planters, Baby Ruth and Oreo, Nabisco Brands Inc. is considered one of the food industry's strongest and most attractive companies. Furthermore, the company has what every food company wants. ''They have shelf space clout,'' said William Maguire, a food analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.   On Wednesday, the big food company confirmed that it had had merger talks with R.J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's second-largest tobacco company. Nabisco did not elaborate and neither Robert M. Schaeberle, chairman, nor F. Ross Johnson, vice chairman, could be reached for comment yesterday.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   New Quarterly Focuses On Professional Offices
