abstract: Oh, yes, there are already magazines that cover office design. But, say the powers that be at the New York Law Publishing Company (and mighty powers they are), there is no adequate coverage for professional offices.

headline: Bomb Threat on Austrian Jet
abstract: An Austrian Airlines passenger jet on a Rome-to-Vienna flight with 65 people aboard returned to Rome tonight after the airline's office in Vienna received a bomb threat, airline officials reported. Police bomb squads checked the baggage while the 60 passengers and 5 crew members waited in a transit lounge, an airline spokesman said.

headline: Turkish Cypriots Vote For New Constitution
abstract: Turkish Cypriots gave overwhelming approval in a referendum today to a new constitution for their self-proclaimed Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.

headline: KOHL'S DEBT AFTER BITBURG
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has emerged from President Reagan's state visit to West Germany deeply in debt to the American leader, and momentarily estranged from his principal partner in Western Europe, President Francois Mitterrand.   In the relationship between Bonn and Washington, Mr. Kohl went into the conference with a strong hand, having secured the deployment of American Pershing 2 missiles in West Germany despite angry street protests and Soviet pressure.   But, in the view of a broad range of West German officials and foreign diplomats, by going to the cemetery at Bitburg - in the face of emotional opposition at home - Mr. Reagan has skillfully played the winning hand.   ''Some people argue that Kohl is now so deeply indebted to Reagan that his capacity to implement German interests or withstand any American pressure is seriously inhibited,'' said Karl Kaiser, the head of one of West Germany's leading foreign policy research institutes. ''I doubt that. But the priority of energies will now have to turn to minimizing damage to the Franco-German relationship.''

headline: Cox Financing
abstract: Cox Enterprises Inc., the publisher based here, plans to finance its proposed acquisition of Cox Communications Inc., the broadcast company, by borrowing up to $1.8 billion from a banking consortium headed by the Texas Commerce Bank of Houston, according to a document sent to Cox Communications shareholders. The loan would also finance a restructuring of the broadcast company's $241.5 million in existing debt. Cox Enterprises, a privately held company, has offered $75 a share for the 59 percent of Cox Communications stock not now owned by Cox Enterprises or members of the Cox family.

headline: '84 Brokerage Pay Cuts
abstract: Executives at most of the major publicly traded Wall Street brokerage houses took substantial cuts in compensation last year, according to proxy statements filed by Wall Street firms with the Securities and Exchange Commission.    ''The retail business was horrible last year, and that had a very negative impact on overall profitability,'' said Perrin H. Long, an industry analyst at Lipper Analytical Services Inc. ''Since a major portion of a Wall Street executive's salary is incentive- related, if the firms are not profitable they aren't going to make as much money.''    The decline in top-level executive pay was most severe at Paine Webber Inc. Pretax profits at Paine Webber fell by nearly 95 percent, to $9.4 million, primarily because of a severe reduction in its retail income.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $22.6 million, to $210.15 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: Appeal to Marcos on Press
abstract: The Committee to Protect Journalists has appealed to President Ferdinand E. Marcos to help protect journalists in the Philippines. Twelve journalists have been killed there since January 1984, the group said, and no one has been brought to trial. In a letter sent June 7, the New York-based group asked Mr. Marcos to investigate the killings and to stop what it called Government harassment of journalists who write on politically sensitive issues.

headline: Cambodian Civilians Go Farther Into Thailand
abstract: More than 19,000 Cambodian civilians began moving today to a site deeper inside Thailand after intelligence reports circulated that Vietnamese forces were closer to their camp.   Thai and international relief officials started moving the Cambodians in 55 trucks and buses from what has been called Site 6 to Site 2.

headline: Home State Units
abstract: The First National Cincinnati Corporation said it had reached an agreement in principle to buy 10 Ohio offices of Home State Savings Bank from the American Financial Corporation's Hunter Savings Association subsidiary for undisclosed terms. It said five branches are in Cincinnati, one in Middletown and four in the Dayton area. All will become federally insured full-service commercial bank branches.

headline: LEBANON BATTLES GO ON DESPITE TRUCE
abstract: The Christian militia that has been fighting against Moslems around the southern port of Sidon announced a cease-fire today. But artillery exchanges continued hours after the truce was supposed to take effect.     A Moslem radio station here said the Christians had failed to observe their own truce. But a Christian radio station, Voice of Lebanon, said Christian fighters were observing the cease-fire, and accused Moslem militias of continuing to fire on Christian villages east of the Mediterranean port.

headline: $340 Million Offering By Piedmont Municipal
abstract: The Piedmont Municipal Power Agency, taking advantage of recent declines in tax-exempt bond yields, decided this week to offer $340 million of new bonds through underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company. The financing supplants a $110 million bond sale scheduled for June.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Wilderness Publication Begins Accepting Ads
abstract: The quarterly publication of the Washington-based Wilderness Society is emerging from the wilderness of adless media to join the crass majority group.

headline: CANADIANS INVESTIGATING A REPORT AIR-INDIA PILOT CARRIED A PACKAGE
abstract: Investigators were said today to be checking a report that the pilot of the Air-India airliner that crashed last Sunday might had been persuaded by a Sikh acquaintance to carry a package aboard.   The cause of the disaster has not been determined, but investigators are pursuing a theory that it might have been blown up by a bomb.   Because of the size of a Boeing 747, a bomb would have to be placed in or near the cockpit for the plane to explode, investigators have said.   The investigation into the package incident was disclosed by The Globe and Mail of Toronto, which said that officials were looking into a report that a Sikh living in the Toronto suburb of Mississauga might have given the package to the pilot, S. S. Binder, who was also a Sikh, The Air-India plane, en route from Toronto to Bombay, crashed in the sea off Ireland, killing all 329 aboard.

headline: KODAK AND GENERAL FOODS OFF
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company, hard hit by the strength of the dollar abroad, reported that earnings in the first quarter dropped 27 percent, as sales slipped slightly.   Kodak, which is based in Rochester, said that net income in the latest three months fell to $115.2 million, or 50 cents a share, from $157.8 million, or 64 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1984. Per-share results were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split announced April 12, after the quarter ended. Sales dipped to $2.13 billion, from $2.14 billion.

headline: Warner Unit May Get Bid
abstract: The Motown Record Corporation said it was considering buying the recorded music division of Warner Communications Inc.

headline: Choice Called Near On Big Board Post
abstract: Robert J. Birnbaum, president and chief operating officer of the American Stock Exchange since 1977, will be voted in as the next president of the New York Stock Exchange at a directors' meeting on Thursday, a Wall Street executive who has spoken with board members said yesterday.    ''It's a fait accompli; there is no objection among board members,'' the executive said.    Rumors that Mr. Birnbaum, who is 57 years old, might move over to the Big Board have been circulating in trade publications for weeks.

headline: 5 LATIN NATIONS AGREE ON PANEL ON ARMS LIMIT
abstract: Five Central American countries agreed tonight to establish a commission to monitor an accord being negotiated on reducing arms in the region, an international group sponsoring the talks announced.   In a communique after two days of meetings, the group described the agreement on a commission as a ''notable advance in the negotiation'' of a regional treaty by the five countries - Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua. The arms reduction accord would be a major part of that treaty.    The agreement tonight gave new life to the two-year-old effort to find a peaceful solution to the turmoil in Central America. The effort, which had been stalled for six months, is being led by the Contadora group - Mexico, Venezuela, Panama and Colombia.

headline: Ketchum Continues To Grow
abstract: KETCHUM COMMUNICATIONS, which is in the top 25 American ad agencies but aspires to the top 10, is having the best first half-year in its 62-year history.   And that's on top of the best year, a year that saw billings reach $406 million, revenues hit $56 million and net income before taxes come to $4.6 million.   The first excitement of this year came in January. It was the Digital Equipment Corporation, billing more than $20 million, and then in April American Honda announced that Ketchum would be introducing its new Acura model car, with initial billings of between $10 million and $15 million.

headline: FAILED CHINATOWN BANK REOPENS TO SKEPTICISM
abstract: Hundreds of people lined up outside the main Canal Street offices of the failed Golden Pacific National Bank yesterday to withdraw their money, even though the Chinatown bank had just been taken over by one of the largest banks in Asia and all deposits were insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.   Depositors appeared, passbooks in hand, as early as 5 o'clock in the morning. They waited quietly, in contrast to some of the more boisterous demonstrations earlier this week, accepting tea and doughnuts provided by the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, which took over $117 million of Golden Pacific's insured deposits, plus its Canal Street headquarters and three other branches.   The bank was supposed to open at noon, but it was not until 2:58 P.M. that officials began allowing customers to enter - six at a time. Only then did the crowd became unruly, trying to rush past the dozen or so policemen stationed at the door. During the first two and a half hours about $300,000 was withdrawn, according to a Hongkong and Shanghai spokesman.

headline: MORE G.E. CONTRACT CASES DISCLOSED
abstract: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating charges brought by former employees of the General Electric Company that the company submitted false or fraudulent claims for work on Government engine contracts at a plant near Cincinnati, according to court documents and the former G.E. employees.   Moreover, last week the company agreed to pay $1 million to the Government to privately settle allegations of mischarging on a Federal satellite contract, a Justice Department official said on Monday.   The disclosure of these two actions comes as G.E. is preparing to go on trial next Monday in Federal District Court in Philadelphia on criminal charges of submitting false claims on missile contracts. The company, the nation's sixth-largest military contractor, was indicted in March.

headline: Alexander's Names Officers
abstract: Alexander's Inc., the New York department store chain, yesterday named two executive vice presidents, Roger A. Barrer, 59 years, and Louis Powell, 62, to a newly formed office of the president.   The president's post has been vacant since Alexander Farkas resigned last July. Mr. Farkas's brother Robin L. Farkas remains chairman of the company, which was founded by their late father, George.      A group that includes Robert   M. Bass, the Fort Worth investor, and Interstate Properties, a New Jersey real estate developer, now owns about 35 percent of Alexander's.

headline: GENERAL DYNAMICS DRAWS PENALTIES ON NAVY DEALINGS
abstract: Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. announced today that he was suspending the signing of all new contracts at two major divisions of the General Dynamics Corporation because of ''pervasive'' business misconduct.   In addition, the Secretary said he was canceling two missile contracts worth $22.5 million and putting them up for competitive bidding.   But he said he saw no reason why the Navy and General Dynamics could not reach an agreement that would restore normal business relations in a few weeks, assuming the company did not choose to be ''confrontational and litigious.''   Mr. Lehman also said he was fining the company, the nation's third-largest military contractor, $676,283 for giving gratuities to Adm. Hyman Rickover, who directed the Navy's nuclear submarine program until he retired in 1981.

headline: FOR REMEMBERED G.I.'S, THUMBS UP SIGN IN CHINA
abstract: Four decades ago this old city in southwest China was one of the hubs of World War II, familiar to thousands of Americans who helped Chiang Kai-shek's ''Free China'' survive invasion by Japan.   In the teahouses and free markets that enliven the city center, and in other spots where old-timers gather, fond memories linger of the Americans who helped push the ''Burma Road'' through the jungles from Kunming to Mandalay. Equally remembered are the men who flew lumbering transports over ''the hump'' of the Himalayas into the airfield to the west of town.   One old man with gapped teeth paused to offer his assessment while trying on a new pair of spectacles at a stall along Qingnian Street. ''Americans? Terrific, terrific!'' he said, shooting out an upraised thumb.

headline: REPEAL OF LAWS ON INTERRACIAL SEX IS HAILED IN SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: The decision to repeal South African laws forbidding interracial marriage and sex was widely hailed here today as a major departure from the attitudes that produced apartheid.   But while the repeal of the laws, announced in Parliament on Monday, was welcomed by all but the extreme right in this country, apartheid opponents said the move was largely cosmetic and did not address the lack of political rights for the 23 million blacks who constitute a 73 percent majority.   The laws forbidding marriage or sexual relations across racial lines ''encapsulate all that is hurtful in racism and the stigma of their grotesque intrusion into people's private affairs,'' The Argus, a Cape Town daily, said in an editorial today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $85 million of bonds.    * Communications Satellite Corp. has arranged a $185 million revolving Euronote facility, through Credit Suisse First Boston.    * Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp. will offer, on May 29, $1.195 billion of bonds, due Dec. 2, 1985; $657 million, due March 3, 1986, and $761 million, due Jan. 20, 1988.

headline: TAX REFORM: DON'T COUNT ON IT, BUT DON'T IGNORE IT
abstract: OVER the next several months, Congress will be considering a major overhaul of the Federal income tax, a move that could dramatically alter the relative merits of many types of investments. Real estate, for example, stands to lose some of its investment luster if depreciation and other real-estate tax benefits are scaled back. Tax-exempt municipal bonds would become less valuable, if personal income-tax rates were lowered, while corporate bonds, savings accounts and other fully taxable investments would become relatively more attractive. Any decision to curtail the existing preferential tax treatment of long-term capital gains would reduce the after-tax return on collectibles, precious metals and other investments whose principal return is capital appreciation.   A fundamental overhaul of the corporate income tax would have a profound influence on the investment merits of most companies and industries. Proposals to eliminate many of the tax incentives for business that now pervade the tax code and to impose a lower tax rate on corporations, if enacted, would prompt a reordering of the after-tax returns of corporate America. Companies now unable to take much advantage of tax breaks end up paying close to the statutory corporate rate of 46 percent; under the proposed changes, they would experience an increase in after-tax profits. Companies that now pay little or no tax face reduced profits.

headline: Moscow's Condolences Are Rejected by Albania
abstract: Albania today rejected Soviet condolences on the death of the Albanian leader, Enver Hoxha, and refused to let any foreigners attend his funeral.   A spokesman for the Albanian Embassy in Vienna said about a Soviet telegram of condolences: ''The message was sent back as unacceptable.

headline: BankAmerica Appoints Mortgage Group Chief
abstract: The BankAmerica Corporation said that Charles E. Reed, a former president of the Sears Mortgage Securities Corporation, had been named director of its residential mortgage banking unit.    The unit, which has a real estate portfolio of more than $10 billion, was not part of the scandal that surfaced last year involving mortgage-backed securities. That scandal caused the bank to create a $95 million reserve.

headline: BUSINESS
abstract: Indiana Standard Hires A Minerals Specialist      As chief executive of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation in the 1970's, John C. Duncan built a lead and zinc producer with annual sales of $194 million into a diversified natural resources company with revenues of more than $1 billion.   In an apparent effort to take advantage of that expertise, the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said yesterday that it had hired Mr. Duncan, 64, as a consultant and expects to name him chairman of its minerals subsidiary when it is spun off as a separate company this summer.   Indiana Standard announced in January that it would spin off its Amoco Minerals Company, which last year lost $35 million on revenues of $644 million, in a tax-free distribution to shareholders. Details of the transaction have not been determined, pending approval from the Internal Revenue Service, but the company expects it to be completed by midyear.

headline: Hospital Corp.
abstract: The Hospital Corporation of America said it had tentatively agreed to acquire United Medical Plan Inc.'s 4.1 million outstanding shares for about $24 million. United, with headquarters in Richmond, is the state's largest health maintenance organization, composed of 13,000 enrollees and 1,200 participating physicians. In addition to its Richmond operation, United also operates in Norfolk and Newport News, Va., and has 4,000 members in Houston.

headline: MAZE OF OVERHEAD WIRES EXPECTED AT S.I. PROJECTS
abstract: As the home builders on Staten Island remember it, Lady Bird Johnson's campaign to ''beautify America'' had a direct positive effect on the appearance of new subdivisions.   The stress on beautification helped induce utility companies to put their connections to houses in new subdivisions underground. And, indeed, at many new developments the sky is free of overhead wire.   But although new phone lines still go underground, the builders say that the picture is changing on electrical connections, to their dismay. They say that for the last year Consolidated Edison has been using overhead poles to the extent allowed by law and running overhead connections to individual housing units.

headline: Carteret Savings Picks Muir Cornelius Moore
abstract: Muir Cornelius Moore, long a specialist in financial advertising, has been named agency by the Carteret Savings and Loan Association of Morristown, N.J. The budget could come to $4 million, according to M.C.M.   The bank has 50 branches in New Jersey and 30 in Florida, and its new agency will handle the job through its New York and Boca Raton, Fla., offices. Doyle Dane Bernbach was the former agency.

headline: Ivan Boesky Buys 8.7% CBS Stake
abstract: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he and companies he controls have purchased 8.7 percent of CBS Inc. stock for $247.1 million.

headline: Alfonsin Appears Willing to Make Cuts
abstract: As some Argentine officials signed a new agreement with the International Monetary Fund in Washington today, others here announced an 18 percent devaluation of the peso, the largest since June 1981.   The action was in sharp contrast to the Government's attitude and actions when it signed an agreement last year and tried to give the illusion that the country's $48 billion in foreign debt could be paid without sacrifices or pain.   Unlike his speeches of a year ago, President Raul Alfonsin is now talking austerity, and he recently warned Argentines that ''suffering is and will be our daily companion.'' He has followed this by keeping cost-of-living adjustments to public employees at only 90 percent of the previous month's inflation rate, and by pledging a 12 percent budget cut.

headline: CONTINENTAL HAS PROFIT
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation reported yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 30.6 percent, to $133.9 million, from $102.5 million in the comparable period of 1984. The per-share figure was up 14.5 percent, to $2.92, from $2.55.          Much of the $31.4 million improvement was a result of these nonrecurring factors: the sale of a minority stake in the Diamond Lease Company of Japan, which bolstered after-tax net income by $15 million, and the acquisitions last summer of the Lincoln First Bank of Rochester and the Nederlandse Credietbank of the Netherlands, which together contributed $12 million to net income.

headline: VATICAN DOCUMENT DISPLEASES JEWISH GROUPS
abstract: The Vatican issued a document today on relations between Christians and Jews that immediately drew sharp criticism from several leading Jewish organizations.   The Vatican statement, issued by the Commission for Religious Relations with the Jews, emphasized the ''Jewish roots of Christianity,'' condemned anti-Semitism and called for ''objectivity, justice, tolerance.''   ''There is evident in particular a painful ignorance of the history and traditions of Judaism,'' the statement said, ''of which only negative aspects and often caricature seem to form part of the stock ideas of many Christians.''   But the International Jewish Committee on Interreligious Consultations, which includes leading Jewish organizations, said the document reflected a ''regressive spirit'' and ''little recognition of how Jews conceive of themselves.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: TUESDAY, JUNE 25, 1985        The Economy    The tax plan's provisions for middle-income families are under review and the proposed changes in the treatment of child-care expenses will probably be rewritten, a top tax official said. Changing the status of that item from a tax credit to a deduction would be more unfavorable to families of modest means than the Administration first realized, said Richard A. Pearlman of the Treasury Department. Changes are also possible in the proposed tax treatment of families in which both spouses earn wages, he said. [Page A1.]  Several leading governors expressed support for eliminating the Federal tax deduction for state and local taxes. [D8.]

headline: Federal Express Gives Its Overseas Work
abstract: Federal Express, the nation's leading air express company, which has just begun international service, has assigned its overseas advertising program in Europe and the Far East to McCann-Erickson.   McCann, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has 113 overseas offices in 64 countries.   Federal stressed that the assignment would in no way affect its relationship with Ally & Gargano, which has long been producing award-winning advertising for the domestic market.

headline: Thai-Vietnamese Clash
abstract: Thai forces today battled 400 Vietnamese troops who crossed into Thailand in pursuit of Cambodian guerrillas opposing Hanoi's occupation of their country, military sources said.

headline: U.S. SAYS 7 MISSING MUST ALSO GO FREE WITH AIR HOSTAGES
abstract: The United States demanded today that seven Americans missing in Beirut be freed as part of any arrangement for the release of the 39 airliner hostages.   The announcement came as the crisis entered its third week amid signs that snags had developed in discussions with the Lebanese Shiite leader, Nabih Berri, and various governments and international organizations on how to resolve the standoff.   Mr. Berri has said he is mediating on behalf on the Shiite hijackers who commandeered a Trans World Airlines jet June 14. The hijackers' principal demand has been that Israel free more than 700 mainly Shiite detainees who have been held without charges for up to 19 months.      News Blackout Maintainted   For a second day, the Reagan Administration maintained a news blackout on diplomatic efforts, which centered on Israel, France, Syria and Mr. Berri.

headline: Article 142529 -- No Title
abstract: A battle for control of the Hilton Hotels Corporation broke out yesterday with the announcement by Golden Nugget Inc., the big casino operator, that it had offered to buy 25 percent of Hilton from the estate of Conrad N. Hilton, founder of the giant hotel chain, for $72 a share, or $488 million in cash.     Stephen A. Wynn, chairman of Golden Nugget, said that if he were successful in buying the estate stock - which is tied up in a probate dispute between Conrad Hilton's executor and Mr. Hilton's son, Barron - he would ''consider'' buying the rest, paying what he called ''similar values.'' On that basis, the Hilton chain, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., would bring close to $2 billion.   But there are indications that the the price could go substantially higher, considering the tug-of-war going on for the Hilton stake. And on the New York Stock Exchange, Hilton's stock jumped $8.50, to $72.50, in heavy dealings, a strong sign that Wall Street traders felt the $72 price was only an opening bid.

headline: HEAVY COST-CUTTER WITH A LIGHT TOUCH
abstract: LAST summer, when Lee L. Morgan, the recently retired chairman of the Caterpillar Tractor Company, asked George A. Schaefer if he would accept the post of chairman, Mr. Schaefer requested two weeks to think it over.   For days, Mr. Schaefer, then an executive vice president, fretted about how difficult, even painful, it would be to serve as chairman of a company under siege. Caterpillar suffered $954 million in losses over the past three years and laid off almost 30,000 workers as part of a brutal cost-cutting campaign. Mr. Schaefer also worried that the demanding job would upset the tenuous balance he has created between his career and his family and community life.   Ultimately, his loyalty to Caterpillar and his reluctance to shy away from a challenge pushed him to accept the offer. But three months into the chairmanship, the 56-year-old former accountant has not laid all his doubts to rest.

headline: DAVIS QUITS MURDOCH'S TV DEAL
abstract: Marvin Davis, the wealthy Denver oilman, said yesterday that he was pulling out of the highly publicized deal in which he and Rupert Murdoch were to acquire six television stations from Metromedia Inc.   Mr. Davis's withdrawal leaves Mr. Murdoch's News America Publishing Inc. as the lone purchaser in the transaction, which was announced last month and has a total value of about $2 billion. A spokesman for Mr. Murdoch, Howard Rubenstein, said that the development would not stop the Australian-born publisher from going ahead with the purchase.   Mr. Murdoch expects to file an application for a change in ownership of the stations' broadcast licenses with the Federal Communications Commission on Monday, Mr. Rubenstein said. As part of that filing, Mr. Murdoch will ask for a temporary waiver, of up to two years, of Federal regulations that would require him to sell The New York Post and The Chicago Sun-Times, the spokesman added.

headline: SENATE VOTE NEAR ON GENOCIDE PACT
abstract: After almost 36 years of delay and intermittent debate, the Senate is nearing a vote in which it is expected to consent to United States ratification of the United Nations treaty condemning genocide.     The treaty, which has its roots in Nazi Germany's mass killing of Jews, has been accepted by 96 nations, including the Eastern European bloc led by the Soviet Union.    The Senate came close to approval of the treaty last October but did not act after a few conservative opponents threatened a filibuster. Instead the Senate voted 87 to 2 for a nonbinding resolution that supported the principles of the convention and said the Senate should act ''expeditiously'' on the treaty this session.

headline: Article 013668 -- No Title
abstract: The Boeing Company agreed yesterday to sell about $1 billion worth of planes to a leasing company. Boeing was also chosen by Australia's state owned Trans-Australia Airlines for about $500 million worth of aircraft orders.   The International Lease Finance Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif., said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to buy 21 Boeing aircraft for delivery in 1986, 1987 and 1988.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, MAY 17, 1985        The Economy    The House Budget Committee approved a 1986 budget plan which, if adopted by the House, would set up a major confrontation with the Senate and Administration over the military budget and cost of living increases for Social Security. Democratic leaders said they expect the full House to approve the plan, possibly with the addition of revenue from a corporate minimum tax. [Page A1.]    President Reagan's tax revision plan drew mixed reviews from legislators, tax reformers and interest groups in Washington. Supporters, viewing the elements disclosed so far, said the President was striving for vast changes in tax policy. But others said he missed a rare opportunity to make the system more equitable. [A1.]  Business representatives applauded the plan, but some expressed concern that investment incentives would shrink. [D5.]

headline: IN PERU, PREPARING BALLOT BOXES, AWAITING BOMBS
abstract: The election posters and flags decorating the walls of this colonial mountain city are matched in variety only by the khaki and camouflage uniforms and automatic weapons to be seen on soldiers patrolling its narrow streets.    Yet, beyond the first jarring impression of democracy under seige, the relaxed mood in Ayacucho just three days before Peru's general elections contrasts sharply with the city's reputation as the focal point of a vicious war between security forces and guerrillas that has so far taken at least 5,000 lives.   In the arcade surrounding its main plaza, Indians and other locals peer at instructions indicating where they should vote, while others line up outside the Electoral Office to renew their voting cards. In the square itself, two parties have set up tables to show sympathizers how to mark their ballots.

headline: Inmates Briefly Seize Island Prison in Peru
abstract: Some 400 accused guerrillas imprisoned on an island off Peru's coast held the warden and seven Government officials hostage for 30 hours, demanding better jail conditions. The hostages were released today after authorities agreed to most of the inmates' demands.

headline: INDUSTRY HAILS TAX PROPOSAL
abstract: Business representatives applauded President Reagan's tax plan yesterday, a day after it became known that the President favored lower capital gains tax rates, among other changes.   However, many people in business expressed concern that other elements of the plan would dampen incentives for new investment. And spokesmen for the housing industry objected strongly to limits that would be placed on deductions for interest paid on purchases of second homes. Another affected group, restaurateurs, firmly opposed reducing the deductability of meals and business entertainment.

headline: Jewelcor Buyback
abstract: -BARRE, Pa., April 3 (Reuters) - Jewelcor Inc. said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 700,00 shares of the company's common stock. The price will be determined based on prices offered by tendering shareholders but will not exceed $9 to $9.75 a share. Jewelcor was the largest percentage gainer today on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $9, up $1.125, a gain of 14.2 percent.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Economist Newspaper Unit Head
abstract: After a year-long search, The Economist Newspaper Ltd., publisher of the influential weekly magazine, The Economist, announced that Marjorie M. Scardino, a publisher and a lawyer, had been named president of its fast-growing American  subsidiary, The Economist Newspaper Group Inc. The appointment is effective June 3.         Mrs. Scardino, who is 38, fills a post that has been vacant since April 1984, when Clive L. Greaves, 44, resigned to become the company's worldwide publishing director for magazines in London.

headline: SOVIET SAYS REAGAN IS GRADUALLY ENDING PACT
abstract: The Soviet Union said today that President Reagan's statement pledging continued adherence to the 1979 arms treaty confirmed his intention to destroy the entire system of arms-control accords.   A statement issued by the Foreign Ministry also denied that the Soviet Union had been violating the 1979 treaty, which set limits on long-range nuclear missiles and bombers.   The Russians specifically rejected the allegation that they were developing two new land-based intercontinental missiles, the SS-24 and the SSs-25, instead of the one permitted by the pact. The Soviet statement reiterated that the SS-25 was a modernized version of an earlier weapon, the SS-13.

headline: Court Refuses to Free A Death Row Japanese
abstract: A lower court here today denied a request to release a 93-year-old man who has spent 30 years on death row.

headline: EASING BY FED IS SEEN
abstract: Fresh evidence of a weak economy and low inflation sent interest rates plummeting yesterday and led many economists and traders to predict that the Federal Reserve would soon ease monetary policy and encourage lower interest rates.   According to many analysts, the decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in industrial production during May provided the Fed with a motive for easing monetary policy, while the slight rise in producer prices of two-tenths of 1 percent was a comforting reminder that the central bank could stimulate the economy without reviving inflation.   The decline in industrial production was especially important, analysts said, because Fed officials have cited the problems in the manufacturing sector as a reason for easing monetary policy.      'Enough Signs of Weakness'    ''The Fed's focus is clearly on the economy and there are enough signs of weakness to warrant a move to lower rates,'' said Kathleen Cooper, senior vice president and economist at the Security Pacific National Bank.

headline: Alexander Unit
abstract: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the insurance broker, said that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell the Lloyd's of London insurance management operations of its Alexander Howden Underwriting Ltd. to executives of the subsidiary. The subsidiary is part of its Alexander Howden Group, which it bought in 1982. Alexander & Alexander earned $10.7 million in the first quarter of 1985 after losing $49.6 million last year, when it wrote off $77.1 million for discontinued casualty operations.

headline: CELLULAR PHONES: THE BIG PAYOFFS ARE STILL ON HOLD
abstract: A few years ago, when Tom Guzek drove from his home office in Boston to his company's regional office in New York, there was little else to do but glance at the scenery. Now his car is equipped with a cellular telephone, and, said Mr. Guzek, a regional manager for an electrical supply firm, ''I'm on the phone constantly. What used to be dead time away from the office, is now productive time.''   Mr. Guzek, of Cooper Industries, is one of about 146,000 cellular phone subscribers nationwide who have signed up since 1983, when the Federal Communications Commission gave the green light to commercial cellular phone service, which held out the promise of millions of subscribers.   But the numbers have not grown as quickly as predicted. That is principally because many consumers are having second thoughts about the high rates for cellular calls, not to mention the initial cost of the equipment. And there are other problems: the providers of cellular communications - the old Bell system companies and entrepreneurs flooding the field - find they have huge start-up costs; the Japanese command a big share of equipment sales, and there are some glitches in the technology (See Box).

headline: Dunlop to Sell U.S. Tire Unit
abstract: Dunlop Holdings P.L.C. said that it had agreed to sell its United States tire operations to a group including management for $118 million, plus the repayment of $60 million in loans.

headline: F.A.O. Schwarz May Be Sold
abstract: The Swiss parent of the F.A.O. Schwarz toy stores, which has sold 10 smaller Schwarz outlets, may sell the entire chain, according to Franz Carl Weber, chairman of the Zurich-based company that bears his name.   He also said in an interview that because he had suffered a heart attack last summer, he would even consider selling Franz Carl Weber International, the parent company. 23 European Stores Closed Over the last two years, he said, 23 Franz Carl Weber toy stores in France and Austria have been sold because of what he called ''restrictive taxation and import restrictions,'' while the small American stores were closed because they weren't productive enough. Now, however, he said, the remaining 90 stores worldwide and the 22 large stores in the United States are being consolidated and ''in the U.S. we are well stabilized.''

headline: CONDOMINIUMS RISE IN FLATLANDS AREA
abstract: Four years ago Sidney Steinberg and Anthony Clemenza were renovating vacant loft buildings as apartments on lower Broadway in Manhattan. They did 32 units in Nos. 710, 722 and 620 Broadway, selling finished, full-floor apartments.   ''But that business is dead,'' Mr. Steinberg said. ''You can't get vacant buildings and the city wants you to pay $5 to $10 a square foot to convert buildings that still have commercial tenants.'' The payment is intended to support a fund that helps manufacturing businesses relocate when residential development displaces them.

headline: F.A.O. SCHWARZ SOLD TO CALIFORNIA DEVELOPER
abstract: F.A.O. Schwarz, the 22-store retailer whose lavish toys and games have delighted children and their indulgent parents for more than a century, is being acquired by the Christiana Companies, a California real estate developer and investment company. Christiana will be Schwarz's third owner in 11 years.   The announcement yesterday by Christiana and Franz Carl Weber International, parent of F.A.O. Schwarz, said that their boards had approved the all-cash purchase. The amount was not disclosed. Christiana said it would continue and even expand the toy retailer. John S. Roberts, Christiana's chairman, also said that ''some consideration may be given to closing some of the stores but we have no immediate plans for it.''

headline: Informatics
abstract: The Informatics General Corporation, a computer software company, said it was exploring its possible sale to a larger corporation or to an investment group that includes members of management. The company recently rejected as inadequate a $26-a-share offer from Sterling Software of Dallas.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Ligne Roset, a French furniture manufacturer, to AC&R Advertising and AC&R Public Relations.    * Shopko Stores Inc., Green Bay, Wis., a chain of discount department stores, to D'Arcy MacManus Masius/Chicago.

headline: THE VISITOR FROM SEOUL
abstract: Rarely does a day pass without photographs of President Chun Doo Hwan appearing on the front pages of South Korea's Government-regulated newspapers. Nightly news programs begin invariably with long recapitulations of his day.   Yet for all his familiarity, almost inescapability Mr. Chun, who is to meet with President Reagan in Washington on Friday, remains a distant figure to most South Koreans, five years after he seized control of an unstable Government as head of a military coup.   Personal glimpses of him are few; even the wedding of his daughter four months ago was not reported. When Koreans are asked for an opinion of their President, the reply, regardless of economic level or political background, tends to be, ''He is not popular.''

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Amax Inc., Greenwich, Conn., said it would close two molybdenum mines in the Colorado Rocky Mountains for nine weeks beginning in July, affecting about 1,200 workers.    * Boeing Co., Seattle, won a $72.8 million Air Force contract for B-1B offensive avionics systems, the Defense Department said.

headline: Shells on Way to Britain Use Polish Explosives
abstract: Britain is to import artillery shells from a Belgian company that uses Polish explosives, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today.   She was answering questions in Parliament by the opposition Liberal Party suggesting that the TRB Company, a state-run Belgian concern, would be using Polish explosives to fulfill a British order for 11,000 medium artillery shells.

headline: General Mills' Fashion Spinoff
abstract: General Mills Inc., which disclosed in January that it might sell its fashion business, said yesterday that it had decided to spin off that division as a separate company that would include Monet jewelry and the Izod, Lacoste and Ship n' Shore apparel operations.   General Mills also said that it had sold its Foot Joy subsidiary to American Brands Inc. for $53 million.

headline: CHINESE FIND IT HARD TO SAY NICE THINGS ABOUT THEIR FORMER ALLY HANOI
abstract: For a quarter of a century until 1975, this city in southwest China was a major transshipment point for the weapons and materiel that enabled Vietnamese Communist troops to drive French and American forces from Vietnam.   As Hanoi marks the 10th anniversary of the capture of Saigon, Chinese generals here continue to look southward. But instead of joining their Vietnamese counterparts at parades commemorating the victory, the officers pass their days poring over maps of the mountains that divide the two countries, planning new moves against an ally that became a bitter foe.   Kunming was the terminus for the American airlift over the Himalayas that helped prevent the Japanese from overrunning all of China during World War II, and it is still a hub of military activity. From the headquarters of the Kunming Military Region, army officers direct the activities of tens of thousands of Chinese troops who are fighting an undeclared border war with Vietnam.

headline: Fanny Farmer Chain Goes to Marschalk
abstract: The Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, that great American sweets tradition that is owned by Poulain, a French food company, has decided to give its advertising to Marschalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: NEW AID PLAN ON NICARAGUA SEEN
abstract: House Democrats, uneasy over the visit to Moscow by the Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, said today that interest was increasing in a compromise with the White House on aid to Nicaraguan rebels.   ''I would say there's some movement within the vacuum,'' said Representative Bill Alexander of Arkansas, the chief Democratic whip.

headline: Ohio Bank Bid Reported
abstract: A group of 28 Ohio bankers met with state officials yesterday in response to a one-day deadline to counter a reported bid by New York's Chemical Bank to acquire the failed Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati.    Last night, bankers said that an Ohio bank had made a competitive bid for Home State, but those reports could not be confirmed.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: East German Guard Defects
abstract: A 20-year-old East German border guard defected across the frontier near Fulda today, the West German border police said. He was in uniform but not armed.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Wall St. Bond Expert To Run St. Louis Fed
abstract: Thomas C. Melzer, a former managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company, was named yesterday as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis.    Mr. Melzer, now 40, joined Morgan Stanley in New York in 1968 and served as a managing director from 1977 through the end of last year, when he resigned to pursue other interests. For the last five of those years, he was head of Morgan Stanley's Government securities department. Before that, he did various work at the firm, including corporate finance, real estate finance and securities sales and trading.

headline: City Bonds Are Priced; Yields at 5 1/2% to 9 3/4%
abstract: To finance the hiring of additional police officers and increase other services, New York City is selling $586 million of long-term bonds this week. Proceeds of the sale will be used to repay before maturity all but $1 million of the federally guaranteed city bonds sold to public employee pension funds during the financial crisis of the mid-1970's.   Underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets priced the bonds yesterday with yields ranging from 5 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7 3/4 percent in 1990, 8 7/8 percent in 1995, 9 1/2 percent in 2000 and 9 3/4 percent in 2004 through 2009. The financing also includes 9 1/2 percent bonds due in 2015 priced at 97.552 to yield 9 3/4 percent.

headline: MARYLAND IS OPENED TO CITICORP
abstract: Citicorp today won a monthlong lobbying battle that pitted it and Gov. Harry Hughes against Maryland's bankers. In an overwhelming vote, the state's Legislature passed landmark legislation that will give the nation's largest banking concern full banking powers in Maryland and direct access to the lucrative Baltimore-Washington market.   The Maryland House of Representatives voted, 108 to 16, to accept a Senate-amended bill that would allow Citicorp to establish 20 full-service branches within the next two years. In return, Citicorp has promised to invest $25 million in the state and create at least 1,000 new jobs, primarily in Hagerstown, an economically depressed area of Maryland.

headline: A.T.&T. Selects Olson as President
abstract: James E. Olson, who began his career in telecommunications by cleaning manholes and splicing cables, has been named president and chief operating officer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, effective June 1.   The move puts responsibility for A.T.&T.'s long-distance telephone operations under Mr. Olson, 59 years old, who has led the rest of the company's businesses - including computers, electronics and research - since last year. The president's post has been vacant since William M. Ellinghaus retired after the breakup of the Bell System last year.

headline: Shamrock Sells Stake
abstract: The Shamrock Broadcasting Company, which is controlled by the Disney family, said it had sold its entire 9.9 percent stake of the Orion Capital Corporation on the open market for $13.9 million.

headline: Court Backs States on Health Plans
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that states may require group health insurance plans for private employees to cover specific types of medical care.   By a vote of 8 to 0, the Court upheld a Massachusetts law that requires specific mental health benefits to be included in all group insurance plans offered in the state. The ruling backed a decision by the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, which had rejected arguments by two insurance companies that the state rules conflicted with Federal law.

headline: GENERALS OUT, BRAZIL IS NOW HEARING VOICES OF PAIN
abstract: On the morning of April 15, Jose Brandao Monteiro says he recognized his torturer. The man had lost some hair and grown a mustache, but the face, Mr. Brandao said, was unmistakable.   ''He was a great connoisseur of the electric shock,'' Mr. Brandao said. ''He liked his work so much, he even stayed on weekends. I'll never forget the man.''   Most surprising to Mr. Brandao, now the Transport Secretary in Rio de Janeiro state, was that the man was working for the same state government. The man was identified as Col. Valter Jacaranda, deputy chief of the Fire Department. Colonel Jacaranda has since been dismissed from his job after an official investigation. He is shielded from prosecution by a 1979 general amnesty.

headline: Beirut Fighting Rages After a Brief Lull
abstract: Christian and Moslem militiamen continued their battle for control of Beirut today despite selection of a new Christian militia leader in an effort to halt sectarian warfare.   It was the 13th day of intense street fighting in the capital.

headline: EUROPEAN LEADERS SPLIT ON CHANGES
abstract: A meeting of Western European leaders broke up in disagreement here today after the leaders failed to resolve differences over how to of strengthen the 10-nation European Economic Community.   The government leaders agreed that far-reaching changes were needed in the way the Common Market operates in order to unify the trading bloc. But after two days of difficult negotiations, the community leaders split over the best approach to change.   The final break came over plans by France and West Germany for a conference to rewrite the Common Market's charter, the 28-year-old Treaty of Rome, along more federalist lines and draw up a new Treaty of European Union. The changes are intended to speed decision making and commit Europe to greater political unification.

headline: 3 Syrians Convicted of Spying For the Israelis Are Hanged
abstract: Three Syrians convicted of spying for Israel were hanged at dawn today.

headline: Actor to Represent U.S.
abstract: President Reagan said today that he was sending the actor Fess Parker and his wife as United States representatives to the Australian commemoration of the 43d anniversary of the Battle of the Coral Sea. The naval battle, a turning point of World War II, is being commemorated in Australia by celebration of Australian-American Friendship Week May 3-10.

headline: U.S. VOICES HOPES ON 1979 ARMS PACT
abstract: The State Department said today that it did not accept as ''definitive or final'' the negative Soviet response to President Reagan's decision to abide by the terms of the 1979 strategic arms agreement at least until the end of the year.   Mr. Reagan said Monday in a message to Congress that he had decided to dismantle a Poseidon submarine to stay within the treaty limits, despite purported Soviet violations. He said future steps would be dictated by Soviet compliance with the accord.

headline: 12% Drop in April Sales Of One-Family Homes
abstract: Sales of single-family homes plummeted 12 percent in April but housing industry leaders said today that they were not concerned because lower mortgage interest rates have already started to spur additional buying.   The report from the Commerce Department and the Department of Housing and Urban Development put April sales at 612,000 units on a seasonally adjusted annual rate, compared with 695,000 in March.

headline: General Foods Denies Rumors
abstract: Officials of the General Foods Corporation denied again yesterday that the company had been involved in merger talks with Philip Morris Inc. or any other companies. The food and packaged goods company also said it had not been approached by anyone and that it had no statement to make.

headline: Uganda Rebels Say Front Is Expanded
abstract: Uganda rebels fighting the Government of President Milton Obote said today that they had opened a front in western Uganda, the first expansion of their four-year campaign in the Luwero region north of Kampala.   A statement issued here by the rebels of the National Resistance Army said ''a large column of troops'' marched 200 miles from Luwero to the Rwenzori mountains.   It was the first confirmation by the rebels of reports that some of their guerrillas had moved west from strongholds outside Kampala where they have waged a hit-and-run war against the army since early 1981.

headline: Shell Oil Plan Backed
abstract: A Delaware Chancery Court yesterday approved a proposal by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group to pay $2 a share more for the Shell Oil Company in exchange for dismissal of a suit by shareholders who complained that the 1984 offer, which expired last year, was inadequate. The suit had charged that Royal Dutch's offer of $58 a share, or $5.5 billion, for Shell Oil was unfairly low.

headline: U.S. in Shift On Chile Loan
abstract: The Reagan Administration, in a policy shift that immediately touched off Congressional criticism, voted today in favor of a loan to Chile by the World Bank.   The vote came two days after the military Government in Santiago announced it was lifting a state of siege enforced since Nov. 6.

headline: Advertising;   Royal Crown's Cola Drive
abstract: IN the cola business once you leave the top two, Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola, you are nowhere. And the really big brand there is Royal Crown, which intends to be somewhere and plans to get there with advertising.   While the big two flailed at one another with advertising the flagship brand of the Royal Crown Cola Company stood aloof from the conflict . . . and lost market share. The innocent bystander hurt again.

headline: 5 Troops in Sri Lanka Killed by a Land Mine
abstract: Five anti-terrorist commandos were killed and at least two were seriously wounded late Monday when a land mine exploded under their vehicle near the eastern port of Batticaloa, according to officials here.   The officials, attached to the National Security Ministry, said a gun battle between guerrillas and surviving commandos followed the ambush.

headline: Pickens Asserts Banks Unfairly Cut Him Off
abstract: T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the acquisition-minded Mesa Petroleum Company, charged today that the nation's corporate ''establishment'' has been putting pressure on the largest New York and Chicago banks to deny him financing for takeover bids.   ''We can't get a money center bank,'' Mr. Pickens complained at a hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee, which is considering a bill that would put a moratorium on hostile takeovers. He said of his situation, ''It's absolutely unfair competition'' in which the biggest American companies tell their banks ''we don't like you to do business with Boone Pickens.''

headline: TRIPS TO ATHENS ARE BEING CANCELED
abstract: Tourists, athletes, a cruise line and Pan American World Airways canceled or altered planned trips to Greece yesterday after President Reagan's warning about security problems at the Athens airport and general unrest in the Middle East.   ''We've had people canceling their travel plans all weekend,'' said Joseph H. Stallbaum of Bartlett's Travel Service in Philadelphia, ''and the President's message has precipitated more cancellations this morning. There's no question about it.''   A National Basketball Association all-star team, scheduled to leave for Greece next week for two exhibition games, called off its trip yesterday. Citing the President's warning, Larry Fleisher, the N.B.A.'s general counsel, told the group's Greek host, ''It would clearly be improper for representatives of the National Basketball Association to go against the wishes of our Government.''

headline: $100 Million of Notes Are Offered by Textron
abstract: Textron Inc. yesterday took advantage of favorable market conditions and offered $100 million of 11 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.70, to yield 11.05 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.   Proceeds from the sale of the bonds will be used as part of the company's ongoing refunding and restructuring program to reduce debt incurred in the acquisition of the Avco Corporation.   The bonds are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: SOUTH KOREAN FOE OF CHUN WARNS OF AN 'UPRISING'
abstract: A South Korean opposition leader said last week that President Chun Doo Hwan could face a ''serious uprising'' and possibly the disruption of the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul in 1988 unless he is willing to accept changes to the Constitution.   The Korean, Kim Sang Hyun, a former legislator who said he represented the views of other opposition leaders, including Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam, has met with State Department officials and members of Congress during a two-week visit to the United States.   In an interview Friday, he said through an interpreter that Mr. Chun must accept a constitutional amendment allowing direct elections for President. Mr. Chun, who came to power in a military coup in 1980, was confirmed in office a year later by an electoral college controlled by the ruling Democratic Justice Party. Mr. Chun has said that he will step down when his seven-year term expires.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Liberia Executes Officer In Assassination Plot
abstract: A colonel in the bodyguard of the Liberian leader, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, was executed by a firing squad today after he was accused of trying to assassinate the general.    Earlier in the day the general had ordered the release of four opposition politicians implicated by the officer, Lieut. Col. Moses M. D. Flanzamaton, deputy chief of the guard.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Coastal Petroleum Co., Tallahassee, Fla., has elected Phillip W. Ware president.    * Johnson & Johnson, the health care products company based in New Brunswick, N.J., has elected to its board Roger B. Smith, chairman of General Motors Corp.    * Seafirst Corp., Seattle, a bank holding company, has appointed two new senior vice presidents, Michael L. Mauer and Clifford K. Scarbo.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * BASF America Corp. has signed contracts, valued at close to $20 million, to build a floppy-disk plant and a plant to make TDI, a polyurethane foam component, in China.    * Financial Corp. of America, the California thrift institution, said its board had decided not to declare a cash dividend on its common stock for the second consecutive quarter.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Another Lift for Incomes Personal income continues to climb, says Robert J. Genetski, senior vice president and chief economist of Chicago's Harris Trust and Savings Bank. But whether the new money means a stronger economy remains a matter of doubt. The added income could flow into savings, rather than into consumer spending, he said.      Mr. Genetski expects   Washington's report on personal income, due out Wednesday, to show a jump of eight-tenths of 1 percent in May, compared with somewhat smaller gains in March and April. ''It's not a difficult forecast to make,'' he said, ''because we already know that 345,000 people found work in May, bringing the total of new jobs since March to well over 800,000.

headline: A CONSENSUS ON REBEL AID
abstract: After months of debate on Capitol Hill, and countless meetings between members of Congress and White House officials, the outline of a consensus on United States policy toward Nicaragua has now emerged.   The core of that consensus is a twofold belief: that the structure of the Nicaraguan Government should be changed, and that only military pressure by insurgent forces will force such a change. But the consensus rejects the idea that the Sandinistas should be overthrown by force.   The ultimate goal is a negotiated settlement between the Sandinistas and their foes, known as contras. The settlement that is envisioned would lead to elections and a new balance of power that would give greater weight to the sort of centrist democrats who now rule in neighboring El Salvador.

headline: 2-Year Job Between Degrees
abstract: TWO-YEAR job stints have become an attractive revolving door for new college graduates. More and more companies in the financial services industry such as Merrill Lynch & Company and the First Boston Corporation, along with management consulting firms such as McKinsey & Company and Booz, Allen & Hamilton, seek top-grade students to take these positions, which often carry the title of research associate or associate consultant.   What the jobs most resemble is an internship, a career concept that has been around at least 50 years.   Everybody knows about hospital interns - those hard-working young doctors who examine patients upon entry to a hospital. In recent years many college students have been taking summer internships in government agencies, law firms, corporations, museums and elsewhere, with the idea of getting a head start on a career or at least some knowledge of the business world.

headline: Profit Data, G. N. P. Send Stocks Down
abstract: A batch of disappointing corporate profit reports, together with lower- than-expected growth in the gross national product, caused stock prices to drop yesterday as Wall Street suffered its first losing session in almost two weeks.    Texas Instruments was hurt most by the earnings reports, losing about 11 percent of its market value as it fell 12 3/4 points, to 97 3/8. News of its sharply lower first-quarter earnings and planned layoff of 1,000 workers reverberated through other semiconductor stocks.    The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.18 points, to close at 1,265.13, snapping a seven-day streak that saw the blue-chip indicator inch its way higher in erratic fashion.

headline: Auditors Criticized In House
abstract: In a debate that could lead to an expansion of the responsibilities of outside auditors, members of a Congressional subcommittee and representatives of the accounting profession clashed today over the extent to which auditors needed to make independent assessments of concerns with which their clients have substantial financial dealings.    The debate erupted at a hearing into the effectiveness of auditors, part of a continuing inquiry by the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations into the practices of the accounting profession.    Members of the panel questioned whether auditors should continue to rely on the word of other independent auditors in assessing the risk of large investment transactions their clients have with other concerns.

headline: Union Texas Sale
abstract: The Allied Corporation said it had agreed definitively to sell 50 percent of its oil and gas unit, Union Texas Petroleum, to an investor group led by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. The group includes members of Union Texas management. As previously announced, Allied will receive $1.4 billion in cash and $300 million worth of Union Texas preferred stock in the transaction.

headline: 29 Firms On London Dealer List
abstract: The Bank of England said today that 29 firms had confirmed their intention to become primary dealers in British Government securities when Britain adopts its new trading system late next year. Eleven of them are linked with American banks or securities dealers.   The firms will fight for a stake in a market roughly one-tenth the size of the United States Government bond market in New York, which has 37 licensed dealers.

headline: New Cruise Ship
abstract: Norwegian Caribbean Lines said it plans to build a 2,500-passenger cruise ship that will be the largest luxury liner in the world. Then it will continue looking at plans to build one twice that size. The company's president, Ronald J. Zeller, estimated the first ship would cost between $150 million and $200 million and would have the capability for world-ranging cruises.

headline: STARTS IN HOUSING SURGE BY 16.2%
abstract: Housing construction soared by 16.2 percent in March, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.895 million units, the Government said today.   The monthly percentage gain in housing starts was the biggest increase since a 17.7 percent jump in May 1983, and followed a steep 11.8 percent decline last February.    The weather apparently influenced both swings, holding down February activity and spurring a rebound in March when mild weather aided construction around the country.

headline: STUDY PROJECTS REVENUE LOSS UNDER REAGAN TAX PLAN
abstract: The Congressional Budget Office reported today that President Reagan's tax revision proposals would cost the Government a significant amount of revenue over the next 15 years.   The findings of the Budget Office, a nonpartisan agency that conducts economic and fiscal analyses for Congress, are sure to provide fuel for people who oppose the Administration tax plan. But those who have been following the tax debate in Congress said it was too early to predict the outcome.   President Reagan has insisted, and most legislators have agreed, that any new tax system be ''revenue neutral.'' When the President sent his tax package to Congress last month, the Administration submitted detailed estimates showing that the plan would generate approximately the same amount of money over the next five years as the current tax system would.

headline: KEEPING AN EYE ON WASHINGTON
abstract: THE economy. Tax reform. Interest rates. The price of oil. The dollar. And, of course, the twin monster deficits in foreign trade and the Federal budget. These are the uncertainties, extraordinary both in their number and potential for disaster, that have lead many professionals and do-it-yourselfers these days to throw up their hands in despair of finding a profitable investment strategy. Too many imponderables, each related in ways unfathomable to the most sophisticated computer program, have produced in many a sense of near helplessness.   ''It's always hard,'' lamented Arthur K. Carlson, a former New Yorker who oversees $5.4 billion of trust assets at the Valley National Bank of Arizona. ''But it's harder now.''   But with the myriad of investment vehicles now readily available - it was not so long ago that Treasury bills were a bit exotic and there was practically no market at all in options - there are many ways to exploit the opportunities that such uncertainty provides. Assuming you've sized up your financial and psychological resources and decided, as the Wall Street aphorism puts it, whether you want to ''eat well'' or ''sleep well,'' you're ready for the challenge.

headline: 'White-Collar' Crime Hearing
abstract: The Senate Judiciary Committee said today that it would hold hearings on the Justice Department's handling of ''financially sophisticated white-collar crime,'' including the recent prosecution of E.F. Hutton & Company.

headline: Minimum Tax Plan Gains Democratic Support
abstract: The House majority leader, Jim Wright, said today that a Democratic budget for 1986 might include revenue from a minimum tax on corporations and individuals.    On Thursday, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, and Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, plan to propose their own minimum tax plan in the Senate. Both are members of the Finance Committee, which has jurisdiction over taxes.

headline: AFRICAN GOSPEL RADIO: DOSES OF BIBLE AND MEDICINE
abstract: An outbreak of measles was claiming young lives in a rural area of this tropical West African nation. Deaths mounted, but the local people refused to have their children vaccinated out of fear that the medicine was a poison more deadly than the disease.   A missionary working in the area turned to ELWA, a Liberia-based radio station, for help. Broadcasting in Kru, the tribal language of the affected area, the station explained the disease and the benefits of the vaccine and encouraged parents to have their children innoculated. Before long, mothers and children were increasingly going to the clinic.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, MAY 31, 1985    The Tax Revision Plan    Federal financing of Presidential elections would be repealed under the Administration's tax plan. The end of the $1 checkoff on tax returns would radically alter the way Presidential campaigns have been paid for since 1976. [Page A1.]    Treasury Secretary Baker was promised bipartisan help at the opening Congressional hearing on the tax plan. But sharp questioning foreshadowed months of debate over particular elements, particularly the proposed repeal of the deductibility of state and local taxes. [D16.]  President Reagan appealed for support for the plan in stops chosen to reflect the rebellious spirit of colonial America and the present frustrations of middle America. [D17.]

headline: Vietnamese Forces Retake Cambodian Guerrilla Camp
abstract: Vietnamese forces recaptured a Cambodian guerrilla camp near the Thai border today in a two-hour battle that began at dawn, Thai military sources said. They said six guerrillas were killed and 35 wounded.

headline: 13 Resign From Paris Paper
abstract: Thirteen senior journalists, including the two chief editors, have resigned from the leftist daily newspaper Le Matin after Max Gallo, a former spokesman for the Socialist Government, was named chief editorial writer. The journalists said the appointment jeopardized the paper's independence.

headline: JAPAN HINTS AT APPROVAL OF HUGHES JOINT VENTURE
abstract: The Hughes Aircraft Company said today that it had received ''very positive'' indications that the Japanese Government would grant a license to a joint venture it formed with two Japanese companies to sell a sophisticated communications satellite system to Japanese companies.   Albert D. Wheelon, president of Hughes's space and communications group, said the company had been given ''one of the first tangible examples'' of the Japanese intention to increase imports of American-made products.   The joint venture, known as the Japan Communications Satellite Company Ltd., was asked on Monday to deliver an application for the communications system to the Ministry of Post and Telegraph in Tokyo. The Ministry received the application today, Hughes officials said.

headline: Soviet Lets 166 Jews Leave
abstract: The number of Soviet Jews allowed to leave the Soviet Union in April climbed to 166, the highest monthly total in almost two years, a resettlement agency said today. The emigres arrived in Vienna and 66 moved on to Israel, according to a news release from the Intergovernmental Committee for Migration.

headline: THE VOLATILE COCOA MARKET
abstract: -moving, volatile market. They do not have to look far these days for a cliffhanger that has been offering a fast swing for the money. It is the May cocoa futures contract, traded on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, which has swung between a contract high of $2,570 a metric ton and a contract low of $1,998 a metric ton.   On Thursday (most commodity markets were closed Friday), the closing price was $2,321, down a mere $1 from $2,322 the previous day. On Wednesday, there had been a $33 decline.

headline: Warsaw Pact's Commander Vows to Answer 'Star Wars'
abstract: The commander of Warsaw Pact forces said in an interview published today that the Soviet Union will take measures to respond to any challenge posed by President Reagan's planned space-based missile defense, which the President calls the Strategic Defense Initiative.   ''The so-called Strategic Defense Initiative, more precisely the program of elaborating an antimissile defense system in space, today is increasing the temperature in the world, destabilizing the strategic situation,'' the commander, Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov, was quoted as saying in an interview published in the Paris newspaper Le Figaro.

headline: Article 013034 -- No Title
abstract: A jury in a Federal antitrust case today awarded the MCI Communications Corporation $37.8 million in its suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. MCI had sought $5.8 billion.   Wall Street analysts called the verdict a clear victory for A.T.&T.   The award will be tripled to $113.3 million by Federal statute, but lawyers for the two sides said they doubted that MCI would get the money anytime soon. MCI officials are likely to appeal, a process which can take years.

headline: A LARGER FORCE OF LATIN REBELS SOUGHT BY U.S.
abstract: The White House, pressing for $14 million in aid for Nicaraguan rebels, has told Congress that it wants to expand the insurgent forces to put more pressure on the Nicaraguan Government.    A document sent to two Congressional committees said the Administration had for now ruled out ''direct application of U.S. military force,'' but warned that this course ''must realistically be recognized as an eventual option, given our stakes in the region, if other policy alternatives fail.''   Publicly, President Reagan has given no indication of any plan to expand guerrilla forces. Talking to trade association lobbyists at a White House gathering today, he accused Congress of being ''paralyzed over a mere $14 million in humanitarian aid.''

headline: BELIEVED IN SOUTH AMERICA
abstract: The principal Israeli police official assigned to the search for Dr. Mengele says that Israel has fingerprints, handwriting specimens and photographs tending to prove he is living in South America.   The official, Menachem Russek, declined to describe the evidence in more detail. Mr. Russek heads the Israeli police department charged with investigating Nazi crimes.   Another official with special responsibility in efforts to bring war criminals to justice also declined to describe the nature of recent evidence of Dr. Mengele's whereabouts so as not to compromise the inquiry. But the official, M. Dennis Gouldman, head of the international section of the Justice Ministry's state attorney's department, noted that an interagency team had recently been formed ''to trace, extradite and bring to trial Mengele and other war criminals.''

headline: IT'S A NEW GAME FOR A TV BROKER
abstract: THE Federal regulation of broadcasting has been    good to Howard E. Stark. And deregulation should   be just fine, too.   Mr. Stark, one of the nation's leading independent broadcast brokers, has negotiated the purchase or sale of hundreds of television stations - tallying, by his estimate, some $1.3 billion in sales - in his 30 years in the business. ''You mention a market, I'll tell you the deals I've done there,'' he said.

headline: SUDAN'S PRESIDENT IS RETURNING HOME IN FACE OF UNREST
abstract: The President of the Sudan cut short his overseas tour today and headed home from the United States to deal with the growing challenge to his one-party rule.    The President, Gaafar al-Nimeiry, had been in the United States for talks since last week.    He had planned to go to Egypt and Pakistan before returning to the Sudan in mid-April. But today, after conferring with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, he decided to return home this weekend ''to take hold of the situation,'' a Reagan Administration official said.   He said he would make a brief stop in Cairo to consult with Egyptian officials about the situation in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital.

headline: Futures;   Confusing Soybean Market
abstract: THE market for soybeans, one of   the world's leading sources of   protein and edible oil, is confusing analysts, commodity brokers, farmers, processors and foreign nations.    Richard A. Loewi, senior grain and oilseed analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities, calls the market ''tricky - tenderly tricky, that is,'' meaning it is volatile.    Kyung H. Lee, a vice president in the commodity division at Paine Webber who handles domestic and foreign commercial accounts, calls it ''the toughest market to predict.''    Walter Emery, director of research for the Commodity Research Bureau, says, ''Nobody wants to hold inventories because nobody knows where prices are going.''

headline: PAPANDREOU'S PATH DIVIDES GREEK-AMERICANS
abstract: Political developments in Greece in recent weeks have stirred concern - and created strains - among Greek-Americans.   Some of them say Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou may be a threat to democracy in Greece and to relations with the United States. Others say the problems have arisen largely because of what they see as favoritism by the Reagan Administration toward Turkey, Greece's archenemy.   Those who fault Mr. Papandreou say he is trying to manipulate Greek-Americans by using the Turkish issue; those who fault President Reagan say he is trying to do the same thing by raising the specter of Communism.

headline: INVESTIGATORS TURN ATTENTION TO MENGELE FAMILY CONTACTS
abstract: Growing indications that the son and perhaps other relatives of Josef Mengele may have kept in touch with the fugitive Nazi doctor over the years have focused the attention of investigators on the tight-lipped Mengele family.   The family of farm-machinery manufacturers based in Gunzburg, West Germany, has never spoken out in any detail on Dr. Mengele but has always maintained that it had lost all contact with him and supposed him to be long dead.   A French Nazi-hunter, Serge Klarsfeld, asserted yesterday that Dr. Mengele's son, Rolf, had traveled to Brazil under a false name in 1977, possibly to visit his father. Mr. Klarsfeld, a Paris lawyer, said he had been informed more than a year ago that Rolf Mengele, a lawyer in Freiburg, West Germany, had traveled with a false West German passport in the name of Wilfried Busse to Brazil from Aug. 11 to 23, 1977.   He gave the passport number as C 5479673 and said it had been issued in 1970 to the real Mr. Busse. Mr. Klarsfeld said he did not know where Mr. Busse could be found now.

headline: PAN AM PLANS SALE OF PACIFIC ROUTES TO UNITED AIRLINES
abstract: Pan American World Airways, which pioneered routes across the Pacific and grew into the most extensive global carrier, has agreed to sell its Pacific operations to United Airlines, the companies announced yesterday.     United, the nation's largest airline, would pay $750 million to Pan Am, which needs cash to modernize its fleet of planes. The transaction is subject to approval by the Department of Transportation, President Reagan and the other governments involved.    In a statement, both companies sought to assure ''the traveling public that all their service options and benefits will be preserved during the transition period.'' United would keep flying every route, assuming it gets the approval of each government.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: A SENSE OF TIMING HELPS AN EAST 75TH ST. BUILDER
abstract: Jeffrey Katz learned a painful lesson about timing a few years ago. Mr. Katz, a 38-year-old real estate developer who is now completing his first large construction project in Manhattan, had converted an old garage in Greenwich Village to condominium apartments.   As bad luck would have it, however, the apartments came to the market at the bottom of the 1981-82 recession, when apartments were not selling well anywhere in the city. Mr. Katz was forced to cut his prices substantially. The project, he said, was far from a success.   ''The people who bought apartments there made more money than I did,'' he said.

headline: AGCA DENIES DEAL WAS MADE TO IMPLICATE SOVIET
