abstract: Former Italian intelligence officials and the Turkish gunman Mehmet Ali Acga denied today that Mr. Agca had been involved in a deal to concoct testimony implicating Bulgaria and the Soviet Union in a conpiracy to kill Pope John Paul II.   Last week, Giovanni Pandico, an admitted mobster testifying in a major trial against organized crime in Naples, accused the former deputy head of military intellignce, Gen. Pietro Musumeci, of using underworld leaders to assure Mr. Agca that he would be freed if he implicated the Soviet bloc in the shooting. Mr. Acga has already been convicted of the May 1981 shooting of the Pope.   Mr. Agca, testifying in the assassination-conspiracy trial here of four other Turks and three Bulgarians, said that ''I have never met any member of the Camorra,'' the organized-crime group in Naples.   General Musumeci and other officials of the the Italian Defense Ministry's intelligence unit are themselves on trial in Rome, accused of subverting the service to enrich themselves and to establish a kind of security network to hinder the Italian Communists from coming to power.

headline: GQ's Florio Is a Man to Watch
abstract: The magazine community's major mumblings yesterday had to do with Steven T. Florio, the 36-year-old dynamic publisher of Gentleman's Quarterly, the magazine that had a greater advertising page increase than any other monthly last year. The rumor is that he is Conde Nast's selection to be publisher of The New Yorker.

headline: PAWNSHOP IS MEXICO'S TICKET TO ROMANTIC PLACES
abstract: Mexico City is sputtering into its traditional Holy Week tranquillity.    Nearly every departing airplane has been booked solid, and highways leaving the city are clogged. Trips around the capital that normally require 40 nightmarish minutes of vehicular endurance have become 15-minute pleasure drives. The cloud of photochemical smog that nearly always shrouds this capital of more than 17 million has lifted a bit; it is as if the city itself has taken a deep breath.

headline: Financial Deposits
abstract: Financial Corporation of America said it had gained $107.7 million in deposits during May but had lost $2.45 billion in deposits for 1985 to date. In its monthly report, Financial Corporation listed total deposits of $17.88 billion as of May 31, down from $23.77 billion at the same time last year.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Arizona Public Service Co. is offering $150 million of 11 1/2 percent first mortgage bonds, due 2015, at a price of 100, through underwriters led by First Boston Corp.    * Associates Corp. of North America, a unit of Gulf and Western Industries, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $500 million of unsecured senior or subordinated debt securities and warrants.    * Chapman Energy Inc. is offering 20,000 units, at $1,000 a unit, through Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. Each unit consists of a $1,000 face amount 12 percent senior subordinated debenture, due 2000, and 40 common shares.    * Merrill Lynch & Co. filed for a shelf offering of $363 million of unsecured senior debt, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.    * Nortek Inc. is offering $250 million of 13 1/2 percent, 12-year notes at a price of 98.548, to yield 13 3/4 percent, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

headline: Oklahoma Bank Failure
abstract: A spokesman for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said the loans and $84 million in deposits of the First City Bank N.A., Oklahoma City, which failed on Friday, would be assumed by City Bank and Trust of Oklahoma City, a newly chartered institution. In a statement issued Friday, the F.D.I.C. blamed the failure on deposit brokers taking advantage of the bank's high interest rates. The insuring agency said it had advanced $56.9 million to City Bank and Trust in the deal.

headline: CHINA STEPS UP DRIVE TO REVIVE BUREAUCRACY
abstract: Deng Xiaoping's campaign to rejuvenate China's sluggish bureaucracy has been stepped up with the naming of a new Shanghai party chief and the promotion of three 42-year-old officers to top military posts.   Earlier this week, the Government announced the appointment of nine new officials to head ministries that play a crucial role in Mr. Deng's modernization drive. At the same time, he has been pressing ahead with a shakeout of regional military commanders and top Communist Party and Government officials in the provinces.

headline: Contractors Investigated
abstract: The Pentagon is investigating 45 of the nation's military contractors, including 9 of the top 10, concerning allegations that include bribery, kickbacks and bid-rigging, according to Defense Department documents.

headline: Berkey in Deal With Fuqua Berkey Photo Inc. said that it
abstract: had agreed to sell its photofinishing operations to a Fuqua   Industries subsidiary for $40   million, and that it would reposition itself as a marketing and   distribution company. In addition, Berkey said that   it had acquired the B&E Sales   Company for $22.5 million and   up to an additional $6 million   based on future B&E earnings.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES
abstract: WHEN the Arab oil embargo was declared in 1973, the search for new sources of energy in the United States took on new meaning. Americans no longer wanted to rely on sources that could dry up because of events in far-away countries. The push was on, in fact, to find energy sources - the wind, the sun, the flowing rivers, even the trash bins - that would not run out for any reason.

headline: ITT Net Up 42.9% In Quarter
abstract: The ITT Corporation, aided by strong gains in all its divisions, yesterday reported a 42.9 increase in earnings in the first quarter.   Net income rose to $113.3 million, or 75 cents a share, from $79.3 million, or 52 cents a share, in the 1984 quarter. Revenues edged up 2.2 percent, to $4.70 billion, from $4.60 billion.

headline: FRANCE BLOCKS TRADE TALKS AS SUMMIT CONFERENCE ENDS; REAGAN PRESSES 'STAR WARS'; DISPUTE ON TIMING
abstract: The world's seven leading industrial nations ended their annual economic summit conference here today with a majority agreeing on the urgency of negotiations to eliminate barriers to free trade, the No. 1 issue here. But they failed to set a date to start the talks because of relentless objections from France.   President Reagan had made an urgent appeal for the talks to help him stem pressures in Congress for new American barriers against the rush of imported goods flooding the country, and he had the support of most of the other participants.   The three days of deliberations, the longest stop on a 10-day trip President Reagan is making in Western Europe, have been eclipsed by public controversy over the visit the President will make Sunday to the military cemetery at Bitburg, which includes the graves of 49 Waffen SS soldiers, and the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp site.      Struggle With Trade Issue    But those questions intruded little upon the economic conference itself. There the national leaders, along with their finance and foreign ministers, struggled most with the question of world trade, which all consider vital to their growth and prosperity but disagree over how to provide for it.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: * Aluminum Co. of America, Pittsburgh, said it was reducing primary aluminum production by 11,000 tons a year.    * First National Supermarkets Inc., Maple Heights, Ohio, said its board had agreed to the acquisition of the company by a management group for $24.25 a share. or about $63 million.    * Geico Corp., a Washington-based insurance concern, agreed to acquire Financial Insurance Risk Management Inc., a closely held Milwaukee-based underwriter of financial guarantee insurance. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Kissinger Voices Doubt About Summit Efforts
abstract: Henry A. Kissinger declared last night that this year ''is not an ideal time for a summit meeting'' between President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.   Mr. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, said he questioned why the United States appeared to be so eager for a top-level conference at a time when Mr. Gorbachev was preoccupied with domestic problems.

headline: COMPETITION OVER HOSTAGES IS FIERCE FOR THE U.S. TV NETWORKS IN BEIRUT
abstract: When the Cable News Network broadcast 20 minutes of interviews with the hostages from a schoolyard near Beirut yesterday, it underlined the extent to which television has continued to be part of the story of the 39 airliner hostages.   The unedited videotapes of the interviews with the captives, who spoke as their airline luggage was piled up for transfer to Damasacus, had been flown to Cyprus and transmitted to a satellite, then relayed to Atlanta, where the cable service has its news headquarters.   The deceptive conventionality of that transmission - ABC, CBS and NBC have been carrying similar reports -belied the fierce competition among the networks to beat each other in getting the hijacking victims on their broadcasts.   The competition has extended so far that at least one television network, NBC, was confirming reports yesterday that it would consider flying relatives of the hostages to the meeting point, and paying for their hotel rooms, in order to interview them immediately after the hostages were reunited with their families.

headline: Swiss Rail Station Bombed
abstract: A bomb exploded in Geneva's main train station at 12.45 A.M. today, breaking windows and knocking down parts of the ceiling but causing no injuries, a police spokesman said.

headline: DROP THE 'ONE SHARE, ONE VOTE' RULE
abstract: SPURRED by the actions of corporate managers intent on repulsing ''hostile'' takeover attempts, the New York Stock Exchange is re-examining its 60-year- old ban against listing the securities of companies that issue two classes of common stock that have different voting rights.   The exchange adopted that prohibition in 1926, when there were few Federal or state restraints on promoters seeking substantial amounts of capital from public investors without revealing much about their credentials or plans. And, it has steadfastly maintained its equal voting rights policy over the years.   In 1975, when Wang Laboratories went public with two classes of common stock, the New York Stock Exchange declined to list the company and watched it go on to become a star performer on the American Stock Exchange. More recently, despite intensifying competition for new listings, the Big Board has refused to recruit otherwise eligible companies that have issued two classes of stock.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Boston Sells $65 Million Of Upgraded Bonds
abstract: A $65 million issue of Boston bonds, carrying a new investment grade rating from Moody's Investors Service, was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. The bonds were tentatively assigned yields ranging from 5.75 percent in 1986 to 7 3/4 percent in 1990, 9 percent in 1995, 9 1/2 percent in 2000 and 9 3/4 percent in 2005.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: April 1, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Outer Space Legal Subcommittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Ad hoc committee on Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: KEY CONGRESSMEN PRAISE EMBARGO
abstract: Key Congressional leaders generally praised President Reagan's imposition of a trade embargo against Nicaragua today as a useful first step in pressing the Sandinista Government to change its policies.   But even supporters of the President criticized his failure to consult his Latin American allies and act in concert with them.   ''It's a plus rather than a minus,'' said Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, who heads the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. ''But it's nowhere near being an essential part of the policy that should be implemented, particularly when it's done unilaterally.''

headline: FUROR IN JAPAN OVER TV MURDER
abstract: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone joined other Japanese today in expressing dismay that a group of journalists had stood by and taken photographs while two men bayoneted a businessman to death.   Hundreds of protest calls were received by news organizations in Japan.

headline: CANADIANS CELEBRATE A NEW CHARTER OF RIGHTS
abstract: The anti-discrimination part of Canada's three- year-old Constitution goes into effect Wednesday.     The section, Section 15, forbids discrimination on grounds of sex, color, race, ethnic origin, religion or disability.   ''It represents a maturing of human rights in this country,'' Shelagh Day, president of the Women's Legal Education and Action Fund, formed to fight sex discrimination cases under Canada's new Charter of Rights and Freedoms, said today.

headline: Sudan Announces Ties With Libya Will Resume
abstract: The Sudan said today that it will resume relations with Libya, after a four-year break. It is the first major foreign policy shift since the military seized power.

headline: Arms Teams Meet in Geneva
abstract: United States and Soviet negotiators discussed defense and space weapons for three and a half hours today, a United States statement said. Details of the substance of the meeting, which took place at the United States arms control offices, were kept secret under the confidentiality agreement between the two sides.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: An article on May 5 about Yale University's acquisition of some weapons used in the killing of four Kent State University students in 1970 incorrectly described some of the victims.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: June 19, 1985 SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 11 A.M. on situation in Namibia.   Meets at 3 P.M. on complaint by Angola.      GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Subcommittee on Small Territories - 10:30 A.M.   Committee on Information - 11:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.      ECONONIC AND   SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Development Program Governing Council - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: CITY STORES POST A SLIM SALES RISE
abstract: Sales in May at New York's City's largest department stores rose by an average of 1.1 percent from the period a year ago, continuing the disappointing trend that has been evident for almost a year, a monthly spot-check found last week.   Sales in the metropolitan area were up 1.2 percent, according to the spot-check. The gains in both the city and the area represent a year-to-year decline in real terms, when inflation is taken into account.

headline: Unocal, Mesa Ratings Study
abstract: Debt ratings of securities of the Unocal Corporation and the Mesa Petroleum Company are under review for a possible downgrading, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.

headline: A BENCHMARK CASE ON COMPARABLE PAY
abstract: NEARLY 10 years ago, the state of Washington asked Norman D. Willis & Associates, a Seattle consulting firm, to study whether the state was guilty of sex-based discrimination in setting salaries for state employees. The firm found that indeed, it was.   But apparently Washington has not applied the findings fast enough for the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. The union sued, and last year Federal Judge Jack Tanner ruled in its favor. The state appealed. And now unions, lawyers and governors across the country are on tenterhooks, waiting for the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals decision on what is being viewed as the country's benchmark comparable worth case.

headline: SEARCH IN BAVARIA LED TO EXHUMATION
abstract: Several tips, including a letter from Paraguay, spurred the West German authorities last week to search a house in Josef Mengele's hometown in Bavaria, where they found documents placing the long-sought Nazi death camp doctor in Sao Paulo, Brazil, officials and investigators close to the case said yesterday.   The trail led West German, American and Israeli investigators to a cemetery outside Sao Paulo, where the body of a man the Brazilian police say could be Dr. Mengele was said to have been buried after a reported swimming accident in 1979. The bones have now been exhumed for scientific analysis.   Officials say privately, however, that the investigation has been hampered by the refusal of members of the Mengele family to provide any information. West German law broadly shields family members from having to testify against a relative. Repeated efforts by reporters to reach family members in West Germany have been fruitless.

headline: East River Savings Sale
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the New York State Banking Department yesterday approved the sale of the East River Savings Bank to Alvin Dworman, a New York real estate developer.   Mr. Dworman has agreed to pay $43 million to acquire the savings bank, which will have to convert from mutual to stock ownership.

headline: Mozambique Insurgency Topic of African Meeting
abstract: The growing insurgency in Mozambique and possible ways to combat it were discussed here today by Mozambique's President, Samora M. Machel, in a one-day meeting with his closest allies, President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania and Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe.   The three leaders discussed the possibility of sending Tanzanian and Zimbabwean troops into Mozambique's countryside to deal with the rebels, according to sources close to the talks.

headline: Dunlop Slazenger Goes To McCann-Erickson
abstract: For the third time this year, McCann-Erickson, one of three international agency networks run by the Interpublic Group of Companies, has received a major multinational assignment.

headline: SALVADOR TROOPS RAID STRUCK HOSPITALS
abstract: Security forces occupied several hospitals before dawn today in an attempt to end a strike that the Government said was being manipulated politically to the benefit of leftist guerrillas. Four Government agents were killed, apparently by other Government forces in the confusion.   At the 489-bed General Hospital in the capital, a helicopter landed troops on the roof at 3 A.M. and other troops stormed in through the basement and the emergency room.   More than 100 soldiers, some wearing gas masks, raced through the eight floors, ordering doctors, nurses, technicians and patients to lie down with their hands behind them. Many were tied up.

headline: BRAZILIAN LEADER HAS 4TH OPERATION
abstract: Brazil's President-elect, Tancredo Neves, underwent his fourth abdominal operation in 19 days today, once again dashing hopes that he was recovering well from intestinal problems that prevented him from assuming office last month.    A Government spokesman said Mr. Neves's latest surgery was to remove a hernia that threatened to block his lower intestines. He said that doctors had described the operation as a ''complete success'' and that, unlike the previous three operations, a general anesthesia had not been necessary.

headline: Computerland
abstract: A state judge in Oakland has upheld a jury verdict granting partial ownership of the Computerland Corporation to a group of outside investors and denied a motion by Computerland for a new trial.

headline: Investment Rises In Partnerships
abstract: Investments in publicly registered limited partnerships rose to more than $2 billion in the first quarter of 1985, up from about $1.7 billion for the first quarter a year ago, according to Robert A. Stanger & Company, a Shrewsbury, N.J., investment research firm.   The latest quarter's roundup of registered partnership activity showed that ''the public is more interested in investments and suitable growth vehicles for I.R.A. and Keogh funds than in deferring taxes,'' according to Robert A. Stanger.

headline: American Motors Posts $29 Million Quarter Loss DETROIT, April 19 (AP) - The American Motors Corporation today reported a $29 million first-quarter loss, attributing the results to the increasing popularity of larger cars and strong price competition in the small-car market.
abstract: The loss followed five successive quarters of profits by the fifth-largest domestic auto maker. It had posted a profit of $5.1 million, or 3 cents a share, in the 1984 quarter.   A.M.C.'s sales for the quarter fell 15.1 percent, to $919.4 million, from $1.08 billion a year earlier.

headline: S.E.C. GOVERNMENT SECURITIES RULES
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission decided today on the proposals it would recommend to Congress for regulating the Government securities industry if Congress should pass regulatory legislation. The vote was 3 to 1.   The recommendations would require that all dealers in Government securities be registered with the Federal Government. Also, the S.E.C. and bank regulators would have the power to bar certain individuals, and the Treasury Department would have the rule-making authority to set standards on capital levels, auditing, record-keeping and the use of collateral.

headline: S.A.S. Will End Flights to Johannesburg
abstract: Sweden, Norway and Denmark agreed today to end all Scandinavian Airlines System flights to Johannesburg to protest South Africa's apartheid policies.

headline: Yields on U.S. Issues Up a Bit
abstract: Yields on Treasury notes and bonds rose modestly yesterday, reversing some of the sharp decline in the previous seven trading sessions.     Short-term rates were little changed, except for the three-month Treasury bill, which fell to 7.80 percent from 7.96 percent. Analysts noted that demand for Treasury bills had been increased by the failures of E.S.M. Government Securities and the Bevill, Bresler & Schulman group of securities firms.    Although major banks and securities dealers report no problems in financing their activities, they acknowledged that some investors, such as local governments, might be accepting lower yields on direct investments in Treasury bills rather than trying to earn a higher interest rate by investing in a repurchase agreement.

headline: DOW DECLINES 4.48 ON PROFIT TAKING
abstract: Profit taking took a bite out of blue-chip prices yesterday on Wall Street, but investors continued to show some interest in secondary, transportation and interest-sensitive issues.   Reports of cuts in crude oil prices by Britain and the Soviet Union, as well as concern over what might develop from a special session of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries moved up to June 30, kept investors away from energy stocks.   ''People are saying maybe this is the straw that breaks the camel's back,'' said Daniel F. McKinley, an oil analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, who himself believes Wall Street is overreacting.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which shot up to a record close Friday because of lower interest rates, backtracked 4.48 points, to 1,310.93.

headline: INVESTING;  A CAUTION SIGN FOR THE TRIBUNE CO.
abstract: WHEN analysts and portfolio managers talk about the long-term prospects for a stock, it is usually a signal they are not that positive about its immediate future. And that appears to be the general reaction to recent news surrounding the Tribune Company: Rupert Murdoch's probable move to sell two papers that compete directly with the Tribune's flagship properties, and the Tribune Company's own plan to buy the Los Angeles independent television station, KTLA-TV. Both changes could mean good sailing for the Chicago-based media giant later in the decade, say analysts, but for the shorter run, the view is a bit more cautious.  Speaking of the television purchase, Gregory C. Clark, vice president of Alliance Capital Management, a New York investment management firm that owns 1.3 million Tribune Company shares for its clients, said: ''I think it's an intelligent long-term move.'' But like many analysts, Mr. Clark thinks the price the Tribune paid to a group of private investors for the Los Angeles station may be a bit steep. In fact, the purchase price - $510 million - is the largest ever for a single TV station.

headline: LEBANESE SHIITE THREATENS ISRAEL OF ITS SECURITY PLANS IN THE SOUTH
abstract: The leader of the Lebanese Shiite Moslem militia said today that he would join forces with Palestinian guerrillas if Israel kept troops in southern Lebanon and continued to insist on retaining a security zone north of its border, both of which the Israelis have said they will do.   Nabih Berri, the leader of the militia known as Amal, also warned that Shiites would carry out attacks across Israel's northern border if Israel conducted raids into Lebanese territory.   The Shiite leader issued the warning as the Israeli pullout of combat units continued on the third anniversary of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. Israeli officials have said they would keep soldiers inside Lebanon despite what had been widely interpreted here as a pledge to complete the evacuation of occupied Lebanese territory by the first week of June.

headline: Consumers Power
abstract: The Consumers Power Company said it had reached agreement with its bankers on restructuring payments on nearly $1.2 billion in unsecured loans, clearing the way for an electricity rate increase to avoid bankruptcy. The company will file a statement with the Michigan Public Service Commission on Monday ''indicating that we've met the conditions that they laid out for our 6 percent rate increase,'' said Dan Bishop, Consumers Power spokesman. Under an agreement with about 80 banks, Consumers will make a lump-sum payment of $105 million this year and repay the rest of the debt at about $160 million a year over six years.

headline: GO-BETWEEN TELLS OF TRIPS TO BRAZIL
abstract: A man identified as an intermediary between Dr. Josef Mengele in Latin America and the Mengele family in West Germany said today that he had carried letters to the fugitive Nazi death camp doctor, but not money, as far as he knew.   The man, Hans Sedlmeier, seemed somewhat baffled by the sudden attention given to what he called his ''work'' over the last decade. But by today, most of the camera crews and reporters who had staked out his house had lost hope of seeing him, and Mr. Sedlmeier, a small, spry man of 72 years, felt free to putter in his backyard again.   He said he knew Wolfgang Gerhard, the man whose identity Dr. Mengele is said to have assumed in Brazil, as well as Gitta and Geza Stammer and Wolfram and Liselotte Bossert, who purportedly harbored Dr. Mengele in Brazil over the years. ''Of course I knew all of them,'' he acknowledged, with a hint of pride.

headline: Technology;   The Plastic Pollution Fight
abstract: AMID the seaweed and broken shells, a small stretch of beach on Long Island Sound recently yielded several clear plastic soda bottles, an assortment of plastic bags and a dented plastic milk jug. Despite the continuing action of wind and weather, all remained largely intact and are likely, experts say, to remain that way for several years.   Recently, growing concern about plastic pollution and its resistance to decay has renewed the debate over whether the use of degradable plastics -those that readily decay - should be required. The issue has attracted global concern, as shown by the decision of the Italian Government in January to ban all nondegradable plastic bags by 1991.

headline: POPE IN PLEA FOR THE HUNGRY
abstract: Pope John Paul II called on the Common Market today to use its large farm surpluses to help the hungry of the third world and ''to overcome a flagrant inequality'' between rich and poor countries.   Later, the Pope celebrated mass in this industrial city at an altar set against a smoke-belching steelworks and denounced the ''scourge'' of unemployment.   The Pope arrived here this morning, ending his four-day visit to the Netherlands, a trip that underlined the sharp differences between liberal Dutch Roman Catholics and Rome and that was marred by street riots.

headline: TORIES LEAD IN ONTARIO VOTE
abstract: The Progressive Conservative Party, which has governed Ontario for 42 years, appeared to have narrowly escaped defeat in an election held today in Canada's most populous province.   The returns indicated, however, that if the Tories are to continue in power, they will have to form a minority government with the left-leaning New Democrats, as they did after the 1975 and 1977 elections.

headline: Zellerbach Ruling
abstract: The Nevada Supreme Court has ruled that the Crown Zellerbach Corporation should go on as scheduled with its May 9 annual meeting, overturning a lower court order that would have required a two-week delay requested by the British financier Sir James Goldsmith. The court also said Sir James's General Oriental Securities Ltd. had no right under Nevada law to inspect the shareholder list, and Zellerbach ''acted lawfully in refusing to produce the records.'' Sir James, who has been trying to take over the San Francisco-based paper and forest products company, owns 8.5 percent of its stock.

headline: Storer Files Suit
abstract: Storer Communications Inc. and three of its subsidiaries in Connecticut filed suit against Coniston Partners, which is leading a dissident group trying to unseat the company's board.

headline: G. A. O. STUDY CITES RISK IN OIL STOCKPILE DELAY
abstract: A Reagan Administration proposal to temporarily delay completion of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, the nation's protection against a sudden oil shortage, may set back the country's ability to withstand such a shortage, according to a study by the General Accounting Office.    The study, which has not yet been released, is the first independent examination of the possible effects of the Administration's proposal to stop filling the reserve when it reaches the 489-million-barrel mark at the end of September.    The proposed moratorium has been incorporated into the deficit reduction package agreed to Thursday by the President and the Senate Republican leadership.

headline: INDIA TEMPORARILY HALTS ALL FLIGHTS INTO CANADA
abstract: India announced today that it had temporarily suspended Air-India flights to Canada in the aftermath of the crash of an Air-India jumbo jet off Ireland with 329 people aboard.   India's Minister of State for Civil Aviation and Tourism, Ashok Gehlot, denied press reports that flights to Canada had been suspended because of continuing concern in the Government and among travelers.   He said in a statement that the temporary suspension had been prompted by a shortage of aircraft in the Government-run airline.   Mr. Gehlot said the flights would be resumed as a soon as possible after a rescheduling of aircraft now using different international routes. Air-India has nine Boeing 747 jumbo jets, most of which fly the Bombay-New Delhi-New York route.

headline: Federated Issue
abstract: Federated Department Stores Inc. is issuing $100 million of 10 1/8 percent Eurobonds due in 1995, at a price of par, through underwriters led by Goldman Sachs International. The company said proceeds from the sale of the bonds, which are non-callable, would be used to reduce short-term indebtedness.

headline: MENGELE WAS REPORTEDLY HELD IN P.O.W. CAMPS RUN BY U.S.
abstract: Josef Mengele was detained in a series of American prisoner of war camps at the end of World War II, but was released into the American occupation zone in Germany without being identified, according to a report here.   In an article on the underground life of the Nazi war criminal based on materials and information supplied by his son Rolf, the West German magazine Bunte also relates that Dr. Mengele hid blood and cell samples from gruesome pseudomedical experiments at the Auschwitz death camp. He retrieved them and took them to Argentina in 1949, according to a consultant to the magazine.

headline: G.E. Credit, Tiffany in Deal
abstract: Tiffany & Company, the New York jeweler, said yesterday that it had reached a major financing agreement with the General Electric Credit Corporation.

headline: RANCOR IS EVIDENT IN COMMEMORATIONS OF DACHAU
abstract: Thousands of people, many of them former inmates, attended ceremonies today marking the 40th anniversary of the liberation of the Dachau concentration camp. But the ceremonies, at the camp site outside this rural Bavarian town and in Munich, 10 miles to the south, reflected the rancor here over how to interpret the collapse of Nazi Germany and the end of World War II.         At Dachau, about 5,000 people attended religious services and laid wreaths at a monument on the site of the camp, where more than 30,000 people died.

headline: ARGENTINE COUP PLOT IS REPORTED
abstract: President Raul Alfonsin, appealing for unity, declared on national television tonight that the Argentine armed forces had rebuffed civilian attempts to involve the military in a coup.     ''I denounce to the Argentine people the divisive activity of those who predict chaos and anarchy, who foresee social explosion, who augur international isolation,'' Mr. Alfonsin said in a 15- minute address.

headline: JOHN PAUL NAMES 28 NEW CARDINALS
abstract: Pope John Paul II named 28 new Cardinals today, including Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York and Archbishop Miguel Obando y Bravo, the head of Nicaragua's Roman Catholic Church.   Archbishop Bernard F. Law of Boston was also named to the Sacred College of Cardinals, the only other American on a list that included natives of 19 countries.   In addition, the Pope named four Cardinals from Eastern Europe, including two from his homeland of Poland. One of the new Polish Cardinals, Archbishop Henryk Roman Gulbinowicz of Wroclaw, is an outspoken supporter of the outlawed Solidarity trade union movement.

headline: Reagan to Fill Economic Post
abstract: President Reagan, as expected, said today that he would nominate Thomas Gale Moore to be one of three members of the Council of Economic Advisers.

headline: Hutton Fills Post Of Treasury Chief
abstract: E.F. Hutton & Company said yesterday that Paul J. Beehler, an independent cash management expert and consultant, had been named senior vice president for treasury operations.   In his new position, which is effective July 1, Mr. Beehler will be responsible for managing the company's corporate cash position and its working capital.   Earlier this month, Robert Fomon, Hutton's chairman, acknowledged that the firm's treasury controls had broken down and had contributed to the illegal activities of its brokerage unit. In May Hutton acknowledged it had defrauded numerous small banks of millions of dollars through a check-writing system that gave it interest-free loans.

headline: VICTOR LUSINCHI, VETERAN REPORTER
abstract: Victor Lusinchi, a foreign correspondent for 50 years and a contributor to The New York Times based in Geneva, died yesterday near Grenoble on his way to the south of France for a vacation. He was 73 years old.    Mr. Lusinchi and his wife, Paulette, were staying overnight at a hotel when he died, apparently from complications arising out of emphysema, from which he had suffered for years.

headline: Computers Displayed By Compaq
abstract: Two companies taking on the International Business Machines Corporation in the office market - the Compaq Computer Corporation and the Xerox Corporation - introduced computer systems yesterday.   Most of the enthusiasm was reserved for the Compaq announcement, which involved both a portable version of the I.B.M. PC-AT and an AT-compatible desktop computer.   Like the AT, the first of a new generation of I.B.M. machines, Compaq's machines use the Intel 80286 microprocessor, which is much faster than the chip used in the original I.B.M. Personal Computer.

headline: TENNESSEE BANKER IS GIVEN 20-YEAR JAIL TERM
abstract: Jacob F. Butcher, a prominent banker and politician in Tennessee, was sentenced yesterday to two concurrent 20-year prison terms for defrauding his banks of as much as $30 million.   The Justice Department called it one of the stiffest sentences ever imposed for a white-collar crime - a financial crime, such as fraud or market manipulation, committed by someone in government or business.fixes prices.   The sentences for eight counts of fraud and conspiracy were the heaviest that Judge William K. Thomas of the Federal District Court in Knoxville could have imposed under a plea agreement worked out in April between the United States Attorney, John W. Gill Jr., and Mr. Butcher.   The sentencing fit the pattern of increasingly stiff penalties being meted out to prominent white-collar criminals, who are often influential in their communities and who rarely went to jail for these crimes before 1970.

headline: 2 ARRESTED IN ARGENTINE FIRE
abstract: The federal police said today that the director and another administrator of  a private hospital were being held for questioning about the cause of a fire in  which 79 people were killed and 247 injured.         ''They are detained incommunicado,'' said Omar Benedictis, a police spokesman.

headline: OFFICIAL SAYS U.S. LEADS IN ARMS TECHNOLOGY
abstract: The Administration's top official on developing space-based defenses said today that the United States ''is ahead and continuing to move ahead'' of the Soviet Union in defense technology.   Lieut. Gen. James A. Abrahamson Jr., the director of the Administration's Strategic Defense Initiative program, told a group of foreign reporters that while Moscow held the lead in certain areas of defensive technology, the United States was ahead in ''the vital areas'' of computers and software and in the ''overall balance of technology.''   These were the sharpest statements by any senior Administration official in over a year as to the overall standing of Soviet-American competition for defense against nuclear attacks.

headline: Prices Mixed in a Light Day
abstract: Bond prices were mixed in light trading yesterday, as credit market participants chose to shrug off developments that could have sent yields lower across the maturity spectrum.   At the close, short-term and long-term rates had declined, while yields on intermediate-term issues rose.   In the opinion of some analysts, traders might have reacted more positively to a drop in the Federal funds rate, the overnight rate for bank loans, as well as to word from the Treasury Department on the results of yesterday's auction of $6 billion worth of new seven-year notes, a sale that went better than expected.   Comments from Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggesting that the pace of economic activity in the second quarter might be slower than originally reported could have also been viewed optimistically, the analysts said.

headline: PATENTS ;  Inventors Exposition In New York May 3-7
abstract: At least 25 countries are to have displays in 175 booths at the ninth annual Worldwide Inventors Exposition, to be held May 3 through May 7 at the Sheraton Exhibition Center in New York. About 500 or more patented inventions are to be shown.  According to Harold L. Kleiman, president of International Inventors Technology Ltd., a New York company that operates the expositions, special awards and prizes will be given by an international jury for the best inventions and for new products in selected classifications. Mr. Kleiman expects attendance of more than 2,500 inventors and manufacturers.

headline: Account
abstract: Loctite Corp. to Fahlgren & Swink, Cleveland, for its chemical adhesive and sealant products.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: WASHINGTON WATCH ;   Trying to Sell Radio Waves
abstract: Mark S. Fowler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, may try to get Congressional approval to auction radio frequencies.

headline: ORDER ON 3 STORER CABLE UNITS
abstract: A Connecticut judge has issued a temporary injunction ordering a group of dissident Storer Communications shareholders not to take ''any action to terminate the currently constituted corporate existence'' of Storer's three Connecticut cable television subsidiaries without approval from utilities regulators.         In the injunction, which was issued Friday, Superior Court Judge Ronald J. Fracasse of the Judicial District of New Haven also ordered the dissidents led by Coniston Partners to file an application by May 1 with the Connecticut Department of Public Utility Control for approval of their proposed takeover of  Storer.

headline: SALVADORAN DENIES RIFT AMONG REBELS
abstract: The leader of a small, non-Marxist rebel political party that publicly criticized a terrorist attack last week in which 13 people were killed, 4 of them United States marines, has declared that American military advisers and President Jose Napoleon Duarte are legitimate targets of war.   The statement, issued Thursday, appeared to contradict hopes among Salvadoran and United States officials that more moderate members of the rebel coalition would try to halt attacks on American military personnel and Government figures here. The statement also indicated that there was no significant rupture in the rebel alliance, as some Salvadoran officials have suggested in recent days.

headline: Block Rejects Compuserve Bid
abstract: The board of H & R Block Inc. formally rejected a $72.5 million offer to buy the company's Compuserve Inc. subsidiary.

headline: AS BITBURG VISIT NEARS, KOHL, UNDER FIRE, SAYS IT WILL GO ON
abstract: The West German Government today rejected warnings that its plans for President Reagan's state visit would profoundly damage relations with the United States and said that the American leader would lay a wreath at a German military cemetery Sunday as scheduled.   Chancellor Helmut Kohl was reported by a well-placed official to have spoken today by telephone with President Reagan, but no details of their conversation were made available.   The Chancellor met Sunday with representatives of West German Jewish groups who reportedly sought to find alternatives to the stop at the Bitburg cemtery where 49 Waffen SS soldiers are interred. Flowers were seen on some of the SS graves today.

headline: ENGLISH SOCCER CLUBS ARE BANNED FROM EUROPEAN PLAY INDEFINITELY
abstract: Europe's governing soccer association banned English club teams indefinitely from European competition today because of a riot at a match in Brussels last week in which 38 people died.   The decision by the 34-nation Union of European Football Associations was announced at a news conference after a meeting of the organization's executive committee here.   The soccer union's president, Jacques Georges, said the committee based its decision on a preliminary report by three of its members. Nine committee members, including the representative from Scotland, were present, and two, from the Soviet Union and Italy, were absent.

headline: DATABANK
abstract: THE ECONOMY Gross National ProductI Q'85IV Q'84Year Ago In billions, annual rate$3,817.1$3,758.7$3,553.3 Real G.N.P. Growth Annual rate,1972 dollars, in percent#0.7#4.3#10.1 Corporate After-Tax ProfitsI Q'85IV Q'84Year Ago In billions, annual rate$140.0$141.0$102.6 Industrial Production IndexAprilMarchYear Ago Percent change, monthly and year to year-0.2+0.3+2.0 Housing StartsAprilMarchYear Ago Thousands of units, annual rate#1,913#1,883#1,949 New Orders for Durable GoodsAprilMarchYear Ago By manufacturers, in billions$100.70$99.73$97.31 Plant and Equipment SpendingIV Q'84III Q'84Year Ago In billions, annual rate$367.21$361.12$325.45 Mfg. headline: Sallie Mae Notes
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $275 million of floating-rate notes due Oct. 10, 1985, at a price of 100. The interest will not be paid until maturity but will be adjusted weekly to two-tenths of a percentage point above the bond equivalent yield of 91- day Treasury bills.

headline: COMMUNISTS FALTER IN ITALIAN ELECTIONS
abstract: Voters handed a setback to the Communist Party and bolstered Prime Minister Bettino Craxi's five-party coalition in regional elections that ended today.   All major parties had considered the two-day vote for regional, local and provincial governments an important test with a direct bearing on national politics. The Communists were counting on a victory to support their demand for a share in the national government.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: 'The time has come for Congress, as part of more comprehensive banking legislation, to authorize some interstate banking.'      Paul A. Volcker   Chairman, Federal Reserve Board

headline: TROUBLESHOOTER: Stanton D. Anderson;   JAPAN'S TOP U.S. LOBBYIST
abstract: STANTON D. ANDERSON'S Sunday school teacher was a state senator who taught the boy more than Bible studies: Mark O. Hatfield, now Republican Senator from Oregon, instilled in the youngster a taste - and a skill - for politics that never disappeared. And today the 44-year-old Mr. Anderson wields political power of a sort that would have seemed inconceivable to a Baptist minister's son growing up in Salem, Ore., during World War II.   By all accounts, Mr. Anderson is Japan's most influential lobbyist in Washington, a leading figure in what is the capital's biggest growth industry: Japanese Government and industry representation.   ''You can measure a good lobbyist by the ripples he doesn't make, and Stan doesn't make ripples,'' said one of his adversaries, Travis Marshall, chief lobbyist for Motorola, an American telecommunications company that has been campaigning for an import surcharge to help redress the growing trade deficit.   Mr. Anderson, whose lean, 6-foot 4-inch frame has been a fixture in Washington for about 20 years, prefers to operate with low visibility, wielding his considerable power behind the scenes. He shuns the word lobbying, preferring to call what he does ''trade-policy legal work.'' In Japan, ''lobbyist'' carries a pejorative connotation: The word means ''action behind the curtains.''

headline: BROWN & ROOT
abstract: The Halliburton Company said today that its subsidiary, Brown & Root Inc., was studying whether to take a ''significant'' write-down on certain investments and marine vessels because of the extended depressed conditions in the marine construction industry.   A Halliburton spokesman would not say when the company would decide whether to take a write-down, adding that a decision ''is not necessarily imminent.''

headline: Fluor-McDonnell
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it and the Fluor Corporation had signed an agreement to jointly seek airport projects in China. It said that Fluor China would join McDonnell Douglas China Inc. to pursue all phases of airport projects from planning a complete new facility to designing and supervising improvements at existing sites. It said that the work would include feasibility studies, engineering and design and construction management.

headline: Futures/Options;   Witching Hour For Investors
abstract: SUPERSTITIOUS or not, many stock investors have come to regard the last hour of trading on the third Friday of each month as the ''witching hour,'' a time when the market seems to plunge for no apparent reason. It is also a time when the current month's Major Market Index options expire.   On March 15, for example, when that month's M.M.I. options died, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped more than 14 points even though there was no significant market news. Previous expiration dates of the options have witnessed similar downward price ''spikes.''

headline: Mademoiselle Publisher Is Formerly of Hearst
abstract: Former Country Living magazine publisher, Ronald A. Galotti, has left Hearst Magazines to join Conde Nast as publisher of Mademoiselle, its thriving monthly fashion publication.

headline: GORBACHEV WARNS ARMS TALKS MAY FAIL
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned today that the Soviet Union would reassess its participation in the Geneva arms talks if the United States continued ''marking time'' there, as he put it.   Though he did not directly threaten a walkout, the statement was the strongest warning to date that the talks could collapse over American plans to develop a space-based missile defense, popularly known as ''Star Wars.''   In a televised speech in Dnepropetrovsk, Mr. Gorbachev called the proposed American program ''a blank wall blocking the way to agreement.''   ''If our partners in the Geneva talks,'' he continued, ''carry on their line, marking time at the sessions of the delegations, avoiding solutions to the problems for the sake of which they have gathered and using that time to intensify their arms buildup programs in space, on land and on the seas, we will, of course, have to reassess the entire situation.

headline: Bausch Unit To Avrett
abstract: won the Bausch & Lomb contact lens account in a competition that the agency chairman,   John G. Avrett, called ''the   most extensive presentation   I've ever been involved in.'' He said the billings should be   around $7 million to $8 million.

headline: A.T.& T. ERRS ON BELLSOUTH CUSTOMERS
abstract: The BellSouth Corporation said yesterday that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had notified it that as many as 41,000 business customers might have been improperly assigned to A.T.&T. long-distance service.   A spokesman for A.T.&T., however, said the actual number was substantially lower.   BellSouth has filed plans with the Department of Justice to correct the results of an A.T.&T. computer program that erroneously assigned service under the equal-access program mandated by the breakup of the Bell System.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE KILL BLACK
abstract: A black man was shot to death by the police in a small black township near the southeast coast after a group of blacks began stoning police officers and firefighters who were responding to an incident of arson, a police spokesman said today.   The incident late Thursday night followed by a few hours a Government announcement of tougher measures to deal with what it called the ''situation of unrest in black areas.''   The incident in the township, the police spokesman said, was one of several disturbances to take place in the last 24 hours, most of them in the southern townships near Uitenhage, where 19 people were killed three weeks ago after the police fired on a black demonstration.

headline: UAL Posts A Deficit In Quarter
abstract: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, yesterday reported a $661,000 first-quarter loss. It attributed the loss to discounted air fares.   UAL Inc., which also owns Westin Hotels, Hawaii resort development operations and a business services unit, said the results in the period ended March 31 came on revenue of $1.59 billion. In the first quarter of 1984, the corporation earned $25.6 million, or 56 cents a share, on sales of $1.65 billion.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: American Petrofina Inc.   [2,700,000)   -

headline: Mrs. Reagan Planning Activities of Her Own
abstract: Nancy Reagan plans a number of activities of her own during the trip to Western Europe, some of them focused on her interest in the fight against drug abuse.   On Thursday, according to Jennefer Hirshberg, who is Mrs. Reagan's press secretary, she is to present a check in Bonn for $5,000 from the National Federation of Parents for Drug-Free Youth, of Silver Spring, Md., to its West German counterpart.

headline: Military Contracts
abstract: The Grumman Corporation won a $126.7 million Navy contract for 24 F-14A Tomcat aircraft for the fiscal year 1985, the Defense Department said. It said the Navy had also awarded $71 million to the General Electric Company for material and services for 188 F404-GE-400 engines. Also, a division of the General Motors Corporation received Army contracts totaling $30.2 million for transmissions, and White Engines Inc. of Canton, Ohio, received $33.1 million from the Army for engines.

headline: CHATPER 11 FOR INDIANA ELECTRICITY GROUP
abstract: An association of electrical cooperatives in northern Indiana yesterday filed for protection from its creditors yesterday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. It said it was unable to make payments on some $500 million that it borrowed from the Federal Government for its share of the Marble Hill nuclear power plant, which was canceled last year.   The filing by the Wabash Valley Power Association is the latest salvo in a battle over who should end up paying some of the costs of the Marble Hill plant: Indiana electrical rate payers or American taxpayers as a whole.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Parr Cited In Closing
abstract: Kenney & Branisel Inc., a small government securities dealer that formerly owned the Parr Securities Corporation, has stopped trading and has withdrawn from the market after Parr's collapse earlier this week.   Parr admitted in a signed statement on Monday to Securities and Exchange Commission charges of fraud, and the S.E.C. said that Parr had less than $1 million in assets to cover more than $16 million in obligations. Parr was a subsidiary of Kenney & Branisel until it was bought by Gregory Herbert for $609,000 in December, Howard R. Hawkins Jr., an attorney with Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, who is representing Kenney & Branisel, confirmed that the firm had closed out all of its positions in the government securities market, a net total of about $40 million, on Wednesday.

headline: Luxembourg Is Blacked Out As 2 Blasts Topple Towers
abstract: Two explosions brought down a string of four high-voltage electric towers on the outskirts of Luxembourg, blacking out most of the city for about an hour and slightly injuring five motorists, the police said today.   The explosions late Tuesday wrecked towers between the southern outskirts of Luxembourg and Leudelange, a village five miles south of the capital, the police said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: NATO Delegates Split On 'Star Wars' Proposal
abstract: French, Norwegian and Danish delegates to a NATO meeting today criticized the United States-proposed ''Star Wars'' antimissile system on the grounds it could unhinge the peace in Europe.   But the Pentagon's proposal drew support from the British delegation in discussions among the alliance's Military Committee and Committee on Science and Technology.

headline: THE RESTRUCTURING OF APPLE COMPUTER
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. took a giant step today in the painful transition from its entrepreneurial origins to the ranks of more conventionally managed multibillion-dollar companies.   In a move aimed both at streamlining Apple and moving it out of the shadow of its co-founder, Steven P. Jobs, the company announced a corporate restructuring that does away with its two separate product divisions, in favor of manufacturing and marketing divisions responsible for all Apple products.   The restructuring eliminates the day-to-day operating responsibilities of Mr. Jobs, who had been general manager of the Macintosh division. Mr. Jobs will remain only as chairman of the board, and will take what the company called a ''more global role'' in product development and strategy formulation.   Apple insiders and analysts saw the move as an urgent attempt by John Sculley, president and chief executive, to assert leadership at a time when the company is beset with numerous problems. There is a growing feeling on Wall Street and in Silicon Valley that Mr. Sculley, who was recruited two years ago from Pepsico Inc., must act soon to turn the company around.

headline: South African Unions Call For 2-Hour Strike
abstract: Forty black trade unions called today for a nationwide two-hour strike to protest the deaths of two black activists from head injuries, hours after their release from police custody.   A lawyer, Richard Spoor, said a state autopsy showed that Sipho Mutsi, 20 years old, an organizer for the Congress of South African Students, died Sunday of a brain hemorrhage caused by ''a blow to the top of the head.''

headline: LIFE OF 'MENGELE' EMERGING: MUSIC, TV AND FEW VISITORS
abstract: The man identified by associates here as Josef Mengele, the long-sought fugitive Nazi war criminal, led a reclusive life for nearly two decades in and around Brazil's largest city, according to neighbors, friends and a housemaid who says she loved him.   They portray the man as an authoritarian figure, but also as someone who was cultivated and sometimes charming. They say he spent his days at secluded farms and simple cottages, tended sick animals, disparaged black people, kept a diary but never publicly discussed history or politics, and liked to watch ''Disneyland'' on television.   The accounts, given in news interviews and in depositions to the Brazilian police, help explain how the man -if indeed he was the Auschwitz death-camp doctor - managed to escape his pursuers for so long only to drown, as his former protectors here say, in a swimming accident in 1979.      Many Questions Unanswered    In fact, the story that is now emerging of a robust but lonely exile bears almost no resemblance to the often lurid accounts over the years of a surgery-altered Dr. Mengele, surrounded by armed guards, torturing Indians or serving as the personal physician of President Alfred Stroessner of Paraguay.

headline: REAGAN MEETS ALGERIAN PRESIDENT
abstract: President Reagan and the President of Algeria today discussed at length various proposals for bringing Palestinians into expanded Middle East peace talks with Israel, a high-ranking Administration official said.   The Palestinian issue dominated the first meeting between Mr. Reagan and President Chadli Benjedid, the official said, with both agreeing there could be no progress in the Middle East without involvement of the Palestinians.

headline: ASIA'S DEVELOPING NATIONS THRIVE
abstract: The developing countries of Asia, aided by increased exports and lower oil bills, continued to register strong economic gains last year, averaging 5.5 percent growth in 1984, according to the Asian Development Bank.     In its 1984 annual report, the bank notes that the average for the 16 Asian countries surveyed outpaced last year's rise in global output, which was 4.6 percent. Asia's 5.5 percent growth also surpassed the 1984 growth rate for the industrial nations (4.9 percent), oil-exporting developing nations (3.8 percent) and non-oil developing nations (3.7 percent).

headline: AGCA, AT ROME TRIAL, AGAIN PROCLAIMS HE IS CHRIST
abstract: The prosecution's main witness in the purported plot to kill Pope John Paul II repeated in testimony today that he was Jesus Christ and that the world was about to end.   The witness, Mehmet Ali Agca, made the remarks on the second day of the trial of three Bulgarians and five Turks, who include Mr. Acga. Mr. Acga has already been convicted of having shot and wounded the Pope at the Vatican in 1981.   Bulgarian diplomats observing the trial expressed delight at Mr. Agca's words, and Giuseppe Consolo, a lawyer for the Bulgarians, described Mr. Acga's testimony as ''proof that he has led Italian justice around by the nose for three years.''      Agca's Credibility Defended    But the prosecutor, Antonio Marini, denied that his case against the Bulgarians centered on the testimony of Mr. Agca or that the remarks diminished his credibility when discussing details of the conspiracy. Implicit in the prosecution's case is that the Bulgarian Government, with the possible collusion of the Soviet Union, was behind the plot against the Polish-born Pope. Both the Soviet and Bulgarian Governments have denied involvement in the purported conspiracy.

headline: Secretive Debt Reviewers
abstract: It is a secretive group of nine top Federal bank examiners who refuse even to say where they meet and who never divulge anything publicly. Three times a year, they pass judgment on the creditworthiness of major third world and other countries.

headline: B.N.O.C. Said To Pay More
abstract: The British National Oil Corporation has proposed raising the price it will pay its suppliers for the major grade of North Sea oil by 40 cents a barrel, to $27.90, European oil industry sources said today.   B.N.O.C., which the British Government is in the process of removing from the oil-trading business, started paying market-related prices for oil earlier this year and has refused to announce official prices.   While the reported price proposed for May shipments of Brent grade crude is up from the $27.50 a barrel in effect in April, it is below the $28.65 that prevailed for the previous five months and the $30-a-barrel level before that.

headline: TECHNOLOGY;  Robots That 'See' and 'Feel'
abstract: TWO robots are working together in a manufacturing cell assembling oil pump units for an automobile engine. One uses a remotely mounted television camera to ''look'' at the small castings that are the top and bottom of the pump housing as they move along a conveyor belt. When it recognizes a bottom part, it reaches out, picks it up and places it on a fixture.  Then the other robot, which has a camera mounted on its arm, looks for one of the two gears that make up the internal mechanism of the pump. Placing one inside the housing, it reaches for the other gear and attempts to mesh the two together.

headline: ADVERTISING ;Nadler & Larimer
abstract: Nadler & Larimer, which lost the major part of its fragrance business to Kenyon & Eckhardt last year, has agreed to part with those advertisers altogether on Aug. 1 so that it can go out and seek some new fragrance clients.  That means giving up the shampoo brands, which will probably go to K.&E., too. The fragrances were Brut for men and Babe for women. N.& L. is a subsidiary of the Mickelberry Company. K.&E. is a subsidiary of Lorimar.

headline: Nuclear Plant Suit Is Lost
abstract: The State of Washington is not responsible for $7.25 billion in bonds and interest lost by investors after a public utility association canceled two nuclear power plants, a Superior Court judge ruled today.   Judge Terrence Carroll dismissed the suit brought against the state by investors seeking the value of their bonds, $2.25 billion plus $5 billion in interest, bought from the Washington Public Power Supply System.   Judge Carroll said he ''categorically rejects'' any attempt to make the state responsible for bonds bought from the supply system, which consists of 88 utilities.

headline: AGCA IMPLICATES AN ITALIAN BEING HELD IN NEW YORK
abstract: Mehmet Ali Agca said today that a businessman wanted for involvement in Italian political and financial scandals had visited him in jail and urged him to implicate Bulgaria in a purported plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II.   But Mr. Agca, the Turkish gunman who shot and wounded the Pope in 1981, insisted that ''no one suggested anything to me'' about Bulgarian involvement. He said it represented his ''own personal truth.''   He also said today that at least three Turkish gunmen were in St. Peter's Square the day of the shooting.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Litigant Battles Western Union
abstract: Abraham Feldman has won a court victory against the Western Union Telegraph Company, the principal subsidiary of the financially troubled Western Union Corporation, and now he is looking forward to a large sum from the troubled company.    Last Wednesday, Western Union Telegraph was found guilty by a Federal court jury in Chicago of monopolistic practices against two teleprinter companies that Mr. Feldman founded in the 1970's, the Olympia Equipment Company and the Alfco Telecommunications Company.    The jury, which heard evidence for six months and spent between six to seven hours before delivering its verdict, awarded Mr. Feldman $24 million, a figure that was automatically trebled by Federal District Judge Charles P. Kocoras, as dictated by Federal antitrust laws. Another $30 million was awarded in contract claims, raising the size of Mr. Feldman's potential award to $102 million.

headline: Gandhi Meets Mubarak
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India met with President Hosni Mubarak today after his arrival in Cairo, his first stop on a five-nation tour that will take him to Europe and the United States.

headline: C.I.A. Chief Said to Urge Manila to Move Up Vote
abstract: Newsweek reports in its current issue that William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, has told President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines that the White House wants Manila to hold an election before Mr. Marcos's term expires in 1987.   The magazine quotes unidentified sources as saying the message was delivered by Mr. Casey last week during an unpublicized meeting in Manila.

headline: Advertising;   Beber Silverstein On Move
abstract: RECENTLY Pfizer Inc. decided to assign the creative work for its Coty's Sophia fragrance and Musk for Men to Beber Silverstein & Partners.    A short time earlier the State, County and Municipal Employees union also decided to take their account to Beber Silverstein.    What do you suppose such a diverse pair of advertisers see in this agency that they are willing to commit a portion of their future into its care?    George M. Klas with his touch of English accent would probably say ''tenacity, talent and perseverance.'' But, then, he's been vice president and general manager of the agency's New York office for 15 months. Perhaps he's biased.

headline: Quebec Liberal to Seek To Bring Down Levesque
abstract: Robert Bourassa, leader of the Liberal Party in Quebec, said yesterday that he intended to introduce a no-confidence motion on June 14 to defeat the governing Parti Quebecois government.   Mr. Bourassa and three other Liberals were elected to the Quebec legislature, called the National Assembly, in by-elections on Monday.

headline: Addenda
abstract: Cahners Publishing Co., Newton, Mass., part of Reed International P.L.C. of London, has acquired Physicians' Travel and Meeting Guide, a quarterly.    * Roberta Greene, formerly executive vice president of Rogers & Cowan's corporate division, New York, has formed her own public relations firm, Roberta Greene & Associates.

headline: Fannie Mae Rate Down
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association's yield requirement for 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage loans it buys from lenders is 12.1 percent, the lowest in two years, it said today.

headline: AIDE SAYS KOHL WILL NOT SUGGEST ALTERNATIVE TO BITBURG CEMETERY
abstract: A close aide to Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that in a telephone call to President Reagan last Friday the West German leader obtained a firm promise that the American would not change his plans to visit a German military cemetery.   According to the aide, Mr. Kohl had placed the call to Mr. Reagan after hearing that the President was being advised to call off the visit.    The aide also said Mr. Kohl had no intention of suggesting an alternative site to the cemetery at Bitburg because of the uproar over the graves of 47 Waffen SS soldiers among its 2,000 dead. Sen. Bob Dole suggested Sunday that ''maybe Chancellor Kohl could be helpful'' in coming up with an alternative.   In the 20-minute telephone conversation, the aide said, Mr. Kohl impressed on the President the importance of the Bitburg visit and found Mr. Reagan receptive. The Chancellor said that since the cemetery was formally opened in 1959, after scattered war dead had been brought there, American, French and West German officers have held a ceremony there every November.

headline: ITALY SEEKING TO CUT FALLOUT FROM THE TRIAL
abstract: An Italian diplomat, in a recent conversation, was upbraided by a Bulgarian colleague. The Bulgarian said the trial here that is examining a possible conspiracy, involving Bulgarian citizens, to assassinate Pope John Paul II slandered Bulgarian Communism and undermined East-West ties.   The Italian shrugged and replied, ''The problem is yours, not ours.''   ''Learn to be silent,'' he went on. ''And if there is a conviction, simply say: 'These are the scum of the Bulgarian nation. Anyone who would dare to shoot the Pope of Rome offends against the ideals of Bulgarian Communism.' ''

headline: Addenda
abstract: * New Woman magazine's rate base will increase 15 percent, to 1.15 million, with its August issue, and its advertising rates will also increase 15 percent.

headline: The Day's Developments
abstract: Hostage Separation Confirmed - A Berri aide confirmed that 6 to 10 hostages had been held separately, suspected of having ''Zionist connections.'' Page A6.

headline: WRITER WAS WORLD BANK AIDE
abstract: William Donaldson Clark, a writer, diplomat, and former vice president of the World Bank, died Thursday night of liver cancer at his home in the Oxfordshire village of Cuxham. He was 68 years old.   Mr. Clark was a leading Fleet Street figure in the early 1950's as a foreign affairs correspondent for The Observer. In 1955, he became press adviser to the Prime Minister, Sir Anthony Eden, but he resigned the next year after Britain, France and Egypt invaded Egypt, which had nationalized the Suez Canal.

headline: TRUST SUIT DROPPED BY CHRYSLER
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it had dropped an antitrust suit seeking to stop the joint production of Chevrolet Nova cars in California by the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan.    Richard Goodyear, vice president and chief lawyer for Chrysler, said he could not comment on the reasons for the out-of-court settlement because its contents were sealed by the United States District Court in Washington, where the suit was filed in January 1984.    Chrysler's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, had denounced the G.M.-Toyota accord as an illegal linkup of industrial giants that could severely damage competition in the industry.

headline: Big Board View Of Allis Move
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange has advised the Allis-Chalmers Corporation that, according to the exchange's interpretation of its shareholder approval rules, the company's conversion of debt to equity last month should have had prior shareholder approval. Allis-Chalmers said that the exchange would ''technically commence delisting proceedings,'' but that its stock would continue to trade while the exchange completed a review of its shareholder approval policies.   On May 24, the Milwaukee company announced a recapitalization plan in conjunction with the sale of its agricultural equipment unit to a West German concern, that called, in part, for converting certain debt and a series of preferred stock to equity.

headline: South Korea Accepts North's Plan for Talks
abstract: South Korea's National Assembly decided today to accept a North Korean proposal for preliminary discussions in July that are intended to set up political talks between the legislatures of the two countries.   Replying to the North Korean offer, the Assembly adopted a message approving contacts between five representatives from each of the two parliaments.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;Journalists in Italy Strike Over Wages
abstract: Italian journalists working for newspapers and the Government broadcasting network went on strike today, creating a news blackout in the country.         Journalists have stopped work several times, but today was the first time in  several years that the country was simultaneously without news from newspapers,  radio and television.

headline: Macmillan Offers Convertible Issue
abstract: Macmillan Inc., the book publisher, is offering $75 million of 7 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2010, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.   The debentures, which are offered at face value, may be converted into common stock any time before maturity at $41.75 a share. Proceeds from the sale will be used for general corporate purposes, including future acquisitions, the company said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 24, 1985        The Economy         The Consumer Price Index rose last month by the largest amount in more than a year. The 0.5 percent rise was led by a surge in gasoline prices. (Page A1.) Consumer prices in New York and northeastern New Jersey rose 0.2 percent. (D22.)

headline: 3 IN POLAND SENTENCED TO PRISON FOR PLANNING A STRIKE
abstract: Three political activists were sentenced today to terms ranging from two to three and a half years after being found guilty of fomenting civil disorder by planning a 15-minute strike. The strike never took place.   In a hushed Gdansk courtroom, Judge Krzysztof Zieniuk declared that the 11-day proceedings did not constitute ''a political trial but just a normal trial.''   Then, in what relatives of the defendants described as a calm, low voice, he read off the sentences.

headline: TRADE GAP SWELLS TO $12.7 BILLION
abstract: The nation's trade deficit swelled to $12.7 billion in May, the second-highest total on record, the Commerce Department reported today.   Imports climbed to a near-record $30.1 billion, while exports sank to the lowest level in 15 months, the department said.   The growth in imports and the weakness in exports left the trade deficit 6.9 percent higher last month than the $11.9 billion imbalance in April. The May deficit was the highest since a record $13.8 billion in red ink suffered last July.

headline: Philippine Journalist Slain at Beauty Pageant
abstract: Gunmen shot and killed a commentator for a labor-run radio station as he watched his 19-year-old daughter compete in a beauty contest in the central Philippines, officials said today.   The commentator, Nabokodonosor Velez, 47 years old, was the second from station DYLA to be slain in five months and the 11th Philippine journalist to be killed since January 1984.

headline: Bethlehem and Armco Have Losses in Quarter
abstract: Two more steel companies, Bethlehem and Armco, yesterday reported losses for the first quarter as the industry's bad times continued.    The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported that its loss widened to $62.1 million, from a $54.6 million deficit in the comparable period last year. It said, however, that it expected to be marginally profitable in the current quarter.

headline: PROUD AUSTRALIAN A HIT AS TV ENVOY
abstract: An ocker, according to the Macquarie Dictionary, the guide to Australian English, is ''the archetypal uncultivated Australian working man,'' who is ''boorish, uncouth and chauvinistic.''   Paul Hogan, a Sydney bridge painter-turned-comedian, is considered an ocker (pronounced AW-ker). He is sometimes called the ''Archie Bunker of Australia,'' an image he has nurtured for fame and profit here.   No harm in that, except when Mr. Hogan became the national spokesman last year in a series of television advertisements promoting Australia to Americans as a tourist destination.

headline: Banker Sues E.S.M. Auditor
abstract: Marvin L. Warner has filed a $1.15 billion lawsuit against Alexander Grant & Company, the accounting firm that audited the since-collapsed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., a lawyer for Mr. Warner said today.   The suit, filed in Federal District Court, contends that the Chicago-based auditors ''participated with E.S.M. Government Securities in a conspiracy and scheme to defraud Warner and corporations in which he had an interest,'' said John Averill, the lawyer representing Mr. Warner.

headline: EGYPTIANS AND ISRAELIS AGREE ON TERMS FOR IMPROVING TIES
abstract: Egyptian and Israeli negotiators concluded three days of talks here today by agreeing to present to their Governments a package of measures intended to improve relations.   Israeli and Egyptian officials failed to agree on the fate of Taba, a 700-yard strip of beachfront land in Sinai that both sides claim.   Israeli negotiators argued that the issue should be submitted to nonbinding arbitration, whereas Egypt insisted that Taba's fate be decided by binding arbitration.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The Tandy Corporation said that it had cut the price of its Tandy 1000 personal computer to $999, from $1,199. The company also introduced peripherals for the computer, including a built-in 10-megabyte Winchester disk drive for $1,199 and an external 10-megabyte drive for $699.

headline: CORPORATE FEVER HITS THE ESKIMOS
abstract: EARLIER this month, the Canadian Government auctioned off its Northern Transportation Company Ltd., a 51-year-old company that had revenues of more than $30 million last year from transporting freight over 5,000 miles of water routes in the Canadian North. The Ministry of Transport accepted the winning bid in principle on May 17. If all goes as planned, the company will belong to the Inuvialuit Development Corporation of the western Arctic and the Nunasi Corporation of the eastern Arctic, a consortium of Eskimos who just a few years ago knew little more about business than the hunting and selling of fur pelts.   The native Canadians - particularly the Inuvialuit, as the approximately 3,000 people living along the Beaufort Sea of the western Arctic call themselves - have come a long way since 1977, when they began complaining about the oil companies' search for petroleum under the Beaufort Sea. The seismic blasting, clatter of helicopters and other activity, they said, discouraged the fish from spawning, scattered the whales, frightened away the snow geese - in general, started to destroy the fragile environment that provided their livelihood.

headline: SEARS: A GIANT GROWS BIGGER
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Company, long viewed as a stodgy giant, is now moving in so many new directions at once that it seems almost dizzying.   On the financial side, the nation's No. 1 retailer will introduce its long-awaited general purpose credit card, named Discover, in Atlanta this fall, to be followed by nationwide distribution next year. It also recently purchased a bank in Delaware and is negotiating to buy another in South Dakota.   And it has installed 306 Sears Financial Network centers - combinations of insurance, securities and real estate brokerages - in its stores. The centers consist of three Sears subsidiaries - an Allstate insurance broker, a Dean Witter securities borker, and a Coldwell Banker real estate broker.

headline: Doctors in the Sudan Call for a General Strike
abstract: Doctors extended a work stoppage today and called for a general strike to unseat President Gaafar al- Nimeiry, who is visiting the United States.   President Nimeiry, who is scheduled to meet Monday with President Reagan, left this North African country last week as rioting broke out to protest steep increases in the prices of food and essential commodities.

headline: A.T.&T., QUOTRON DEAL LIKELY
abstract: Entering a crowded but growing market, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is expected to announce today that it is joining with Quotron Systems Inc. to provide up-to-the-minute financial information and data-processing abilities to stockbrokers and other investors.   The joint venture's first customer will be Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., which has committed itself to buy a number of A.T.&T. computers equipped to receive Quotron's service. Eventually, if Shearson Lehman likes the service, it could equip all of its 5,500 brokers with A.T.&T. personal computers. Neither A.T.&T. nor Shearson Lehman would discuss their arrangement before a news conference this morning in New York. And a spokesman for Los Angeles-based Quotron said executives were traveling and could not be reached.

headline: Fare Discounts Set by United
abstract: United Airlines today announced a series of marketing promotions aimed at winning back customers following settlement of the 29-day strike by the airline's pilots.   The carrier will offer a 50 percent cash rebate on tickets for passengers flying between July 1 and July 7.

headline: RENAULT SEEN SET FOR A.M.C. LOAN
