abstract: France's state-owned auto producer, Renault, is planning to lend $175 million to its 46 percent owned American company, the American Motors Corporation, a union official said in Paris yesterday.

headline: Khmer Rouge Said to Kill 28
abstract: Khmer Rouge guerrillas said today that they had killed 28 Vietnamese soldiers and wounded 34 in an attack on a Vietnamese base in southwestern Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge radio, monitored in Bangkok, said the battle took place Monday near Koh Konglue in Koh Kong province. Khmer Rouge claims cannot be independently verified, and are often regarded as exaggerated.

headline: GULF FOES CALLED STILL WIDE APART
abstract: The Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar, left Baghdad today saying the gap between Iran and Iraq was ''as wide as ever.''    In the Persian Gulf war, which began in September 1980, Iraqi planes raided two Iranian cities today and Iran accused its enemy of using poison gas.    Iraq said its jet fighters attacked a tanker in the Gulf, in its campaign against the oil imports that finance Iran's war effort, but there was no confirmation from shipping sources.

headline: Chess Rematch Is Now Set For Moscow Starting Sept. 2
abstract: The head of the International Chess Federation said today that the world title rematch between Anatoly Karpov, the champion, and Gary Kasparov, the challenger, will start in Moscow on Sept. 2.   The chess president, Florencio Campomanes of the Philippines, said at a news conference that the match would have a 24-game limit and that whoever won six games or 12.5 points would be declared champion.

headline: Four Books on Investing
abstract: SEX AND MONEY: Behnd the Scenes With the Big-Time Brokers. By John D. Spooner. 258 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95.   EVERY now and again something stands out. Sometimes it is a tantalizing ad, sometimes a lapel pin. But more often than not it is one of those proclamations about the potential for easy money. In other words, how to make it big in the stock market, and make it fast. It is a fact that library bookshelves are laden with volumes that purport to offer the sound and secret wisdom of financial investment experts. It is also a fact that many of those books fail to deliver on any of their promises. So what could possibly be intriguing about yet another Wall Street book, even with a title such as ''Sex and Money''? Yet the book begins with a disclaimer: ''But you should pay attention. The lessons you may learn here are as real as your losses all these years in the stock market.''

headline: RETURN OF CUBA FROM U.S. IS 'GOING WELL'
abstract: A number of Cuban refugees who have been returned here from the United States because of histories of criminal offenses or mental illness are ''back at home and living completely normal lives,'' according to a senior Cuban official.   Others among some 200 refugees who began returning to Cuba in February are still in medical quarantine, the official, the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Ricardo Alarcon, said in an interview. Still others, who were accused of committing crimes in the United States, have been sent to prison, he said.   United States officials here said they had not been physically monitoring the return of the refugees, which will eventually reach the rate of 100 a month. But they said that they believed it was ''going very well'' and that they had no reason to suspect that the refugees were being mistreated.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: June 20, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Israel and Egypt Plan Talks; First Since Sadat and Begin
abstract: Egyptian and Israeli officials are drafting plans for the countries' first talks since Anwar el-Sadat met with Menachem Begin, Israeli officials in Cairo and Jerusalem said today.

headline: RIPLEY CO.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: REAGAN'S PEACE PROPOSAL: IDEAS LONG OPPOSED BY SANDINISTAS
abstract: In his proposal for peace negotiations with Nicaragua today, President Reagan listed provisions that the Sandinistas have said they would never accept.  ''The bottom line'' of the Reagan proposal, a senior Administration official said today ''is new elections in Nicaragua,'' an idea the Sandinista Government has said was not open for negotiation.    The Nicaraguan Ambassador here, Carlos Tunnerman Bernheim, said today, ''I don't see any reason we should take recognition away from legitimate elections, just because the Administration didn't like the results.''    In addition, Mr. Reagan tied postponement of renewed military aid for the Nicaraguan rebels to an agreement that the Sandinistas would sit at the bargaining table with anti-Sandinista rebel leaders.

headline: Petrofina Aim
abstract: American Petrofina Inc., based here, is seeking a merger, according to James Henderson, the company's general manager for acquisitions. Mr. Henderson said the company's parent, Petrofina S.A., seeks a $200 million to $400 million acquisition of an American energy company. He said, however, that ''we haven't found one that meets our objectives.

headline: WEILL'S DEPARTURE AT AMERICAN EXPRESS
abstract: It came as no surprise to anyone who knows Sanford I. Weill well that he had decided to resign as president of the American Express Company, a $62 billion conglomerate with a diverse range of businesses and run by a large bureaucracy.   An entrepreneur with a deft financial touch and a passion for making deals, Mr. Weill began to long once again for a chance to run a company his own way, rather than holding the No. 2 job. This desire was evident when Mr. Weill said yesterday in an interview: ''Whatever I do next, I will want to be the top person in it.''   It was four years that ago that Mr. Weill, now 52 years old, sold Shearson Loeb Rhoades, the large brokerage company he built through acquisitions over 21 years, to American Express for about $1 billion. He traded his control for a personal gain of about $30 million and the opportunity to help shape the much larger financial conglomerate.

headline: McGraw-Hill Videotex Talks
abstract: McGraw-Hill Inc. said that it had held discussions with Tele-Communications Inc., a Colorado cable company, about a possible joint videotex venture, which would provide data for homes and small businesses using cable television.

headline: PERFECT FIT MERGER
abstract: Perfect Fit Inc., a furniture company, said it had entered into a definitive merger agreement providing for its acquisition by Home Furnishings Enterprises Inc., a new corporation, for about $33.6 million. The new company is owned by Joseph Vitale, president and chief executive of Perfect Fit, certain other members of Perfect Fit's management and other investors.

headline: Election Board Chief In Peru Is Wounded
abstract: The president of the National Election Board in Peru was shot several times in the face as he rode to his office today, and the Government blamed the Maoist guerrilla group Shining Path, which had threatened to disrupt presidential elections held April 14.

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS INCOME UP
abstract: The American Express Company reported a 30.5 percent increase in first-quarter earnings, reflecting an improved performance from its Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. subsidiary and a narrowing of losses in its cable television business.    The company earned $151.6 million, or 67 cents a share, on revenues of $3.4 billion. This compares with a net income of $116.2 million, or 54 cents a share, on revenues of $2.9 billion in the 1984 first quarter.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: 'CBS is strong; CBS is healthy. . . . To throw this away would be a tragedy.'      William S. Paley   Founder and former chairman, CBS Inc.

headline: EASING THE TAX BITE FROM A SUMMER JOB
abstract: IF your teen-ager is one of the lucky few who have landed a steady job for the summer - say, working on a construction crew or serving up ice cream sundaes at the local soda shop - be sure that he or she is not making an interest-free loan to the United States Treasury at the same time.   If your youngster does not take the steps to prevent taxes from being automatically withheld from his or her paycheck, that is what will happen - even if the summer earnings are sparse enough to be exempt from Federal income tax. Your youngster will be entitled to a refund if tax is withheld - but only after filing a tax return next April.   ''Many working kids are under the impression they must have income tax withheld,'' said Randy Bruce Blaustein of Siegel, Mendlowitz & Rich, a New York accounting firm. ''They often don't realize they may have the right to be exempt'' from withholding, he added.

headline: Lebanon Hair Salons Reopen
abstract: Hairdressers in this northern Lebanese port resumed work today after closing for a week under pressure from Islamic fundamentalist militiamen, local hairdressers said. The fundamentalists allowed them to reopen on the condition that only women would be allowed to cut women's hair. The hairdressers said four salons were bombed during the last 10 days because men on the salons' staffs were dealing with women.

headline: Data Bank;   April 7, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: Chinese Rat Control: A Recipe for Success
abstract: Marinated rat steaks and rat-skin shoes are popular in some areas of rural China and are a good way to help control the pests that are said to consume 15 million tons of grain a year, a newspaper said today.   The official English-language newspaper China Daily said live rats were being sold in the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region of southern China for about 50 cents a pound, almost as much as chicken.   ''In Fujian Province, local people hail rat steak as the best steak in the world,'' it said, quoting a report in the Chinese-language newspaper Economic Information.

headline: NICARAGUAN REBELS APPEAR READY TO FIGHT ON EVEN IF AID IS CUT OFF
abstract: Despite serious political and military problems, guerrillas fighting the Nicaraguan Government have achieved a base of popular support, and their war is likely to continue whether or not Congress votes to give them assistance, according to Nicaraguan refugees, rebels and Western diplomats in the region.    Visits to rebel bases and Nicaraguan refugee camps in the last month indicate that the guerrillas are growing in number and that they have been able to pose a significant threat to the Sandinista Government. Their principal support seems to lie in northern Nicaragua, where the level of fighting and the number of exiles fleeing to Honduras appear to indicate that something close to civil war is being waged.        Outlook of 2 Salvadorans    Two Salvadoran guerrilla officials who have spent considerable time in Nicaragua said in separate interviews that they believed the anti-Sandinista rebels were a serious problem. One of the Salvadorans has been involved in organizing the left for over 20 years.

headline: Signal Companies
abstract: Forrest M. Shumway, chairman and chief executive of the Signal Companies, confirmed today that the company is considering a bid for the Hughes Aircraft Company. Speaking at Signal's annual meeting in San Diego, Mr. Shumway said the company is ''taking a long, hard look'' at the aerospace concern, which is up for sale by the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. So far, only Signal and the Allied Corporation have publicly announced their interest in Hughes.

headline: Dynamics Inquiries Reported
abstract: The Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission are investigating charges that payments made by the General Dynamics Corporation to overseas consultants were used to bribe foreign officials, a Congressional source said today.    The investigations were said to have begun after a March 25 hearing of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's oversight subpanel, in which David S. Lewis, chairman of General Dynamics, was questioned about payments to the Buyeon Company, a South Korean consulting firm.    Mr. Lewis denied that payments of hundreds of thousands of dollars to E.Y. Yoon, a member of the firm, were improper, or that company funds had ever been used to bribe foreign officials in order to sell General Dynamics products.

headline: Woodward's Loses Officer in Bid Fight
abstract: Six weeks ago, Grant Woodward MacLaren, the 52-year-old president of Woodward's Ltd., was declared the successor to Charles Woodward as chairman and chief executive officer of the Canadian retailing giant as part of the company's pending sale to the Cadillac Fairview Corporation. Mr. Woodward, 61, intended to retire. But last Friday Mr. MacLaren ended his dealings with Cadillac and resigned as president and a director after a dispute with his cousin, Mr. Woodward, over an unexpected, competing proposal for the Vancouver company made by Cambridge Shopping Centres of Toronto.   A new president will be named within days and sources close to the situation expect that Frank Robertson, executive vice president, will win the post.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Floods in Brazil Kill at Least 27
abstract: Severe flooding brought on by heavy rainstorms has driven more than 500,000 people from their homes across northeastern Brazil, according to the Government.

headline: AGCA SAYS BULGARIA ABETTED A TERRORIST GROUP IN TURKEY
abstract: The Turkish terrorist who shot and wounded Pope John Paul II testified today that members of the Turkish underworld, working with the Bulgarian authorities, helped finance terrorism to undermine Turkey's civilian Government in the late 1970's.   The Turk, Mehmet Ali Agca, who is serving a life term for the assassination attempt in 1981, also told a court here that he was trained in the art of terrorism, including the use of guns and bombs, in 1977 at a Syrian camp in Latakia that was run by Bulgarians and Czechoslovaks under the direction of the Syrian secret service.   Lifting his voice, and speaking of the Syrian experience as if enunciating a formal pronouncement, he added: ''I learned with certainty that the political and financial center of international terrorism was the Soviet Union.''

headline: New Quarterly Aims At Black Professionals
abstract: Corporate Headquarters is the name of a new quarterly publication on employment opportunities for black professionals that is due out in May. It is being published in Westfield, N.J., by Harold E. Fisher.

headline: FRENCH AND SWISS WILLING TO ACCEPT FREED HOSTAGES, BUT NOT HOLD THEM
abstract: France and Switzerland said in separate announcements today that they were willing to take the 39 American hostages into their Beirut embassies, but were not willing to act, in effect, as jailers.   The French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, said today that France could not take custody of the 39 Americans being held in Beirut unless they were turned over to the French as free men.   In Bern, a Swiss Foreign Ministry spokesman said that Switzerland was willing to welcome the captives ''in its embassy in Beirut, but without any conditions, and with the assurance of being able to freely transfer them to Switzerland or wherever, and release them.''   Mr. Dumas, who made his comments on a radio interview here this morning, implicitly rejected an offer by the Lebanese Shiite leader, Nabih Berri, that the hostages be turned over to a Western embassy in Beirut on condition that they be held there until 735 detainees, most of them Lebanese Shiites, are released by Israel.

headline: Medicus Intercon Wins Top Spot in Health Care
abstract: It appears that Sudler & Hennessey has been toppled from its No. 1 position as the biggest specialty agency in the health care field. And they have been toppled by Medicus Intercon International, which acquired the ADA Group in London, pushing its worldwide billings to a projected 1985 figure of $160 million from $136 million last year. S.&H. clocked $137 million in 1984.

headline: Chevron Capital
abstract: Chevron Capital U.S.A. is offering $300 million of 10 3/4 percent, 10-year notes at a price of 99.576 to yield 10.82 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The securities are rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: 2 Earthquakes Hit Indonesia
abstract: Two strong earthquakes rocked separate areas in Indonesia today, the national meteorological agency said.

headline: NIKE STRUGGLES TO HIT ITS STRIDE AGAIN
abstract: This article is one of an occasional series of journalistic case studies, modeled on a technique widely used in business schools to examine management problems. After a brief review of a company's history - in this case Nike Inc. - several interested outsiders offer their solutions to its recent problems. CAN the runner who stumbles still win the race?   Executives at Nike Inc., the nation's leading manufacturer of athletic shoes, are asking that question a lot these days. Nike's earnings declined 29 percent in the fiscal year 1984, the first drop in 10 years. ''Orwell was right: 1984 was a tough year,'' Philip H. Knight, Nike's co-founder, chairman and chief executive, said in the company's annual report.

headline: ETHIOPIA REFUGEES LEAVING THE SUDAN
abstract: Relief officials and Western diplomats here say they fear for the lives of thousands of Ethiopians now returning from refugee camps in the Sudan.   Up to 50,000 people are said to be heading for their homes in Tigre and, to a lesser extent, Eritrea, regions that have suffered the combined effects of famine and chronic warfare between Government troops and rebels.   According to reports from the Sudan, the refugees are leaving of their own free will. They have told relief workers that ''they are returning because they have heard rains have arrived and they need to plant their fields,'' one such report said.

headline: RALLY TIED TO POLICY REPORTS
abstract: Hints of a slightly more generous monetary policy were enough to bring lower interest rates to the Treasury note and bond market last week, despite a heavy supply of new issues and widespread skepticism that the rate declines would endure through the spring and summer.     Although there were no conclusive, overt signals of a change in Fed monetary policy, there were enough hints for market participants to quickly set aside their earlier fears of an imminent rise in rates.    ''The atmospherics of the fixed-income markets continue to shift abruptly,'' said Alan C. Lerner, senior vice president at the Bankers Trust Company. He attributed it to market participants reacting to new economic statistics and ''subtle gradations in the conduct of monetary policy.''

headline: MISTAKE, ENVOYS SAY
abstract: A United States Embassy van loaded with sophisticated electronic equipment was seized by Mexican customs agents Monday, and American diplomats said today that it was all an innocent mistake.   The van, bearing diplomatic plates, was impounded along with its contents after Mexican customs agents found that it had none of the necessary permits for the equipment it carried.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Caterpillar Names A New President
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the world's largest maker of earth- moving and heavy construction machinery, yesterday named Peter Donis president and chief operating officer, effective June 1. He succeeds Robert E. Gilmore, who will retire after turning 65 next month.   Mr. Donis, who is 60 years old, has been executive vice president of the financially troubled company since 1977. Several analysts said yesterday that they were somewhat surprised by the appointment.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Bass Exports to Stan Merritt Inc. for beer from Britain.    * Emmis Broadcasting Corporation, Indianapolis, to Fallon McElligott Rice, Minneapolis.

headline: PENTAGON SAYS SECRET PRESS PLAN WENT AWRY
abstract: The Pentagon said today that it conducted a test Sunday of arrangements for letting a selected group of reporters cover a secret military operation, and that the experiment had gone awry when news of it reached other reporters.     Ten reporters were flown to Honduras early Sunday morning under an agreement of strict secrecy. Their news organizations were not told that they were going to watch United States troops in training exercises. Such a group, whose purpose is to represent all news outlets, is called a ''pool.''

headline: EXCERPTS FROM AN INTERVIEW WITH RABIN
abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview with Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' as recorded by The New York Times:   Q. Mr. Rabin, as you have heard, CBS News is reporting that in your Cabinet session this morning Israel decided to release 31 of the Shiite prisoners. Can you confirm this?   A. Yes. We are going to release them tomorrow morning. Q. Why did you make this decision? A. Well, look, our policy vis-a-vis the Lebanese detainees, was and is to keep them as long as we are going to complete our withdrawal from Lebanon, but mainly in relation to the development of the security situation in southern Lebanon. In addition to that, we are bound by the Israeli law. And in accordance to the Israeli law, every detainee can appeal to a special committee, which is headed by a district judge. And these people appealed, some of them. Some of them, we came to the conclusion that we'll not be able to convince the committee, and, therefore, we decided to release. They are not the first to be released this way. Since we've brought them, from April, we've released eight before, or even more than that, as a result of the legal procedure in accordance to the Israeli law. Therefore, it is not linked whatsoever to the problem that the United States, Israel, and the whole world are facing today in regards to the hostages in Beirut.

headline: EASTERN WEIGHS T.W.A. BID
abstract: Eastern Airlines is exploring whether it wants to make a bid for Trans World Airlines, Richard McGraw, the senior vice president of communications at Eastern, announced yesterday.   ''At this point we don't know whether we have any interest,'' said Mr. McGraw, who added that the process might take a week or more. ''We are trying to determine that.''

headline: Eaton Seeks Deal
abstract: The Eaton Corporation is in a position to make a $1 billion acquisition and is considering possible companies to complement its electrical and electronics business, its president, James R. Stover, told securities analysts. Mr. Stover said any major acquisition would probably be in the semiconductor equipment or defense sectors. He said the transaction could be accomplished with the company using a 40 percent debt-to-capital ratio.

headline: Boesky Stake
abstract: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, holds a 9.8 percent stake in the Southland Financial Corporation, he disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Boesky said he had bought 1.6 million Southland shares as part of the ''general investment activities'' of several companies he controls and not to gain control of Southland. He said he had paid $29.4 million for his stake.

headline: MANY IN NEW YORK WOULD FACE A LOWER TAX
abstract: For all the debate over how President Reagan's tax proposals would affect New York, some New Yorkers who would lose large deductions for state and local taxes would nevertheless pay lower Federal income taxes, according to quick calculations by a major accounting company.   One example of a family that could gain even though it would lose substantial deductions would be a two-income couple with two children living in Westchester County and earning $80,000 annually. A similar family earning $50,000 and living in New York City would also pay lower Federal taxes under the Administration's proposal, as would a single person making $23,000.

headline: BANGLADESHIS SAY 10,000 MAY BE LOST IN CYCLONE'S WAKE
abstract: Government authorities, widening search and rescue efforts in the islands of southeastern Bangladesh, said tonight that as many as 10,000 people were now believed missing and feared dead after a cyclone devastated the area over the weekend.   The seas were reported littered with floating bodies. The Government-run Bangladesh radio said that 80 percent of croplands had been devastated and that it was feared that 500,000 head of cattle were missing. News reports said hundreds of fishing boats had been swamped in a fishing area critical to the nation's economy.

headline: REAGAN CALLS PLAN REVENUE-NEUTRAL
abstract: President Reagan insisted today that his sweeping tax revision plan would close loopholes and lower tax rates without a loss in revenue to the Federal Government.   Mr. Reagan offered that view a day after the Congressional Budget Office estimated that the Administration's plan would cost the Government a significant amount of revenue over the next 15 years. The nonpartisan Budget Office based its estimate on a projected drop, as a percentage of the gross national product, in receipts from corporate taxes between 1990 and 2000 as some parts of the plan are phased in and others phased out.

headline: American Said to Help Seize Guerrilla Leader in Salvador
abstract: An American working on private contract to the Salvadoran Air Force accompanied the Salvadoran military unit that captured a senior guerrilla commander last month, according to Salvadoran officials and a United States Embassy spokesman.   They said the American, a specialist on infrared vision equipment, was invited by a Salvadoran officer with whom he was acquainted to go on the daytime helicopter attack that captured the rebel commander, Nidia Diaz.

headline: Ex-Sperry Executive Is Moving to Datapoint
abstract: John C. Butler, a veteran executive of the Sperry Corporation, has been named chief operating officer and a director of the Datapoint Corporation, the financially troubled computer maker based in San Antonio.   The chief operating officer's post has been vacant since March, when Asher B. Edelman, the New York financier, took over Datapoint and replaced Harold E. O'Kelley, 59, as chairman. Edward P. Gistaro, 49, formerly president and chief operating officer, then became president and chief executive, jobs he retains.

headline: SHIITE IS SAID TO OFFER TO SEND HOSTAGES TO SWITZERLAND IN EXCHANGE
abstract: The Swiss Government said today that Nabih Berri, the leader of the Lebanese Shiite militia Amal, had formally offered to send the American hostages in Beirut to Switzerland if the Lebanese prisoners held by Israel are released, as the Americans' captors are demanding.   The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Edward Brunner, said that Mr. Berri made the offer to the Swiss Foreign Minister, Pierre Aubert, in a telephone call last Thursday, and that it was formally delivered Friday to the American and Israeli Embassies in Bern, the Swiss capital.   Mr. Brunner and other Foreign Ministry officials said, however, that they had received no formal response from either embassy, and stressed that they were playing only a ''postman'' role and not negotiating on behalf of Mr. Berri or the hijackers of the Trans World Airlines jetliner seized June 14.   ''Our position is very clear,'' Mr. Brunner said during an interview with Swiss television. ''We do not want to be the instruments of a deal, or a blackmail opportunity.''

headline: CHURCH READY TO MEDIATE
abstract: The Roman Catholic Primate of Nicaragua said today that the church hierarchy was ready to mediate the Nicaraguan conflict, but only if both sides accepted its services.     The Primate, Archbishop Miguel Obando y Bravo, has been a forceful critic of the Nicaraguan Government, and he said today of the Sandinistas that ''it seems they are not ready for a dialogue with elements that have taken up arms.''

headline: IN MOSCOW, A BACH MASS AND THE RUMBLE OF TANKS
abstract: The audience at a performance of Bach's B-minor mass at a concert hall here the other night was caught by surprise during the intermission by a column of T-64 tanks rolling down the street outside.   As the orchestra waited for the rumbling to stop, the T-64's were followed by T-72 tanks, their machinery creaking and clanking and their 125-millimeter cannons bobbing.   ''Don't worry, they're ours,'' joked a concertgoer on returning to his seat.   The tanks were heading for Red Square for a rehearsal of what may be the biggest Soviet military parade since the end of World War II.

headline: West German Vessels Collide
abstract: A West German Navy submarine collided with the motor vessel Wilhelmine Oltmann in fog today near the mouth of the Kiel Canal, the coastal police said.

headline: Inventories Down 0.1%, Sales Up 0.4% in March
abstract: Business inventories fell one-tenth of 1 percent in March, the first decline in two years, as sales rose a modest four-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.   The increase in sales and slight drop in inventories left the ratio of inventories to sales at 1.38 in March, the same as the February level.

headline: U.S. WILL GIVE DEVELOPMENT AID TO ETHIOPIA
abstract: The United States, the largest supplier of aid to victims of the Ethiopian famine, is also planning to provide development assistance because of a change in United States law, according to relief officials here.   Until now, amendments to the United States Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 have divided aid into two categories: humanitarian and development. Nations such as Ethiopia, which had nationalized American private or Government property without ''making sufficient effort to compensate,'' have been excluded from receiving any assistance for development purposes.   But a provision in the African Famine Relief and Recovery Act of 1985, approved last month, will allow the United States to grant assistance to Ethiopia and other nations in crisis ''without regard'' to the previous legislation, known as the Hickenlooper and Brooke amendments.

headline: FREDDIE MAC OFFERING 4 COLLATERALIZED SERIES
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation is offering nearly $1.04 billion of collateralized mortgage obligations, divided into four series, through various securities dealers. The obligations, known as C.M.O.'s, are secured by a pool of conventional home mortgages with an average interest rate of 12.9 percent that were purchased by the organization, commonly called Freddie Mac.

headline: Western Airlines
abstract: Gerald Grinstein, chief executive of Western Airlines Inc., told securities analysts that the airline's recovery continued into the second quarter, and he predicted it would earn at least $14 million for the period. He said this would equal the company's record second-quarter profit, which was posted in 1979. The airline, which has had extensive losses, reported a record first-quarter profit this year of $13.3 million.

headline: TO OUR READERS
abstract: Because of transmission problems at The Associated Press, the 52-week highs and lows do not appear in the Nasdaq national market list.

headline: Levi's Profit Rises 40.2%
abstract: Levi Strauss & Company reported earnings of $32.1 million, or 86 cents a share, for the second quarter ended May 26, up 40.2 percent, from the $6.4 million, or 17 cents a share, for the same period last year. Sales in the latest quarter amounted to $615.7 million, down from $659.8 million for the same period last year.

headline: GERMAN CEMETARY TOWN: FLAVOR IS VERY AMERICAN
abstract: The Kolmesh"ohe cemetery here, which President Reagan plans to visit next month, is not an imposing place.    It is dominated by a squat stone tower put up in 1934 when the flat tract contained only the bodies of German soldiers slain in World War I.    Today, stone tablets embedded in the grass mark the graves of 1,887 German soldiers killed in World War II, and 100 from World War I. Most markers list rank, name, date of birth and date of death; some say merely ''a German soldier'' or ''an unknown soldier.''    Forty-seven of the headstones start with the letters ''SS,'' the initials for the Schutzstaffel, the Nazi elite guard. Most of these men appear to have belonged to the Second and 10th SS Panzer Divisions and most of them died in the Ardennes offensive into Luxembourg and Belgium in December 1944.

headline: NICARAGUAN OFFERS TO LIFT SIEGE LAW
abstract: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua has offered to lift the three-year-old state of emergency in his country if the United States halts its efforts to aid anti-Sandinista guerrillas and resumes talks with the Nicaraguan Government.   The emergency decree allows the Government wide latitude to restrict political activity, labor organizing, press freedom and other rights, as well as to occupy private property and use special courts to try political cases. It was was first imposed in March 1982, as United States-backed insurgents began carrying out attacks across Nicaragua's border with Honduras.   Mr. Ortega, speaking at a public meeting in Managua on Monday night, said the Reagan Administration should call a cease-fire, stop seeking to finance the rebel force and renew direct talks with Nicaragua.

headline: Sugar Plants Sold
abstract: The sale of two Ohio sugar facilities owned by the defunct Great Western Sugar Company to Savannah Foods and Industries was approved by a Federal bankruptcy judge.

headline: Rugby Protest in Wellington
abstract: About 4,000 people marched through central Wellington tonight, singing and chanting protests against a proposed New Zealand rugby tour of South Africa. The protesters carried banners calling for the rugby team not to go to South Africa because of the racial segregation policy of the white-minority Government there.

headline: MACHINE TOOL INDUSTRY REPORTS GAINS FOR MARCH
abstract: The machine tool industry, continuing a gradual comeback from several disastrous years, reported healthy gains in new orders and shipments in March.         In a report released yesterday, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said that net new orders in March for American-made metal-cutting and metal-forming tools climbed 17.6 percent over February's orders, to $279.3 million. Orders surged 34 percent over March 1984.

headline: GORBACHEV URGES PLANT RETOOLING
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said today that the Soviet Union must modernize its economy to expand consumer goods and services and to support the military spending necessitated by ''imperialism's aggressive policy.''   Speaking at a meeting on science and technology, he said the nation must overcome the ''negative trends'' of the Brezhnev era and raise technology and industry to world standards.   Mr. Gorbachev set out a strategy of renovating and upgrading older factories, reducing waste and increasing the quality of goods.   He traced the present problems to the rule of Leonid I. Brezhnev, from 1964 to 1982, when rapid postwar growth began to slow down.

headline: SOVIET WILLING TO HELP, BUT PUTS BLAMES ON U.S.
abstract: A spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry asserted today that the hostage situation in Beirut was an outgrowth of American policies, but he suggested that Moscow might be willing to do what it could to help resolve the crisis, The spokesman, Vladimir B. Lomeiko, speaking in a news conference, declined to say whether the Soviet Union was in fact helping.   ''Our country does and has done all that is possible to assist in the resolution of all conflicts,'' he said in answer to a question. ''In this case, I don't know that the United States has approached the Soviet Union.''   In Washington, State Department officials said last Friday that Richard Burt, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, met with Oleg M. Sokolov, the second-ranking diplomat of the Soviet Embassy, to discuss possible use of Soviet influence.

headline: CHINESE STUDY CHURCH'S ROLE IN U.S. SOCIETY
abstract: Two Chinese religious scholars who have just spent a year studying organized religion in the United States say they were surprised by the role of religious institutions in this country.   ''In China, the function of religion is mainly moral, and the church has a very limited connection with society,'' said one of the scholars, Yan Changyou. ''In America, the church plays a very active social role.''   Mr. Yan and Deng Wenwen, the other scholar, belong to the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences in Peking. They are the first scholars to be sent by China to the United States specifically to visit American religious institutions. The mission was organized under a 1981 agreement between the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences and the New York-based Appeal of Conscience Foundation.

headline: WEST EUROPE LIKES REAGAN, BITBURG ASIDE
abstract: President Reagan's standing and popularity among West Europeans - apart from  the aura of blunder and insensitivity surrounding the Bitburg cemetery visit - seem, on the evidence of polls and interviews, to have strengthened moderately over the past year.         For large segments of public opinion in Western Europe, the reopening of nuclear arms negotiations in Geneva, and Mr. Reagan's repeated expressions of interest in meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, are positive developments that have enhanced the President's reputation. The strong performance of the American economy in comparison with those in Europe has also  increased admiration for Mr. Reagan.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: June 4, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Science and Technology - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Chesapeake & Potomac Telephone Co. of Maryland has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $125 million of debt securities through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co.    * Deposit Guaranty Corp. has filed for $20 million of convertible subordinated debentures due 2010.    * Duquesne Light Co. is offering $50 million of 10 3/4 percent bonds due 1995 at a price of 99 3/8 to yield 10.853 percent through First Boston Corp.    * Equitable Life Financing Corp. is issuing $100 million of 10 1/8 percent Eurobonds due 1992 at a price of 100 through Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd.

headline: PARIS MARKS THE HOLIDAY WITH POMP
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand reviewed troops on the Champs-Elysees from an open car and placed a wreath at the unknown soldier's monument under the Arc de Triomphe today to mark the 40th anniversary of the Nazi surrender.   Only a thin crowd was present along the avenue as Mr. Mitterrand, escorted by motorcycle outriders, cavalry troops and the band of the Garde Republicaine, rode to the Arc in chilly, gray weather.   The President was greeted there by veterans bearing 64 standards from the French regiments that took part in fighting leading to the liberation of Europe. After the national anthem was played, he placed a wreath on the unknown soldier's grave and presented Legion of Honor decorations to several people. Mr. Mitterrand, who was in the Resistance, did not speak.

headline: Nicaragua Reports Clashes With Rebels
abstract: Fierce fighting between Government troops and United States-backed rebels in northern Nicaragua left 40 rebels and a Nicaraguan officer dead, the Defense Ministry said today.   A ministry communique said Government troops killed 30 rebels in San Juan de Bocay in Jinotega Province.

headline: Jobless Filings Decline
abstract: New applications for unemployment insurance benefits declined 28,000 in the week ended June 1, to a seasonally adjusted 367,000, the Labor Department said today. The number of people collecting benefits under regular state programs totaled 2,546,000 in the week ended May 25, the latest period for which that figure was available.

headline: F.D.I.C. Stalls on Repayment
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said over the weekend that it would not immediately reimburse 11 financial institutions that had deposited funds in the Strong's Bank of Dodgeville, Wis., which failed on Friday.   The F.D.I.C. said the deposits from each of the 11 institutions were for $100,000, which ordinarily would be insured.

headline: TOLL IN TRIPOLI BLAST IS SAID TO RISE TO 75, WITH 100 WOUNDED
abstract: The number of casualties in a car-bomb explosion in the northern Lebanese port of Tripoli rose to 75 dead and more than 100 wounded, the state-run Beirut radio reported today.   The radio said that rescue work was continuing around the clock and that more victims were brought out today from under the debris of a four-story building that was destroyed by the blast Wednesday.   The car-bomb explosion in Tripoli, Lebanon's second-largest city, was the worst such attack in Lebanon since a booby-trapped pickup truck exploded on a crowded street in predominantly Christian East Beirut last month, killing about 60 people. Several booby-trapped cars have exploded in Tripoli in the past several months.

headline: Short-Term Rates Continue to Tumble
abstract: Short-term interest rates slid sharply yesterday, further bolstering the market's belief that the Federal Reserve is engineering lower interest rates to reinvigorate the economy.   In a move that confirmed the impact of these lower market interest rates on the cost of funds to banks, a number of major banks lowered their prime lending rates yesterday to 9 1/2 percent from 10 percent. That is the prime's lowest level since the fall of 1978 and continues a steady decline that began last September, when it stood at 13 percent. Several economists said that funding had grown so cheap that a 9 percent prime would be justified.

headline: TOKYO'S MARKET ENTRY PLAN
abstract: Japan's Government completed work today on a package of measures intended to head off complaints that the Japanese market is closed to foreign products.    Details of the measures will be announced Tuesday after they have won the endorsement of Cabinet economic ministers, but both American and Japanese officials have warned against expecting any dramatic moves.   The package, according to press reports and conversations with American and Japanese officials, is intended to streamline regulations, reduce some tariffs and encourage imports of products involving telecommunications, electronics, forestry and pharmacutics.

headline: READER'S DIGEST CAMPAIGN
abstract: THE new high command of the secretive Reader's Digest Association, which has $1.4 billion in annual sales, is throwing open its windows to the public with a $1 million corporate ad campaign, the first in the Digest's 63-year history.   Under the leadership of George V. Grune, chairman, the Digest, a privately held company, will talk about its own business acumen and the impact of the magazine throughout the world and, in particular, in the halls of Congress.   According to Richard F. McLoughlin, vice chairman and publisher, the all-magazine campaign that starts July 1 will be aimed at impressing advertisers; the rest of the business community, including the Digest's suppliers, and the magazine's employees, who were kept pretty much in the dark during the regimes of the founder, DeWitt Wallace, and his widow, Lila, who died a year ago.   As an example of how a family's quest for privacy can pervade a company, Mr. McLoughlin, at a meeting Friday, cited the fact that the elegantly appointed board room at the Pleasantville, N.Y., headquarters had been traditionally locked up and unused between board meetings. Now, Mr. Grune has ordered the doors opened and has invited the work force to enter and look in if they are in the area.

headline: DRESSING UP THE PROCESSED WORD
abstract: SELECTING software for any given application usually involves, as a matter of necessity, a trade-off between ease of learning and the number of available features. Nowhere is this more true than in word processing. Most people do not need - and never use if they have them - 90 percent of the fancy features offered by the so-called powerful word processors. This has led to an explosive growth in the sales of such meat-and-potatoes packages as PFS:Write and its clone, the I.B.M. Writing Assistant.   However, no sooner has one become comfortable with a low-end word processing program than a need suddenly arises for, say, footnotes, a two-column-page format or some other feature that is beyond the software's capabilities. Does the average individual then go out and purchase a more complex word processing package for the occasion? Rarely, would be my guess.  It's far easier to reshape the processed words to the required format by, say, putting the footnotes together on a back page and substituting numbers in brackets for the proper superscripts. Printing out narrow columns and pasting pairs of them together on a single page for photocopying produces an adequate, if fudged, two-column layout. Such simple expediencies, while not elegant, suffice for the occasional exception to straight word processing.

headline: Murchison Debt Meeting
abstract: The former owner of the Dallas Cowboys football team, Clint Murchison Jr., will meet Wednesday with a committee representing his creditors to start negotiating for financial reorganization, his attorney said today.   Papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court show that Mr. Murchison has almost $400 million in debts and a little more than $70 million in assets.

headline: Oil Lotteries Repayment
abstract: A Florida ''filing service'' company, accused of luring investors into the Government's oil lotteries by exaggerating their chances of winning valuable oil and gas leases, has agreed to repay them $700,000.   The J&R Marketing Company of Miami and its officers agreed to pay the money into a consumer redress fund as part of a settlement to a 1983 court action filed against them by the Federal Trade Commission, according to court documents.   The company, which has filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, is operating under the supervision of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Miami.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN TROOPS AND POLICE SEAL BLACK TOWNSHIP OVER UNREST
abstract: South African troops and policemen sealed off a black township in the restive Eastern Cape region today after widespread unrest in the area.   Residents of Kwanobuhle Township, near the automotive center of Uitenhage, said several people were detained. A police spokesman said up to 1,000 soldiers and police officers took part in the operation, described by the authorities as an effort to ''normalize living conditions.''

headline: MENGELE 'DOUBLE' CALLED FERVID NAZI
abstract: An Austrian emigrant who is said to have given his identity card to the fugitive Nazi Josef Mengele in Brazil was a fervent admirer of the Third Reich who adorned his Christmas trees with swastikas, according to sources in the Austrian town of Graz, where he died.   The name of the man, Wolfgang Gerhard, has emerged in testimony given to the police in Brazil as a key figure in efforts to determine whether a body exhumed in Sao Paulo last week is that of the Auschwitz death camp doctor. The body was buried under a headstone marked Wolfgang Gerhard, and on Tuesday, Rolf Mengele, the doctor's son, said he had ''no doubt'' that the remains were those of his father.   According to a series of telephone conversations with people who knew him in Graz, Mr. Gerhard, who died in 1978, was a former member of the Hitler Youth and the Nazi party who served in the German Navy in World War II. His oldest son, Adolf, said by telephone that the family had returned to Austria in 1971 from Sao Paulo, where his father had lived since 1949.

headline: SPAIN IN THE MAINSTREAM: KAFKA, DISCOS, COCAINE
abstract: There is still the blood of bullfights, the sultry swishing skirts of flamenco, the shuffle of old women in black going daily to mass.   But as Spain tries to assess the political and economic effects of joining the European Economic Community, as agreed in Brussels late last month, a dramatic social transformation is drawing the country closer to the rest of Western Europe.   The popular Spanish images depicted by writers such as Ernest Hemingway and George Orwell have not disappeared. But over the last two decades, and particularly since the death of the dictator Francisco Franco in 1975, Spaniards have been casting off nearly four centuries of isolationism.

headline: Trudeau Visits Moscow
abstract: Former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada arrived here today for a monthlong visit at the invitation of the Kremlin's North American institute, the official press agency Tass said. He will spend a month meeting Soviet officials and traveling around the country, Canadian sources said. They did not know if he would meet the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, or other leaders.

headline: SERGEI N. VISHNEVSKY
abstract: Sergei N. Vishnevsky, a Pravda press commentator on American affairs, has died in Moscow, the Communist Party daily announced last Tuesday. He was 55 years old. A graduate of the Moscow Institute of International Relations, he joined Pravda in 1956 and served as its correspondent in Washington in the 1960's.

headline: JAPAN'S PRESS SEARCHES ITS SOUL OVER TV MURDER
abstract: For a few days, Kazuo Nagano was the most closely watched man in Japan.   Newspaper reporters and television crews dogged his trail, even camping outside his apartment in Osaka in the hope of getting an interview or at least a picture.   News gatherers often do that sort of thing in the United States as well. The difference is that when American newspapers and networks want to follow someone they dispatch teams of reporters. In Japan they send out platoons. As the 32-year-old Mr. Nagano discovered, the numbers can be overwhelming.

headline: Times Officer Is Retiring
abstract: Charles B. Brakefield, a vice president of The New York Times Company and the president of its broadcast group, is retiring on June 30 and will form a broadcasting and advertising consulting firm in Memphis, the company said yesterday.

headline: MAJOR REFOCUSING AT GOODRICH
abstract: The B. F. Goodrich Company yesterday announced a major restructuring that will make it smaller, less dependent on commodity businesses such as tires and vinyl and - the company hopes - more profitable.   The cost of the business refocusing, which in part reverses some strategies that arose out of the energy shortage of the 1970's, will be a $365 million charge against earnings to be taken in the current quarter. The charge will result in a loss for the year of well over $200 million.   In the first quarter, the company earned $2.3 million, or 8 cents a share, on sales of $798.7 million.

headline: Big Board, Union Meet
abstract: A Federal mediator, Rosemary LeBoeuf, called a meeting last night between representatives of the union representing trading floor workers and the Big Board in hopes of averting a strike today.   Despite the strike threat, the exchange planned to operate normally, said Richard Torrenzano, chief spokesman for the Big Board.

headline: Rebels Destroy Bridges In Southeastern Peru
abstract: Maoist guerrillas blew up two bridges on a key highway in southeast Peru, causing about $180,000 in damage, officials said today.

headline: Altschiller and Jameson Both Get New Business
abstract: Altschiller Reitzfeld Solin Advertising, a general agency, and Jameson Advertising, specialist in book promotion, have both reported new accounts.

headline: LEVESQUE OUT, QUEBEC PARTY'S FUTURE IS CLOUDED
abstract: The Parti Quebecois, which has governed Quebec for the last nine years, confronted an uncertain future today after the resignation of its founder, Rene Levesque.   Mr. Levesque, who has headed the party since it was formed in October 1968, abruptly announced his resignation Thursday night in a letter to the party's vice president, Nadia Assimopoulos. He said in French that he was resigning after ''weighing everything as best as I could,'' but avoided offering reasons.   He will stay on as Quebec's Premier until his successor is chosen by the party's 110,000 members in an election similar to a United States state primary. According to rules adopted by the party's national council, the campaign to select a new leader will take 90 days.

headline: L.C.&F. Adds Liquor Client
abstract: Like Benton & Bowles, whose good fortune is elsewhere in this column, Laurence, Charles & Free yesterday also filled a client category vacant since March. Its vacancy was marked ''distilled spirits'' and is being filled through the National Distillers Products Company.

headline: REAGAN STATEMENT ON ARMS ACCORD
abstract: Following is the text, issued today by the White House, of a statement by President Reagan on United States and Soviet compliance with the 1979 treaty limiting strategic arms:   In 1982, on the eve of the Strategic Arms Reductions Talks (Start), I decided that the United States would not undercut the expired SALT I agreement or the unratified SALT II agreement as long as the Soviet Union exercised equal restraint. Despite my serious reservations about the inequities of the SALT I agreement and the serious flaws of the SALT II agreement, I took this action in order to foster an atmosphere of mutual restraint conducive to serious negotiation as we entered Start.   Since then, the United States has not taken any actions which would undercut existing arms control agreements. The United States has fully kept its part of the bargain. However, the Soviets have not. They have failed to comply with several provisions of SALT II, and we have serious concerns regarding their compliance with the provisions of other accords.

headline: TAX REVENUES...AND DEBATES
abstract: To the Editor:   In ''Despite Forecasts, Revenues Are Down'' (Forum, March 31), Joseph Minarik writes that ''revenues from the individul income tax have fallen'' in 1982-83, which ''certainly wasn't part of the supply-side script.''

headline: California Governor Criticizes President on Armenian Issue
abstract: Gov. George Deukmejian of California, who is of Armenian descent, said today that President Reagan was ''buckling under to Turkish pressure'' by not endorsing a Congressional resolution honoring 1.5 million Armenian genocide victims.   ''It's time that Turkey admit its role in the Armenian genocide'' under the Ottoman Empire between 1915 and 1923, Mr. Deukmejian, a Republican, said in a speech prepared for delivery at a banquet to commemorate the event's 70th anniversary.   ''And it's time that the Administration and the Congress stop buckling under to Turkish pressure to deny this simple historical truth,'' he said.

headline: PATENTS;  Apparatus Improves Separation of Mail
abstract: An improved apparatus for separating mail with printed addresses, which can be read by automation equipment, from pieces that have been addressed by hand and cannot be so read, is covered for the United States Postal Service by patent No. 4,516,264, issued this week.

headline: 2 Die Off British Columbia
abstract: A storm off northern Vancouver Island sank four boats, killing at least two people, the Coast Guard said Friday. One person was reported missing and 20 people were rescued. Search crews faced 30-foot waves and 65-knot winds, the Coast Guard said.

headline: Hughes Aides Set Meeting
abstract: The Howard Hughes Medical Institute, owner of the Hughes Aircraft Company, said yesterday that its nine trustees would meet in Manhattan Tuesday amid signs that it will announce the winner of a multibillion-dollar sealed bidding contest for the giant defense supplier.   The Ford Motor Company, with Wall Street advice from Goldman, Sachs & Company, is the only one to have acknowledged officially that it is in the running.

headline: SPANISH SAY THEY PLAN TO STAY TOUGH
abstract: Spanish officials say the Beirut hostage crisis has frustrated Madrid's diplomacy in the Middle East and complicated the handling of Basque terrorism at home.   But senior officials in the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said in interviews that Spain would remain tough in rejecting a subsidiary demand of the hijackers of the Trans World Airlines jetliner, who are holding 40 Americans hostage in Beirut. In addition to demanding the release of more than 700 Lebanese and Palestinians jailed in Israel, the hijackers want Spain to free two members of the Lebanese Amal militia jailed here.   The Government defied threats made against the Spanish Embassy in Beirut and put the two on trial last week on charges of shooting and wounding a Libyan diplomat last year.

headline: Ex-Aide of ITT Opens A Consultant's Office
abstract: Edward J. Gerrity Jr., the communications chief of the ITT Corporation who left the company in March after being suspended by management, has opened Ned Gerrity & Associates at One Rockefeller Center, from which he will consult in public relations, advertising and government relations.   Mr. Gerrity, then an executive vice president, was suspended in December because of suspicions that he gave some information unfavorable to management to the press. This Mr. Gerrity denied.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Accounts
abstract: * Excel Wood Products of Lakewood, N.J., to Shaller Rubin & Winer.

headline: Cable Project
abstract: A $600 million trans-Atlantic fiber optic telecommunications project planned by Cable and Wireless P.L.C., and Tel-Optik, a private United States company, has been approved by the Federal Communications Commission.

headline: Gannett Board Special Session
abstract: The Gannett Company has scheduled a special meeting of its board for Monday.

headline: AGCA ASSERTS SOVIET ORDERED RADIO FREE EUROPE BOMBING
abstract: The Turkish gunman who shot Pope John Paul II testified today that the Soviet Union had commissioned right-wing Turkish terrorists to blow up an American-financed radio station in West Germany that broadcasts to Eastern Europe.   The gunman, Mehmet Ali Agca, who was convicted in the 1981 shooting, also said Bulgarian officials here sought to enlist him in plans to kill President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia; the then Maltese Prime Minister, Dom Mintoff, and Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity labor movement in Poland.   The reference to the anti-Communist radio station in West Germany came while Mr. Agca was describing a meeting with other Turkish extremists in Milan, Italy, in December 1980.

headline: 20 PRESUMED DEAD
abstract: An Israeli gunboat sank an Arab ''terrorist vessel'' with 28 people aboard in an exchange of fire off the Israeli coast Saturday night, a military spokesman announced early today.    Eight Arabs were captured, one body was recovered and 19 people were missing and presumed drowned, according to a communique.

headline: Ecumed Project Shelved in Florida
abstract: Ecumed, a proposed $775 million medical trade and exposition center scheduled to open in 1988 on 300 acres in southwest Broward County, Fla., was shelved today by its developer, Tishman Speyer Properties of New York.

headline: U.S. STEEL PROFIT IS $58 MILLION
abstract: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported a first-quarter profit of $58 million, well below the comparable period a year ago. But the company apparently outdid most of its steel industry competitors, which have been reporting widened first-quarter losses.   For example, the LTV Corporation, which is the second-largest steel operation in the United States, after U.S. Steel, said yesterday that its loss in the first quarter widened to $156.4 million, from $29 million a year ago. The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the No. 3 producer, has reported a first-quarter deficit of $62 million, larger than the $55 million loss it reported a year ago.

headline: UNOCAL LAWSUIT
abstract: The Unocal Corporation said that it would comply with an order by the Interior Department to post a $100 million bond by next Wednesday for damages sought by the Federal agency in a year-old lawsuit against the company. A Federal judge in Anchorage has set a hearing date for September in the case, which Unocal is contesting. The Interior Department has accused Unocal of undervaluing natural gas it produced from the Kenai gas field for eight years, beginning in 1977.

headline: U.S. Envoy, Leaving Thailand, Says He Expects India Post
abstract: John Gunther Dean, who has been Ambassador to Thailand for the last three years, left Bangkok this week saying he expected to become the Ambassador to India within the next few months.   No announcement of the appointment has been made in Washington or New Delhi. Diplomats say they believe the formal naming of Mr. Dean to the post may come with the visit of the Indian Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi, to the United States later this month.

headline: HOUSE GETS COMPROMISE ON REBEL AID
abstract: A group of Democrats introduced compromise legislation in the House today designed to break a deadlock over aid to the rebels seeking the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government.   The bill would allot $14 million to the rebels during the current fiscal year, but the money could be used only for such ''humanitarian assistance'' as food, clothing and medicine. The funds would be distributed by the Agency for International Development and not the Central Intelligence Agency, which has been the main conduit for American support to the insurgents.   In addition, the bill would continue a law that bans the use of any American funds for military purposes in Nicaragua.

headline: FIRST BOSTON AND HUTTON UP
abstract: The wave of takeover activity and a high level of overseas bond financing by American corporations in the first quarter helped to produce record revenues and a 29.7 percent increase in earnings for First Boston Inc., the firm reported yesterday.    Also reporting a big earnings rise was the E.F. Hutton Group Inc., which benefited from a pickup in retail stock trading in January. Its earnings rose 84 percent.      FIRST BOSTON      First Boston reported net income of $26.2 million, or $1.85 a share, for the quarter ended March 31, up from $20.2 million, or $1.58 a share, a year ago. Revenue came to a record $192.6 million, up 38.5 percent from $139 million a year ago.

headline: FOR BANGLADESH VICTIMS, 'NO PLACE ELSE FOR US TO GO'
abstract: Thousands of peasant families in search of a livelihood migrate each year to the low-lying fringes of this impoverished country. Once there, they say they will remain despite the hazard of being washed violently away.   On the tiny island of Urir Char, Mohammed Abdullah, 50 years old, with thick graying hair and a face of sad resignation, told why in simple terms this week.   ''We came here to start a new life,'' he said. ''There is no place else for us to go.''

headline: Brazil's President-Elect Said to Remain in Peril
abstract: Doctors were increasingly doubtful about the chances for recovery of Brazil's President-elect, Tancredo Neves, today, after he underwent another emergency abdominal operation.    A Government spokesman said doctors had removed three abscesses close to Mr. Neves's kidneys in an all-night operation, his seventh in 29 days.

headline: Columbia Report
abstract: Columbia Pictures Industries, a subsidiary of the Coca-Cola Company, has declined comment on published reports that it is negotiating to buy Embassy Communications Inc., the movie and television production company co-founded by the producer Norman Lear. Trade reports have said that Columbia would pay $250 million for a controlling interest in Embassy.

headline: Storer Studies Takeover Bid
abstract: Storer Communications Inc. confirmed yesterday that its board met during the weekend to discuss a takeover attempt by dissident shareholders but that no action was taken.    Andrew Holdgate, a Storer spokesman, would not comment when asked about Wall Street conjecture that the Miami-based company had received an $85-a-share bid from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, an investment firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts, and an offer from Tele-Communications Inc., a Denver-based cable operator.

headline: TRIANGLE TO ACQUIRE CAN MAKER
abstract: The National Can Corporation has agreed to be acquired by Triangle Industries for $42 a share, or about $430 million, bringing to an end a year of jockeying among several suitors for control of the Chicago-based packaging company.   The agreement, reached late Friday, means that Triangle, a maker of jukeboxes, vending machines and electrical wire products, is acquiring a company nearly seven times its size, as measured by revenues.    Triangle, which is based in New Brunswick, N.J., reported 1984 net income of $3.23 million, or $1.29 a share, on revenues of $290.8 million. For the same period, National Can posted net income of $43.15 million, or $4.25 a share, on revenues of $1.91 billion.

headline: Hughes Tool Suit Asks $722 Million
abstract: Smith International Inc., a leading oilfield services concern, said the Hughes Tool Company is seeking $722 million plus interest from Smith in a patent-infringement suit. Smith, in its annual report, disclosed that Hughes Tool had recently put the dollar amount on the damages being sought in the 13-year-old legal battle.

headline: COMPUTER MAKERS IN A SEVERE SLUMP
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a maker of computer chips, celebrated last Christmas with typical Silicon Valley flamboyance - a $700,000 employee Christmas party featuring entertainment by the rock group Chicago and a 50-piece orchestra.   Six months later, Advanced Micro is making its employees work longer hours for no extra pay and will close its factories for two weeks to cope with plunging earnings and possible losses. It has introduced an austerity program called Staunch, which stands for ''Stress Those Actions Urgently Needed to Check Hemorrhaging.''   The computer industry, long considered one of the nation's bright spots, has plunged into a sudden, deep and unexpected slump that shows no signs of disappearing.      Confidence Suffers a Blow    The slowdown has proved a rude shock to an industry that has always believed in its own boundless future. Some executives are beginning to suggest that the old days of extravagance may be gone for a long time.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   U.S. Lifts Suspension Of Polish Flights to U.S.
abstract: The United States and Poland signed an agreement today to resume within two weeks the commercial flights that Washington suspended after the Polish Government imposed martial law in December 1981.

headline: Pharmaceuticals
abstract: To the Editor:   With reference to ''Glory Days End for Pharmaceuticals'' (Feb. 24), it should be noted that Hoffmann-LaRoche is headed by marketing people who have known for 17 years that the valium patents were running out. But marketing people only know how to sell something, not how to make it, or even what to make.

headline: A.T.&T. to Cut 1,650 Positions
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in a move to cut expenses, said it was eliminating 1,650 positions in its AT&T Information Systems, the marketing arm for its telephone, switching and computer equipment. A.T.&T. said that additional reductions were planned but offered no timetable and did not say how widespread they might be.   Craig A. Lowder, an A.T.&T. spokesman, said the job cuts would occur at various times through the rest of the year, ''depending on union contracts.'' Mr. Lowder added, ''Our business is changing and part of that change requires that we drive every unnecessary cost out of the business.'' He declined to say how much the company would save by the cuts.

headline: MEDDLING CHARGED BY SOUTH AFRICA
abstract: President P. W. Botha denounced what he termed Western double standards toward his country today, and said South Africa could solve its problems without ''international meddling'' in its affairs.   The tone of his address to Parliament in Cape Town seemed to reflect a mood of embattled defiance nurtured by South Africa's growing isolation from Western allies, the United States in particular. Washington has recalled its Ambassador here, Herman Nickel, for consultations following South Africa's most recent military forays into neighboring Botswana and Angola.   ''The international community should be in no doubt with regard to South Africa's resolve and ability to maintain itself at home, now and in the future,'' Mr Botha said. ''We can solve our problems without international meddling.''

headline: PLANNING FOR TAX SIMPLIFICATION
abstract: PRESIDENT Reagan's proposed tax revision has many middle-class taxpayers apprehensive about the possible loss or diminution of such cherished tax shelters as real estate limited partnerships and Clifford trusts.   The uncertainties will linger for most of 1985, since the proposal - if it is adopted at all - will be revised substantially by Congress. But financial planners and tax accountants do suggest some steps, bearing in mind the fluidity of the situation. ''It isn't going to fly in this form, and you don't want to do things that involve irrevocable changes,'' warns Lee J. Seidler, a general partner in the New York investment firm of Bear, Stearns & Company.

headline: MILITIA IN LEBANON TO FREE HOSTAGES
abstract: The Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army agreed today to release the 21 Finnish soldiers of a United Nations unit whom it has been holding hostage for a week, United Nations and Israeli military sources said.   The release, scheduled to take place Saturday at 11 A.M. in the southern Lebanon village of Merj 'Uyun, was decided upon by the commander of the South Lebanon Army, Gen. Antoine Lahd, after he became convinced that 11 S.L.A. men whom the Finns turned over to the Shiite militia Amal on June 7 had indeed defected, Israeli military sources said.   General Lahd told the Israeli Army, which arms, trains and advises his militia, of his decision this evening, an Israeli Army spokesman said.      Questioning by Red Cross   A representative of the International Committee of the Red Cross met alone Thursday with the 11 South Lebanon Army militiamen in the southern Lebanese city of Tyre, where Amal was holding them. According to United Nations sources, the 11 men said they did not want to return to General Lahd's militia or their homes in the area along the Israel-Lebanon border that Israel refers to as its security zone. The 11 South Lebanon Army men are Shiites. General Lahd is a Maronite Christian, and the ranks of the South Lebanon Army are predominantly Christian.

headline: REAGAN PEACE PLAN FOR NICARAGUA GETS ONLY COOL SUPPORT IN REGION
abstract: President Reagan's recently announced proposal to deal with Nicaragua has received only limited support from the four-nation regional negotiating group, officials of the group and Central American Governments said today.   As Mexico, Panama, Venezuela and Colombia resumed talks with five Central American Governments today, it became clear that officials saw some improvement in the American position in Mr. Reagan's talk of dialogue with the Sandinistas and, to some extent, in his call for a cease-fire between the Sandinistas and the United States- backed guerrillas. But much of the rest of his plan was seen as unacceptable.    A statement from the Panamanian Foreign Ministry said that President Nicolas Ardito Barletta had met with President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, Harry W.  Schlaudeman, today and had told him that there were ''positive elements'' in the plan, including a call for cessation of hostilities and the use of ''dialogue instead of confrontation'' with the Sandinistas. But he also said the negotiating group held to ''the principles of international law, among which that of nonintervention in the internal affairs of each country is basic.''

headline: SUICIDE CAR BOMB KILLS 23 AT ARMY POSITION IN BEIRUT
abstract: Two suicide bombers crashed a car loaded with explosives into a Lebanese Army position in West Beirut today, killing 23 people and wounding 36, the state radio said.   The explosion rocked Beirut shortly after nightfall and left shattered bodies along the seaside boulevard.   The army's predominantly Shiite Moslem Sixth brigade, which controls West Beirut, appealed through radio stations for ''urgent blood donations and for all doctors to report immediately to duty at hospitals to save the lives of victims.''

headline: FAST FOOD'S CHANGING LANDSCAPE
abstract: COLUMBUS, Ohio     TOOLING down Route 161, cutting through the northern tip of   this synthetic all-American city, you see them. Red-roofed cubes. Wooden rectangles with glass- sheathed fronts. Orange neon signs. Echenrode Furniture is offering one- year free financing. But the eye hardly notices. The kings of the road are McDonald's, Flakey Jake's, Burger King, Pizza Hut, Wendy's, G.D. Ritzy's, Sister's Chicken & Biscuits, Rax, White Castle, Showbiz Pizza Place, D'Lite's.    The hallowed names of fast-food America.

headline: Accounting Firm Calls E.S.M. Case 'a Betrayal'
abstract: The actions of Jose Gomez, the accountant for Alexander Grant & Company who reportedly helped to produce fraudulent financial statements for E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., were ''clearly a betrayal'' of the firm, Peter Skomorowsky, regional managing partner in New York for Grant, said in a telephone interview yesterday.    He also said, however, that Grant's internal review procedures would not have detected such wrongdoing by a partner because the controls were designed to uncover errors, not fraud.    Internal review ''is not a police function,'' Mr. Skomorowsky said. ''We don't assume that people are thieves,'' he added.

headline: HEAD OF STATE DEPT. BUREAU FOR LATIN AREA STEPS DOWN
abstract: The head of the State Department's Latin American bureau, Langhorne A. Motley, resigned today to return to private life.   Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who announced Mr. Motley's resignation, said Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, would take his place.   As Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs the last two years, Mr. Motley played an important role in shaping United States policy toward Nicaragua.

headline: AS LEBANON'S CHRISTIANS YIELD TOWNS, DRUSE SEIZE COAST HIGHWAY
abstract: Druse forces took control of the coastal road linking Beirut with the southern port of Sidon today while other Moslem militiamen continued their advance against Christian positions in the hills east of the port.         Druse members of the Progressive Socialist Party occupied six Christian villages along the Mediteranean coastline and Iqlim al Kharoub at the foothills  of the Shuf mountains. They also took over the small port of Jiyeh, which had been used by Christian refugees fleeing the fighting of the last few days.

headline: MURDOCH TV DEAL EXPECTED
abstract: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher who bought a half interest in the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation in March, is expected to announce today that he will buy at least six television stations from Metromedia Inc. for about $1.55 billion.   The deal, which would include WNEW-TV Channel 5 in New York, as well as stations in Los Angeles, Chicago, Dallas, Houston and Washington, would be the largest group sale of independent television stations.   Mr. Murdoch and Metromedia's chairman, John W. Kluge, spent Saturday negotiating the deal in Mr. Kluge's apartment in the Waldorf Towers. The same day, the Hearst Corporation announced that it had agreed in principle to buy Metromedia's seventh television station, in Boston, for $450 million.

headline: MENGELE'S SON TO BREAK SILENCE ON FATHER'S FATE
abstract: Rolf Mengele, son of the Nazi death camp doctor Josef Mengele, will issue a statement soon about his father's fate, breaking the family's longstanding refusal to discuss Dr. Mengele's disappearance, his secretary said today.   The secretary, speaking from Rolf Mengele's law office in the West German city of Freiburg, said a statement was being prepared and would be given to the West German news agency Deutsche Presse-Agentur.   Rolf Mengele and other family members could not be reached for comment tonight.   The promise of a statement from the Mengele family came after the Brazilian police exhumed the body of a man they believe may be Josef Mengele near the town of Sao Paulo last week.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Liberians Said to Jail American as Conspirator
abstract: An American was reported today to have been sentenced to 10 years in jail in Liberia after he had been convicted of plotting to overthrow Gen. Samuel K. Doe, the Liberian leader, last November.    Meanwhile, the deputy chief of General Doe's bodyguards, Col. Moses Flanzamaton, confessed in a broadcast today that key politicians had offered him $1 million to kill General Doe on Monday.

headline: CHURCH TEACHINGS ON SEX WON'T CHANGE, POPE TELLS DUTCH YOUTHS
abstract: Pope John Paul II, who has been trailed by young protesters in his four days in this country, responded today to what he called ''blunt criticisms'' by rejecting calls for changes in Roman Catholic sexual rules.   The church's teaching on sexual issues, he said, will remain the same ''for all time.''   In a speech before one of the smallest crowds ever seen on a papal trip, the Pope told several hundred young people at an outdoor meeting here that their criticisms ''sometimes give us old people problems.''   ''Sometimes you hurt us,'' said the 64-year-old Pope, who has faced fierce protests during his visit, including stone- and bottle-throwing.

headline: Restraint Advised By Unocal
abstract: The Unocal Corporation advised its stockholders today ''not to act hastily'' in response to a $3.46 billion offer by an investment group led by T. Boone Pickens to acquire majority control of the oil company.   In a terse statement, the company said its directors would review the offer, which was filed late this afternoon with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and give its response within 10 days, as required by Federal procedures.   Unocal's shares, after trading as high as $51, closed on the New York Stock Exchange at $49.75 today, up 62.5 cents. It was the most active issue on the Big Board, with almost 2.7 million shares changing hands.

headline: REVOLUTIONARY VENTURES: SURVIVING AND PROFITING THROUGH THE CENTURIES
abstract: WHEN President Reagan works out on his exercise treadmill at the White House, he lopes along on belting from the nation's oldest business: J. E. Rhoads & Sons Inc., of Delaware, established in 1702. When President Washington wanted a gift for the Marquis de Lafayette he chose Number Six cologne, a scent still on sale at the nation's oldest apothecary, Caswell-Massey Company (1752), then of Newport, R.I.   In a nation stirred by entrepreneurship, where 90 percent of start-up businesses fail within their first decade of existence, there are still almost 40 venerable companies that have operated since the time of the Revolution and the first Fourth of July. Some of these have scarcely changed in over two centuries: The nation's oldest undertaking concern, Kirk & Nice Inc. (1761), built coffins for the soldiers that were killed when George Washington lost the Battle of Germantown in 1777; today, a Kirk scion operates the funeral home on its original site near Philadelphia.   Other companies loosened their family ties decades ago and evolved to match their changing markets. The Dexter Corporation (1767) in Windsor Locks, Conn., the oldest company listed on the New York Stock Exchange, started as a sawmill; now it makes specialty products for the aerospace, biotechnology and electronics industries.
