headline: VOLKWAGEN'S AUDI UNIT EMPHASIZES INNOVATIONS
abstract: Compet-ing with Japanese automobile companies is like a sword fight with an opponent who keeps honing his weapon to an ever finer edge, observes Ferdinand Piech, the chief engineer for Audi, the West German auto maker.   ''The Japanese are better at sharpening swords than the Western world,'' he said during a recent visit here. ''We have to try to invent weapons other than swords, so we can stay two or three years ahead of them.''   Despite the current scramble by the American auto companies to reduce Japan's advantage of $2,000 or more a car in production costs through such efforts as the Saturn Corporation, the subsidiary set up by the General Motors Corporation to make a new subcompact car, Audi officials maintain that Japan's fine-tuning of its assembly lines and the rise of low-cost manufacturing countries such as South Korea will make it impossible to ever close the gap. The solution for specialty manufacturers, they say, is innovation.

headline: USAIR POSTS 45.9% DROP
abstract: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, yesterday reported a slight decrease in earnings in the first quarter, to $60.2 million, or $1.12 a share, from $60.3 million, or $1.13 a share, in the first quarter last year. Revenues rose 9.4 percent, to $1.39 billion, from $1.27 billion.

headline: McDonnell Hughes Unit Penalized on Army Bills
abstract: The Army announced today that it had halted overhead payments to the Hughes Helicopter division of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation because of ''serious'' accounting irregularities.   C. Richard Whiston, the Army's chief of legal services, said that the payments, which amount to $30 million a month, were suspended on May 17 after the Defense Contract Audit Agency found numerous accounting problems at the company, including unallowable billings, duplicate charges and inconsistent bookkeeping.   Hughes, which was acquired by McDonnell Douglas in early 1984 from the estate of Howard R. Hughes, builds the Army's AH-64 Apache helicopters and guns for the Bradley Fighting Vehicle, a hybrid personnel carrier-tank. Army contracts with the company are valued at about $4 billion. James R. Ambrose, the Under Secretary of the Army, will direct an investigation into the problems found by the audit agency, Mr. Whiston said.

headline: Rothschild Unit Picks President
abstract: Rothschild Ventures Inc., the venture capital arm of Rothschild Inc., has named Jess L. Belser president, effective today. He replaces Arch J. McGill, who resigned, according to a Rothschild spokesman, ''to pursue personal interests.''    Mr. Belser, 60, resigned as executive vice president of the Continental Group and as president of Continental Forest Industries last October when Peter Kiewit Sons and David H. Murdock acquired the Continental Group.

headline: Eckerd Denies Merger Rumor
abstract: The price of the Jack Eckerd Corporation's stock rose yesterday in heavier-than-normal trading as rumors circulated that the drugstore chain might be seeking ways to fight off the advances of the Dart Group Corporation, including a merger with another company.   Eckerd's stock gained $1, to $28.75, as 288,000 shares traded.

headline: I.B.M. Circuits
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said its scientists had made the world's densest integrated circuits using a new fabrication process. It did not predict when it might be able to develop a commercial product using the new technology. The process, I.B.M. said, shrinks circuits into an area 16 times smaller than that permitted by current semiconductor technology.

headline: Nigerian Newspaper Closes;Financial Problems Are Cited
abstract: A Nigerian Sunday newspaper, The Democrat Weekly, is to shut down in the face of growing financial difficulties and a shortage of newsprint, the newspaper's editorial adviser said today.   The editorial adviser, Ajit Bhattacharjea, said the paper would publish its last issue on Sunday. The newspaper, based in the northern city of Kaduna, began publication on Jan. 1, 1984, a day after the military seized power in a coup.

headline: F.B.I. SAYS IT FOILED PLOT BY SIKHS TO ASSASSINATE GANDHI IN THE U.S.
abstract: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had foiled a plot by Sikh terrorists to assassinate Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India during his visit to the United States next month.   William H. Webster, director of the F.B.I., said in a statement here that the bureau had penetrated a plan to ''train a group of Sikhs in the use of firearms and explosives'' and that the group had planned ''guerrilla-type operations'' against the Indian Government.   In addition to the purported plot against Mr. Gandhi, Mr. Webster said, the Sikh terrorists had also planned to assassinate Bhajan Lal, Chief Minister of the Indian state of Haryana, who was in New Orleans for medical treatment. #5 Detained in New Orleans Five of the seven men identified by the F.B.I. as part of the purported conspiracy are in custody in New Orleans. The two others are being sought in the New York area.

headline: PROMOTER IS GUILTY IN $445 MILLION TAX FRAUD
abstract: A financial promoter pleaded guilty yesterday to conducting a fraudulent tax shelter scheme that provided $445 million in false income tax deductions for wealthy investors.   The promoter is 35-year-old Edward A. Markowitz of Washington, who waived his right to an indictment by a grand jury and pleaded to charges filed yesterday by prosecutors in the Federal District Court in Manhattan.   ''It is, up to this point, the largest tax fraud case ever prosecuted,'' the United States Attorney, Rudolph W. Giuliani, said at a news conference at his Manhattan offices.   More than 100 investors put about $20 million into Mr. Markowitz's tax shelter partnerships, lost most of their investments and now face large bills for back taxes, according to Federal authorities. They said the investors included celebrities who apparently invested on the advice of tax advisers.

headline: Talks on Afghan Dispute Said to Move Ahead
abstract: The United Nations mediator at talks between the Foreign Ministers of Afghanistan and Pakistan said today that negotiations on a political settlement of the Afghan conflict had ''moved forward'' during a three-day meeting here.

headline: Washington Watch;   Rostenkowski Stand on Trade
abstract: WHEN Dan Rostenkowski speaks out on trade issues, people listen. One reason is that he rarely addresses the subject publicly. Another is that he is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which handles most trade legislation and is now inundated with protectionist bills.

headline: TREASURY POST SEEN FOR WALL ST. BANKER
abstract: President Reagan will name George D. Gould, a Wall Street banker and a former top official of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, to a new Treasury position overseeing domestic banking regulation, Administration sources said yesterday.   The President is expected to announce the appointment ''in two or three weeks,'' a senior official said. As Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, Mr. Gould will hold the third-ranking Treasury job.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Purchasers Report March Downturn
abstract: The first quarter ended on a sobering note, with the economy easing in March after improving during the first two months of the year, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday.   According to the trade group's monthly survey of purchasing managers at 250 major industrial companies, new orders dropped and production slowed after expanding briskly in February, while inventory levels declined after two months of increases. Indeed, 40 percent of the respondents said the first quarter fell below their expectations, while only 18 percent said that it exceeded their expectations.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: DIFFICULT ROAD AHEAD FOR ARGENTINA
abstract: The Argentine economy and its intractable inflation problem has toppled governments and ruined the political careers of a slew of bright financial ministers for more than four decades.   Now, President Raul Alfonsin, a man who came to power promising his countrymen a better life, has proposed the most radical program in the nation's history. It will mean a dramatic short-term drop in the Argentine standard of living and will require a long, difficult road to recovery, economists said.   Mr. Alfonsin has frozen wages and prices and has issued a new currency that he says will not lose its value, fixed at $1.25.

headline: Stocks Surge In Hong Kong
abstract: Signs of a boom in Hong Kong's property market set off a rush for shares Friday, pushing the stock market index here to a four-year high.   Brokers said sharp gains by property stocks were a sign of confidence in the territory's future.

headline: TWO HAWKS AND A DOVE: HOW THEY LOOK AT THE INDOCHINA WAR NOW
abstract: Dean Rusk says the lesson of the Vietnam War is that the United States should look very carefully at the possible implications before it enters into any security treaties.   Noting that the Southeast Asian Treaty Organization was worked out by the United States without much discussion or debate in 1954, he said the accord turned out to be the document that obligated Washington to come to the support of South Vietnam.   In a recent telephone interview from Athens, Ga., where he is a professor at the University of Georgia Law School, Mr. Rusk said one factor that led President Kennedy to increase the American role in Vietnam was concern over how it would look to Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet leader, if he did not stand by the Seato treaty.

headline: Real Estate;   Relocating Jersey City Companies
abstract: IT would be hard to name an old city with more ambitious revitalization projects than Jersey City, but business gentrification has its costs and hardships just as residential gentrification does. The upgrading of factories into office and residential spaces there, as well as rising rents, has been forcing out some manufacturing tenants.   While a state law requires municipalities to find alternative space for any commercial tenant displaced by public urban renewal projects, companies forced from their quarters by private projects have no such protection. But the industrial tenants now leasing space in one of Jersey City's largest conversion projects, the Harborside Financial Center, were recently given the option of moving to another site a few blocks away when the private developers of Harborside purchased a former supermarket warehouse. The warehouse is now being renovated for those tenants.

headline: CHOLERA REPORTED IN 2 MORE ETHIOPIAN CAMPS
abstract: A disease believed to be cholera has broken out in two more Ethiopian relief centers, according to Western relief workers and diplomats.   The officials said that at last count there were 168 cases at Ibnat in the Gondar region and about 200 cases at Makele, capital of the Tigre region. They added that in both instances the situation appeared to be under control.

headline: REAGAN TO GET PLANS FOR AIR SECURITY
abstract: President Reagan will receive a ''comprehensive package'' of recommendations from the Transportation Department today on measures to increase aviation security after the surge in terrorist actions in the last 10 days, according to a high-ranking department official.   If put into effect, some of the proposals could result in delays of two hours or more in boarding aircraft at some airports, the official said.   The recommendations will include replies to requests made by Mr. Reagan last Tuesday, four days after a Trans World Airlines Boeing 727 was hijacked by Arab gunmen and taken on multistop odyssey that wound up in Beirut, Lebanon. Forty American hostages are still being held.

headline: Regional Bank Merger
abstract: The Bank of New England, based in Boston, and the CBT Corporation, the Connecticut bank holding company, whose intention to merge led to the regional banking decision handed down last Monday by the United States Supreme Court, said yesterday that they had completed their merger. The agreement between the banks to merge was the first made under a regional compact that allowed New England-based bank holding companies, but not those from New York or other states outside the region, to acquire local banks.

headline: Rosenfeld to Handle Yugoslav Car Import
abstract: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson has been named agency for Yugo America, the Montvale, N.J., company that is going to import a Yugoslav automobile that will be the lowest-priced car available in the United States. The ad budget for the introduction of the car in just the Boston-Washington corridor could be as much as $10 million.    The vehicles, being made by Zastava, an employee-owned manufacturer, will be the Yugo GV (for Good Value) with a suggested retail price of $3,990 and the Yugo GVX (Good Value Exceptional) for under $5,000.

headline: COLOMBIA SEIZES SUSPECT IN U.S. DRUG AIDE'S DEATH
abstract: A man believed to be the leader of a major cocaine trafficking ring, who is also a key suspect in the killing of a United States drug enforcement agent in Mexico, was arrested in Cartagena, Colombia, on Tuesday, drug officials announced here today.   John C. Lawn, the acting administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, said the man arrested by the Colombian National Police, Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, was one of four top suspects in the murder of Enrique Camarena Salazar, the American drug agent abducted in February in Guadalajara.   Two other suspects, Rafael Caro Quintero and Ernesto Fonseca Carillo, were arrested last month. Mr. Lawn said the fourth suspect, Miguel Felix Gallardo, who is still at large, was a ''subordinate to Ballesteros'' and had been ''directly linked'' to the drug agent's murder.   Mr. Lawn said at a news conference today that Mr. Matta Ballesteros was one of the ''most significant cocaine traffickers in the world'' and the head of the so-called Padrino trafficking organization, which supplies cocaine to the United States, especially the Southwest. It operates in Peru, Mexico, Colombia and Honduras, he said.

headline: British Telecom Study
abstract: The British Office of Telecommunications is studying several ways in which the planned merger of British Telecommunications P.L.C. with the Mitel Corporation of Canada might be modified. A spokesman for the telecommunications office said today that the interests of other British telephone exchange suppliers might be given some protection by limiting the amount of equipment that British Telecommunications could take from Mitel.

headline: Harvester Earnings Up
abstract: The International Harvester Company, the nation's largest producer of medium- and heavy-duty trucks, reported net income of $59 million, or 42 cents a share, in the quarter ending April 30.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *        Aries Technology Inc., a Lowell, Mass., company that supplies evaluation systems to mechanical engineers, has appointed Larry McArthur president and chief executive officer.          * Arvin Industries of Columbus, Ohio, a diversified manufacturer, has elected L.K. Evans and John P. Sohn executive vice presidents.

headline: Ames Unit Link
abstract: Ames Department Stores Inc. and the G.C. Murphy Company said they had agreed to combine their discount retail chains, with Ames paying $48 a share, or a total of $198 million, for Murphy. Murphy's stock, which traded as low as $9.62 three years ago, closed at $47.75 a share today, up $2.375. Ames closed at $37.625 a share, up $2.125.

headline: F.D.I.C. Issues Bank Ruling
abstract: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation tentatively approved rules that would require federally insured banks to operate real estate development and insurance activities through separate subsidiaries.

headline: Advertising ;   HUMANA'S CARE PLUS CAMPAIGN
abstract: HAVING learned that it can increase the sales of group health plans to about 34 a week, from about four, by the simple addition of TV advertising in a test market, Humana Inc. of Louisville, Ky., is bumping its annual ad budget to more than $5 million from a mere $1 million, and is planning an incursion into Chicago, Miami and Oakland, Calif. It will be selling its Humana Care Plus plan.    And while up to now, Humana, whose 90-plus owned hospitals are the basis of its health, has restricted its selling activities to markets where it is represented by health-care institutions, in those three cities it will be breaking in a new concept it calls ''networking.'' That means lining up affiliated hospitals willing to maintain Humana standards and give group discounts to Humana policyholders.

headline: Karim Khalef Is Dead at 50; Former Mayor in West Bank
abstract: Karim Khalef, a former Mayor of the West Bank town of Ramallah who was maimed in a bombing in 1980, died Saturday of a heart attack, the Israeli radio reported. He was 50 years old.

headline: Paying Up at the I.M.F.
abstract: Even as the United States was severing trade links with Nicaragua, or maybe because of it, the Sandinista regime was quietly paying up arrears, totaling about $20 million, to the 148-nation International Monetary Fund.   Washington monetary officials believe that Managua acted out of fear of being stigmatized as ''ineligible'' for I.M.F. loans.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *       Amcast Industrial Corp.  Dayton, Ohio, said it had agreed in principle to sell its Ironton, Ohio, plant to a new employee-owned company, Ironton Iron Inc. Terms were not disclosed.     *        Continental Air Lines Corp., Houston, said Continental Air Lines began offering its nonstop Houston-to-London service with a $199 one-way promotional fare in coach class and a two-for-one ticket sale in first and business class. The fares will be available through May 31.

headline: Mengele Investigators Return to Brazil Grave
abstract: Brazilian and West German police investigators returned today to the grave of a man believed to be Josef Mengele to search for missing bones and other evidence needed for a positive identification of the long-missing Nazi doctor who friends and family say drowned in 1979.   What appeared to be several solid objects and clumps of earth from the grave at Embu, about 12 miles from Sao Paulo, were removed in plastic bags for analysis.

headline: U.S. Plans Military Exercise
abstract: The Defense Department said today that United States and Canadian forces would hold an air defense exercise Sunday over North America. Jet fighters from the North American Air Defense Command, a joint United States-Canadian military organization, will try to intercept bombers from the Strategic Air Command.

headline: RENE PORTOCARRERO
abstract: Rene Portocarrero, considered Cuba's finest modern artist, died today at the age of 73, the state-run press agency Prensa Latina reported.

headline: KIN OF 'OTHER HOSTAGES' SEE A CHANCE TO INCREASE EFFORTS FOR THEIR CAUSE
abstract: Relatives of ''the other hostages'' -the six or seven Americans who have spent the last three months to one year in captivity in Lebanon - generally hope the high level of attention focused on the hijacking of Trans World Airlines Flight 847 will help their own cause.   Some of them do not hide their bitterness toward the United States Government and news organizations, which they say have ignored the earlier kidnap victims or at least not done everything possible to obtain their release.   And while some prefer not to speak out on the complex issue, others openly express concern that any military action would be detrimental not only to the hostages but to all American residents in the area.   ''We feel the Reagan Administration hasn't done what it could have on our cases and we're disappointed in the media too,'' said Andrew Mihelich, a nephew who has been the spokesman for the family of the Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, a Roman Catholic priest kidnapped Jan. 8. Mr. Mihelich, who is College Administrator at Joliet College in Jolet, Illinois, said the hostage problem should be treated as ''an entire issue'' and not as two separate cases.

headline: Data Bank;   May 5, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: Temple-Inland To Buy G.E. Unit
abstract: Temple-Inland Inc. said that it had agreed to acquire the National Fidelity Life Insurance Company from the General Electric Company's financial services subsidiary.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THURSDAY, APRIL 11, 1985        Companies         An $18-a-share offer for control of Uniroyal was made by Carl C. Icahn, the Wall Street financier. The rubber company's stock closed at $18.75, indicating that the market expects a higher bid to emerge. Shareholders are scheduled to vote Tuesday on measures intended to make a takeover virtually impossible. Mr. Icahn, who holds about 10 percent of Uniroyal, is leading a proxy fight to defeat those measures. (Page D1.)         CBS stock plunged in heavy trading amid widespread rumors that Ivan F. Boesky was reducing his holdings. (D1.)

headline: Big Project On Hudson In Jersey
abstract: FOR all the projections and proposals for the New Jersey side of the Hudson River, the 18-mile-long sliver of land stretching from Fort Lee to Bayonne is still largely undeveloped.   Over the last three years nearly every acre of the waterfront has been claimed by developers ranging from local builders to Daniel K. Ludwig, one of the world's richest men. But for various reasons, including the long process of getting local and environmental approvals, as well as financing, most of the activity so far has been restricted to the construction of some expensive town houses in Edgewater and North Bergen and the conversion of old industrial buildings in Jersey City and Hoboken into offices.   About the only all-new commercial structure built recently is a 600-seat restaurant called Shanghai Red's, at the end of an old pier in Weehawken.

headline: Italian Premier Backs France's 'Eureka' Plan
abstract: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy said today that his country would seek to cooperate with a French-sponsored high technology program, but would not rule out participating in President Reagan's program on research into space-based weapons.   Speaking at a Renaissance palace here after two days of meetings with President Francois Mitterrand of France, Mr. Craxi continued his effort to achieve what Italians have called a ''harmonizing'' of the American space proposal with a French technology proposal known as ''Eureka.''   Mr. Craxi's stand was significant as another indication that despite French resistance to Mr. Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative, popularly known as 'Star Wars,' the European allies - and European companies - will find it difficult to resist the lure of high technology contracts.

headline: Xerox System
abstract: The Xerox Corporation said it was introducing an electronic publishing system that would automate the production of business publications, such as manuals, directories and catalogues. Xerox said the new XPS 700 publishing system would include editing and design pagination terminals, a 1,600-bit-per-inch magnetic tape drive, a high-capacity 456-megabyte disk drive and communications ports. The company said that in addition to input from  the terminals offered with the system, the XPS 700 can accept input from a variety of word processing machines, personal computers and grapic scanning machines from Xerox and other vendors.

headline: American Embassy in Cairo Is Sealed Off in Security Drill
abstract: Security forces staged a mock attack today on the United States Embassy, and armed policemen sealed off several blocks surrounding the mission, witnesses and embassy sources said.   Egyptian spokesmen refused official comment on the operation, but Foreign Ministry sources said it was a security drill involving the United States and other diplomatic missions in the neighborhood.

headline: REBELS TO VOTE IN NEW CALEDONIA
abstract: Kanak separatists in New Caledonia have chosen conciliation with France by deciding to take part in French-run elections in the territory and canceling a demonstration in Noumea, the capital.   Before closing a two-day congress late Sunday night, the Kanak Socialist National Liberation Front endorsed participation in the August poll, the first stage in a plan toward ending 130 years of French rule.   The roughly 1,500 separatist delegates also decided to cancel a June 8 independence rally in Noumea and to end a monthlong Kanak boycott of French-run schools. The boycott has been only partly successful.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: May 22, 1985 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Meets at 3 P.M.   Economic Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Social Committee - 10:30 A.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Wartime Mine Kills 4 in Riga
abstract: Three boys and a 77-year-old woman were killed in an explosion apparently caused by a World War II antitank mine in Riga, according to the newspaper Sovetskaya Latviya. The boys, aged between 7 and 12, were apparently playing with the mine, the paper said. The incident occurred on May 27.

headline: New Bid For Robertson
abstract: The battle for control of the H.H. Robertson Company heated up yesterday as a California investor offered $45 a share, or a total of about $247.5 million, for all of the company's shares. Robertson said it would reject the offer from Paul A. Bilzerian of Sacramento because it was subject to three ''highly subjective'' contingencies. Mr. Bilzerian later said he might try a hostile takeover.

headline: ANXIETY GROWING OVER PERU'S DEBT
abstract: By last summer, Peru's creditors had reluctantly concluded that no solution to the country's foreign debt problem would be possible before a new government takes office here on July 28.    President Fernando Belaunde Terry had not only suspended most payments on the $13.5 billion debt and repeatedly ignored the International Monetary Fund, but he was also spending heavily in a rush to complete a series of pet development projects.   Yet while Peru's financial situation deteriorated steadily, with interest arrears now exceeding $600 million, there was confidence that a new Government would have an I.M.F. ''adjustment'' program and a long-term debt rescheduling in place before the end of 1985.   In the past few weeks, however, that confidence has been shaken. Alan Garcia Perez, the 35-year-old Social Democrat who became President-elect on April 14, has already begun criticizing the I.M.F., raising the specter of a continuing confrontation between Peru and its creditors.

headline: Advertising;   A Marriage Made in the Backyard
abstract: UNDER the Mickelberry Group corporate umbrella, LCF&S has been merged into Nadler & Larimer to form Calvillo, Shevack, Goldberg & Partners, which has billings of about $60 million.   Arch Nadler and Robert Larimer, founders of the larger agency, which is bringing about $45 million in billings to the marriage, have retired but will be available for consultation.   LCF&S spun off from Laurence, Charles & Free, another Mickelberry company, in 1983, taking the Adidas sports shoes business. Its most recently acquired clients include the Uniden Corporation of America, a high-tech company largely in satellite transmitters; Sanyo copiers and computers, and, previously unannounced, the pension operations of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. The rest of Equitable remains at D'Arcy MacManus Masius, according to Brett Shevack, 35-year-old former president and creative director of LCF&S and now president and chief creative officer of C.S.G.&P.

headline: Unocal Wavers on Buyback
abstract: The Unocal Corporation said yesterday that it might end or amend its offer to buy back nearly 29 percent of its stock if it was unable to exclude shares owned by the investor group headed by T. Boone Pickens.   Unocal is appealing a decision issued on Monday by the Delaware Chancery Court that it must end its offer unless Mesa Partners II, the Pickens group, has the right to participate.   The Unocal offer to exchange each of 50 million shares for $72 of debt securities is aimed at warding off a hostile takeover attempt by the Pickens group. If Mesa Partners participates in the exchange, its net gain could amount to more than $150 million. That money could then be used to resume buying Unocal shares.

headline: C.I.A. STATEMENT DENIES BEIRUT BOMBING LINK
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency issued a statement today saying that it had not had advance knowledge of a car bombing in a Beirut suburb last March that killed more than 80 people.   Intelligence sources also said that the C.I.A. had no connection to a Lebanese counterterrorism group that reportedly hired the bombers.   But that account was disputed by some Administration and Congressional officials who said that the agency was working with the group at the time of the bombing.   One Administration official indicated that the C.I.A. and intelligence sources were trying to discount the agency's relationship to the counterterrorism unit out of fear that terrorists might retaliate against United States operations in Lebanon.

headline: Overseas Banking
abstract: To the Editor:   ''Bringing Competition to Canberra'' (April 14) left off Banque Nationale de Paris from the list of foreign banks in Australia. Banque Nationale de Paris has been a full trading (commercial) bank in Australia since 1881, when an enterprising Frenchman from Comptoir d'Escompte de Paris (later Comptoir National d'Escompte de Paris, which in 1966 merged with Banque Nationale pour le Commerce et l'Industrie to form B.N.P.) hopped on the ship to Australia to pre-export finance wool and hides going to France.KEN BARNETT Assistant Treasurer, B.N.P.   New York, April 15

headline: U.S. PROGRAM IN HONDURAS HELPS FAMILIES OF NICARAGUAN GUERRILLAS
abstract: The United States Government has begun to provide $7.5 million in medical and other nonmilitary aid to an area near a main camp in Honduras for guerrillas fighting the Nicaraguan Government.    A private American relief agency, Friends of America, is working in the same zone, near the Nicaraguan border, supported by conservative United States legislators and private church groups.    Officials in charge of the relief programs strongly denied in interviews that their intention was to assist guerrillas fighting the Sandinista Government, and a reporter found no evidence that either program has directly helped armed rebel fighters. But the projects appear to offer an example of how humanitarian assistance can indirectly support guerrilla fighters.

headline: French Offer Tenneco Aid
abstract: The French Finance Ministry said today that it would pay close to $4 million in subsidies if Tenneco Inc. takes over the International Harvester Company's French subsidiary, International Harvester France.   News reports said that Tenneco was planning to invest close to $60 million in a takeover, but the company has not yet announced any firm agreement.   On Monday, however, Tenneco said it expected to complete the acquisition of International Harvester's subsidiaries in France, West Germany and Denmark by mid-May.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: The tax system is 'a system whose most serious sin may be its most subtle. . . . For it seems so rigged, so unfair, that it corrupts otherwise honest people by encouraging them to cheat.'   President Reagan

headline: Ketchum President In New York Named
abstract: Thom Miller, 36 years old, has been running the Ketchum Advertising/ New York for about three years as executive vice president and chief executive officer. Well, top management at Ketchum Communications down in Pittsburgh has finally loosened up and bestowed the New York president's title on him.

headline: Philippine Official Denounces U.S. Senate for 'Interference'
abstract: A United States Senate resolution linking American aid to Philippine domestic policies was denounced today by a senior Cabinet member.   ''This is simple and pure interference or meddling in our domestic affairs by foreign Government officials,'' said the Cabinet member, Leonardo B. Perez, the Political Affairs Adviser.   The nonbinding Senate resolution, introduced by John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, was approved last week.

headline: Treasury Sales to Total $34.5 Billion
abstract: After a five-week lull in long-term Treasury financings, the Federal Government will dominate the credit markets this week with three note and bond auctions, totaling $20.5 billion, as well as a regular weekly sale of Treasury bills, totaling $14 billion.   The note and bond sales will pay off about $10.6 billion of maturing Treasury issues and raise $9.9 billion of new cash to finance the Federal budget deficit, while the bill sales will only refinance the same amount of maturing bills. In advance of today's three- and six-month bill auctions, the outstanding three-month issue was bid late Friday at 7.70 percent, while the six-month issue was at 7.90 percent.   Investors who are seeking higher yields and willing to accept more fluctuation in the price of their investments can select from $8 billion of new three-year Treasury notes, to be sold Tuesday; $6.5 billion of 10-year Treasury notes, to be sold Wednesday, or $6 billion of 11 1/4 percent Treasury bonds, to be sold Thursday. The bond issue will be an addition to the already outstanding 11 1/4 percent issue, due Feb. 15, 2015, which was auctioned Feb. 7.

headline: EGYPT'S LEADER URGES WASHINGTON NOT TO USE FORCE IN HOSTAGE CRISIS
abstract: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt today condemned the Beirut airline hijacking and other acts of terrorism, but urged the United States not to resort to military action to free the hostages or to retaliate.   ''I could tell you that any violence that is going to take place will lead to more violence,'' Mr. Mubarak told reporters when asked about the stationing of American warships off the coast of Lebanon following the hijacking.   President Mubarak, pressed further about whether he thought it would be a mistake for the United States to retaliate militarily, replied: ''I think there is no need for that, because it will not solve the problem at all.''   He denounced the seizure of the T.W.A. Boeing 727 and the detention of some 40 American passengers in questions after a major speech that attacked Islamic fundamentalism. Though he did not mention fundamentalist forces by name, Mr. Mubarak said he would not tolerate ''agitation and marches'' under ''slogans that appear good on the surface but have all kinds of evil underneath.''

headline: Afghan Talks Scheduled
abstract: Talks on the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan will resume in two weeks when representatives from Pakistan and Afghanistan meet in Geneva with a United Nations envoy, a spokesman announced today. The discussions began in 1982, with the last round ending in August 1984.

headline: Sallie Mae Notes
abstract: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday offered $300 million of short-term floating-rate notes due Nov. 14, 1985, at a price of 100, through various securities dealers. The interest on the floating-rate notes will be adjusted weekly at two-tenths of one percentage point above the average bond equivalent yield set at the weekly auction of 91-day Treasury bills. Interest will be paid at maturity.

headline: LAST-HOUR FIREWORKS FROM OPTIONS, FUTURES
abstract: It was what Wall Street called the ''double witching hour'' between 3 and 4 P.M. yesterday, as arbitragers and institutional traders had their final opportunity to close out both June stock-index options and futures positions. The activity gave a strong boost to the Dow Jones industrial average and volume on the New York Stock Exchange.   The Dow closed at 1,324.48 for the day, up 24.75 points, with 14.90 points of that gain occurring in the last hour of trading. Turnover amounted to 125.4 million shares, with 38.7 million of those shares changing hands after 3 P.M.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Atlantic Richfield Co. is issuing $250 million of 10 1/4 percent Eurobonds due 2000 at a price of 99 3/4 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers International.    * Chase Manhattan Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $250 million of two-year extendible notes due 1997 through Salomon Brothers.

headline: AGAINST BITBURG VISIT, GIRL SAYS
abstract: A 13-year-old Jewish girl cited by President Reagan as supporting his decision to lay a wreath at the Bitburg cemetery honoring ''the future of Germany'' said today that she actually opposed his visit to the military gravesite.   The girl, Beth Flom of Marlboro Township, N.J., said that in a telex she sent to President Reagan on April 21, she made it clear she disapproved of his decision to visit Bitburg.

headline: RADIO MARTI GOES ON AIR AND CUBA RETALIATES BY ENDING PACT
abstract: A new United States broadcasting service aimed at Cuba went on the air shortly before dawn today, and the Cuban Government responded sharply by suspending a major immigration agreement with the United States and threatening other measures.   In a strongly worded statement condemning the new service, known as Radio Marti, Cuba said it was also suspending visits to Cuba by Cubans living in the United States.   The immigration agreement, the first major agreement between the two countries in seven years, provided for the return to Cuba of nearly 3,000 Cubans with histories of crime or mental illness and the acceptance by the United States of up to 20,000 Cuban immigrants a year.      Reagan Statement Broadcast    The United States also agreed to accept about 3,000 political prisoners who had been released from jails some years ago. The Cuban Government's action today appeared to bring these procedures to a halt.

headline: OIL PRICE FALL SEEN PERSISTING
abstract: Industry reports that Norway is cutting oil prices mark a new downward trend that will persist for a few months at least, analysts said yesterday.   Norway has been considered an oil-price leader since it cut prices last October, initiating a important round of declines. Its latest cut by Statoil, reported by industry sources over the weekend, lowers its North Sea crude by up to $1 a barrel, to about $26.50 for June deliveries.   ''This Norwegian development reflects what has been going on in the market for five weeks,'' said Philip L. Dodge, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''We are definitely in a weak phase of the price cycle.''

headline: Argentina Is Reported Close to I.M.F. Accord
abstract: Argentina has virtually completed negotiations with the International Monetary Fund on a new loan program to replace the one suspended by the fund in February, a source close to the negotiations said yesterday.   President Raul Alfonsin ''jumped the gun'' in his announcement of an agreement on Friday, the source said, adding that an official statement would probably be made today or tomorrow.

headline: SILESIAN EXILES JEER KOHL SPEECH
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl insisted to a Silesian exile organization today that West Germany had no claims on the territory of Poland and would not raise them in the future.   Making an appearance in Hanover before the Silesian Compatriot Association, a group representing Germans who fled their homeland at the end of World War II, Mr. Kohl was repeatedly interrupted by hecklers who whistled and shouted and flashed Hitler-style salutes.   Mr. Kohl's forthright endorsement of a 1970 treaty with Poland, which implicitly recognized its existing frontiers, was unwelcome to many of the 10,000 Silesians and their descendants who heard the Chancellor. He was roundly jeered when he made friendly allusions to Poland and praised Silesians who had plotted against Hitler.

headline: VMS Realty to Buy Holiday Inn Units
abstract: The Holiday Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell as many as 28 hotels to VMS Realty Inc. of Chicago for more than $400 million.   Holiday said that its subsidiary, Holiday Inns, would continue to operate the hotels under long-term management contracts. The company, based in Memphis, said that if all 28 units were sold, the deal would yield $200 million in cash after mortgages on the properties were paid off.

headline: Yugoslav Judge Jails 11
abstract: A judge sentenced 11 Croatians today to terms of up to 15 years and said Croatian, Serbian and Albanian nationalists had united in a struggle against Communist rule in Yugoslavia. The 11 Croatians were part of a group tried on charges of involvement in bomb attacks as part of a campaign for an independent nation of Croatia.

headline: BANK CUT PRIME RATE TO 9 1/2%
abstract: The nation's major banks cut their prime rate half a percentage point yesterday, to 9 1/2 percent. This is the first time the benchmark lending rate has been below 10 percent since 1978.   The drop in the prime rate, to which many loans in the United States and abroad are tied, is expected to stimulate the nation's economy. Also businesses, individuals and debtor nations that are carrying an immense amount of floating-rate debt should find it easier to repay their loans.

headline: O'CONNOR OF NEW YORK
abstract: John Joseph O'Connor, the 65-year-old Archbishop of New York, has been a forceful presence during his first 14 months as head of the nation's fourth largest archdiocese.   As the eighth archbishop of New York's 1.8 million Roman Catholics, he has become embroiled in political debate over abortion and homosexuality,has sharply attacked social problems such as hunger and homelessness and has firmly defended church doctrine. The Archbishop of New York has customarily been named a cardinal and the elevation of Archbishop O'Connor was expected. The last five of his seven predecessors had also been elevated to Cardinal.

headline: POWER PLANT FOR TEXAS
abstract: A subsidiary of Internorth Inc. will build a new power plant in Texas City to provide electricity to customers of the Texas Utilities Electric Company of Dallas, Internorth announced today.

headline: Taft Agrees to Sell 5 Radio Stations
abstract: The Taft Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it plans to sell five radio stations, two of its own and three belonging to the Gulf Broadcast Company, in order to pave the way for Taft's acquisition of several Gulf properties.   Last February, Taft agreed to purchase five television stations and seven radio stations from Gulf Broadcast for $755 million. To get Federal Communications Commission approval, Taft said that it must sell either the radio or the television station in those markets in which it would own both as a result of the acquisition. F.C.C. regulations forbid one company to own both television and radio stations in the same market.

headline: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: In Washington, a Tense Watch;   RELEASE OF HOSTAGES PUT OFF AS LEBANESE CALL FOR PROMISE THAT U.S. WILL NOT STRIKE BACK U.S. IS DISAPPOINTED
abstract: A White House spokesman said today that President Reagan was ''obviously disappointed'' by the failure of the plan to free the American air hostages. But he said the President hoped for an early resolution of the 15-day-old hijacking crisis.   Senior Administration officials, looking fatigued from being up through the night, said they could not predict when the arrangements for freedom for the 39 Americans from the Trans World Airlines plane would be put together again after the talks had been snagged by a demand from the hostages' captors for a guarantee that the United States would not retaliate.   But later tonight, in what appeared to be an effort to advance the diplomatic efforts to resolve the standoff, the State Department took the unusual step of issuing a statement without elaboration.      'Preservation of Lebanon'    At 10:30 P.M., in what seemed to be a response to the insistence of Nabih Berri, the Lebanese Shiite Moslem leader, that the United States pledge that it would not attack Lebanon once the hostages were released, a State Department spokesman said that ''the United States reaffirms its longstanding support for the preservation of Lebanon, its Government, its stability, and its security, and for the mitigation of the suffering of its people.''

headline: POPE AND JEWISH LEADERS MARK IMPROVED TIES
abstract: A group of Roman Catholic and Jewish religious leaders this week celebrated the 20th anniversary of a declaration by the Second Vatican Council that revolutionized the relationship between Catholics and Jews.    Pope John Paul II told the group that the Holocaust, ''which so cruelly decimated the Jewish people,'' was the result of ''an absence of faith in God,'' and said Catholics and Jews should join together to help restore religious faith.   The Vatican Council declaration, ''Nostra Aetate,'' or ''In Our Time,'' in 1965 rejected the once widely held Christian view that the Jewish people were responsible for the death of Christ.   At the conference, the document was repeatedly hailed by both Catholic and Jewish leaders. But one prominent Italian Jewish leader strongly criticized the Pope for his recent meeting with leaders of Europe's far right.

headline: C.&W. Is Assigned New Beecham Billing
abstract: Cunningham & Walsh, a Mickelberry company that already serves Beecham Inc., has been assigned that company's Beecham Home Improvement Products subsidiary.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 12, 1985    International    The I.M.F. said Argentina had agreed on an austerity program that opens the door to $1.2 billion of loans from the fund. The measures include cuts in money supply growth, higher interest rates and a limit on wage increases. The agreement calls for the inflation rate, which ran 1,010 percent in the last 12 months, to be cut to an annual rate of 150 percent by next April. Argentina is more than $1 billion in arrears on its $48 billion debt to foreign creditors. [Page A1.]  Argentine officials, who had played down the hardships of previous austerity programs, announced an 18 percent devaluation of the peso and warned that sacrifices lie ahead. [D6.]      The Economy    The tax plan had a difficult day before a Senate committee as senators took issue with many of its central elements during testimony by Treasury Secretary Baker. The reception seemed to confirm Administration fears that its plan would face rougher going in the Republican-controlled Senate than in the House. [D1.]  The House Ways and Means Committee heard criticism of the tax plan from economists who warned that it might slow the economy. [D5.]

headline: Gas Contracts
abstract: To the Editor:   Your article ''The Long Litigation over Broken Contracts'' (April 7) inaccurately depicts Tenneco's natural gas purchase policies. Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co. did not cancel its purchase contracts or take-or-pay provisions, and did not announce it would ''chop 42 cents per thousand cubic feet from suppliers' invoices.''   In early 1983, natural gas prices had risen too high and the resulting soft market threatened the entire natural gas industry. Tennessee attempted to renegotiate its contracts, but producers refused, apparently believing the problem would resolve itself.

headline: FOR RADIO MARTI, CHEERS IN MIAMI, SCORN IN CUBA
abstract: There was joy in Miami today, outrage in Havana and rising debate on the benefits to the United States of the Government's new broadcasting service directed at Cuba.   Some experts on Cuba and in the field of communications said they were dubious of the need for the new service, known as Radio Marti, and of its potential effectiveness.   Furthermore, they said that since Radio Marti's inception on Monday, the United States had paid a high price in increased tensions with Cuba and the suspension by the Cubans of a major immigration agreement that benefited both countries.   But John R. Silber, the president of Boston University and a member of the Radio Marti Advisory Board, said ''no price is too high to take a stand against totalitarianism.''

headline: A New Economic Council
abstract: Trade issues, fast exploding into perhaps the hottest potato of the second Reagan term, will get more concentrated attention under a White House reorganization announced last week.    The new Economic Policy Council, under Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, has now become the principal body for setting trade strategy.

headline: Xerox's Debt Rating Reduced
abstract: Ratings on debt of the Xerox Corporation were reduced yesterday, Moody's Investors Service announced. The changes affect about $2.4 billion of securities issued by Xerox, the Xerox Credit Corporation and Xerox's overseas finance company.

headline: U.S. Ships Off Lebanon
abstract: The world's second nuclear-powered aircraft carrier was sailing from Haifa, Israel, to Livorno, Italy, when it was dispatched to waters off Lebanon in response to the hostage crisis. Built after two years of delays in the delivery and testing of its nuclear plant components, the Nimitz is equipped with rockets, missiles and more than 90 aircraft. It was commissioned in 1975 at an estimated cost of $1,881 million. Displacement: 91,487 tons. Aircraft: More than 90. Complement: 6,300, which includes 3,000 assigned to air wing. Missiles: Three launchers with Sea Sparrow missiles. Gunnery: Three 20mm Mark 15 Close In Weapon Systems. Rockets: Mark 36 Super Rapid Blooming Offboard Chaff, used as large decoys. Speed: About 30 knots. Endurance: 13 years for reactors, 16 days for aviation fuel. Combat Ships of the Nimitz Group Navy department spokesmen say that normally a battle group is accompanied by one or more ships carrying fuel, ammunition and supplies. Frequently there is also an attack submarine, though the U.S. Navy, as a matter of routine, does not comment on the identity or whereabouts of submarines. South Carolina. A nuclear-propelled guided-missile cruiser equipped with two 20 mm Mark 15 guns, two 5-inch guns and 80 surface-to-air missiles. Commissioned in 1975 and built for $180 million. Kidd. One of the most powerful destroyers in the U.S. fleet, designed for general warfare instead of anti-submarine warfare. Equipped with two helicopters, two 5-inch guns, 68 surface-to-air missiles and two torpedo launchers.

headline: Harriman Honored by Soviet For His Role in World War II
abstract: The Soviet Union has awarded W. Averell Harriman, a former Ambassador to Moscow, its Order of the Patriotic War, First Degree, citing his ''great personal contributions to the improvement and strengthening of Soviet-American cooperation'' in World War II.   The announcement was made in Moscow yesterday by the official press agency Tass, which said the award was made ''in connection with the 40th anniversary of victory'' over Nazi Germany.   In a statement made public in Washington, Mr. Harriman, who served in Moscow from 1943 to 1946, said he was ''proud to work with the Soviet Union in our common struggle'' against the Nazis and that he would ''never forget the enormous and heroic sacrifices made by the people of the Soviet Union'' in World War II.

headline: WISDOM OF THE PEOPLE EMPHASIZED AS PRESIDENT SETS POPULIST STRATEGY
abstract: President Reagan today outlined the strategy he will use to sell his landmark tax simplification plan as he braced his senior aides for a long and difficult battle.   Mr. Reagan, offering the image of his Presidency at halftime of a critical football game, said that the proposal would pit the wisdom of the American people against the wisdom of the Washington establishment. In the end Mr. Reagan reportedly said, the wisdom of the people would prevail.   According to aides present at the private meeting, Mr. Reagan elaborated on his populist theme as follows: ''The premise the founding fathers built our government on is that over the long run the uncommon wisdom of the common people is far greater than that found in any gathering of Washington officials or politicians.

headline: SOVIET ENDORSES BID FOR A HALT THIS YEAR TO ALL NUCLEAR TESTS
abstract: The Soviet Union has endorsed a Washington group's proposal for a ban on all nuclear tests by Aug. 6, the 40th anniversary of the atomic attack on Hiroshima. The United States, however, has rejected the proposal.

headline: THE RUMORS ABOUT HILTON
abstract: WHY, investors on Wall Street are asking themselves, has the stock of the Hilton Hotels Corporation been rising steadily in the last few days when the casino and lodging company seems to have successfully fought off the unwelcome advances of Stephen A. Wynn and his Golden Nugget?   In answer, they point to vague rumors that somebody else may have set his sights on taking over Hilton, or that the company's management might even be planning a deal of its own.   Hilton's stock, which has risen 3 3/4 points in the past two sessions, closing at 68 1/2 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, seems to be benefiting from a variety of rumors, the loudest of which is that the company might use cash it recently raised to buy back some of its publicly held shares.   But that is only part of the speculation. Investment banking sources say there have been more interesting rumors that Hilton is trying to raise additional funds, and this has created suspicions that the company might eventually attempt a leveraged buyout.

headline: Reagan Criticizes High-Tax States
abstract: President Reagan, stumping through the South in support of his tax plan, said today that people in low-tax states should not have to pay for the policies of high-tax states.   Before he flew to Atlanta, Mr. Reagan's first stop was an AT&T Technologies plant at Oklahoma City.

headline: Guarding the Price Index
abstract: With trading to begin next week in futures contracts on the Consumer Price Index, the Labor Department has strengthened security measures to guard against leaks. The new contract, to be traded on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, is the first based on a general-purpose figure produced by the Federal Government.   ''The existence of the new futures market will give the C.P.I. a direct monetary value as a traded commodity and will increase the incentive of those who may seek to gain unauthorized access to pre-release data,'' Janet L. Norwood, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told Congress.

headline: TAX URGED ON HEALTH PREMIUMS
abstract: Reversing its position, the Treasury Department is recommending that all workers be required to pay taxes on a small portion of the health insurance benefits their employers pay, Administration officials said today.   They said this was one of dozens of tax policy recommendations that President Reagan has taken with him to review during his European trip. They said that the Treasury was receiving daily communications from Secretary James A. Baker 3d, who is traveling with the President, indicating what decisions the President had made on taxes, and that a final proposal for revamping the nation's tax system would probably be sent to Congress the week after next.   The Treasury is recommending that the first $25 a month of employer-paid health insurance premiums should be taxable to workers and that most other fringe benefits should go untaxed, the officials said.

headline: Merrill Lynch Reports Net Tripled in Quarter
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company, parent of the nation's largest stock brokerage, yesterday reported a tripling of its net earnings in the first quarter from the year earlier, aided by the booming stock market and a tough cost-cutting program begun last year.    Merrill Lynch said that its net income in the first three months of the year totaled $55.6 million, or 58 cents a share, up sharply from $18.6 million, or 21 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1984.   Revenues rose 14.4 percent, to $1.59 billion, from $1.39 billion in the comparable period of 1984. Total expenses rose 8 percent, to $1.497 billion.

headline: Peru Debt Assessment
abstract: The Peruvian Economy Minister, Guillermo Garida Lecca, told reporters today that he doubted commercial bank creditors would attach Peruvian assets at present since such a move would risk straining ties with the incoming administration.         ''I think the possibility of embargo is remote at this moment,'' he said. ''It would be very improbable that the banks would carry out the embargo or adopt those attitudes when we are at the verge of a new Government.'' Mr. Garida Lecca said a seizure of assets could only bring about a greater confrontation with the new Government, whose officials the banks had not had the opportunity to talk to.

headline: MADISON APPOINTS NEW CHIEF
abstract: Madison Resources Inc., an exploration and oil producing company, said yesterday that Stanley R. Rawn Jr. had been named chairman and chief executive officer.   Mr. Rawn, who is 57 years old, succeeds George D. Gould, also 57, who is expected to be nominated this month to a new post at the Treasury Department overseeing domestic banking regulation.   Madison Resources said yesterday that Mr. Gould would serve as chairman of its finance committee pending his appointment and confirmation for the Treasury post. When that occurs, he will resign from the company, Madison Resources said.

headline: HOPES FOR DOMESTIC BENEFIT
abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan, buffeted by recent political changes in his country, hopes to bolster his domestic standing when he meets President Reagan in Washington Friday.   Officials of the two nations say Mr. Chun, who left for Washington today, can expect White House support on most fundamental issues. These include South Korea's military plans, its strategies for dealing with North Korea and its efforts in what the Seoul Government calls ''political development'' but that critics call human rights problems.

headline: EVIDENCE IS SAID TO POINT TO MENGELE IDENTIFICATION
abstract: The Brazilian official in charge of the Josef Mengele investigation said today that ''all experts are coming to the same conclusion'' and that he hoped to have an announcement by the end of this week.   Romeu Tuma, the Federal police chief in Sao Paulo, stopped short of saying that the experts were convinced that the bones unearthed in a suburban cemetery June 6 were in fact those of the fugitive death camp doctor. But he left little doubt that the forensic tests were backing up previous testimony of witnesses who said that Dr. Mengele drowned at a nearby beach in 1979 and was buried under another name in the cemetery at Embu.   A test of the age of the skeleton - Dr. Mengele would have been almost 68 when he died - ''seems to be positive,'' Mr. Tuma said. ''What's missing are three or four more tests.''

headline: DYNAMICS HEAD PLANS TO RETIRE BY END OF 1985
abstract: The chairman of the embattled General Dynamics Corporation, David S. Lewis, said yesterday that he would retire from the giant military contracting company by the end of this year.   The 67-year-old Mr. Lewis made his announcement one day after the Secretary of the Navy, John F. Lehman Jr., canceled two contracts and suspended the signing of new ones at two of the company's biggest divisions.   Secretary Lehman cited ''pervasive'' business misconduct by General Dynamics, which has been under investigation for fraud and deliberate overcharges on a variety of military projects. But he turned down a recommendation from the Pentagon's Inspector General to ban Mr. Lewis and two other top company officials from working on military contracts.

headline: Leucadia Starts Proxy Fight
abstract: The Leucadia National Corporation began a proxy fight yesterday to place four directors on National Intergroup Inc.'s board and to institute a recapitalization plan that Leucadia asserts would increase National Intergroup's value to shareholders.   Leucadia is National Intergroup's largest shareholder, with a 9 percent stake.

headline: Agency in Wisconsin Offers Housing Bonds
abstract: The Wisconsin Housing and Economic Development Authority is offering $170 million of single-family housing revenue bonds in a wide variety of forms through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.   By selling bonds in the tax-exempt bond market, local housing authorities have recently been able to make available long-term fixed-rate mortgages at rates of about 9 1/2 percent to 10 percent.

headline: TERRORIST THREAT TO SUBWAYS PUTS TORONTO POLICE ON ALERT
abstract: The police continued to keep a close watch in and around the subway system today, a day after an Armenian terrorist group had said it would detonate a bomb there.     Torontonians meanwhile nervously went about their business after the unusual decision of local officials to disclose the threat last Friday. In Europe and the United States, threats of general terrorism, rather than those to a specific site, are normally not made public.

headline: HYPER-INFLATION TRAUMATIZES BOLIVIA
abstract: Bolivia has entered the world of hyper-inflation, a twilight zone where banks no longer function, bills are paid with foot-long bundles of folding paper money and buying sprees overtake the most sensible person.     Americans were frantic several years ago when faced with double- digit inflation. For Bolivians, inflation jumped to triple digits in 1982 and quadruple figures in 1984. Based on economic data for January, inflation is now running at an annual rate of more than 50,000 percent, although some economists estimate conservatively that by the end of the year the annual rate will be only 16,000 percent.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;Israeli Officer Punished For Prisoner Privileges
abstract: An officer of the Israeli Border Police was punished today for giving special privileges to Jews accused of terrorism who are on trial in Jerusalem's District Court.         The commander of the border police demoted the officer, Chief Inspector Meir  Levi, to inspector, fined him 15 days' pay and reprimanded him after a summary disciplinary trial.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation said it planned to sell the buildings, equipment and vehicles at two of its Montana mills at public auctions later this month.

headline: Israelis Bid Aviation Agency Take Up Anti-Terrorist Steps
abstract: Israel asked the International Civil Aviation Organization today to reconsider anti-terrorist measures the agency had rejected previously for political and budgetary reasons.   The Israeli Minister of Transport, Haim Corfu, said in Jerusalem that he had asked the president of the aviation agency, Assad Koaite, to summon an extraordinary session of the General Assembly of 147 member countries to discuss the latest wave of terrorism.   Shay Shohamy, director of civil aviation who represented Israel at the earlier sessions, recalled that he had introduced a list of 50 measures at a session of the assembly in January 1978 but most had been rejected for ''budgetary and political reasons.''

headline: Sprinkel Wins Confirmation
abstract: Beryl W. Sprinkel was confirmed by the Senate today to be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

headline: Sudanese Rebels Reject New Military Rule
abstract: Sudanese rebels fighting for autonomy in the southern Sudan have renewed their denunciations of the new Government, calling the civilian Prime Minister ''a figurehead'' and vowing not to negotiate a truce with the country's military Government.   The southern rebels, rejecting peace overtures from the Government in Khartoum, the capital, said in a radio broadcast Monday, which was monitored in Nairobi, that Dr. al-Gazouly Dafallah, the physician named last week by the ruling Military Council to be Prime Minister, is ''a figurehead with no power.''   Gen. Abdel Rahman Siwar el-Dahab set up a 15-man Military Council, which he heads, and promised a return to civilian rule within a year.

headline: PUSHING AMERICA OUT OF CHIPS
abstract: JUST a summer ago, the makers of computer chips rode atop the high-tech world. To supply parts for a seemingly insatiable computer industry, giants like Texas Instruments and Mostek raced to retool their plants for a new generation of memory chips. And three Silicon Valley stalwarts, National Semiconductor, Advanced Micro Devices, and Intel, spent hundreds of millions of dollars adding plant capacity - sure of a quick payback.   This summer, in hindsight, those grand expansion plans look like they were assembled by brash river explorers who discover too late that the noise ahead is Niagara Falls. The industry's strategy of overcoming Japanese competition with a combination of new technology and greater manufacturing muscle has gone dramatically awry. A huge flow of Japanese-made chips, combined with slow computer sales and wild price cutting from Japan, have plunged American semiconductor makers into their deepest slump ever. More importantly, the downturn has brought permanent damage to one of the few manufacturing industries whose rapid growth had raised hopes of supplanting the declining rust industries.

headline: DOW EDGES UP BY 1.43 AS TRADERS TURN WARY
abstract: Stock prices closed slightly higher in a light session on Wall Street yesterday as big and small investors pulled out of the market for fear of potential wild price gyrations caused by the expiration of stock index options.     But the erratic price movement seen on previous options closing dates never occurred, traders said, because there was a balance of buyers and sellers in the final minutes.   The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.43 points to close at 1,266.56. For the week, the Dow gained 0.88 point.

headline: 11 KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICAN STRIKE
abstract: At least 11 blacks were reported killed today after a night and day of clashes between migrant workers and longtime residents of a township 30 miles east of here.   The police attributed the fighting to tribal differences, but other accounts indicated economic rivalries between residents of the township, Tsakane, and migrants accused of working for lower wages.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Mennen Shift To McCann Set
abstract: conflict developing at SSC&B,   the Mennen Company is   switching its Speed Stick deodorant and Afta after shave lotion to McCann-Erickson. What   makes the move particularly   interesting is that both agencies are part of the Interpublic   Group of Companies and that   Mennen is not letting its conflict worries extend beyond an   individual agency.

headline: Lorillard Chief Is Appointed
abstract: The Loews Corporation announced that J. Robert Ave, president and chief operating officer of its Lorillard subsidiary, had been named chief executive of the tobacco manufacturing unit. The appointment is effective today.   Mr. Ave succeeds Curtis H. Judge, who is retiring. Mr. Judge, 60, has served as chairman and chief executive of Lorillard since March 1, 1984. From 1970 until 1984, he was president and chief executive.

headline: Jordan Jet in Athens Damaged by Bazooka
abstract: An unidentified man fired a bazooka at a Jordanian airliner today as it prepared to take off for Amman, causing minor damage, the Greek police said.    An announcement said ''a young man with a tanned complexion'' was spotted as he fired his bazooka from behind a bush, in an opening in the fencing of Athens International Airport.

headline: Ruling Against Robins
abstract: A panel of Federal judges has rejected the A.H. Robins Company's efforts to move pretrial matters here for all pending Federal lawsuits on the Dalkon Shield intrauterine birth-control device. The seven-member Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation ruled that the 1,700 Federal suits should stay where they are, saying there was no need ''for disrupting the many Dalkon Shield actions.'' The pharmaceutical company distributed the Dalkon Shield from 1971 to mid-1974, when the device was pulled from the market after women began complaining of pelvic infections and other problems they said were associated with the use of the shield.

headline: Rockwell Starts Additional Layoffs
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation has begun laying off between 300 and 400 of its 7,000 workers from its space operations facility in Downey, Calif., after the National Aeronautics and Space Administration discontinued a portion of the company's work on spare parts for the space shuttle.   Last month, 1,800 workers were laid off at Rockwell's southern California facilities after the last shuttle orbiter was delivered in April. A company spokesman said some of the workers from each round of layoffs might be reassigned to other Rockwell sites.

headline: ARGENTINA FACES NEW FINANCIAL TEST
abstract: A high-level Government official sat in his office last Friday and painted a convincing scenario in which Argentina would once again recover from a financial crisis.   ''It is at a very critical point,'' he said. ''But, believe me, we want nothing more than to settle everything, and so we are going to.''   Late that night, the Government tried to settle - at least temporarily - one of the flashpoints of the latest crisis when it announced that it had frozen all dollar accounts for 120 days. Other foreign currency accounts were also frozen. The freezing of assets was an attempt to end a flood of bank withdrawals that began about 10 days ago when the Government closed a large bank on the verge of failure, the eighth private bank to be shut in two months.

headline: SRI LANKA AND REBELS ANNOUNCE A CEASE-FIRE
abstract: The Sri Lanka Government announced today that separatist guerrillas had agreed to a cease-fire, the first in more than two years of fighting.   A spokesman for the Tamil Tigers Movement, the largest insurgent group, confirmed the agreement in a telephone interview from the southern Indian city of Madras. But he said he had no details of the accord.

headline: DISCORD AMONG SIKHS BLOCKS TALKS
abstract: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's attempt to negotiate a solution to the angry dispute with India's Sikhs has stalled because of factionalism and disarray among Sikh leaders.   Last week the longstanding rivalry between militants and moderates among the Sikh leaders flared into the open in an unusual display of rancor. Each side claimed the role of leadership, with the result that there is to be a meeting later this month to decide the issue.   Mr. Gandhi, in Parliament last week, announced that the Government would wait before making any more concessions to the Sikhs or their fractious political party, the Akali Dal. ''Let the Akali Dal consolidate itself,'' he said, appearing to show frustration.

headline: V. A. Mortgage Rate Trimmed
abstract: The Government said today that it was lowering the maximum interest rate on federally backed Veterans Administration mortgages for single- family homes to 12.5 percent, from 13 percent.

headline: ITT Director Resigns Post
abstract: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that Alvin Friedman had resigned after 15 years as an outside director ''to pursue other personal interests.''

headline: Hebrew National Account to TBWA
abstract: TBWA Advertising has won the competition for the Hebrew National Kosher Food account, whose budget is expected to be $2.5 million to $3 million.   The products involved are the hot dogs, salamis and pickles, all of which are in spotty distribution throughout the country. All of the advertising was previously done by Geers, Gross Advertising and before them, by Scali, McCabe, Sloves.

headline: TAX AIDES PUT CHOICE TO REAGAN
abstract: President Reagan met today with his chief tax policy advisers from the White House and the Treasury Department and was given three alternatives for reducing the 50 percent top tax rate that applies to individuals, according to Administration officials.   They said Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d suggested that the top rate could be 30 percent, 35 percent or a figure in between, depending on what other elements the President wants to include in his plan to overhaul the income tax system.   The President, according to the officials, made no final decision on the top rate or other tax matters, and another meeting was scheduled for Wednesday.   One White House adviser who attended today's meeting called it a general discussion during which ''all points were presented to the President.'' Other officials said the President would probably settle on a final plan in the next day or two, announce it in a television address early next week and then submit it to Congress.

headline: Hanoi Sends Troops To Cambodian Border
abstract: Vietnam has sent a fresh battalion of 600 soldiers into combat with Thai soldiers near the Thai-Cambodian border, Thailand's naval commander said today.   Vietnamese and Thai troops have been battling in Thailand's southeastern Trat Province since late last month, when Hanoi's forces crossed into Thai territory in pursuit of Cambodian guerrillas.

headline: Exxon Shifts Refinery
abstract: The Exxon Corporation's European unit said today that it was temporarily shutting down oil refinery capacity in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, to convert to a sophisticated new $1.2 billion Flexicoker conversion project that produces higher grade petroleum derivatives from vacuum distillates.   The closing, effective from June 15 to next March 1, is part of a major rescaling of the European oil refining industry, which has seen unprofitable refineries shut down and new ones built to squeeze more high-value products from each barrel of oil at lower cost.   The idea is to offset the decline in demand for heavy petroleum products, such as heating oil, by shifting to lighter, more costly products.

headline: Concessions on Conrail Sale
abstract: The Reagan Administration agreed today to deny to the Norfolk Southern Corporation a large part of the potential tax benefits that Norfolk Southern might realize if Congress approves its proposed purchase of Conrail.    The concession by Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole was one of several she offered during a House subcommittee hearing on the proposed sale.

headline: Tax Fairness: What Is It?
abstract: PRESIDENT REAGAN has declared the aims of his proposed revision of the tax system to be ''fairness, growth and simplicity.'' Of the three goals, fairness is the hardest to define objectively.   Growth can be measured as the rate of increase in the gross national product, adjusted for inflation - or, more fundamentally, the growing capability of the United States to produce goods and services. But will the President's tax proposal increase growth, as he says, or slow it down, as the plan's critics assert? At a news briefing last week, Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House director of communications, said, ''They've got their economists and we've got ours.''

headline: DEPOSITS OF CHINATOWN BANK SOLD
abstract: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, one of the biggest banks in Asia, agreed yesterday to acquire $117 million of insured deposits of the Golden Pacific National Bank, the Chinatown bank that was closed last Friday by Federal authorities.   If approved by the courts, the bank's headquarters on Canal Street and its three branches - one in Manhattan's Chinatown and two in Queens - would reopen as branches of Hongkong and Shanghai. Officials of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which took over Golden Pacific after it was declared insolvent, said they hoped the branches would reopen by Friday.      Uncertainty on Deposits    At a news conference held yesterday to announce the agreement, Alan Whitney, the F.D.I.C.'s chief spokesman, said that prospects remained unclear for the uninsured depositors and other creditors to whom the bank owes $49 million.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH LEADER OF SHIITE MILITIA
abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview with Nabih Berri, the leader of the Shiite Moslem movement Amal, on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' as recorded by The New York Times:   Q. As you know, the Israeli Government today released 31 Lebanese Shiites, those people who were detained near Haifa. Do you regard this as a good-will gesture from Israel? And what do you say about it?   A. What we are asking, please, we're asking about 731, not 31.   Q. We understand that you are asking for all of them, but do you see this as a first step?

headline: In Brief: Reagan's Key Points
abstract: Tax Rates Individuals would be taxed at 15, 25 and 35 percent with the top rate falling on income taxable income above $70,000 on joint returns, and above $42,000 on single returns. The tax code now more than a dozen brackets ranging from 11 percent to 50 percent . Corporations, which now pay rates up to 46 percent, would pay graduated rates of 15, 18, 25 and 33 percent. Personal ExemptionTThe figure would rise to $2,000 from $1,040 for the taxpayer and each dependent. Standard deduction would rise to $3,000 for single filers, from $2,390. On joint returns it would increase to $4,000, from $3,540. Interest Expense Mortgage interest would remain deductible for principal residences. Deductions for other personal interest would be limited to $5,000 above investment income. Charitable Gifts Contributions would remain fully deductible only for taxpayers who itemize. State and Local Taxes The deduction for income taxes would be repealed. Property taxes, sales taxes and other levies would not be deductible unless incurred in income-producing activity. Fringes Company-paid health benefits would be taxed as income up to $10 a month for individuals and $25 for joint filers. Business Deductions for sports, theater, and similar entertainment would be disallowed. Deductions would be denied for 50 percent of costs of meals above a specific figure, and travel deductions restricted. Income Shifting Using trusts to shift taxable income to children, who fall into lower brackets, would be curtailed. Capital Gains They are be taxed as ordinary income but with 50 percent excluded from tax, which yields a top rate of 17.5 percent.

headline: Murdoch Gets Paper Inquiries
abstract: Rupert Murdoch, who earlier this week agreed to buy Metromedia Inc.'s television stations with a partner, has received several ''serious'' inquiries about buying three of his newspapers, including The New York Post, his spokesman said yesterday. Howard J. Rubenstein, Mr. Murdoch's spokesman, also said that the Australian-born publisher would not seek a permanent waiver of the Federal regulations that prohibit ownership of a daily newspaper and a television station in the same city.

headline: MERRILL OFFICER JOINS E.F. HUTTON
abstract: In a move to polish its image, the E.F. Hutton Group yesterday named Robert P. Rittereiser, a well-respected executive vice president at Merrill Lynch & Company, as the company's president.   Mr. Rittereiser's appointment was hailed by analysts and is part of a broader reshuffling of management at Hutton, the nation's fifth-largest brokerage firm.   Robert Fomon remains chairman and chief executive officer of the company, but an office of the chairman is also being formed, consisting of Mr. Fomon; Scott Pierce, president of E.F. Hutton & Company, the brokerage unit; Mr. Rittereiser, and Thomas Lynch. Mr. Lynch, president of the holding company since December 1983, is giving up that title to become vice chairman.   Last month the Hutton brokerage unit pleaded guilty to Federal charges that it defrauded numerous small banks of millions of dollars through a check-writing system that gave it interest-free loans.

headline: Ford Motor Credit Debt Securities
