abstract: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $300 million of fixed- and floating-rate debt securities through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: PALESTINIAN STRONGHOLD IN BEIRUT FALLS TO SHIITES
abstract: Shiite Moslem militiamen, backed by soldiers from the Lebanese Army's mainly Shiite Sixth Brigade, won control of the last stronghold in the Palestinian refugee settlement of Sabra today.   The development came after the Shiite militia Amal and the Palestinians agreed to a cease-fire that was followed within hours by new fighting.   A spokesman for Amal said a large number of Palestinians were killed and 20 captured in a pitched battle for control of the stronghold, a vantage point known as the Daouk Station.   The battle occurred at dawn on the 13th day of the struggle for control of the settlements. A total of 435 people have now been reported killed and 1,200 wounded in the fighting, according to police figures.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: May 10, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on International Development Strategy - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. >ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Plenary meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Kraft Inc., Glenview, Ill., a Dart & Kraft unit, said it had completed its acquisition of Westman Commission Co., a Denver-based food service distributor. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Mideast Prisoner Swap Is Reportedly Planned
abstract: A Palestinian commando group is to exchange three Israeli soldiers next week for 1,800 Palestinians and Lebanese held by Israel, Palestinian sources said tonight.   The sources said the exchange had been agreed to indirectly by Israel and the Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, through the mediation of the International Committee of the Red Cross.

headline: SERVED AS PORTUGAL'S PREMIER
abstract: Carlos Mota Pinto, Portugal's caretaker Prime Minister in the late 1970's and Deputy Prime Minister until February, died of a heart attack today, the Social Democratic Party said. He was 48 years old.   Mr. Mota Pinto, a former leader of the party and a former law professor, died at his home in the central Portuguese city of Coimbra, 110 miles northeast of Lisbon, a party spokesman, Helena Alves, said.

headline: U.S. GIVES WARNING OF REPRISAL STEPS AIMED AT LEBANON
abstract: The White House, stepping up its efforts to free 40 Americans held hostage in Beirut, warned today of economic and military reprisals unless the captives were released in the ''next few days.''   The warning, which appeared aimed mainly at the Lebanese authorities, was issued after Reagan Administration officials backed away from a plan considered earlier in the day to impose immediate sanctions against Lebanon. Sanctions might include closing the Beirut airport and imposing an economic blockade.   Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said President Reagan had delayed action to give continuing diplomatic efforts a chance to ''bear fruit.''      Syrian Overture a Key   Although Mr. Speakes declined to specify what those efforts were, a senior Administration official said they involved overtures by Syria aimed at convincing the Shiite Amal militia leader, Nabih Berri, to release the hostages.

headline: Persistence Pays Off For Georgia Bank Head
abstract: Charles B. Presley, chairman and chief executive of the First Railroad and Banking Company of Augusta, Ga., got something he had wanted for a long time on Wednesday, when the bank holding company said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Calhoun First National Bank, which is headed by Bert Lance, the former United States budget director.   ''That bank is in one of the fastest growing areas in the state,'' Mr. Presley said in a telephone interview from Savannah yesterday. ''I've known Bert Lance for more than 20 years, and we have talked from time to time about a possible sale. About three or four months ago I called him, and he said maybe it was time to get a little bit more serious.''

headline: REAGAN'S TAX PLAN MEETS RESISTANCE ON SOME ELEMENTS
abstract: Resistance to President Reagan's ambitious plan to redesign the Federal income tax system started to take shape today as Congressional critics and lobbyists protested particular elements.   But Mr. Reagan and others in his Administration warned that item-by-item revision of his proposal could endanger a ''historic'' attempt to make the tax law fairer for Americans.   Legislators from both parties, some advocating restoration of specific tax breaks and others arguing that the President had been too willing to retain various deductions, criticized the plan today. Groups ranging from the oil and gas industry to Ralph Nader's organization took issue with individual aspects of the package.

headline: Hilton Sees Gain in Ruling
abstract: Barron Hilton, chairman and president of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, said yesterday that the Internal Revenue Service had tentatively ruled in his favor in a dispute with his late father's estate over ownership of 6.8 million shares of stock in the company. Hilton Hotels also said that it had increased its bank credit lines to $600 million, from $250 million.

headline: Union Pacific Chief To Add Top Post
abstract: The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that William S. Cook, its president and chief executive officer since May 1983, would assume the additional responsibilities of chairman, effective July 1.   Mr. Cook, who is 62 years old, will succeed James H. Evans. Mr. Evans, who has served as chairman of the transportation, energy and natural resources company since 1977, is scheduled to retire at the end of June, when he reaches the age of 65.   A meticulous executive known for a blunt managerial style, Mr. Cook joined Union Pacific as a vice president/finance in 1969. He was elected executive vice president in 1973 and was named president and chief operating officer four years later.

headline: TEXTS OF REAGAN EXECUTIVE ORDER AND MESSAGE TO CONGRESS
abstract: Following are the texts of an executive order and a message to Congress signed by President Reagan today on his embargo against Nicaragua:      Executive Order By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and laws of the United States of America, including the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (50 U.S.C. 1701 et seq.), the National Emergencies Act (50 U.S.C. 1601 et seq.), Chapter 12 of Title 50 of the United States Code (50 U.S.C. 191 et seq.), and Section 301 of Title 3 of the United States Code, I, Ronald Reagan, President of the United States of America, find that the policies and actions of the Government of Nicaragua constitute an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States and hereby declare a national emergency to deal with that threat.   I hereby prohibit all imports into the United States of goods and services of Nicaraguan origin; all exports from the United States of goods to or destined for Nicaragua, except those destined for the organized democratic resistance, and transactions relating thereto.   I hereby prohibit Nicaraguan air carriers from engaging in air transportation to or from points in the United States, and transactions relating thereto.   In addition, I hereby prohibit vessels of Nicaraguan registry from entering into United States ports, and transactions relating thereto.

headline: Sudan to Restore Ties With Ethiopia, Aide Says
abstract: A Government official here said today that the Sudan and Ethiopia planned to restore diplomatic relations for the first time in two years.   The official, Maj. Gen. Fadlulla Nassir Burma, a member of the Sudan's ruling transitional military council, was speaking on his return from a three-day visit to the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa accompanied by Foreign Minister Ibrahim Taha Ayoub.

headline: Canadian Sales Expand
abstract: Retail sales in Canada rose 2.3 percent in February from the month before and 5.6 percent from February 1984, the Government reported today.

headline: MINIMUM TAX LEVEL PROPOSED
abstract: A group of House Democrats today proposed legislation for a minimum tax on corporations and individuals, a proposal they hope could become part of a deficit-reduction package.    The proposal, which has the general support of Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the House majority leader, is an effort, according to the sponsors, to test the sentiment for a tax increase that can be portrayed as a reform rather than a revenue raiser. While general tax increases have been ruled out at least for now by both parties, members of Congress do talk of raising revenue by repealing tax breaks they refer to as ''loopholes.''   House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts and the Budget Committee chairman, William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania, have said they would oppose any general tax increase unless it was proposed by President Reagan. But, according to Mr. O'Neill's spokesman, Chris Matthews, the Speaker supports the idea of making the tax system more fair.

headline: Legal Abortion Backed By Spanish Parliament
abstract: The Spanish Parliament enacted a law legalizing abortion today, ending a 40-year-old ban on the procedure in this predominantly Roman Catholic country.   The lower house of Parliament voted 193 to 56 with eight abstentions to approve the law decriminalizing abortions in cases of rape or danger to the mother's mental and physical health, or when the fetus is believed to be deformed.

headline: THEOLOGIAN IN BRAZIL SAYS HE IS SILENCED BY ORDER OF VATICAN
abstract: The Rev. Leonardo Boff, a Franciscan friar who is a leading proponent of liberation theology, said today that the Vatican had ordered him to keep ''penitential silence'' as punishment for his views. He did not elaborate on the duration of the punishment.   Father Boff, a 45-year-old theologian and author, has been sharply criticized by the Roman Catholic Church for endorsing liberation theology.

headline: Merger Policy
abstract: To the Editor:   What does J. Paul McGrath mean when he says that merger policy is based on efficiency? (''Reagan's Hands-Off Policy Is Working,'' Forum, May 19.) The Justice Department will not challenge a merger unless it believes that the merger is inefficient in the sense that it gives the merging firms increased power and incentive to cut back output of a product.

headline: Harvester Plans Receivables Sale
abstract: The International Harvester Company said that its finance subsidiary, the International Harvester Credit Corporation, had retained Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company to help the finance unit market about $1.2 billion in wholesale and retail notes receivable.   Harvester said that the receivables represent financing provided to agricultural equipment dealers and retail customers for farm equipment purchased before Harvester's sale of its agricultural equipment business to Tenneco Inc. for $488 million in January. Harvester said that proceeds from the sale of the receivables would be used to reduce the unit's debt.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: More than 40,000 Nicaraguan Roman Catholics cheered Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo today as he pledged to work ''to consolidate a stable peace in the entire Central American region.'' The new Cardinal said: ''We do not accept violence as a path to peace. Christianity is our peace.''

headline: AIRLINES' SECURITY TEAM TO VISIT ATHENS AIRPORT
abstract: Greece has agreed to allow a special security team from the International Air Transport Association to visit Athens this week to try to help improve airport security there, an association spokesman said today.   The four-member team of security experts from Swissair, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Qantas Airways of Australia and British Airways is to begin its three-day visit to Athens Wednesday.   The spokesman, David Kyd, said Greece had yet to respond to an association request after the T.W.A. hijacking to allow individual airlines to continue ''secondary checks'' of passengers after they have been checked by official airport security people.   Mr. Kyd said that Greece had asked international airlines to discontinue such secondary checks by June 1 but that the association had obtained a 30-day extension and had asked that such procedures be allowed to continue indefinitely.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Growth's Slowing Track   The American economy is still growing, but at less than half the rate expected by many economists just a month ago. The surprising 1.9 percent drop in March retail sales announced last week has forecasters saying that this Thursday's report on the gross national product will show an economy expanding at a modest real annual rate of about 2 percent. That's roughly what the ''flash'' G.N.P. released in March reported; but most analysts then said the figure would be revised sharply upward this month.  Looking beyond retail sales - which may have been depressed by the delayed mailing of income tax refunds and which are expected to rebound smartly next month - many analysts see key sectors that are not participating in the expansion.    ''The strong dollar is one of the main reasons for the slower growth,'' said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. Paul A. Volcker seems to have reached a similar conclusion: The Federal Reserve Board chairman said last week that growth might be difficult to sustain because of weakness in mining, manufacturing and agriculture. These industries are those most hurt by a strong dollar.

headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS;  GENERAL DYNAMICS IS DEALT NEW BLOWS
abstract: On the surface, the news was bad. Two General Dynamics units were banned from further bidding on Navy projects, contracts were canceled and the company was fined heavily for what the Pentagon called ''pervasive'' business misconduct. Then the contractor's chairman, David S. Lewis, announced he would step down by the end of the year, although he claimed there was no direct connection to the ban. But some analysts said the one-two punch may be a disguised blessing. They note that by agreeing to meet strict Navy conditions for contracts, and by replacing Mr. Lewis with Stanley C. Pace, a TRW executive regarded as a scrupulous businessman, General Dynamics could position itself as a cleaner, more attractive contractor.  Hughes Helicopter, meanwhile, is under investigation for what the Pentagon called massive accounting irregularities, and the Government suspended its overhead payments.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD;Isolation of Albania Goes On, New Ruler Says
abstract: Enver Hoxha, the Albanian leader, was given a hero's funeral today in Tirana, and his successor made clear in a eulogy that Albania would continue to  follow a path of isolation.         Mr. Hoxha died Thursday at the age of 76, having ruled since World War II. Ramiz Alia, 59 years old, his successor as Communist Party chief, said in a funeral speech that Mr. Hoxha was ''the greatest man that Albanian soil has given birth to,'' according to the Albanian press agency.

headline: U. S. WEAPONS MAKERS RING UP HEALTHY PROFITS
abstract: The nation's largest military contractors, whose high earnings are being questioned by the Pentagon and Congress, enjoyed a rate of profit last year that was much greater than the average for industrial corporations, according to corporate annual reports.    The reports for 10 of the largest weapons makers showed that, on the average, they realized a 25 percent return on equity in 1984. By contrast, the average return for manufacturing corporations of all sorts was only 12.8 percent, according to figures the Census Bureau released last week.    The measure of profitability - after-tax profits as a percentage of shareholder equity - is widely used on Wall Street and accepted as fair by the companies. Shareholder equity is the amount by which a company's assets exceed its liabilities.

headline: PRODUCER PRICES UP ONLY 0.2% IN MAY
abstract: Prices at the producer level remained in check last month, with a rise in energy prices all but offset by sharply lower food costs, the Labor Department reported today.   The Producer Price Index for finished goods rose two-tenths on 1 percent in May, following rises of three-tenths of 1 percent in April and two-tenths of 1 percent in March. Revised figures issued today showed producer prices were flat in January and February.   Energy prices rose 3.4 percent last month, after climbing 5.8 percent in April. Analysts have said the spurt in such costs, which began in March, has probably about run its course. A softening of world petroleum markets is already evident.

headline: Senate Backs Fed Nominee
abstract: The Senate confirmed the nomination of Martha Romayne Seger today for a full 14-year term as a governor of the Federal Reserve Board.

headline: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: The Course of Events;   8 DAYS OF MIDEAST TERROR: THE JOURNEY OF FLIGHT 847
abstract: This is the story of the hijacking of Trans World Airlines Flight 847 up to this point, as told by those who have been freed so far. Those who spoke withheld some details, and some said they were doing so because Federal authorities had warned them that the remaining hostages could be jeopardized by their remarks.   As Trans World Airlines Flight 847 waited to take off from Athens International Airport on the hot, windless morning of Friday, June 14, few passengers gave any thought to a minor commotion that had taken place at the terminal just before boarding.   A young, slender, Arabic-speaking man named Ali Atwa had gotten into an argument with T.W.A. ticket agents because they refused to let him board. The jet, they told him, was already full with 145 passengers.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Young & Rubicam At Top in Revenues
abstract: Young & Rubicam may have been No. 2 to Japan's Dentsu in total billings in 1984, Advertising Age reports, but it has surpassed it in gross revenues.

headline: THE NEW ROLE OF RANDOM HOUSE
abstract: EVERY Tuesday when they are both in town, Robert L. Bernstein, the chairman of Random House, and S.I. Newhouse Jr., his boss, have lunch together in the Grill Room of Manhattan's posh Four Seasons. In their circular banquette, amid the silver and crystal, they sift through memos and reports, talking about what Mr. Newhouse calls ''the more mundane side of publishing'' - such things as warehousing and distribution - while Mr. Newhouse scratches notes on yellow legal pads.   ''Basically,'' says Mr. Newhouse, ''I try to look for problems, talk about weaknesses and try to determine what plans there are for the future.''   Such statements are being closely scrutinized in the publishing world for hints of how Mr. Newhouse is likely to behave when his family-owned company, Advance Publications, takes control of The New Yorker magazine. Even The New Yorker - in an unsigned article published last month - seemed to question whether the change in ownership would result in erosion of The New Yorker's 60-year tradition of editorial independence.

headline: Jamaica Protest Broken Up
abstract: The police made several arrests and used tear gas to disperse a demonstration outside an international youth conference that opened here this weekend, the Caribbean news agency CANA said today. It quoted witnesses as having said about 200 people took part in the protest by members of the major opposition People's National Party and the small Workers' Party of Jamaica, which are boycotting the conference because of what they call its right-wing political slant.

headline: CONTROL DATA ENDS PLAN TO SELL FINANCIAL UNIT
abstract: The Control Data Corporation said yesterday that it had abandoned plans to sell its Commercial Credit Company financial services unit.   The company cited an inability to quickly complete a sale on ''acceptable terms.'' Analysts said that meant Control Data was unable to get the nearly $1 billion it was reportedly seeking for Commercial Credit.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   PEOPLE
abstract: *       Karen Ritchie, Dennis Connaughton, Woodrow Litwhiler and       William Ludwig were promoted to senior vice president at Campbell-Ewald, Warren, Mich.     *        Paul E. Coleman has been appointed senior vice president and chief financial officer at DYR USA.

headline: INSTALLMENT DEBT RISES
abstract: Americans took on $8.27 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in April, the Federal Reserve Board said today.   The increase was just under the $8.34 billion rise recorded in March from February's level.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Canadian Pacific Ltd. is issuing $100 million in U.S. dollars of 8-year 10 3/4 percent debentures at a price of 100.50 through Orion Royal Bank Ltd.    * Health Care Property Investors Inc.'s initial public offering of 3.8 million shares at $20 a share is under way through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.    * Owens & Minor Inc. is offering $25 million of 8 1/2 percent convertible debentures due 2010 at a price of 100, through Kidder, Peabody & Co. The debentures are convertible into Owens common stock at $25 a share.

headline: PRIVATE INSURANCE IN SPOTLIGHT
abstract: The Maryland thrift crisis has focused renewed attention on private insurance of thrift institutions.   Five other states have thrift institutions that are insured only by a private insurance corporation: Massachusetts, North Carolina, Georgia, Pennsylvania and Ohio, which experienced a similar crisis in March.   While banking regulators in those states asserted yesterday that their private insurers were sound, thrift institutions in at least two of them had moved to secure Federal insurance in the wake of Ohio's troubles.   The very development of the Maryland crisis reflects the new nervousness about privately insured savings. In Ohio, it took the collapse of the largest savings and loan institution covered by the insurance fund -whose losses threatened to exhaust the fund's resources - to set off a run on deposits. By contrast, Maryland depositors pulled out their savings without any indication that reported irregularities at the Old Court Savings and Loan Association in Baltimore would result in losses that might threaten the insurance fund.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Country Living Campaign
abstract: AFTER 17 years in business, Waring & LaRosa is at long last doing advertising for a magazine client.    The lucky publication is Hearst's highly successful Country Living, and the Waring & LaRosa line is ''The country America is moving to.''   It replaces such past efforts as ''Country Living. The Texture of America Today,'' from Lansdowne Advertising, a subsidiary of J. Walter Thompson, and ''The ideals of yesterday. The ideas of today,'' from Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss.

headline: Diners Club
abstract: Citicorp said yesterday that it was adding a package of services to its Diners Club charge card next month to appeal to business travelers, and that it would now focus its marketing efforts on that segment.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: MONDAY, JUNE 17, 1985        Companies    Union Carbide, India and Bhopal's victims are far apart on monetary damages and emergency relief, according to sources familiar with the case. The negotiations will resume today at an unspecified location in the New York area. [Page D1.]

headline: Bank of Boston to Trim U.S. Securities Activity
abstract: The Bank of Boston Corporation said yesterday that it was beginning to reduce its activity in Government securities trading, following a strategic business plan to focus its resources on other activities.   ''To compete in the area of Government securities trading would require more resources than would be consistent with our current plans,'' said Wayne Taylor, a spokesman for the bank.

headline: Thai Forces Drive Out Vietnamese Troops
abstract: Thai forces backed by air strikes and artillery barrages today repulsed most of the 800 Vietnamese soldiers who had intruded in pursuit of Cambodian guerrillas, a navy spokesman said.

headline: ISRAELI VISITS A WORRIED BORDER TOWN
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres came to this nervous town today to reassure its citizens. It was a day after the Israeli Army staged its largest pullout in the phased withdrawal from Lebanon.   For nearly three years, the people of Qiryat Shemona have not slept in their bomb shelters, and parents have not worried when their children went out. The Soviet-made Katyusha rockets, which for many years struck this town near the Lebanese border at random intervals, have not fallen since Israel invaded Lebanon in June 1982.

headline: Bradford Fire Toll Is Now 55
abstract: Another badly burned victim of the fire at a Bradford soccer stadium has died, bringing the death toll to 55, officials said today. The death was announced on the second day of a public inquiry at Bradford City Hall into the cause of the May 11 disaster.

headline: STEADY FED POLICY WAS VOTED
abstract: The Federal Reserve's main policy body voted at its March 26 meeting to keep monetary policy essentially unchanged, according to minutes of the session published today.   Reflecting an unusually ambiguous set of economic data at the time, the Federal Open Market Committee voted, 12 to 0, to ''maintain the existing degree of pressure'' on banks' reserve positions, one consistent with a growth rate of 8 percent for the narrowly defined M-1 money supply for the following several weeks.   ''Somewhat lesser reserve restraint might be acceptable in the event of substantially slower growth of the monetary aggregates, while somewhat greater restraint might be acceptable in the event of substantially higher growth,'' the committee said in its directive.

headline: ITALY AFTER THE SOCCER HORROR: SCATTERED ANTI-BRITISH DEEDS
abstract: British and Italian officials say they are concerned about scattered anti-British violence in Italy in the aftermath of a riot at a soccer match in Brussels 12 days ago that left 38 people dead and hundreds injured.   Many Italians were quick to blame the British for what happened to their countrymen - 31 of the 38 dead were Italians - and British officials have warned tourists traveling here that they might run into violence.   Since the rioting May 29, a firebomb was thrown at a British school in Milan, windows in British tour buses and cars have been smashed, and tourists have been roughed up in northern Italian cities.

headline: Philippine Debt Accord
abstract: A major obstacle to an agreement for rescheduling the foreign debt of the Philippines was overcome Friday when a Saudi Arabian bank agreed to participate, an officer of one of the banks involved in the talks said.         The rescheduling agreement, to stretch out payments on some of the country's  $25 billion debt, was reached last October, and the International Monetary Fund  had approved fresh credits for Manila. But both the rescheduling and the I.M.F.  credits depended on all the major creditors going along with the deal.

headline: Ghana Sends Protest To Nigeria Over Aliens
abstract: Ghana sent a formal protest to the Nigerian Government today over what it said was the brutal treatment of illegal immigrants who are being expelled from Nigeria.   In a statement broadcast over the state-run radio, the military Government said it ''deplores'' the use of force by the Nigerian authorities against Ghanaian immigrants.

headline: E.F. HUTTON GUILTY IN BANK FRAUD: PENALTIES COULD TOP $10 MILLION
abstract: E.F. Hutton & Company, the nation's fifth-largest brokerage firm, pleaded guilty today to an elaborate fraud that let the firm use as much as $250 million a day of bank funds without paying interest.   By shuffling billions of dollars among many accounts and banks, Hutton was able to use more money than it actually had on deposit. The practice - somewhat analogous to an individual overdrawing a checking account - enabled Hutton to earn up to $8 million in extra income in a 20-month period.   Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said at a news conference that the firm had pleaded guilty to 2,000 felony counts of wire and mail fraud and had agreed to pay criminal fines of $2 million - the maximum under the law - plus $750,000 to cover costs incurred in the Government's investigation.

headline: NICARAGUA SCORNS REAGAN PROPOSAL FOR REBEL TALKS
abstract: Nicaragua today officially rejected a proposal by President Reagan for talks on the guerrilla war there.     Mr. Reagan called Thursday for negotiations coupled with Congressional approval of his request for $14 million in aid for rebels seeking the overthrow of the Sandinista Government    Foreign Minister Miguel d'Escoto Brockman of Nicaragua said in Managua, ''What President Reagan has said is: 'You drop dead, or I will kill you.' ''        Formal Rejection Sent to U.S.   An official in the Nicaraguan Embassy here said the Government had sent a message saying the President's call for a cease-fire and peace talks, offered Thursday, was formally rejected.    The message has not been delivered to the State Department. Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today: ''We will keep the offer on the table. We will hope that the Nicaraguan Government will think it over a little more carefully.''

headline: COURT RULING ON WIVES DEVIDES EGYPT
abstract: The abolition of a women's rights law last month by Egypt's Supreme Court has touched off a furious debate here and put the Government of President Hosni Mubarak in a politically awkward position.   On May 6 the court struck down on procedural grounds the ''personal status'' amendments of 1979. While Egyptian law never banned polygamy, the amendments required a man to notify his wife officially if he took a second wife. If she objected, she could divorce him within a year, receive alimony promptly and retain custody of young children in their apartment, or in another that the husband was required to provide.

headline: Protest in South Korea
abstract: Riot policemen fired tear gas today to rout about 200 students staging anti-Government protests in Seoul, witnesses said. The students hurled firebombs and stones at a police post, smashing windows, they said. No arrests or injuries were reported.

headline: Gulf Unit Is Sold
abstract: The Gulf Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chevron Corporation, said it had sold the Keydril Company, its offshore drilling operation, for $190 million in cash. A spokesman said that Gulf had agreed not to disclose the name of Keydril's buyer. Gulf said that the sale would assist Chevron in reducing debt incurred when it purchased Gulf.

headline: BIG BOARD, LONDON TIE DISCUSSED
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange and London's Stock Exchange announced yesterday that they had set up a study group to examine the creation of a common trading system that could lead to broad trading links between the two exchanges.   The formation of the four-member group formalizes discussions that have already been taking place, according to Donald L. Calvin, the New York Stock Exchange's executive vice president and a member of the panel. He added that it could make recommendations as early as July on the technical issues of developing a common trading system.

headline: Market Place;   Index Option Trading Begins
abstract: WITH a touch of pardonable pride, the Philadelphia Stock Exchange started trading Friday in the first index option geared to the over-the-counter market. ''We're not unhappy about being the first out of the box with this new product,'' said Robert Gilmore, a senior vice president of the exchange.   The exchange's National Over-the-Counter Index Option is made up of the 100 most highly capitalized stocks in the unlisted market. It gives speculators a vehicle for guessing short-term price movements in the vast over-the-counter arena. And it is designed to provide investors with a tool for limiting risks by hedging against their portfolios of over-the-counter securities.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Olsten Temporary Services, Westbury, L.I., to Epstein Raboy Advertising.

headline: Intercontinental Hotels Promotes Its President
abstract: The Intercontinental Hotels Corporation, a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., has promoted Hans G. Sternik, president and chief operating officer, to chief executive officer of the New York-based international hotel chain.   Mr. Sternik, 53, will succeed Paul C. Sheeline, who had been in that position since 1971. Mr. Sheeline, 63, will remain chairman and a member of the executive committee beyond his retirement, which becomes effective Sept. 30.

headline: PHONE COMPANIES TOLD TO SHARE DISTANCE CALLS
abstract: Telephone customers who do not select a long-distance company when asked to do so will have one selected for them under an order issued today by the Federal Communications Commission.   The order directed local telephone companies to allocate these customers among the competing long-distance companies in the same proportion as the customers who do make a choice.   The 5-to-0 vote in favor of the order was a departure from the commission's more familiar stance against Government intervention in the marketplace. Mark S. Fowler, the commission chairman, said the action was needed to stimulate the less-than-impressive growth of competition in the long-distance business.

headline: Afghan Rebel Office Bombed
abstract: A bomb exploded today at an Afghan guerrilla headquarters in the border city of Peshawar, killing one person and wounding seven.

headline: SPANISH PARTIES AGREE TO VOTE FOR LAW PERMITTING SOME ABORTIONS
abstract: A measure to permit abortion in some cases moved closer to legislative approval today after Spain's political parties agreed to vote for it.    Leaders of all the parties represented in the lower house of Parliament agreed to amend an existing law, which never took effect, along lines recommended by the country's top court, the Constitutional Tribunal.   The court declared the law unconstitutional last week but suggested in the complete text of its ruling, issued Wednesday, that the law needed only to be tightened to meet constitutional guarantees of a right to life for both the mother and the child.

headline: BID FOR WARNER AMEX GAINS WITH SWEETENER
abstract: Time Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. moved a step closer to success yesterday in their bid for Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. They won the approval of the American Express Company, co-owner of Warner Amex with Warner Communications Inc., which said it had signed a definitive agreement for the sale.   American Express said its agreement was dependent on Warner Communications also agreeing to sell. Each company owns half of Warner Amex. A Warner Communications spokesman, Geoffrey Holmes, said the company would have no comment.

headline: Brunswick To Buy ICO The Brunswick Corporation,
abstract: a maker of sporting goods and   marine power equipment,   based in Skokie, Ill., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire ICO Inc., a Forth Worth   oilfield service company, for $7   a share, or about $37.7 million   in cash.

headline: AWAITING LEADERS:
abstract: Participants in the economic conference waiting for government leaders to arrive yesterday at Palais Schaumburg in Bonn. From left: Finance Minister Michael Wilson of Canada; Sir Geoffrey Howe, Britain's Foreign Secretary; an unidentified official; Finance Minister Noboru Takeshita, Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe and Trade Minister Keijiro Murata, all of Japan.   Associated Press

headline: CLAYTON & DUBILIER TO BUY UNIROYAL
abstract: Uniroyal Inc. was close to an agreement late yesterday to be acquired for $750 million in a leveraged buyout by the private investment firm of Clayton & Dubilier Inc.   The $22-a-share cash offer comes just days after talks between Uniroyal and the Ethyl Corporation broke off, and on the same day that the investor Carl C. Icahn was to have taken Uniroyal to court to challenge the results of a vote on two anti-takeover measures.   But that case, before Judge Robert E. Tarleton of State Superior Court in Jersey City, was postponed yesterday as Uniroyal's board met during the afternoon to study the Clayton & Dubilier proposal. Sources close to the situation said both sides were putting the finishing touches on the agreement late yesterday.

headline: First Union Notes
abstract: The First Union Corporation offered $100 million of senior floating-rate extendible notes.

headline: PICKING THE WINNERS ON WALL ST.
abstract: WHEN he was 12 years old, Richard Fentin thought he had found the perfect stock in which to invest - a burger chain that was to be the ''next McDonald's.'' That company, whose name Mr. Fentin does not even remember, is no longer putting chopped beef into buns.   ''It went belly up,'' recalled Mr. Fentin, now 30 years old, who heads the Fidelity Group's Mercury Fund, a Boston-based mutual fund that invests in higher risk emerging growth stocks.   The art of picking winners and avoiding losers among the thousands of publicly traded companies on the nation's stock exchanges has become big business for an army of Wall Street professionals. But, the pros say, well-disciplined small investors also have a chance of striking it rich.

headline: MCGRAW-HILL REALIGNS INFORMATION EXECUTIVES
abstract: McGraw-Hill Inc. announced a number of executive changes on its business and financial information services side yesterday.   The company, which is also a book and magazine publisher, said that Howard D. Hosbach, 54, had been named a corporate executive vice president with responsibility for the business and financial information subsidiaries.

headline: U.S.-Mexico Trade Pact
abstract: The United States and Mexico signed a trade agreement today that gives Mexico legal protections against certain American import restraints in return for a commitment by Mexico to end export subsidies.

headline: HAIR GROWTH DRUG SEEN AS A WONDER FOR UPJOHN
abstract: The Upjohn Company may be several years away from receiving Government approval to sell what could be a revolutionary hair-growth ointment, but thousands of balding men are said to be using a homemade version of the product.   And while the company is still a long way from seeing the full financial impact of its drug, called minoxidil, Upjohn may already be realizing considerable benefits from the cottage industry that has grown up around the compound.   Minoxidil has the approval of the United States Food and Drug Administration, but as a tablet taken to treat hypertension. Years ago, however, Upjohn scientists found that the drug promoted hair growth as a side effect. More recently, doctors have been putting patients on minoxidil not to fight hypertension, but to grow hair.

headline: NITZE DISMISSES SOVIET FREEZE
abstract: The Reagan Administration's senior arms control adviser today dismissed a Soviet moratorium on deploying medium- range nuclear missiles in Europe, saying it was inferior to an offer the Russians made to him in 1983.     The adviser, Paul H. Nitze, said the Administration was right to rebuff the newest missile offer because it specified only missiles in Europe, without freezing missiles aimed at Japan or China from Asia.

headline: ITALIAN POLICE REPORT ARREST OF A GUNMAN ON DUTCH PAPAL TRIP
abstract: The police in the Netherlands arrested an armed man at a border crossing from West Germany on the last day of Pope John Paul II's recent visit to the Netherlands, officials here and in the Netherlands have disclosed.   Italian police officials said they received notice from the Paris headquarters of Interpol, the international police network, advising them that the man, who was in his mid 20's and said he was a Turkish national, was arrested by Dutch border police May 14 at a rail border crossing near the small town of Venlo, in Holland.

headline: SSC&B: Lintas Shift
abstract: SSC&B: Lintas Worldwide, one of the three worldwide agency networks of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has restructured itself at the top. From now on there will be an international and a United States unit, both reporting to William V. Weithas Jr., 56 years old and chairman and chief executive based in London. Kenneth L. Robbins, 49, formerly the head man stateside, is going to London as deputy chairman in charge of international, while Spencer Plavoukos, 48, and former chief operating officer in the United States , will be chairman and chief executive of SSC&B, the domestic unit.

headline: MARYLAND'S UNFLAPPABLE CHIEF
abstract: When guards at the Maryland penitentiary staged a sickout last October to protest a colleague's being stabbed to death, Gov. Harry R. Hughes thought long and hard about how to respond.   He then quickly ordered all 2,100 inmates locked in their cells, dispatched police Swat teams to guard them, and negotiated a peaceful end to the sickout.   His approach to that incident, say longtime analysts of the Maryland political scene, exemplified his style: Unflappable in a crisis, he deliberates hard before acting and then moves decisively.   ''When he makes decisions he takes his time to the point of it being agonizing,'' said Victor Cushwa, a state legislator who knows the Governor well. ''Then he stands pat to the point of stubbornness.''

headline: SPEECH BY REAGAN AT BERGEN-BELSEN
abstract: Following is the official text of President Reagan's speech today at the site of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp:   This painful walk into the past has done much more than remind us of the war that consumed the European continent. What we have seen makes unforgettably clear that no one of the rest of us can fully understand the enormity of the feelings carried by the victims of these camps.   The survivors carry a memory beyond anything that we can comprehend. The awful evil started by one man - an evil that victimized all the world with its destruction - was uniquely destructive to the millions forced into the grim abyss of these camps.

headline: KOHL, UNBENDING ON BITBURG, IS GRATEFUL TO REAGAN
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl praised President Reagan today as ''a friend of our people'' for agreeing to lay a wreath next month at a German military cemetery, and gave no hint that he intended to release the President from his commitment.   Speaking in Parliament, Mr. Kohl said:   ''I find it most regrettable that this great man, a friend of the Germans, has encountered considerable domestic difficulties because of the noble gesture he envisaged. Let me say this as a German and as the German Chancellor: I am grateful to him for the attitude he has once again demonstrated.''   He spoke in a debate that was to have reviewed the last two years of Mr. Kohl's coalition, but was dominated by the dispute over Mr. Reagan's visit.

headline: OIL CHARGES DISMISSED
abstract: Most of a $300 million price-fixing suit against six major oil companies by the City of Long Beach and the State of California has been dismissed by a Federal judge.   District Judge William Gray gave no reason for his decision, which was announced Wednesday, and declined to discuss the 10-year-old case. His ruling did not refer to the breach-of-contract portion of the lawsuit but addressed only the antitrust charges, which were considered the heart of the case.

headline: Florida Offers Education Bonds
abstract: The Florida State Board of Education offered $100 million of bonds earlier this week through underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company with a maximum yield of 9.18 percent for 9 1/8 percent bonds due in 2014, which are priced at 99 1/2.   For shorter maturities, yields range from 5 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6.90 percent in 1990, 8 percent in 1995, 8.90 percent in 2000 and 9.10 percent in 2008.   The bonds, rated Aa by Moody's and AA by Standard & Poor's, are backed by the state's gross receipts tax on the sale of electricity, natural gas, telephone and telegraph services, as well as the state's full faith and credit.

headline: LABOR PEACE REIGNS IN JAPAN, AND UNIONS WITHER
abstract: The Labor Ministry issued a little-noted report the other day, saying that strikes had cost the average Japanese employee only 15 minutes and 50 seconds of work time in each of the last three years.   By way of comparison, the ministry might have noted that office workers in crowded Tokyo buildings often lose that much time each day just waiting for elevators. Instead, the agency observed dryly that the average United States employee had given up three hours to labor disputes and even his hard-laboring West German counterpart had lost nearly two hours.   The report drew little public attention because labor tranquillity and job dedication have long been accepted facts of Japanese life. There has not been a major walkout lasting as long as a week since public workers went out for eight days in 1975, demanding, in vain, the same right to strike that private employees enjoy but rarely exercise.

headline: VMS Chairman Bullish On Hotel Investments
abstract: A day after the proposed $400 million sale of 28 Holiday Corporation hotels to VMS Realty Inc. was announced, Peter R. Morris, VMS's chairman and chief executive, had some advice for those who have backed away from investment in real estate until the tax picture clears.   Real estate investment is more than tax breaks and shelters, he said. There are still opportunities to ''work properties'' and make money, he added.

headline: TURNER DEFENDS BID FOR CBS
abstract: Ted Turner, the Atlanta cable and broadcast entrepreneur, vigorously defended the financial viability of his bid to take over CBS, in a filing to the Federal Communications Commission made public yesterday.   Mr. Turner's comments sharply contradicted arguments by CBS in its June 3 petition requesting the five commissioners to deny Mr. Turner's application to take over CBS's broadcasting licenses in connection with his $5.4 billion bid. Offering detailed financial projections for the first time, Mr. Turner said his plan to merge his company, Turner Broadcasting System Inc., with a streamlined CBS broadcasting operation would jeopardize neither the competitive position nor financial status of the CBS television network.   Mr. Turner said that his plans to sell CBS's 18 radio stations, its two radio networks, one television station and the company's publishing division would increase the diversity of information available to the public. He contended that a merger would not diminish competition either in Atlanta, where he owns a television station, WTBS, or nationally.

headline: 200 Soviet Workers At U.N. Called Spies
abstract: The Senate Intelligence Committee said today that about 200 of the 800 Soviet citizens working for the headquarters of the United Nations are actually intelligence agents who have been allowed to travel freely in the United States.   The panel already had approved legislation by Senator William V. Roth, Republican of Delaware, that would bring Soviet employees of the United Nations under the same travel restrictions as regular Soviet diplomats.   The committee released a report, based on information it gathered from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the former chief United Nations delegate, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, that said, ''Approximately one-fourth of the Soviets in the U.N. Secretariat are intelligence officers.''

headline: Chip Maker Posts a Loss
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation, hurt by the slumping demand for computer chips, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $2.7 million in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1985, compared with earnings of $24.4 million, or 28 cents a share, in the 1984 quarter.

headline: Chief Executive Named at Scripps
abstract: Scripps Howard, the privately held communications company, said yesterday that Lawrence A. Leser had been elected president and chief executive.   Mr. Leser, who is 50 years old, will succeed Edward W. Estlow, 65, on July 1, when Mr. Estlow is scheduled to retire.   Since June 1984, Mr. Leser has served as executive vice president of Scripps Howard, which is based in Cincinnati. He joined the company in 1968 after spending 11 years with the Cincinnati office of Deloitte Haskins & Sells, the Big 8 accounting firm.

headline: Cadillac, Daon Sale
abstract: The Cadillac Fairview Corporation said it and the Daon Development Corporation had sold a jointly owned office building on Market Street in San Francisco for $140 million to two limited partnerships sponsored by Merrill Lynch Hubbard Inc., a unit of Merrill Lynch & Company.

headline: Scali, McCabe, Sloves Gets Equitable Product
abstract: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, an Ogilvy Group subsidiary, received an assignment from the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

headline: NEW MARKETING PUSH FOR IRISH WHISKEY
abstract: Although some Irish drinkers give up whisky for Lent, Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. does not normally stop producing and distributing it. This year, though, a labor dispute shut down the giant distilling complex on the rolling outskirts of this town just east of Cork from the beginning of the pre-Easter religious observance in February until April 3.   The confrontation began when Distillers, which produces all Irish whisky in both the Republic and the six British-controlled counties of Northern Ireland, tried to cut down trucking costs by laying off drivers and reorganizing deliveries. The bitter drivers could not accept that a company enjoying record sales and profits needed to resort to such stringent cost cutting.
