headline: COACHING OF AGCA IN ITALY CHARGED
abstract: A major organized crime figure who turned state's evidence in Italy has said that Mehmet Ali Agca, the convicted assailant of Pope John Paul II, was coached in prison by the Italian secret services to say that the shooting of the Pope in 1981 was commissioned by the Bulgarian security service, and thus, the Soviet Union.   Giovanni Pandico, a confessed racketeer now giving evidence in a major trial against the Camorra, the center of organized crime in Naples, told a weekly news magazine that Pietro Musumeci, the former deputy head of Italy's military intelligence service, used organized crime channels to assure Mr. Agca his liberty in exchange for testimony implicating Soviet bloc Governments in the plot.   This explanation of why Mr. Agca is accusing Bulgaria and the Soviet Union of commissioning the murder of the Pope has been suggested before, mainly by Soviet and Bulgarian officials and leftist newspapers in Italy. But Mr. Pandico's claims are expected to have a major impact on the trial here against three Bulgarians and four Turks accused of conspiring to shoot the Pope, because it is the first time a figure with such intimate familiarity with Italian organized crime has described in detail the purported link between Mr. Agca and the underworld.

headline: Polish Dissident Given 3-Month Jail Sentence
abstract: Jacek Kuron, an adviser to the Solidarity movement who publicly urged May Day protest marchers to disperse peacefully, was sentenced today to three months in jail for taking part in the illegal procession with 15,000 people.   The testimony of a police officer whose suggestions for dispersing the crowd Mr. Kuron endorsed and conveyed to the marchers was used in the misdemeanor court that quickly sentenced the 51-year-old pro-Solidarity activist.

headline: A PASTA WAR MAY BE AT HAND
abstract: In an echo of the Chicken War of the 1960's between Europe and the United States over poultry exports, the White House fired a shot today in what threatens to become the Pasta War, having grown from what started out as a skirmish over citrus.   President Reagan ordered that tariffs on imported pasta be increased sharply, to try to protect the $1.3 billion-a-year domestic pasta industry from rapidly rising imports, mostly from Italy.   The United States won the Chicken War by showing that the European Economic Community was unduly subsidizing poultry exports to countries where American poultry companies were competing. The matter ended there with the United States given the right to take offsetting action against $26 million worth of European exports.

headline: REOPENED ETHIOPIA FAMINE CAMP GETS UNEXPECTED FLOW OF REFUGEES
abstract: An unexpected ''floodtide'' of famine victims are returning to a reopened camp in western Ethiopia, a senior aid official here said today.   The official, Dr. Tony Atkins, World Vision International's famine director in Ethiopia, said that as of 6 P.M. Wednesday the camp at Ibnat held 35,118 people, with many more continuing to stream in.   ''We were all caught unawares,'' Dr. Atkins said after his return from Ibnat today. ''None of us anticipated this floodtide of people.''

headline: SHULTZ, MEETING YOGOSLAV PREMIER, PROMISES ECONOMIC ASSISTANCE
abstract: Prime Minister of Yugoslavia met today with President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz for sessions that both sides described as friendly and useful.   In comments to reporters after a luncheon meeting at the State Department, Mr. Shultz said the United States had expressed its ''strong continuing support'' for Yugoslavia's economic stabilization program and had pledged ''constructive assistance.''   He said the discussions with Prime Minister Milka Planinc had covered a range of international issues, including a mutual resolve to combat international terrorism, the United States position on arms-control talks with the Soviet Union and ways to improve cooperation between the United States and nonaligned countries.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Amdahl Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif, said it had introduced two new high-performance computers.    * Carlsberg Corp., a financial services company based in Santa Monica, Calif., said it had suspended negotiations to buy a 36.7 percent interest in the company held by one part of the Carlsberg family.

headline: Doctor Joins Ex-Salesman In Orchestrating Merger
abstract: When Thomas F. Frist Jr. was in medical school and serving as a surgical resident, he used to envy his friends who were businessmen. ''They got the weekend off,'' he said, ''while I was always working.''   Today, Dr. Frist is both a doctor and a businessman, but he still does not get all of his weekends off. He spent this past weekend putting the finishing touches on the merger of his company, the Hospital Corporation of America, with the American Hospital Supply Corporation. Along with Karl D. Bays, the chairman and chief executive of American Hospital Supply, Dr. Frist will now be running an organization that will combine the largest hospital management concern and the largest hospital supplier.

headline: PATENTS;  A Remote Heart Rate Monitor
abstract: A HEART rate monitor that can be operated without baring the patient's skin was patented this week by two research scientists at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J. The remote microwave tests could be used to check the heart or respiration rates of pilots undergoing training, without disturbing them.  Patent No. 4,513,748 was granted to Markus Nowogrodzki and Daniel D. Mawhinney for what is called a dual-frequency heart rate monitor.

headline: U.S. Sailor Rescued in Italy From Crater of Mt. Vesuvius
abstract: Rescue teams using winches and steel cables pulled an American sailor from a deep crater on Mount Vesuvius today.         The sailor had become trapped the day before while trying to save a friend. A Navy spokesman said the friend was killed falling into the crater.

headline: GREECE DEFENDS ITS ACTIONS IN T.W.A. HIJACKING
abstract: Greece gave its European neighbors a report today on its actions in the Beirut hijacking, including a defense of its airport security and its decision to free a confederate of the Lebanese hijackers in exchange for Greek and other hostages aboard the commandeered American jet.   The report was presented to the law enforcement group of the European Economic Community. According to Italy's Interior Minister, Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, it included a discussion of the way Greece coordinated its handling of the hijacking with the United States Government.   He said that Costas Tsimas, the Secretary General of the Greek Ministry of Public Order, told the Common Market group that in the first days of the hijacking affair, the United States had ''thanked'' Greece for helping to save the lives of the hostage passengers.

headline: Israeli Legislators Bar Lebanon War Inquiry
abstract: Parliament defeated motions offered today to set up a commission of inquiry into events surrounding the invasion of Lebanon three years ago.

headline: Storage Fights Asset Claim
abstract: The Storage Technology Corporation and its finance subsidiary have asked the Federal Bankruptcy Court to rule that creditors of the subsidiary do not have a priority claim to Storage's assets. In December, Bankruptcy Judge Jay Gueck gave the computer hardware maker access to $140 million in customer obligations held by its subsidiary, the Storage Technology Finance Corporation.

headline: Architecture Quarterly Wants to Grow in U.S.
abstract: Admittedly, architectural development in the third world is not everybody's intellectual cup of tea, which is probably why a magazine called Mimar that covers the subject has but 1,700 circulation in the United States out of a worldwide circulation of 6,700.   That does not mean that it does not want to grow, because it does, and Hasan-Uddin Khan, its editor, who is a Pakistani, was recently over here to see about that.   The quarterly, which is being distributed by MIT Press, is published out of Singapore by Concept Media, publisher of books on architecture. Mr. Khan said yesterday by telephone from France that he was close to naming advertising representatives in Europe and the United States, who will be selling four-color ad pages for $1,500 and black and white for $1,000.

headline: Indonesian Rebels Give Casualties for Soldiers
abstract: Left-wing separatist guerrillas fighting Indonesia's rule in East Timor said today that they had killed or wounded more than 600 Indonesian soldiers since August 1983 and had established a radio transmitter in the territory.   Abilio Araujo, chief foreign representative of the group fighting for the independence of East Timor, told a news conference in the Portuguese capital that the radio began transmitting from East Timor, a former Portuguese colony, in January.   Mr. Araujo said the radio was smuggled into the area last year.

headline: Bank Ruling Is Reversed
abstract: In a decision that could have far-reaching effect on so-called limited-service banks, a three-judge appeals court in Atlanta has reversed a 1984 decision by the Federal Reserve Board that permitted the United States Trust Company of New York to operate a limited-service bank in Florida, banking spokesmen said today.   Officials of the Florida Bankers Association and the Conference of State Bank Supervisors - co-plaintiffs in the case - said they had not seen the ruling.

headline: G.E. Employee Charged Again PHILADELPHIA, April 9
abstract: A former manager for   the General Electric Company   was indicted today on charges   of lying to a Federal grand jury   investigating a plot to defraud   the Government of $800,000 on a   Minuteman missile contract.

headline: A Congress Party Chief Is Shot Dead in India
abstract: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed a Moslem leader of the governing Congress Party as he rode a rickshaw through a crowded street, domestic news agencies reported.   The politician, Neta Hakimuddin, was president of the Meerut branch of the Congress Party. He died instantly after being hit once in the forehead in Meerut, 50 miles northeast of New Delhi in Uttar Pradesh, the news agencies quoted the police as saying.

headline: Cooper Settles S.E.C. Charges
abstract: Cooper Laboratories Inc. settled charges today brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it failed to promptly disclose its sales of Frigitronics Inc. shares at a time when there was market speculation that Cooper might be trying to take over Frigitronics.   Without admitting or denying any of the charges, Cooper agreed to set aside at least $2.2 million against potential claims from investors.

headline: Bally Contracts
abstract: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said it had been awarded contracts to provide instant tickets, computer software and counseling for starting lotteries in California and Iowa. The California contract is for one year with two six-month options.

headline: Japan Phone Rules Argued
abstract: United States trade negotiators today began their effort to win simpler standards for telecommunications equipment in Japan amid concern that critical differences between the two sides remain.         Leaders of the telecommunications industry have warned that excessively strict standards could keep American goods out of the Japanese market. Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone and other Tokyo officials have promised that the rules would be simplified as a move to defuse protectionist sentiment in the United States. Now representatives of both sides are trying to work out the details.

headline: 'CYCLE OF VIOLENCE' IS ASSAILED -- RELATIONS SAID TO REACH A LOW
abstract: The United States ordered the recall of its Ambassador from Pretoria today to protest South African military raids into neighboring Botswana this morning and into Angola last month.   The South African military moves have raised ''the most serious question about that Government's recent conduct and policy,'' Bernard Kalb, the State Department spokesman, said.   He said the United States ''rejects categorically such a policy which is antithetical to the goal of working for negotiated solutions and an end to southern Africa's cycle of violence.''      Low Point of Relations    ''In light of this and other recent events,'' Mr. Kalb said, ''we have decided to call our Ambassador to South Africa, Herman Nickel, home on consultations to review the situation.''

headline: HE DESCRIBES HIJACKING PLOT
abstract: The Greek police tonight arrested a 21-year-old Lebanese Shiite Moslem who they said confessed to helping plan the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines airliner with 153 passengers and crew members aboard.   The police said the captured Arab had told them that he and two Lebanese Shiites who hijacked the jet belonged to the Islamic Holy War extremist group, which has often carried out attacks against American targets.   The police said the Lebanese in custody had unsuccessfully tried to board the plane.

headline: Journalists' Group Protests Treatment of Indian Reporter
abstract: The International Federation of Journalists cabled Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India today to protest what it called the continued harassment of a reporter for The Associated Press, Brahma Chellaney, and to ask for the free exercise of journalism in India.   The Brussels-based organization, which has a membership of more than 105,000, also protested ''the refusal by Indian authorities to return his passport and renew his press card.''

headline: BULGARIA'S CHIEF PROSECUTOR PUTS TOLL IN BOMBINGS AT 30
abstract: Two weeks before a visit to the United States, Prime Minister Milka Planinc says that a faltering economy has brought Yugoslavia ''to the point of a rather dangerous limit of what people will tolerate.''   ''The most serious problem,'' the Government leader, 60 years old, said in an interview Friday, ''is that we have not been able to increase productivity as much as is needed, or to increase the standard of living.''   The inflation rate was nearly 80 percent for the first four months of the year; the unemployment rate of 15 percent is said to be Europe's highest, and exports are stagnating.   ''But we cannot allow ourselves to grow weary and give up, or return to uneconomic policies,'' she said.

headline: Trade Envoy to Japan Is Not New to Country
abstract: Gaston J. Sigur may at first appear an unlikely candidate to serve as President Reagan's special trade envoy to Japan. He is known by his colleagues at George Washington University as first and foremost a scholar and historian; his name is rarely mentioned among economists or trade specialists.

headline: Drivers Clog Streets In Protest in Teheran
abstract: Thousands of people, many with bouquets of flowers in their cars, snarled traffic here today after a call for protests by the exiled former Prime Minister, Shahpur Bakhtiar.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *        American Telephone and Telegraph Co.  announced the commercial availability of its semiconductor flagship products, full 32-bit microprocessor chips.     *       Boston Edison Co.  has asked the Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities to approve a 16 percent reduction in the fuel-charge portion of customers' bills for the next three months.

headline: BUSINESS IDGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 3, 1985        International         Tough trade reprisal against Japan was endorsed by a Senate panel. The bill calls on the President to obtain increased access for American goods to Japanese markets within 90 days; if not, sanctions would be imposed against Japanese shipments to the U.S. (Page A1.) Japan announced changes in the rules governing its telecommunications industry. (D8.)        Companies         Ted Turner appears to be preparing for a move on CBS.  The Atlanta-based cable and broadcasting entrepreneur is reported to have received financial commitments from MCI Communications and William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary. (D1.)

headline: WHITE HOUSE HAILS NAKASONE
abstract: The White House today praised Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan for his ''courageous'' moves in seeking to open his nation's markets to American goods and investment.   But Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, also made it clear that the Japanese package ''contains few new or immediate'' measures that would open Japanese markets to the Americans. He also voiced uncertainty about the reaction of Congress, which has become increasingly angered at the soaring trade deficit with Japan.   ''It will depend on how the legislators read this entire package,'' Mr. Regan said. He added that Mr. Nakasone's appeal to the Japanese to buy more imported products was ''an important and welcome step.''

headline: RUSSIAN ENVOY URGES TALKS TO BAN NUCLEAR ARMS TESTS
abstract: The Soviet Ambassador to the United States said today that it was ''high time'' for a comprehensive ban on the testing of nuclear weapons.     The Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, said the Soviet Government had repeatedly asked the Reagan Administration in recent years to resume negotiations on such a ban. But the answer, he said, had been ''no, no, no.''    Mr. Dobrynin, addressing a conference on arms control at Emory University here, said Moscow would be ready to accept a treaty banning some nuclear tests within two months after Senate ratification of pacts negotiated in the early 1970's. Ratification of the so-called threshhold test bans would be a ''big stimulus'' for the arms talks under way in Geneva, he said.

headline: I.M.F. PACT WITH BRAZIL ON ADDITIONAL FINANCING
abstract: Brazil and the International Monetary Fund have agreed to negotiate fresh economic goals for the country in exchange for a new loan, Brazilian Finance Minister Francisco Dornelles said Saturday.         An I.M.F. team is scheduled fly to Brazil on May 27 to continue negotiations, which Brazilian monetary sources said they hoped to conclude by the end of June.

headline: CANADA SUPREME COURT VOIDS MANITOBA'S LAWS IN ENGLISH
abstract: The Supreme Court of Canada declared today that all laws established by the province of Manitoba in English since 1890 were invalid because they had not been enacted in French as well.   To avoid chaos in the province's offices and courts, the Supreme Court ruled that the laws would be ''temporarily valid'' for the minimum time needed to translate and enact them into French. But it warned that new laws would have no force if they were not bilingual.

headline: GREEK JOURNALISTS GET JAIL TERMS FOR ILLEGAL USE OF WIRETAP TAPES
abstract: The publisher and the editor of the newspaper with the largest circulation in Greece were sentenced today to five months' imprisonment on charges arising from the wiretapping of an office used by The New York Times in Athens.   George Bobolas, the 59-year old publisher of the daily, Ethnos, was sentenced in absentia after he did not show up in court, citing health grounds. The editor, Alexander Filipopoulos, 57, was in court.   The court ruled that the two could avoid going to jail by paying a fine equivalent to about $500 each. If they wished to appeal the conviction, the court said, they could remain free pending a ruling.

headline: AMID SHOW OF FORCE, A CAIRO MARCH IS POSTPONED
abstract: Islamic fundamentalists today postponed a march to demand the imposition of Islamic law in Egypt, in the face of an overwhelming show of force by President Hosni Mubarak's Government.   The showdown was the first of its kind since Mr. Mubarak became President three and a half years ago. It was widely seen as a crucial test of strength between Islamic fundamentalist forces and the Government, which banned the march this week on the ground that it was a threat to the country's security.   The fundamentalists' decision to postpone the march until an Egyptian court could rule on the legality of the Government's ban was a major, if temporary, victory for President Mubarak, who had never before openly challenged Moslem fundamentalists.

headline: MULTIMEDIA SAYS IT'S 'NOT BEING SOLD'
abstract: Multimedia Inc. said yesterday that it is ''not being sold'' and that it is still considering the recapitalization plan proposed by an investor group representing 40 percent of the company's 16.7 million shares.    The announcement struck analysts as an oddly worded rejection of a $1.02 billion acquisition offer from Lorimar, a California television production company.   ''There was no explanation; I thought the response was a bit cavalier,'' said Barry Kaplan, an analyst at Bear, Stearns.

headline: 86 CIVILIANS KILLED IN SRI LANKA REBEL ATTACK
abstract: At least 86 civilians, including five Buddhist nuns, were killed today when Tamil guerrillas disguised as soldiers drove into the Sinhalese heartland and staged one of the most violent attacks of their separatist campaign, the Government said.   At least 100 people were wounded in the attacks in Anuradhapura, 105 miles north of Colombo, the Government said. A group called the Liberation Tigers claimed responsibility.

headline: Levi Strauss
abstract: Levi Strauss & Company, which closed 22 plants worldwide last year and laid off 5,800 workers, does not plan any more major cutbacks, its president, Robert Haas, said at the company's annual meeting. Levi Strauss, a maker of jeans for more than 130 years, suffered disappointing sales last year - at $591 million, 16 percent below the previous year's - but Mr. Haas told shareholders that the outlook for 1985 was good.

headline: Power Authority Tender Notes Set
abstract: The New York State Power Authority yesterday announced plans to sell a $200 million issue of adjustable rate tender notes next Tuesday, through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.    Because market interest rates on tax-exempt notes that may be redeemed in six months or one year are at roughly 5 to 6 percent, many authorities are issuing such securities rather than selling long-term bonds at interest rates of 9 or 10 percent.

headline: A.T.&T. STILL HAS TOO MUCH CLOUT
abstract: THE breakup of A.T.&T. is heading down a path that could lead to the remonopolizing of the telecommunications industry. While the Federal Communications Commission has shown in recent actions an awareness of the problems the industry faces, it still needs to take steps to insure that competition will become a reality.   The F.C.C. needs to address the critical fact that the long-distance business is still a virtual monopoly. A.T.&T. Communications remains the dominant carrier, with about 90 percent of the market. In this respect, the industry is unlike any other that has been deregulated. In that monopoly situation, deregulation cannot be expected to foster real competition.

headline: Stocks Up Slightly on Late Buying
abstract: An acceleration of buying in the final minutes of trading yesterday helped the stock market close mostly higher despite the decision of many investors to remain spectators until some more first-quarter corporate results are reported.    ''There's no oomph,'' said Richard Paget, senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers. ''People are very concerned about the earnings that are going to be reported over the next few weeks.''

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Chapman Energy Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 20,000 units through Thomson McKinnon Securities. Each unit consists of $1,000 of senior subordinated debentures, due 2000, and 40 common shares.

headline: COURT RULING CALLED BLOW TO BIG BANKS
abstract: The nation's biggest banks were dealt a blow yesterday by the Supreme Court's decision to authorize regional interstate banking, a ruling that allows banks in many states to merge while allowing them to keep the biggest banks out. Ultimately, it could lead to a fundamental restructuring of the American banking industry.   Banking experts said the ruling could jeopardize the predominance of New York's leading banks and predicted that it would squash efforts in Congress to allow banking on a nationwide scale.   As a result of the decision, regional banks - some of them already among the largest in the country -would be allowed to expand through interstate mergers while the New York banks would remain confined to their home states.      No Room for Challenge    The major New York banks and their law firms had hoped that, even if the Court had ruled against them, the decision would have left leeway for legal maneuvering. But H. Rodgin Cohen, a partner in the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell and an authority on banking, said that, because the Court's decision was ''simplistic'' it left no room for challenge. ''It puts the definitive imprimatur on the validity of the regional statutes.''

headline: GANDHI EMERGES FROM THE LONG SHADOWS OF HIS ANCESTORS
abstract: In his first visit to Washington as the leader of India, Rajiv Gandhi has in the eyes of American officials quietly and firmly removed the shadow they felt had been cast over the relationship with the United States by his mother, Indira.   Surprisingly informal and confident, a faint smile flickering across his face in every public appearance, the 40-year-old Indian Prime Minister has given the impression to Administration officials that, although heir to the Nehru dynasty that shaped post-independence India, his style, personality and politics seem quite different from the family that shaped him.   As Mr. Gandhi prepared to leave the United States Saturday after a daylong trip to Houston, United States officials were expressing delight at the visit so far, which began Tuesday night. ''It's exceeded everything expected,'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz said Thursday night.

headline: UNOCAL OFFERS 28.8% SHARE BUYBACK
abstract: Digging in its heels for a showdown with T. Boone Pickens, the Unocal Corporation yesterday offered to buy back 28.8 percent of its stock for $72 a share worth of debt securities. The oil company said its offer replaced an earlier one at the same price for 49.9 percent that was conditional on the success of a takeover bid from a Pickens investor group.     By assuring investors that a large portion of their shares would receive the $72 offer, Unocal is attempting to make Mr. Pickens's bid of $54 per share for 36.5 percent of Unocal less attractive.    Mr. Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, said at a meeting of Unocal shareholders in Los Angeles yesterday that Unocal had come up with a better offer for the amount of shares its offer involved.

headline: PATENTS;  Method to Detect Virus That Is Linked to AIDS
abstract: A method of detecting antibodies in blood samples that indicate the presence of the virus believed to cause Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome, or AIDS, and other diseases was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: American Medical Communications Co. of North Brunswick, N.J., a division of ST&L Associates Inc., an advertising firm, has named Emile Nerlinger president.    * Country Miss Inc., a subsidiary of the Hartmarx Corp., has named Stanley Wax president and chief operating officer, succeeding Alfred T. Gifford, who will become chairman and continue as chief executive officer until Oct. 1.

headline: APPREHENSION AT THE VOICE, AGAIN
abstract: At The Village Voice offices at Broadway and 13th Street, the news that Leonard Stern, chairman of Hartz Mountain Industries, will buy the 30-year-old weekly was met with apprehension by the 120-member editorial staff.   As word of the sale spread, editors stopped work to talk about what the transfer of ownership would mean for the paper. ''Murdoch turned out to be an extraordinary owner in not meddling with the paper,'' one editor said. ''The hope is that Leonard Stern will do the same. But the rumor is that he is politically conservative at a paper with historically liberal politics.''

headline: NEW COMMITMENTS MADE BY JAPANESE ON TRADE, U.S. SAYS
abstract: The Reagan Administration, seeking to blunt Congressional anger over lack of access to the Japanese market, said today that Japan had made ''new commitments'' on trade.    Although White House officials indicated that American-Japanese talks in Tokyo over the weekend had left many trade matters unresolved, Administration aides made it plain that Japanese leaders had tentatively agreed to meet Washington's demands for greater access to the Japanese market, particularly for telecommunications products.    Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said President Reagan had been informed by two special envoys, just back from Tokyo, that ''during the discussions the Government of Japan made new commitments on trade issues.'' The envoys arrived in Washington late this morning.

headline: Sale by Champion
abstract: The Champion International Corporation said that it had agreed to sell its six folding carton plants and two of its paperboard mills to a private group that includes the manager of one of the plants. Analysts estimated the sale price was about $100 million. The sale continues a divestiture program begun after Champion acquired the St. Regis Corporation last year.

headline: STOCK PRICES IN MODERATE RETREAT
abstract: Blue-chip issues joined the rest of the market yesterday in a retreat that sent stock prices moderately lower on slightly increased volume.   Many investors, sensing a crucial period for interest rates, are remaining inactive until there is a better sense of Federal Reserve monetary policy, analysts said.   The Dow Jones industrial average, the only major indicator to rise on Monday, conformed yesterday, when it fell 4.60 points to finish at 1,313.84.

headline: MONENCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: BITBURG VISIT: IS 'RECONCILIATION' NEEDED? The President's Trip
abstract: In seeking ''reconciliation'' - between two nations that have been staunch allies for three decades - Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Reagan have rekindled the dark memories and images of Nazi Germany in the United States and stirred others that haunt an emotional debate in West Germany.   By insisting that President Reagan visit a symbolically flawed German military cemetery - the resting place of 49 soldiers of the Waffen SS - Mr. Kohl has irritated and possibly alienated some of Mr. Reagan's closest advisers, according to American officials.   West German politicians and commentators fear that the public storm in the United States, symbolized by appeals in Congress to cancel the cemetery visit, will be slow to ebb.   ''How do we get out of this?'' a West German diplomat asked an American friend. ''I mean, where do we go from here?''

headline: FARLEY AND NORTHWEST PLAN $1.3 BILLION MERGER
abstract: William F. Farley, a part owner of the Chicago White Sox, can probably be forgiven for being a bit of a cheerleader. Hope springs eternal for baseball owners, especially in April.   Today - the day after his White Sox opened their season with a victory - Mr. Farley enthusiastically announced that his privately held Farley Industries had reached a definitive agreement for a $1.3 billion merger with Northwest Industries.

headline: Sri Lanka to Hold Talks With Tamil Separatists
abstract: The Sri Lanka Government and Tamil separatist political and guerrilla groups are to hold talks in the tiny Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan, a Cabinet spokesman said today.   The spokesman, Information Minister Anandatissa de Alwis, said the Cabinet had agreed that preliminary talks should begin in the next few days.

headline: REAGAN WROTE TO LATIN CHIEFS ON AID
abstract: The White House spokesman, saying he wanted to counter charges that President Reagan's plan on Nicaragua had not been fully explained to Latin American leaders, made public a letter today that he said had been delivered to the Presidents of four Latin American countries on April 4, the day President Reagan announced the plan.     President Belisario Betancur of Colombia said in an interview last week that he had endorsed Mr. Reagan's plan before he was aware it was tied to the release of $14 million in renewed military aid to the rebels.   The letter made public today, from Mr. Reagan to the Presidents of Colombia, Venezuela, Panama and Mexico, explains his proposal in full, including the provision that the United States would give the rebels only nonmilitary aid if the Nicaraguan Government agreed to negotiate with them.

headline: No Headline
abstract: A Hungarian immigrant has told the Brazilian police that a man who identified himself as the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele lived with her family in Brazil between 1961 and 1974 and died here in 1979, according to testimony made public today.   The woman, Gitta Stammer, 65 years old, said the man who managed her family's farm admitted he was Dr. Mengele after she confronted him in 1962 with a newspaper photograph of the Auschwitz death camp doctor.   In the five-page report on her testimony, Mrs. Stammer is also indirectly quoted as saying that she and her husband had been afraid of denouncing Dr. Mengele because ''veiled threats'' had been made by a friend of the doctor's ''that something bad might happen to her children.''

headline: NEW BATTLES BREAK OUT IN BEIRUT
abstract: A pitched battle broke out today between Palestinians and Shiites in and around one of three besieged Palestinian settlements in southern Beirut. The latest fighting came within minutes of the return of the hijacked Trans World Airlines plane to the Beirut International Airport.   As clashes with mortar, tank fire and heavy machine guns raged for control of the Shatila settlement, Palestinians in the surrounding hills came to the aid of their colleagues and pounded Shiite strongholds with artillery and rockets.

headline: First Jersey Sets Changes
abstract: First Jersey Securities Inc. said yesterday that it would put into effect the 25 recommendations made by a court-appointed financial consultant. The New York-based securities firm agreed to hire Benjamin L. Lubin, president of the Securities Industry Management Corporation, to review its 35-office national business and the treatment of its 500,000 customers as part of the firm's settlement of a Securities and Exchange Commission complaint.   Mr. Lubin's recommendations included making formal branch reviews and using a time clock to record the times when orders for stock purchases are entered and executions are completed.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: BRITISH CLINICS ARE STRUGGLING AS HEROIN ADDICTION CLIMBS
abstract: Short of money and overburdened with patients, the Hackney drug addiction center of St. Bartholomew's Hospital in London reluctantly closed its doors for six months last year to 60 heroin addicts seeking treatment.    Similar events are occurring around Britain as addiction centers, renowned since the 1960's for pioneering the use of drug prescription as a cure for heroin addiction, struggle to cope with what is increasingly viewed as a heroin epidemic.   Concern over the number of heroin addicts, which is believed to have quadrupled since 1980, has touched off a hotly debated $2.2 million governmental anti-drug campaign and investigations by two House of Commons committees.    Unofficial estimates place the number of heroin addicts in Britain at 50,000, a figure the Government acknowledges. Official statistics, based on the number of addicts registered for treatment, put the total at only 6,000, a figure that indicates an increase of 25 percent since 1984.

headline: TURK'S '80 TRAVELS FIGURE IN PAPAL-PLOT TRIAL
abstract: Testimony in the trial of eight men accused of plotting the assassination of Pope John Paul II turned again today to the travels of one of the five Turkish defendants, Omer Bagci.   Mr. Bagci and the chief judge, Severino Santiapichi, tugged and peered at a passport and a road map of the Balkans. But the defendant was unable to explain a 1980 trip to Turkey and the circumstances under which his passport was stamped three times.

headline: Big Harbor Fire in Hamburg
abstract: Four hundred firemen fought a blaze in a warehouse in the Hamburg harbor area today, and after six hours put out one of the biggest fires here since World War II. A fire department spokesman put the damage in the millions of dollars. Ships were towed out of the area to escape shock waves from exploding containers.

headline: Pacific Resources Fills Key Post After Search
abstract: The board of directors of Pacific Resources Inc. announced that Robert G. Reed 3d had been elected president and chief executive officer.   Mr. Reed's election ends a six-month search for a leader at Pacific Resources, an oil refining, trading, marketing and distribution company based in Honolulu.

headline: WARSAW, TOO, PAYING HEED TO THE POLLS
abstract: Public-opinion polls, once regarded by Communist theorists as indications of false consciousness, are playing an increasingly important role in political decision making in Poland.   For some years, there have been Government agencies in the Soviet-bloc countries that have charted the effect of propaganda campaigns. But these were often low-profile operations whose studies, often reportedly fashioned to political specifications, received little attention at the top.   Now, for more than a year, in the aftermath of the Solidarity period, opinion polls are being prepared by an independent body that has gained the patronage of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, despite objections by hard-liners. Along with Cabinet ministers, the Polish leader receives and reportedly pores over the polls.

headline: POPE'S VISIT TO LOW COUNTRIES: CLASH OF VALUES
abstract: The visit of Pope John Paul II to the Low Countries, which ended Tuesday, is likely to prove important for the future of the Roman Catholic Church, not just for the way the Pope received criticism, but also for the course he outlined in the face of the attacks.   Many rank-and-file Catholics took the opportunity of the Pope's visit to the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Belgium to say directly to John Paul what millions of Catholics have been saying to each other and to their priests and Bishops.   The dissent covered a wide range of issues, notably sexual issues and birth control, the desire of many women to be ordained as priests and a general wish for greater flexibility by the Pope and the Vatican.   Two facts are noteworthy about the Pope's reaction: First that he accepted the criticism serenely, showing some understanding for those who opposed him; second that he made quite clear that he intends to press ahead with his program to reassert traditional church teaching.

headline: TAX BILL'S '85 CHANCES DIM IN HOUSE
abstract: Prospects for enactment of major tax- overhaul legislation this year are dimming, House Democrats reported today. And next year, a Congressional election year, contains its own political perils for a tax bill, the Administration has warned.    The Ways and Means Committee of the Democratic-controlled House of Representatives, particularly, is planning such long hearings on the President's proposal that committee aides see little prospect for enactment of legislation this year.    Still, aides of the Republican-controlled Senate Finance Committee, despite misgivings of some members over likely elements of the proposal, is expected to press for enactment this year.

headline: Broker Sees Suit by Busch A.G. Edwards Inc., a major regional brokerage based in St. Louis, said yesterday that it had been told by the Anheuser- Busch Companies that it would be sued for several hundred million dollars in connection with allegations of insider trading of Anheuser's shares by a former A.G. Edwards employee and other individuals.
abstract: Edwards called the charges ''wholly without merit.''   The suit is related to charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that W. Paul Thayer, a former Anheuser director and former Deputy Secretary of Defense, had in 1982 provided inside information to associates on Anheuser's bid for Campbell Taggart Inc.

headline: Struggle Intensifies At Gulf Resources
abstract: The proxy battle for control of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation between its chairman, Alan E. Clore, and a group of international investors intensified yesterday as the company denounced the insurgents and said it was ''currently negotiating with several prospects'' to sell some of its businesses. The proxy battle broke out last week.

headline: SPAIN, SPURNING HIJACKERS, WILL TRY GUNMEN
abstract: Spain is going ahead with the scheduled trial Wednesday of two Lebanese gunmen despite demands by hijackers holding American hostages in Beirut that the two be freed, Spanish officials said today.   Foreign Ministry officials said the Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez had rejected the terrorist demands and had informed the kidnappers through their mediator, Nabih Berri, the Lebanese Justice Minister and leader of Amal, the Shiite militia.   The officials said that position could change if the Reagan Administration was to press for the release of the two to save the hostages, but they noted that the Americans also oppose concessions.   The Spanish stand appears to have dashed hopes by many in the mediation process of moderating the attitude of the hijackers by quickly meeting at least one of their demands, Spanish and foreign diplomats said. The principal demand of the hijackers who commandeered an Athens-to-Rome T.W.A. airliner Friday has been that Isreal free more than 700 Lebanese Shiites jailed in Israel.

headline: Greece Moves to Limit Powers of President
abstract: The Greek Parliament approved in principle today constitutional amendments that would trim the powers of the President. The action brings the nation closer to early legislative elections that are expected to be held in June.

headline: New U.S. Pacts on Steel
abstract: The Reagan Administration has signed steel export agreements with three more countries as part of its program to curb the flow of foreign steel into the United States. The new five-year agreements, retroactive to Oct. 1, were reached with Rumania, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, the deputy United States trade representative, Robert Lighthizer, said on Tuesday.

headline: Jacobs Plans Bid To Acquire AMF
abstract: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis- based investor, said yesterday that he plans to make a bid to acquire 50 to 100 percent of AMF Inc., a leisure- equipment maker that has had recent earnings problems.    Mr. Jacobs, chairman of Minstar Inc., said by telephone from his car in California that the AMF management was apparently hostile to his overtures. He said AMF's chairman, W. Thomas York, this week rejected three phone requests for a meeting to discuss Minstar's acquisition of all or part of the concern.

headline: Security Pacific Merger Talks
abstract: The Security Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it was engaged in ''serious negotiations'' to acquire some units of the Commercial Credit Company, a financial services subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation.

headline: Credit Unions Facing a Tax
abstract: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S tax proposal gave little solace to the nation's 2,000 largest credit unions. If he gets his way, all credit unions with assets of $5 million or more will have to pay corporate income tax for the first time in the industry's history.

headline: PRETORIA INSTALL REGIME IN NAMIBIA
abstract: Policemen wielding riot sticks charged demonstrators in a black township here today as South Africa handed over limited powers to a new, multiracial administration in this former German colony.   At least six people were reported injured as the police, reportedly drawn from a special counterinsurgency unit, fired tear gas and wielded batons against 500 demonstrators opposed to the new Government.   The new Government, whose installation marks the end of South Africa's most recent spell of direct rule here, has been accused by critics of being a front for continued South African dominance. South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, is on South Africa's northwest border.

headline: Pratt & Whitney Pact
abstract: Pratt & Whitney Canada Inc., the jet engine subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation, said it had signed a licensing agreement with Rolls-Royce Turbomeca Ltd. to build an advanced technology military helicopter engine. The engine, designed by England's Rolls-Royce Ltd. and France's Turbomeca S.A., is being aimed at Pentagon helicopter engine markets now dominated by Pratt & Whitney's major rival, the General Electric Company.

headline: Turk, Refused a Swiss Visa, Shoots a Consul in Istanbul
abstract: An irate Turk who had been denied a visa to enter Switzerland shot a Swiss consul today.

headline: Loews Negotiating To Sell Theaters
abstract: The Loews Corporation confirmed today that it was negotiating to sell its Loews Theaters division to a group headed by A. Jerrold Perenchio, a producer and co-owner of Embassy Communications.   Although Donald Baker, a spokesman for Loews, refused to comment on the purchase price or to elaborate on the terms of the deal, a source close to the negotiations put the price at about $165 million.   The spokesman said the sale would be made with the assumption that Loews Theaters' current management would be retained.

headline: Washington Watch;On Confirming Fed Nominee
abstract: JAKE GARN, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, has been back from outer space for several days, but there is still no indication of when the Utah Republican will call for a committee vote on President Reagan's nomination of Martha R. Seger to serve on the Federal Reserve Board.         Miss Seger has been serving as a full-fledged member since last July under a  recess appointment by Mr. Reagan. This allows a nominee to serve until the end of the subsequent Congressional session, presumably until late this year.

headline: A Masked Attacker in Poland Reportedly Tortures a Priest
abstract: A masked attacker tortured a priest with a cigarette, burning a ''V'' on his chest, in the latest assault on the Roman Catholic clergy in Poland, civil rights sources said today.   An Interior Ministry spokesman said the police were investigating.

headline: U.N. REPORT SAYS FINNS HELPED 11 DESERT SOUTH LEBANON MILITIA
abstract: A United Nations board of inquiry has established that 11 Christian-led militiamen deserted to the Shiite Amal militia in southern Lebanon earlier this month and that Finnish soldiers of the United Nations helped in the desertion.   The report said the Finns and the militiamen had faked a battle in which the militiamen were captured.   The incident led to the reprisal kidnapping of 24 Finnish soldiers by the militia, the Israeli-supported South Lebanon Army. The South Lebanon Army and Israel had accused the Finns of abducting the 11 militiamen and turning them over, or at least abandoning them, to the enemy.

headline: FACTORY ORDERS FALL 0.5% MORE
abstract: Factory orders fell five-tenths of 1 percent in April, with both durable and nondurable goods showing declines, the Commerce Department reported today.   It was the third consecutive decline in the measure of activity of the nation's manufacturing industry, which is lagging behind other sectors and keeping overall economic growth in check.   One factor was a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in durable goods orders, which had originally been reported as gaining 1 percent in an earlier, more narrow report.

headline: Rioting Continues In Parts of India
abstract: Rioting continued in the states of Gujarat, Kashmir and Bihar today as mobs raised protests over affirmative-action programs and local issues.   Several people have been killed and hundreds injured in western and central India in two months of protests against job quotas in universities and government service for underprivileged castes and classes.   In Gujarat at least 19 people, including the police commissioner of Baroda and 12 other policemen, were injured when crowds threw bricks, the Press Trust of India reported.

headline: SUDANESE BREAK UP A PROTEST BY DOCTORS
abstract: The Sudanese police in Khartoum broke up a protest demonstration by physicians today, and foreign diplomats in London said they had received information that a general strike had begun.   Public communications with the Sudan were cut and independent reports were not available.   The Sudanese press agency said the police had used tear gas to disperse the demonstrating doctors, lawyers and other professionals.

headline: THE PALESTINIAN-SHIITE FIGHT FOR BEIRUT CAMPS INTENSIFIES
abstract: Palestinian guerrillas deployed in the Lebanese mountains fired volleys of rockets into Beirut's southern suburbs today in an effort to relieve the pressure on three Palestinian refugee camps, which have been under attack by Shiite fighters since Sunday.   The Soviet-manufactured Katyusha rockets hit several areas around the Sabra, Shatila and Burj al Brajneh camps in a further intensification of the violence that has gripped the Moslem part of the Lebanese capital for four days.   Militiamen of the Shiite movement Amal and defenders of the camps appeared to be locked in a fight to the finish. All efforts to arrange a truce have so far failed.

headline: SHIITES ATTACK PALESTINIANS IN SOUTH LEBANON DURING LULL IN BEIRUT
abstract: Shiite Moslem militiamen of the Amal movement stormed a Palestinian settlement in southern Lebanon today after a machine-gun clash with armed Palestinians.   The incident occurred as a relative calm enabled the Red Cross to evacuate more wounded Palestinians from the Burj al Brajneh refugee district in southern Beirut.   Meanwhile, a senior Iranian delegation held talks here with Shiite leaders after Teheran publicly declared its opposition to Amal's campaign to disarm the Palestinians in Lebanon. The team, headed by Ayatollah Mahdi Karoubi, arrived from Damascus, where the Iranians had met with the Syrian First Vice President, Abdel Halim Khaddam. Most of the one million Shiite Moslems in Lebanon are known to look to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian religious leader, for guidance.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Abacus Real Estate Finance Group of Wellesley, Mass., has promoted Evan L. Weston to senior vice president of its Boston regional office.    * Andrea Products/L'Erin Cosmetics Co., Brooklyn, has named Dick Musselman senior vice president, sales.

headline: HONDURAS AS ALLY: A BLOT ON THE IMAGE
abstract: The handful of riot policemen who stood on guard in front of the Supreme Court building here this week did not look nearly so frightening as the tight- lipped soldiers who patrol the streets of San Salvador or Guatemala City. But their presence reflected the difficulty Honduras faces as it seeks to consolidate civilian rule.    Events of recent days have shaken the image of Honduras as a functioning democracy, an image the Reagan Administration has tried to cultivate. They also reflect the difficulties Washington may encounter when it tries to turn a poor and backward country like this one into an important strategic and military ally.

headline: Jobs Found In Racing Industry
abstract: HORSE RACING is big business in the United States and Canada. The betting at tracks totaled about $8.1 billion in 1984, up from $5.27 billion 10 years earlier, according to Christopher N. Scherf, director of the service bureau of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations, Lake Success, L.I.   ''Betting averages about $100 a person,'' Mr. Scherf said, adding that other aspects of racing, such as track admissions and food concessions, account for $20 more from each racegoer. These figures do not include the money generated at 45 parimutuel harness racing tracks or the large amounts spent on breeding horses.   The number of thoroughbred racing tracks, Mr. Scherf said, does not change much, hovering around 100. Next week, on Wednesday, a new track called Canterbury Downs will open outside Minneapolis-St. Paul. Some thoroughbred tracks are also used for harness racing.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Bonds Show Little Change
abstract: Bond prices were little changed in light trading yesterday, as market participants decided to remain on the sidelines and assess conditions after last week's rally.     ''The markets have been very wishy-washy,'' said one Government securities dealer, who asked not to be identified. ''We saw plenty of retail interest last week, but there was not much going on today. We have become accustomed to not getting much business done on Mondays.''

headline: Pacific Lighting Settles Suit
abstract: The Pacific Lighting Corporation said it had reached an out-of-court settlement covering the bulk of a $118 million lawsuit brought against it last November by two major oil companies. The agreement with the Union Oil Company of California unit of the Unocal Corporation calls for Pacific Lighting, the parent of the Southern California Gas Company, to resume its purchases of natural gas.

headline: Nepal Bombings Protested
abstract: One-third of Nepal's elected lawmakers demanded today in Parliament that the Government resign ''on moral grounds'' for not preventing the terrorist bomb blasts that killed seven people in Nepal. More than three dozen legislators in the Parliament, which is not divided by party, called on Prime Minister Lokendra Bahadur and his 24-member Council of Ministers to quit for not safeguarding the people.

headline: PATENTS;  Removing Fly Ash At Coal-Burning Plants
abstract: An improved method of removing highly resistant fly ash from the smoke of coal-burning power plants has been developed for the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Coors Reshuffling Is All in the Family
abstract: The Adolph Coors Company, the nation's fifth-largest brewer, continues to prove that blood is thicker than water - or beer.   The company, which was founded in 1873 by Adolph Coors, said yesterday that two sets of Coors brothers had been given new responsibilities in a reorganization of top management.   Under the terms of the reorganization, the company said it had created an office of the chairman consisting of William K. Coors, who is 68 years old, as chairman and chief executive, and Joseph Coors, 67, as vice chairman and chief operating officer.

headline: A.T.&T. Contract
abstract: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had won a five-year Federal Aviation Administration contract to build equipment for radio microwave link stations throughout the nation. The contract is part of the Administration's plan to upgrade the nation's air traffic control system. A.T.&T. said its value could approach $200 million.

headline: Vermont Tax Discrimination Barred
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that the state of Vermont unconstitutionally discriminated against newcomers to the state by refusing to give them credit for sales taxes they paid on cars they bought out of state and brought with them to Vermont.   Vermont residents who buy their cars elsewhere receive a credit against Vermont's automobile use tax for any sales tax they paid to the other state. But the credit only operates if the buyer was a Vermont resident at the time of the purchase. Newcomers must pay a tax based on 4 percent of the car's book value in order to obtain their Vermont automobile registration.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: MONDAY, JUNE 24, 1985        Companies    Arco announced the retirement of its chief executive, William F. Kieschnick, who had recently completed a major restructuring plan for the oil company. Lodwrick M. Cook, chief operating officer of the products division, was named to succeed Mr. Kieschnick. Analysts expressed surprise at the changes. [Page D1.]

headline: Seabrook Unit Gets Rate Rise
abstract: The Maine Public Utilities Commission voted Friday to grant a $22.3 million rate increase to the Central Maine Power Company in exchange for the company taking an after-tax write-off of $44.9 million on its investments in four plants, including the troubled Seabrook nuclear power project.   The commission's action makes official an agreement reached last week between its staff, the Public Advocate and Central Maine Power, which holds a 6 percent stake in Seabrook.

headline: TEXTILE QUOTA BILL IS OPPOSED
abstract: Five Cabinet officers have warned that a textile quota bill that commands co-sponsorship of a majority in both houses of Congress would impose a ''very high cost'' on consumers, violate international obligations, invite retaliation and provide the domestic industry with ''unprecedented'' protection.   In a letter to each of the 535 members of Congress the Cabinet members for the first time manifested their collective concern about a bill promoted by the domestic industry that would have the effect of cutting overall textile imports by 36 percent.   The textile legislation is considered the most likely to pass of a raft of protectionist bills introduced to counteract pressures on many industries from surging imports.   Those signing the letter were Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, who is chairman of the President's Economic Policy Council; Secretary of State George P. Shultz; Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige; Labor Secretary Bill Brock and Michael B. Smith, the acting United States trade representative.

headline: Factory Orders Drop
abstract: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods dropped nine- tenths of 1 percent in February, a sharper decline than previously thought, according to revised figures released by the Government today.   The Commerce Department put total orders for the month at $193.4 billion, compared with $195.2 billion in January.

headline: 25 INVESTORS JOIN IN NEW CONRAIL BID
abstract: Morgan Stanley & Company, as expected, announced today that it had assembled a group of 25 investors to offer to purchase the Government's 85 percent interest in Conrail for $1.2 billion in cash and other considerations. Its investor coalition ranged from the CSX Corporation and Citicorp to Harvard, Princeton and Columbia and several major pension funds.   The Morgan Stanley group, said its proposal, if accepted, would be an interim step toward making at least 60 percent of Conrail's stock available to the public within five years of the date of purchase.   Morgan Stanley said the total value of its offer to the Government could be as much as $1.8 billion. The figure was based on Government receipts that might accrue from an independent Conrail as opposed to the carrier becoming a subsidiary of the Norfolk Southern Corporation, which the Reagan Administration picked in February as its choice to purchase Conrail.

headline: BRITISH SOCCER FAN: WHY SO WARLIKE?
abstract: Although Britain is known for civility and reserve, for gracious manners and the stiff upper lip, it has also been home for quite a long time to a youth culture that in some manifestations is poor, bored and violent.   From Teddy boys and rockers to mod to punk, it has given the world new and outrageous fashions and music, but today it is in the limelight for a less desirable reason: the British soccer fan.   Fan violence at soccer games is hardly the preserve of Britain - the worst soccer violence took place in Peru, where 318 died in 1964 - nor is atrocious behavior peculiar to soccer.   J. M. Lewis, an American sociologist, tallied reports of riots at sporting events in the United States between 1960 and 1972 and counted 312. Baseball topped the list with 97. Football and basketball ranked second and third.

headline: PERES AND KEY ISRAELI AIDES HOLD CLOSED-DOOR SESSION
abstract: Key members of the Israeli Cabinet held an extraordinary session behind closed doors tonight, and there was speculation it was called to discuss an offer by the Shiite militia leader Nabih Berri to turn over the American hostages to a Western embassy in Beirut.   The hostages would presumably remain there until Israel released 735 Lebanese and Palestinian detainees.   The Israeli radio reported that Prime Minister Shimon Peres received ''a message'' this afternoon from the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, about the Beirut hostage crisis. No details of the message were revealed, but there were indications here it was linked to Mr. Berri's offer to hand the American hostages to the Swiss or French Embassy in Beirut for safekeeping until Israel frees the detainees.

headline: CEMETERY PROTESTS REPORTEDLY BARRED
abstract: Two groups of American Jews said today that West German and American authorities had barred them from protesting President Reagan's visit to a German military cemetery where 49 Waffen SS troops are buried.   Kalman Sultanik, vice president of the World Jewish Congress and a member of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, said West German and American authorities had initially promised his group a permit to demonstrate at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp site.   President Reagan is scheduled to visit Bergen-Belsen Sunday morning before flying to a ceremony at the cemetery at Bitburg. Mr. Reagan will be accompanied by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.

headline: PROSECUTOR SEEKS DUTCH EVIDENCE IN PLOT ON POPE
abstract: The prosecutor in the trial here of eight men accused of conspiring to kill the Pope flew to the Netherlands today to seek information about a Turk arrested there last month with a weapon and a forged passport.   The Turk, Samet Arslan, was seized May 14, the last day of a trip by Pope John Paul II to the Netherlands.   Court officials said the prosecutor, Antonio Marini, would seek to establish whether there were links between the Turkish suspect and the five Turks and three Bulgarians on trial here. If links are found, they said, the prosecutor is expected to seek extradition.

headline: Iran Gives Squatters Right to Land They Took
abstract: Iran's Parliament has approved a bill intended to resolve a dispute over land ownership caused by the breakup of big estates after the 1979 Islamic revolution.   The law, enacted Sunday, gives peasants and squatters rights over land they took over, but all landowners who escaped redistribution will be able to keep their estates.

headline: DESPITE PEACE ACCOD, BEIRUT FIGHTING GOES ON
abstract: Artillery and rocket exchanges between armed Palestinians and Shiite militiamen erupted today despite a cease-fire agreement worked out late Monday between Palestinian and Shiite combatants fighting for control of three Palestinian settlements here.   Despite the new clashes, Nabih Berri, the leader of the mainstream Shiite militia, Amal, declared that the fighting for the settlements was over. He said he had ordered an immediate and strict cease-fire and that preparations were under way to evacuate the wounded from the scene of the fighting.   The police said 3 people were killed and 35 wounded when residential areas around the Palestinian settlements and elsewhere in the Moslem area of Beirut were bombarded, apparently randomly.

headline: A DETAILED ACCOUNT OF MENGELE'S LIFE
abstract: The Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele had never met his son Rolf until a ski holiday in Switzerland in 1956 when the boy was 12 years old, according to information supplied to a Munich magazine by the son himself.   Three years later, according to the weekly Bunte, the boy learned that the hard-skiing ''uncle'' introduced to him as ''Helmut Gregor'' was his father.   In an issue that will appear Thursday, the magazine will also report that for four years after the war the elder Mengele worked as a groom on a Bavarian farm and was mistakenly arrested by the Italian authorities in 1949 as he made his way to South America.   For the last week, according to Bunte editors, Rolf Mengele has been describing his relationship with his father, who he insists died in Brazil in 1979. #30 Pounds of Documents The 41-year-old West German lawyer has also reportedly given Bunte more than 30 pounds of notebooks, letters and photographs documenting the war criminal's life in hiding.

headline: PRICES OF LEADED GASOLINE RISING AS NEW E.P.A. CURBS TAKE EFFECT
abstract: Consumers are likely to begin paying as much as 3 cents a gallon more for leaded gasoline this weekend, as Monday's deadline for reducing the lead content in such gasoline approaches.   Late this week Exxon, Sun, Amoco, and Mobil raised their wholesale prices for leaded gasolines in all or part of the country by 2 cents a gallon, and other oil companies are expected to soon follow. The 2-cents-a-gallon figure is widely accepted as the industry's increased cost of producing the lower-leaded gasoline. The other penny a gallon consumers may be paying represents dealers' profit.   The reduction, to five-tenths of a gram of lead per gallon, from the current standard of 1.1 grams per gallon, to be followed on Jan. 1 by a further reduction to one-tenth of a gram, represents a major step in the Federal Government's goal of eliminating lead from gasoline - and eliminating the danger it poses to human health and the environment. Leaded gasoline is used by approximately 35 percent of the nation's 164 million motorists.

headline: SENATOR FAULTS ACCUSATION OF ISRAELIS
abstract: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan criticized the State Department today for asserting on Wednesday that Israel had apparently violated an international agreement by transferring detainees from southern Lebanon to Israel.    The State Department said it stood by its statement.    In a Senate speech, the New York Democrat said that the State Department had wrongly interpreted the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949, which deals with the treatment of captured civilians and others who are not members of organized armed units.   Specifically, the convention applies to everyone who is not a part of an organized military unit. Also included are people who have been convicted of actions ''hostile to the security of the occupying power.''

headline: 40 Drown in Boat Accident
abstract: Forty people drowned when a boat traveling from the Ivory Coast to Ghana sank last week, the Ghana news agency reported today. One of the 35 survivors said the boat was overloaded when the accident occurred, the news agency said in the report monitored here.

headline: Dow Climbs 6.72, to 1,327.28
abstract: Stock prices, again hitting record levels, rose moderately yesterday as General Motors and reborn technology stocks paced the climb.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 5.26 points on Wednesday, improved 6.72 points yesterday to an all-time high of 1,327.28.   Broader market indexes also continued to break records, with the New York Stock Exchange composite index gaining 0.45, to 110.69, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up 0.90, to 191.06.   Over all there were 898 shares that advanced in price and 705 that fell. The average share gained 14 cents. Volume weakened to 117.2 million shares in what was a dull session until the afternoon. A total of 143.9 million shares changed hands on Wednesday.

headline: PATENTS;  Cheaper Way to Make Cancer Drug Chemical
abstract: Two chemists have invented an inexpensive method of manufacturing a chemical component of drugs used in treating cancer.

headline: U.S.-Soviet Summit Meeting Is Not Likely, Brandt Asserts
abstract: Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, who has just returned from talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said today that he doubts there will be a summit meeting this year between Mr. Gorbachev and President Reagan.   Mr. Brandt, chairman of West Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party and a former Chancellor, held talks with Mr. Gorbachev during a visit to Moscow last week.

headline: STRONG SHOWING BY BIG BANKS
abstract: In a quarter when most of the nation's top banking companies reported stronger-than-usual earnings, the top three spots in terms of profitability were taken by New York-based institutions.    J.P. Morgan & Company continued its spectacular performance and, for the second quarter in a row reported that, based on net income applicable to common stockholders, it earned one dollar on every $100 of its total assets.   Morgan was well ahead of its runner-up, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, which also has become a regular top-performer among the nation's 15 largest bank holding companies. Bankers Trust earned 76 cents on each $100 of average total assets.   The rankings of Morgan and Bankers Trust were particularly unusual because the two banks do virtually no consumer business, an area in which increasingly wide profit margins have been the major factor in bolstering the earnings of the other banking companies.

headline: Strike Is Voted At Big Board
abstract: Trading floor and other clerical workers at the New York Stock Exchange have voted to walk off the job Tuesday in what would be the first strike at the Big Board since 1948.      Members of Local 153 of the   Office and Professional Employees International Union voted, 911 to 76, yesterday to reject the exchange's offer, which includes a 15 percent wage increase over three years.

headline: Times Co. Net Up 32%
abstract: The New York Times Company today reported record first-quarter earnings, as higher newspaper revenue helped net income rise by 32 percent above the 1984 quarter.    The company's profit in the first quarter was $32.3 million, or 81 cents a share, up from $24.5 million, or 62 cents a share, a year earlier. The latest quarter's results included a one- time after-tax gain of $2.8 million from the sale of property in New York City. Excluding that gain, net income was 20 percent above the 1984 period.

headline: NICARAGUA MEN FLEEING DRAFT FILL HONDURAN REFUGEE CAMP
abstract: There is a new kind of refugee in Central America, and Ervin, a strapping youth of 19, is an example.      Ervin has a wife and two children in Nicaragua. When he fled last month, he was less than a year away from a degree in accounting. He wears a crucifix. People like him do not usually wind up in desolate, dusty camps like the one outside this shabby town.

headline: ETHIOPIA DEBATES HOW TO FEED ITSELF
abstract: In the months since the famine in Ethiopia became known around the world, the primary concern has been to find ways to get food from outside to the millions of starving people here.   Increasingly, however, attention has been turning to the less dramatic but far more complex problem of what can be done to help Ethiopia transform itself from a recipient of charity into a nation capable of feeding itself.   The rains that have lately fallen, combined with a recent announcement that the United States will begin paying for Ethiopian development as well as relief assistance, has brought new immediacy and hope to the debate.   But a growing number of Western development specialists say that rain from above and dollars from abroad, while necessary, are insufficient in themselves in bringing economic viability to this country.

headline: Suspect in Drug Killing Is Returned to Mexico
abstract: Rafael Caro Quintero was returned to Mexico tonight under armed guard for questioning about the slaying of an American narcotics agent.    At least 40 plainclothes policemen, armed with shotguns and automatic rifles, were stationed along the runway as a Mexican Government jet landed here with Mr. Caro Quintero and four men captured with him in Costa Rica.

headline: PROBLEM OF TOXIC EMISSIONS
abstract: In Parkersburg, W.Va., a million pounds of a Government-listed carcinogen are released into the air each year from a chemical plant owned by the Borg-Warner Corporation.   The chemical is acrylonitrile, also called vinyl cyanide. In its liquid state, the chemical is clear and flammable. It is used to make hard plastics for computer terminals, telephone receivers and other products.   There are no Federal or West Virginia standards that control emissions of acrylonitrile, and Borg-Warner says the Parkersburg emissions are safe. If the plant were in Philadelphia, however, such emissions would be double the safe limit established there. And in New York State they would be 50 percent above the limit.

headline: Transco Purchase
abstract: The Transco Energy Company said it had agreed to acquire the Exchange Oil and Gas Corporation for about $180 million, subject to certain adjustments. Exchange is a unit of the Georgia-Pacific Leasing Corporation, which in turn is a subsidiary of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation. Transco said it expected its affiliate, Transco Exploration Partners Ltd., to acquire the assets of Exchange Oil after the closing of the deal, which is expected on Aug. 1.

headline: Chase Promotes 3 To Vice Chairman
abstract: Three of Chase Manhattan Corporation's 14 executive vice presidents were promoted to vice chairman yesterday and became members of what the bank calls its top management team. They are Robert R. Douglass, Arthur F. Ryan and Anthony P. Terracciano.   The three were also named directors of the corporation and of its principal subsidiary, the Chase Manhattan Bank.

headline: Bolivian City Is Strikebound
abstract: A general strike paralyzed Cochabamba, Bolivia's third largest city, today and strikers threatened to cut electricity to mines Wednesday if their demands for Government funds were not met.

headline: ITALY AND POPE RATIFY A NEW CONCORDAT
abstract: The Vatican and Italy ratified a historic pact today ending Roman Catholicism as a state religion in Italy.   Pope John Paul II said the new church-state treaty, known as a concordat, was a sign that Catholicism respected Italy's independence, but he added that the church reserved the right to speak out on political and moral issues.   Prime Minister Bettino Craxi went to the Vatican for the ceremony in his first official visit since taking office. He declared that the new concordat ''exalts religious freedom and the freedom of the church.''

headline: Crown Zellerbach
abstract: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said that a Nevada court had upheld the company's plan to hold its annual meeting on May 9 in San Francisco.

headline: UNESCO NEGOTIATES ON BUDGET AFTER U.S. FUND CUT
abstract: The Director General of Unesco proposed today that money be used from a reserve fund to help make up the loss of Washington's 25 percent contribution to the budget.   The proposal by the agency head, Amadou Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, came at the start of a six-week meeting of the executive board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. The board is trying to draw up a budget and program for the next two years.

headline: Swiss Wholesale Prices
abstract: Wholesale prices in Switzerland rose one-tenth of 1 percent in April from March, and were up 3.4 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today. The 12-month rise was down from increases of 3.5 percent in March and 4.4 percent in February.

headline: Guidelines Issued for Banks Lending Securities
abstract: Two Federal regulatory agencies issued guidelines today on how banks and other regulated financial institutions can protect themselves when lending securities that they either own or hold in trust for clients.   Both the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation adopted an extensive policy recommendation by the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council on the best procedure for the lending of securities, including collateral requirements, record keeping and credit analysis. The council, which represents five regulatory agencies, is a policy research organization for those agencies.

headline: U.S. Steel Talks Reported A report that the United
abstract: States Steel Corporation was   negotiating a link with Pohang   Steel of South Korea drew a   quick reaction yesterday from   the United Steelworkers of   America.

headline: KOHL IS PLANNING RISKY ENCOUNTERS
abstract: The Government said today that Chancellor Helmut Kohl would hold to two politically risky encounters: an address to a gathering of Silesian Germans in June and a visit to Bonn in early July by Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, the Paraguayan leader.   Jurgen Sudhoff, a Government spokesman, said at a news conference that Mr. Kohl would address the annual meeting of the Silesian Compatriot Association in Hanover on June 16. The planned encounter came under fire after an article was published in the group's official organ attacking President Richard von Weizsacker in language that had anti-Semitic innuendo.   The spokesman said that the ''working visit'' by General Stroessner, who has ruled his South American nation with an iron hand for 31 years, would ''go forward as planned.''

headline: Pennsylvania
abstract: A $106 million issue of Pennsylvania general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 4.50 percent for bonds due in Dec. 1, 1985, to 6.80 percent in 1990, 7.80 percent in 1995, 8.60 percent in 2000 and 8.70 percent in 2004 through underwriters led by Citibank. The bonds are rated A by Moody's and A+ by S.&P.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 1, 1985:

headline: CBS Agrees to Buy 5 Radio Stations
abstract: CBS Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to buy five radio stations from the Taft Broadcasting Company for an undisclosed price.   Analysts estimated that the stations - in Washington, Dallas, Houston and Tampa, Fla. - would probably be sold for about $100 million.The two companies said the transaction was subject to a definitive agreement and necessary regulatory approvals. Some of the stations are also involved in Taft's pending acquisition of the broadcast properties of the Gulf Broadcast Company.

headline: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS HOLD STEADY
abstract: After dropping for three consecutive months, the prices farmers get for raw products held steady in June, remaining at their lowest average level in more than two years, the Agriculture Department said today.   The preliminary June reading also was 10 percent below the level of a year ago. The index in the last two months has been the lowest since January 1983. The index had remained steady in January and February before dropping in March, April and May.

headline: IRAN SAYS IT FIRED MISSILE AT BAGHDAD IN A REPRISAL
abstract: Iran fired a surface-to-surface missile at Baghdad today after Iraqi air strikes on Teheran, the official Iranian press agency reported.   The agency, in a dispatch monitored here, said the missile was launched at 4 A.M. ''in retaliation for the recent inhuman attacks upon civilian areas in Teheran and other Iranian cities.''   ''Scores of innocent civilians have been killed or wounded in Iraqi air and missile attacks upon Teheran and a number of other towns in the country over the last two days,'' it said.   The Iranian agency said Iraqi aircraft bombed two civilian areas of the capital at about 2:30 A.M. It was the second time Iraqi planes had appeared over Iran in less than four hours, the press agency said. [The agency said at least 5 people were killed and 15 wounded in the bombing of Teheran, United Press International reported.]  There was no immediate Iraqi comment on the latest Iranian reports.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The San Diego, Northeast Indiana and the Southern Cadillac Dealers' Marketing Associations to Sawdon & Bess.

headline: ASSAD, IN MOSCOW, CONFERS ON MIDEAST ISSUES
abstract: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met today with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in talks that appeared to be centered on American-backed peace moves in the Middle East and the continuing strife in Lebanon.
