Syria is one of the Soviet Union's closest allies in the Middle East, and the two countries are linked by a long-term treaty of friendship.   An account by Tass made only a general reference to the negotiations involving the United States, Israel, Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization to find a peace formula, but the Government press agency made evident that the Soviet Union was concerned about the moves.

headline: GEMAYEL HAS NARROW ESCAPE AS HIS PALACE IS BOMBARDED
abstract: President Amin Gemayel was reported to have narrowly escaped injury today when artillery shells and rockets struck the presidential palace in the predominantly Christian suburb of Baabda.   The incident occurred during a flare-up of artillery exchanges between Christian and Moslem militiamen across the Green Line that divides Beirut and in the hills to the east, but the source of the rockets and shellfire was not clear.   The bombardment was apparently unrelated to the bitter fighting between armed Palestinians and Shiite militiamen and soldiers that has been going on for the last 11 days in and around three Palestinian refugee settlements in the south of Beirut.      Talks in Syria   After the incident, Mr. Gemayel flew to Damascus for emergency talks with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. Mr. Gemayel was expected to seek Syrian assistance in putting an end to the latest wave of violence, and there was speculation here that he would ask Mr. Assad to order Syrian troops into Beirut to halt the fighting.

headline: French Steel Pact
abstract: France's state-owned steel company, Usinor, signed a preliminary deal worth $425 million to supply steel products to the Soviet Union, the company's managing director, Rene Loubert, said.

headline: U.S. MAY SOON STOP TAKING REFUGEES FROM THAI CAMPS
abstract: State Department officials said today that the United States would soon stop processing Cambodian refugees in Thailand for resettlement in this country.   Unless there is a change in plans, this would mean the end of a program that has brought 120,000 Cambodians to the United States since Indochina became Communist in 1975.   The officials explained the cutoff by saying that no more Cambodians in Thailand were deemed eligible for admission. Of the 25,000 in the main refugee camp, at Khao-i-Dang, all but 2,000 have been processed and deemed ineligible, the officials said.

headline: Yeutter's Trade View
abstract: Clayton K. Yeutter, who is expected to be confirmed this week as President Reagan's chief trade negotiator, said at his Senate confirmation hearing today that the nation's $123 billion trade deficit was ''intolerable and unsustainable.'' He added that ''simultaneous, almost instantaneous,'' action was needed to redress it.

headline: PATENTS;  Award for Patent Aide
abstract: Rene D. Tegtmeyer, Assistant Commissioner for Patents, will receive the Jefferson Medal from the New Jersey Patent Law Association next Friday at a dinner in Totowa, N.J. He is being honored for his contributions to intellectual law, relating to patents, trademarks and copyrights.

headline: Indonesian President Warns the West
abstract: President Suharto, opening a meeting of 80 Asian and African nations today, warned the West that prolonged backwardness in the third& world would lead to disaster for industrialized nations.   He told the meeting, which marked the 30th anniversary of the Asia-Africa Bandung Conference, that the only way to close the gap between advanced countries and the developing world was to establish a new international economic order.

headline: U..S. Bars More Bills From Dynamics
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation billed the Government for $244 million in improper overhead expenses in recent years, Pentagon auditors have concluded.  A review of the company's billing procedures, which was ordered March 5 by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger when he placed a 30-day freeze on overhead payments to it, found $154 million in unallowable claims not previously contested. The review identified another $90 million in overhead charges already withheld by the Pentagon.   Michael I. Burch, the Defense Department's chief spokesman, said today that the review would be released in a few days. He noted that about $30 million had been withheld from General Dynamics during the 30-day freeze, leaving $124 million still to be collected.

headline: AFTER-TAX INCOME OFF LAST MONTH
abstract: The disposable, after-tax income of Americans fell by five-tenths of 1 percent in March after a February decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.    Both months were hurt by computer-caused delays that deprived Americans of $6.7 billion in Federal income tax refunds in the two months.    The declines in disposable income sent consumer spending tumbling by five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the biggest decline in more than a year, the department said.

headline: Vietnamese Visits Moscow
abstract: The Vietnamese Communist Party leader, Le Duan, traveled to the Soviet Union with a delegation today for an official visit, the Hanoi radio announced in a broadcast monitored in Bangkok.

headline: Showbiz Pizza Time Names New Top Officer
abstract: The Brock Hotel Corporation said yesterday that Richard M. Frank, who is executive vice president of the S&A Restaurant Corporation, will become president of Showbiz Pizza Time Inc., a restaurant chain in which Brock has a controlling interest.   Mr. Frank, who is 37, succeeds Robert L. Brock, 60. In a telephone interview from the company's headquarters in Irving, Tex., Mr. Brock said he would remain chairman and chief executive of Showbiz Pizza Time for the next several months, and would probably cede those titles to Mr. Frank in March. Mr. Brock is chairman and chief executive of Brock Hotel.

headline: Chrysler-Maserati Car
abstract: A $30,000 sports car developed by the Chrysler Corporation and Maserati of Italy will bear the Chrysler name and will contain many Chrysler parts, Chrysler said today. Production in Italy will start late next year.

headline: Business and the Law;   Responsibility For Job Safety
abstract: THE recent murder conviction of three Chicago-area corporate executives in the death of an employee from cyanide poisoning was certainly a landmark in criminal law, but many job-safety and legal experts question whether the case will become a precedent for prosecutors or a deterrent to corporations.   The case is generally considered the first time that corporate officials have been found guilty of murder in a job-related death, so a lot of lawyers wonder whether the verdict will be upheld when the defendants appeal.   The facts of the case were unusual. Stefan Golan, a 59-year-old immigrant from Poland, died in February 1983 after having worked two months over bubbling vats that spewed cyanide fumes. The company, Film Recovery Systems Inc., was reclaiming silver from used photographic film at its now-defunct plant in Elk Grove Village, Ill.

headline: T.W.A. Reply Due
abstract: Resorts International Inc. expects to hear whether Trans World Airlines Inc. will accept its takeover bid within ''24 hours,'' a source close to Resorts told the Reuters news agency yesterday. Wall Street sources said the T.W.A. board reviewed Resorts' offer of $22 a share last Friday. Separately, American Airlines confirmed reports that it had taken an informal look at T.W.A. But Lowell Duncan, an American spokesman, said the airline had decided not to make an offer.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS TROOPS WILL LEAVE ANGOLA
abstract: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today that South Africa would complete the withdrawal of its forces from Angola by the end of this week.         Mr. Botha, in a statement issued here early this evening, said the ''disengagement'' of forces was aimed at fostering ''dialogue'' with Angola. He  added that he hoped the move would lead to a withdrawal of Cuban troops from that country.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, has named Alan T. Fletcher president and managing director of its Wilkinson Sword Consumer Products division, a unit of its International Group.    * Bank of New York has named Leonard A. Weiss a senior vice president in its financial sector.

headline: Apparent Israeli Support
abstract: Israel tonight appeared to throw its full backing behind the South Lebanon Army, telling the commander of the United Nations troops in Lebanon that Israel would only seek the return of kidnapped United Nations soldiers if the United Nations secured the release of captured S.L.A. troops.   When asked if Israeli troops were in any way supporting the seizure of Finnish troops, an Israeli Army spokesman in Tel Aviv said, ''S.L.A. troops are staying in the area and the Israel Defense Forces are watching closely after their activities.''   The Israeli spokesman then issued a communique giving the S.L.A.'s version of events and details of the Israeli conditions for helping to free the Finns. The South Lebanon Army, a force of some 2,000 men led by the Christian Lebanese General, Antoine Lahd, is armed and trained by the Israeli Army. Israeli military advisers are in contact with almost all units, although at times the militia initiates action.

headline: Bradford Trust
abstract: The Bradford Trust Company, a New York financial institution, denied that the bank is ''the specific target'' of an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Northrop Backs Tigershark Jet
abstract: Thomas V. Jones, chairman and chief executive of the Northrop Corporation, said that Tuesday's crash of an F-20 Tigershark jet fighter would not deter the company from promoting the plane to prospective buyers, including the Air Force. The crash, which killed the pilot, David Barnes, was the second of an F-20 in eight months and leaves only one Tigershark in operation.

headline: 1,000 HOLD PROTEST IN GUATEMALA
abstract: More than 1,000 people marched on the national palace today to dramatize their search for relatives who have disappeared after being abducted.    There were no major incidents, and no uniformed security officers were visible along the 14-block route of march.

headline: INCENTIVES FOR BUYING A HOME
abstract: THERE is a mystique to home ownership in American culture, but in the 1970's the mystique was bruised. With inflation rampant, homes suddenly became a ''tangible'' that could be purchased essentially for their investment value. House-buying was promoted as a hedge against inflation, and in many markets people bought for speculation above all.   Now, with inflation curbed, mortgage rates seemingly unable to break below a level of about 13 percent and such formerly overheated markets as Houston, Denver and southeastern Florida decidedly cooled, the speculative boom has subsided. ''The bloom is off the rose,'' said Arthur Wright, a housing economist at the Texas Real Estate Research Center in College Station, Tex.   But judging from comments by Mr. Wright and other housing economists, real-estate brokers, mortgage lenders and other specialists from coast to coast, the bloom has merely mellowed, and they are far from displeased about it. Traditional values in home-buying have reasserted themselves, they say, and the expectation of short-term appreciation is not as significant as it was.

headline: Sakharov Is Reported To Stage Hunger Strike
abstract: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and dissident, was on a hunger strike last month but has ended it and is in better health, a close friend said today.   The friend, Irene Kristy, a 47-year-old mathematician, told reporters on arrival in Vienna from Moscow that Dr. Sakharov was on a hunger strike from April 16 until at least May 3, and was force-fed on April 21.

headline: Toy Maker Offers Debentures, Stock
abstract: Hasbro Bradley Inc., a toy manufacturer, yesterday began offering a $60 million of convertible debentures, as well as 2.25 million shares of common stock.    The 7 1/2 percent convertible debentures that mature in 2010 are convertible into Hasbro common stock at a price of $33.75 a share and are offered at a price of 100 through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as sole underwriter.    The concurrent offering of common stock was offered at $28.25 a share, through underwriters led by Drexel.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $3.12 billion, to $213.26 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: Dow Rises 3.32 as Volume Slackens
abstract: Trading activity slowed substantially yesterday on Wall Street, but the stock market still managed to rise for the third consecutive session as investors continued to debate the impact of recent developments on the Federal budget deficit.   Richard Rippe, economist with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said that while he and others believe a deficit reduction package will eventually pass Congress, Wall Street now realizes ''it's not a done deal yet'' and must still win approval in the House of Representatives.   The Dow Jones industrial average, coming off 10.49- and 13.91-point gains on Thursday and Friday, advanced another 3.32 points, to 1,277.50.

headline: Reagan Says a Pledge To Saigon Was Broken
abstract: President Reagan said today that the United States did not lose the Vietnam War on the battlefield, but lost it by breaking its ''pledge as a government'' to support South Vietnam against North Vietnamese violations of agreements.   Addressing regional editors and broadcasters at a luncheon at the White House, Mr. Reagan was asked for his thoughts on the 10th anniversary of the end of the war in Vietnam.

headline: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 5, 1985
abstract: Companies   G.M. has bought Hughes Aircraft, outbidding Ford and Boeing in a secret auction, according to insiders. The terms of the deal were not immediately available, but sources said G.M. had to have paid close to $5 billion for the military supplier. [D1.]   Sales of new American-made cars fell 4.9 percent in the last 10 days of May, while light-truck sales dropped 13.9 percent. G.M.'s car sales were off 9 percent and Chrysler's by 9.6 percent, but Ford improved 8 percent. For the month, car sales edged up 0.5 percent. The sales results were considered fairly strong in light of the winding down of cut-rate financing incentives. [D1.]

headline: HEAVY TAX-EXEMPT BOND SCHEDULE
abstract: The only Treasury financing scheduled this week is today's regular sale of new bills due in three and six months. Government securities dealers do not expect any auctions of Treasury notes or bonds until June 19, when a two-year issue is expected, followed in the last week of the month by a major financing consisting of notes due in four and seven years, as well as 20-year bonds.   In advance of today's bill auction, the outstanding three-month issue was bid late Friday at a rate of 7.17 percent, while the six-month issue was bid at 7.29 percent.   Corporate financial officers, who sold nearly $3.5 billion of notes and bonds when interest rates were falling last week, continue to hold their cards close to the vest. This week's scheduled offerings of fixed-income debt exceed $800 million but could be more if corporations are so eager to borrow that they will pay interest rates that are about a quarter of a percentage point higher than the low levels set last week.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 17, 1985:

headline: Insider Reports
abstract: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follows: NEW YORK EXCHANGE BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORPORATION-Alfred Brittain 3d, officer, sold 11,037 shares leaving him directly with a balance of 16,144 shares.

headline: Chip Market Is Still Sluggish
abstract: Sluggish conditions in the semiconductor market continued in May, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today, citing a a key gauge of the industry's performance that it said fell from already low levels.   The indicator, called the book-to-bill ratio, slipped to 0.72 last month, from 0.77 in April.

headline: BRAZIL MAY ACCEPT HELP IN NAZI CASE
abstract: The Brazilian authorities have reluctantly agreed to allow United States and West German experts to work with them in determining whether the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele died here in 1979, a source close to the investigation said today.   The source said the federal police chief in Sao Paulo, Romeu Tuma, who had initially rejected all outside involvement in the case, had now acceded to the participation of foreign fingerprint and handwriting experts.   But the source said Mr. Tuma had also insisted that forensic tests on the body that was exhumed here Thursday, which is said to be that of Dr. Mengele, would first be carried out exclusively by Brazilian medical examiners.   ''The entire issue is highly sensitive because all sorts of questions of sovereignty and pride are involved,'' the source said. ''But it's essential that any positive identification be endorsed by international experts if world opinion is to be fully convinced.''

headline: HBM/Creamer Wins Two New Clients
abstract: HBM/Creamer is celebrating two new clients. One big (Nestle). And one not so big (Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company).

headline: PENTAGON REPORT SAYS SOVIET SPURS ITS ARMS PROGRAM
abstract: The Defense Department today made public a new assessment of Soviet military power, charting what the Pentagon called continuing, rapid progress in weapons technology.     It said progress was especially marked in submarines, nuclear missiles and space weaponry.   The report spoke of an expanding Soviet program in laser weapon research, which it said was part of a drive for superiority in space weapons that demonstrated the need for President Reagan's own space-based missile defense program.      Laser Weapons Are Described    The Russians were reported to have built prototype ground-based laser weapons deemed capable of interfering with American satellites and of being deployed by the late 1980's.

headline: Posner Units List Losses
abstract: The NVF Company, the main holding company in Victor Posner's $1 billion financial empire, reported a net loss for the fourth quarter of $113.8 million, compared with a loss of $6.8 million in the period a year earlier. For the year, the company's net loss was $147.5 million on revenues of $1.3 billion, compared with a loss of $54.4 million on revenues of $999.7 million in 1983.

headline: O.E.C.D. SEES SLOWER GROWTH
abstract: The major industrial democracies, with the best of the economic recovery behind them, now face slowing growth and modestly rising unemployment, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in its latest forecast, released today.   The forecast follows by less than a month this year's economic summit conference at which West Germany and other low-inflation countries declined to fight the approaching slowdown by adopting more expansionary policies.   But the O.E.C.D. is urging them to think again, warning that Europe and Japan are dangerously dependent for growth and jobs on their exports to the United States, which will decrease if Washington succeeds in reducing its budget deficit and the dollar weakens.      Helping Supply and Demand    ''In countries where inflation and budget deficits have been brought under control, yet growth is too slow and unemployment too high,'' the O.E.C.D. says, ''attention could usefully be paid to measures, such as appropriately designed tax cuts, which simultaneously were able both to improve supply-side potential and to provide some support for demand.''

headline: Amoco to Close Marketing Offices
abstract: The Amoco Oil Company said that it would close its 3 regional marketing offices, in Kansas City, Kan.; Baltimore and Oak Brook, Ill., and also shut 5 of 15 district offices, as part of a restructuring. Certain operations of the closed offices will be redistributed to the company's Chicago headquarters or to the remaining district offices, Amoco said.

headline: Storer Plans F.C.C. Appeal Storer Communications Inc.
abstract: said yesterday that it would ask   the Federal Communications   Commission to review a staff   decision issued Friday that   denied the company's request   for action to slow a dissident   shareholder group's attempts   to elect new directors and liquidate the broadcasting concern. Storer said it intends to file   an application asking the full   commission to reverse the staff   decision, which said that the   group's efforts did not need a   review by the full F.C.C.  The group, which calls itself   the Committee for Full Value   of Storer Communications, has   said that it owns 5.3 percent of   the common shares outstanding of Storer.

headline: Solzhenitsyns Apply For U.S. Citizenship
abstract: Alexander Solzhenitsyn, the exiled Russian author and Nobel Prize winner, has applied for United States citizenship along with his wife, Natalia.

headline: INVESTING TO EASE THE TAX BITE
abstract: CONSERVATIVE investments with favorable tax treatment can be an important part of overall financial planning, particularly for building a retirement fund or accumulating money for the children's educations. Indeed, they can appeal to any investor who does not want the risk associated with shelters -either investment risk or risk of running afoul of the I.R.S.   ''The tax-advantaged investment is still very much alive in this era of governmental crackdown on tax shelters,'' said Lawrence B. Eichler, a partner in Laventhol & Horwath and head of the firm's personal financial counseling department in New York. Mr. Eichler, who prepared the table below, added, ''These are classic investments. They're liquid, they produce income, and most of them are considered to be quite conservative, that is, they have low risk.''

headline: Touche Reacts to Suit
abstract: The accounting firm of Touche Ross & Company said that it had reconfirmed that the information provided by its client, the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, to CBS Inc. during CBS's purchase of 12 magazines was fair.

headline: Sperry Said to Get Burroughs Offer
abstract: Directors of the Burroughs Corporation made a formal offer yesterday to buy the Sperry Corporation, according to sources close to the negotiations.

headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ANGOLA'S CHILDREN OF WAR
abstract: There had been rain in the night, unseasonal showers, and so the gray blankets were laid out to dry around huts of pale straw that, evidently, had leaked.   A little way off, in thick bush freckled with foxholes and scarred by trenches, the children were at school, in shaded places below trees, learning math with song and slivers of reed. Then, still farther, there were the artillery range and the assault course and workshops and a tailor's shop that produced military uniforms.   In the 10 years since Angola's bloodstained independence from Portugal, a society has grown in these remote lands; a society independent of and defiant toward the Marxist authorities in Luanda, living in the shadow of the cult that surrounds its leader, Jonas Savimbi, and reflecting his determination not to succumb to the Government's many campaigns against him.

headline: S. E. C. Views Boston Bank
abstract: The Bank of Boston said today that it is the target of yet another Government investigation, this time by the Securities and Exchange Commission.    Its regional office wants to see if the bank violated Federal securities laws in failing to report $1.2 billion in international cash transactions to the Government, the bank said.

headline: HAVANA, LONG GRAY, GETTING A FACELIFT
abstract: Along the oceanfront boulevard in downtown Havana workmen are scraping the facades of Colonial-style buildings, getting them ready for fresh coats of paint. Heavy Russian paving machines are resurfacing some of the streets and new traffic signals are being installed.   After years of neglect, the Cuban capital, a gray and dreary shadow of what is said to have once been the most beautiful city in the Caribbean, is getting a facelift.   Western diplomats and other foreign residents say they believe the Government is sprucing up Havana as part of its attempt to attract Western tourists and because the third congress of the Communist Party of Cuba is going to be held here in December. Government officials and journalists from all over the world attend the congresses, which are held every five years and at which party leaders list accomplishments and lay out new goals.

headline: Inertia Benefits Bell Investors
abstract: AN example of how simple shareholder inertia can pay off handsomely in the market is seen in the performance of the components of the ''old'' American Telephone and Telegraph Company stock.   At the start of 1984, seven regional Bell companies were divested from A.T.&T., thereby breaking up Ma Bell's shareowner family. The 3.2 million A.T.&T. stockholders received one share in each of the seven regionals for every 10 shares of A.T.&T. they held while retaining their original number of the parent company's shares.   The last day that A.T.&T. traded in the form of the ''package'' containing all the pieces was Feb. 15, 1984, when the old stock finished at a price of $63.50.

headline: Nipon Is Given 3 Years in Jail
abstract: Albert Nipon, head of a $60 million internationally known women's fashion empire, was sentenced today to three years in jail for bribing Internal Revenue Service agents to avoid payment of more than $1.5 million in personal and corporate income taxes.   Federal District Judge Raymond Broderick, in imposing the jail term, but no fine, said he ''feels compassion'' for the 57-year-old businessman.

headline: SMALL STAFFS
abstract: To the Editor:   Tom Peters's description of the economic effect of decentralizing purchasing departments is much too simplistic.

headline: U.S. CHIP MAKERS TO ASK AID
abstract: Domestic producers of semiconductors, the leading edge of this country's high-technology sector, will ask the Government Friday to make Japan end alleged restrictions against buying American semiconductors.   Although producers of products such as shoes and steel have long asked the Government for help against unfair trade practices abroad, the complaint to be filed by the 48-member Semiconductor Industry Association represents the first direct Government intervention sought by a high-technology industry.   ''We're asking for a dramatic improvement in United States sales in Japan in a short time - commensurate with the demonstrated competitiveness of United States products in other world markets,'' said George M. Scalise, senior vice president of Advanced Micro Devices Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., and chairman of the industry association's public policy committee.

headline: ISRAELI LABOR PARTY GAINING, BIG UNION ELECTION INDICATES
abstract: Israeli workers re-elected Yisrael Kessar of the Labor Party as secretary general of the Histadrut Labor Federation today, according to a projection of early returns by Israeli television.   The Histadrut election involved only the 1.5 million Jewish and Arab men and women who are members in the labor union. But because they amount to some two-thirds of the eligible voters in Israel and because all of the major parties put up lists of candidates for the union leadership, the Histadrut election has become an important barometer, widely watched by pollsters and politicians for what it says about the public mood.   Judging from the voting projections from early returns, the Histadrut election indicates that Prime Minister Shimon Peres's Labor Party is gaining slightly in popularity, much as the public-opinion polls have been indicating for months, and that the Likud bloc under Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir is losing some ground. #2 Important Categories The Histadrut voting is are divided into several categories, but the two most important are those for the national council and secretary general and those for the local municipal workers' councils, which are important grass-roots power bases and sources of patronage.

headline: People
abstract: Justin Harrington named senior vice president at Hill Holliday Connors Cosmopulos in Boston.    * Richard Wittstadt designated a senior vice president at DYR/Los Angeles.    * Samuel M. DePhillipo named vice president, marketing, of Filene's Basement.

headline: Advertising;   Premium Incentive Show
abstract: BOB SIEMON, who started making jewelry in his garage when he was a teen-ager, for 15 years specialized in adornments of a religious nature. His Master Craft Jewelry now has 75 people turning them out in Fountain Valley, Calif. In recent years he decided that making jewelry for corporate premiums would be a good way to help the company grow. That is what brought him yesterday for the first time to the Premium Incentive Show that opened at the New York Coliseum.   His booth is on a busy aisle on the main floor, a good place to get seen. And his colorful booth - all bright green and red and blue and yellow graffiti against a stark white background - is sure to be noticed. Some 30,000 buyers are expected to pass through before the doors close on Thursday and close on this show for the last time after 25 years in the hall, because plans call for next year's commercial extravaganza to be in the new Jacob Javits Convention Center.

headline: Seabrook Plan
abstract: The New Hampshire Public Utilities Commission approved a proposal by the Public Service Company of New Hampshire to raise up to $525 million for its share of the completion of the Seabrook One nuclear power station.

headline: Jackson Hopes to Aid In Freeing Hostages
abstract: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said here today that he was working to see if he could help win the release of the hostages in Beirut.   Mr. Jackson said that Michael Suggs, a brother of one of the hostages, had called him from Indiana ''and asked me to make my services available to try to get to him.''

headline: GETTING READY FOR VISIT TO BITBURG, WHITE HOUSE KEEPS AN EYE ON TV
abstract: Wearing a blue trench coat, Jeff Brian, a White House advance man, stood today in the Kolmeshohe cemetery here negotiating one of the most momentous television appearances of Ronald Reagan's Presidency.   On Sunday at 2:45 P.M., Mr. Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany are scheduled to walk down a gravel path flanking the graves, swing around to a squat monument and, assisted by four West German soldiers, lay two wreaths at its base.   At 2:55 P.M., according to the detailed timetable, the two leaders will walk back along the same path and out of one of the most disputed ceremonial undertakings in recent history.   The way this 10-minute event - and Mr. Reagan's ride through Bitburg to the cemetery - will look on television may determine whether the President's visit is judged a fiasco or a damage-limited draw.      Fresh Flowers Festoon the Graves    The cemetery was bustling today as volunteers were busy festooning its 2,000 gravestones with tulips and other flowers. The sprouting of color gave the cemetery a festive look. But the placing of flowers on all the graves also diverted attention from the 49 graves of Waffen SS soldiers, whose presence has been at the heart of the dispute.

headline: PATENTS;  Pressurized Helium Used in Heating System
abstract: A compact electric fluid heater that employs pressurized helium gas was patented this week by Harry J. Scanlan of New York and Leif Liljegren of Oakland, N.J. It is recommended as a hot water heater for residences, apartments, hotels and office buildings.

headline: Debt Issues ;    Common Stock
abstract: General Telephone Co. (Southeast), a unit of GTE Corp., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $75 million of first- mortgage bonds due in 1995.

headline: THE WARRENS OF SHIITE SHANTYTOWNS: A MOST LIKELY PLACE FOR THE CAPTIVES
abstract: The most likely places for the American hostages to be held are in the sprawling shantytowns around Beirut's International Airport.   The areas are warrens of cinderblock hovels set amid a few larger apartment blocks and houses in a maze of dirt lanes that have become a staging area for Shiite Moslem militancy.   It would be nearly impossible, particularly given the mobilization of heavily armed Shiite militiamen, for an outsider to determine exactly where the hostages are being held, let alone for a commando force to free them from what are presumed to be several different locations.   While the area is referred to as ''the southern suburbs,'' of Beirut, the section bears little resemblance to the image of a typical leafy American suburb. A more accurate picture is conveyed by the local phrase ''belt of misery,'' for the loop of such settlements that used to circle Beirut before Moslems and Palestinians were expelled from the Christian areas in the north and east at the beginning of the civil war in 1975-76.

headline: SMOG-BOUND MEXICO CITY: HAS IT SEEN THE LIGHT?
abstract: It is still too early to draw a deep breath of relief - at least without coughing - but Mexico's Government is showing new signs of interest in halting the capital's environmental decline.   One indication appeared in local newspapers recently. The governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, in celebration of World Environment Day, placed advertisements in several local newspapers demanding in unusually strong terms that the right to a clean environment be elevated to constitutional status, that air and water pollution standards be ''rigorously applied'' to businesses, and that open-air burning of trash be halted, among other things.   Describing itself as ''the vanguard of the Mexican people,'' the party declared its ''firm will to intensify'' its actions in promoting environmental improvement. Environmental activists here said they viewed the statement with some degree of hope.

headline: FREED HOSTAGE SAYS HIJACKER STRUCK HER AS SHE KNELT IN JET
abstract: A woman held hostage aboard the hijacked Trans World Airlines jetliner said here today after her release in Algiers that one of the hijackers struck her on the back of her neck while she was kneeling near her seat.   The woman, Agnes Leber of Middletown, R.I., said one of the hijackers ''chopped me on the back of the neck while I was down.''   She added: ''I was in that position for four hours. He just came along and chopped me.''

headline: Neves Now Given Chance of Recovery
abstract: Doctors treating President-elect Tancredo Neves said today that although he was very ill, there was still a chance he could recover.

headline: EGYPT'S ASSEMBLY BARS FULL ISLAMIC LAW
abstract: The Egyptian Parliament today in effect rejected calls for the imposition of Islamic law in this predominantly Moslem country.   Instead, the 448-seat People's Assembly voted to review Egypt's legal code ''gradually and scientifically'' to revise provisions that contradict Islamic law.   The vote today was a defeat for Egyptians who have championed the immediate imposition of Islamic law, or Sharia, as it is known.

headline: POPE'S SPEECH TO CARDINALS
abstract: Following, in official translation, are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's speech in St. Peter's Square today after he elevated 28 prelates to cardinal:   ''Let us sing to the world with joy.''   Yes, venerable brothers in the episcopate and priesthood. Yes, dear faithful people who have come together in this square from various places, some of them very far away. We are right to sing to the Lord in joyful gratitude for the solemn event which he has enabled us to experience: the College of Cardinals is being enriched this morning with 28 new members.

headline: MEETINGS ON BHOPAL RESUMING
abstract: As negotiations resume today on claims from last December's gas leak disaster in Bhopal, India, both sides are far apart on monetary damages, emergency relief for victims is uncertain and there are continuing disagreements among victims' lawyers, sources familiar with the case said.   The sessions are to be held at an unspecified location in the New York area among high officials of the Indian Government and American lawyers representing India, individual victims and the Union Carbide Corporation, the majority owner of the Bhopal pesticide plant that leaked the toxic gas.   One Indian environmental consultant, who met recently with top Union Carbide and Indian officials, said there was hostility on both sides; he described the legal and relief efforts as ''chaos and confusion.'' The consultant, Rashmi Mayur, said that ''things are at an impasse; there is no direction and focus.'' $230 Million Offered Union Carbide has formally offered $230 million to settle all claims arising from the death of more than 2,000 people and injury of 200,000 from the gas leak on Dec. 3, the sources said, but Indian Government officials have said privately that they want $1 billion to $5 billion.

headline: THE BATTLE ON STEEL IMPORTS
abstract: In the face of the Reagan Administration's commitment to roll back foreign penetration of the American steel market, imports have continued to rise, prompting Congress and the industry to voice fresh concern.   It would appear that the Government has made progress. With Japan's signature today, the Administration has reached agreements on limiting shipments with countries that produced more than three-quarters of America's imported steel last year.   Accords have been reached with Australia, Brazil, Finland, Mexico, Spain, South Africa, South Korea and the European Common Market. And one American negotiator has described as ''practically in the bag'' additional agreements with Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary. Negotiations are in various stages of progress with Argentina, Austria, Sweden and Venezuela.

headline: THURSDAY, APRIL 18, 1985
abstract: Companies    A.T.&T. plans to reduce the price of long-distance service by 5.6 percent on June 1. That is when households will begin paying local phone companies a new long-distance access charge of $1 a month. The price cut would put further pressure on A.T.&T.'s competitors. A.T.&T. earnings rose 55.9 percent in the first quarter. (Page A1.)

headline: FOR REFUGEE WOMEN, AN EVEN HARDER ORDEAL
abstract: Refugee women suffer all the familiar problems of life in exile: a sense of isolation, powerlessness and loss of status. But a growing number of relief workers, physicians and psychologists say women who have left their homelands bear extra burdens as well.   ''Women are the most vulnerable refugees,'' said Monique Bauer-Lagier, a Swiss doctor and politician who led a roundtable discussion on the topic organized by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva on Friday. And, she added, ''few measures are taken to respond to their specific needs.''

headline: Supreme Soviet to Meet
abstract: The Supreme Soviet, the Soviet parliament, is to meet on July 2, it was announced today. The session may be used to make Mikhail S. Gorbachev the Soviet Union's President in addition to party leader, following a precedent set by Leonid I. Brezhnev. This is largely a protocol device, allowing the party chief, who wields the real power in the Soviet Union, to meet foreign heads of state on equal terms.

headline: Illinois Relatives Pray For Hijacking Victims
abstract: Prayer services were held here today for the pastors of three local Roman Catholic Churches and more than 20 of their parishioners who were among those aboard the T.W.A. jet hijacked over Athens.   At St. Margaret Mary Church in Algonquin, friends and family of 18 parishioners on the flight attended a service.

headline: FIRST CHINA EUROBOND OFFERING
abstract: A syndicate of 10 Western banks, led by Deutsche Bank, West Germany's largest commercial bank, has initiated the first Eurobond issue ever guaranteed by the Bank of China, even though nearly $100 million of pre-revolution Chinese government-backed bonds are still in default.   German bank officials said the banks were seeking to improve their position in the emerging market for bank services in China. Several large German banks, including Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank, the second largest, have expanded their activities in China in recent months.

headline: HOSTAGES IN LEBANON: Dashed Plans for a Joyous Welcome;   RELEASE OF HOSTAGES PUT OFF AS LEBANESE CALL FOR PROMISE THAT U.S. WILL NOT STRIKE BACK STANDOFF IN BEIRUT
abstract: A plan to free 39 Americans held hostage for the last 15 days was put off today. The setback came after their Lebanese Shiite captors added a new demand, insisting that the United States guarantee that it would not retaliate militarily after the hostages were released.   The Shiites' principal demand has been the release by Israel of 735 detainees, most of them Shiites. The new condition apparently grew out of the Shiites' reaction to a speech by President Reagan in Illinois on Friday, which they interpreted as a threat to take military action after the Americans were freed.

headline: EUROPEANS RETALIATE ON TARIFFS
abstract: The European Economic Community today announced higher tariffs on walnuts and lemons imported from the United States in retaliation for Washington's restrictions on imports of pasta from the 10-nation bloc.   The Europeans' import duty on American lemons was more than doubled, to 20 percent, from 8 percent. The import duty on American walnuts was more than tripled, to 30 percent, also up from 8 percent.

headline: Tower Sold By Interfirst
abstract: The Interfirst Corporation of Dallas said yesterday that it had sold the tower portion of its Interfirst One building for $55 million, and that the entire amount would be placed in its reserves for loan losses.    As a result, Interfirst said its first- quarter earnings would remain at about the same level as in the fourth quarter, despite the gain from the sale of the tower.

headline: APRIL 21-30 CAR SALES UP BY 1.5%
abstract: Sales of new American-made cars rose 1.5 percent in the April 21-30 selling period, according to a compilation of reports issued today by the manufacturers.   Most of the companies reported decreases in sales, but hefty gains by the Chrysler Corporation and the American Honda Motor Company offset those declines.   Sales by all the companies totaled 282,654 autos in the period, which had eight selling days this year and last. In the comparable 1984 period, 278,540 cars were sold. Based on the latest selling period, auto sales were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8.2 million units.

headline: Muse Merger
abstract: Stockholders of Muse Air unanimously approved a proposed merger with arch-rival Southwest Airlines, a combination deemed vital to Muse's survival. At a news conference after the company's annual meeting, Muse's chairman, Lamar Muse, said he was ''cautiously optimistic'' that the Department of Transportation would approve the merger.

headline: Arrow Electronics Names a President
abstract: Arrow Electronics Inc., a leading distributor of semiconductors and other electronic components, yesterday named Stephen P. Kaufman president and chief operating officer, effective immediately.   Mr. Kaufman, 43 years old, has headed Arrow's electronics distribution division since 1982. He succeeds John C. Waddell, 47, who remains chairman and chief executive of the company, which moved its corporate headquarters to Manhattan from Greenwich, Conn., this week.

headline: MAY ORDERS UP 22% FOR MACHINE TOOLS
abstract: Orders for American-made machine tools increased 22 percent in May from the previous month and shipments rose 5 percent. The increases were paced by strong growth in the metal-cutting industry and offset by losses in the metal-forming machine tool sector, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said in a report to be released today.   However, orders were still off 30 percent in May from their strong level of a year ago and shipments declined 15 percent, the association's report said.

headline: RUDOLF GNAGI
abstract: Rudolf Gn"agi, twice the President of Switzerland, died today after suffering a heart attack, a Defense Ministry spokesman said.

headline: CHANGE IN SEX LAW UNSETTLES PROPS OF APARTHEID
abstract: Not too long ago, a scholar named Hans Heese came up with a series of studies that showed South Africa's dominant Afrikaners to be, in some cases, less than racially pure.   In a book titled ''Group Without Boundaries,'' published last month, Dr. Heese, himself descended from a racially mixed family of the mid-1600's but now classified as white, found that such redoubtable Afrikaner lineages as those of the Bothas and the Treurnichts were built on interracial relationships between Dutch settlers and Malay slaves in the 17th and 18th centuries.   Dr. Heese, from the University of Cape Town, stressed that his research did not necessarily mean that President P. W. Botha or the right-wing white opposition leader Andries P. Treurnicht were descended from those liaisons.      Response Is Outrage    Nonetheless, publication of his book elicited outrage from some other Bothas and Treurnichts, who threatened to sue for libel. Moreover, the research added one more twist to the conundrums surrounding legislation barring interracial sex, which the authorities have now promised to repeal.

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN ARMY IS GIVEN WIDER ROLE IN QUELLING DISORDER
abstract: South Africa is calling in the army to work with the police in riot-torn areas wherever necessary to maintain law and order, a Government minister said today.   Adriaan Vlok, deputy minister of defense and of law and order, said the army would man roadblocks and cordons, escort police in trouble spots, and assist in ''such other situations as circumstances may demand.''

headline: Diversifoods Bid Is Fought
abstract: Jesart Partners, in which the Horn & Hardart Company is principal, has filed suit in Federal court in Nebraska seeking to bar the Pillsbury Company's tender offer for Diversifoods Inc., an Illinois-based restaurant company.   Last month, the Diversifoods board voted to accept Pillsbury's $11.50 cash offer for the company over a $12-a-share cash and stock offer by Horn & Hardart.

headline: May Home Sales Off 1%
abstract: Sales of existing single-family homes dropped 1 percent in May, the National Association of Realtors said today. Previously owned homes were sold at an annual rate of 3.01 million units last month, down from the April pace of 3.04 million units.

headline: TYING PERSONAL COMPUTERS TOGETHER
abstract: ONE of the hallmarks of the office is the water cooler, a communications node where people gather to exchange information. The talk is probably as often about nonbusiness matters as it is about any consuming office projects at hand, but regardless of the content, people are communicating. The point is, people talk to each other, computers do not.   And that fact highlights one of the limitations of personal computers in an office environment. The first users were so mesmerized by the wonders of word processing or the marvel of spreadsheets automatically recalculating values that they asked for little more than their very own machines.

headline: Nitze Blames Russians For Lag in Arms Talks
abstract: President Reagan's senior arms adviser said today that the Soviet Union had demanded that the United States halt research on a missile defense program and was entirely responsible for the lack of progress in the Geneva arms talks.   ''It is the Soviet approach as a whole that is blocking U.S. efforts to facilitate movement in negotiations,'' the adviser, Paul H. Nitze, said in a speech at the National Press Club.

headline: THE SURGE IN AIRLINE TRAFFIC
abstract: Valerie Bergman had just bought a ticket to Des Moines for $178, round trip, the ''ultimate super saver'' fare, at the American Airlines office at Rockefeller Center.    ''This trip wouldn't have happened if it hadn't been for the low fare,'' she said.    Miss Bergman, a dancer, is visiting her family for the third time this year. Normally, she said, she would get home perhaps every other year, because the regular $600 round-trip fare was too dear.

headline: SOUTHLAND TUMBLES 93%
abstract: The Chevron Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest oil company, and the Southland Corporation, parent of Citgo Petroleum, yesterday reported quarterly earnings that reflected the oil industry's recent volatility.   Profits at both companies were dragged down by the slide in prices for crude oil and gasoline at the beginning of the quarter, and both benefited from the subsequent price upswing at the end of the quarter.   Chevron said that its income for the first quarter dropped 6.3 percent from the comparable period a year ago. The San Francisco-based giant earned $354 million, or $1.03 a share, compared with $378 million, or $1.10 a share, in the first quarter of 1984.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Thompson Plans to Sell EA International Units
abstract: The individual units that make up the second European agency network that the J. Walter Thompson Company began putting together in 1980 are going to be sold back to their founders. The network, EA International, never did live up to expectations.

headline: Melanesian Is Killed In New Caledonia Riots
abstract: A Melanesian was shot to death today and 65 other people were injured in violent confrontations between nationalists and opponents of independence for this French Pacific island, Government officials said.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: * Chevron Corp. has elected Robert E. Daniel president of Chevron Resources Co. and William E. Foster president of Chevron Land and Development Co.

headline: PRESIDENT ACCEPTS TALKS ON PULLOUT OF TROOPS IN SPAIN
abstract: President Reagan and Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez agreed today to start discussions leading to the eventual withdrawal of the 12,000 American troops stationed in Spain, according to American and Spanish officials.   White House aides said the agreement was essentially a trade-off in which the United States would start serious negotiations for the military reduction as long as Spain remained in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Spain is to hold a referendum next year on whether to remain in the alliance.      One Dispute: Nicaragua    As Mr. Reagan concluded a two-day visit here, he and Mr. Gonzalez, a Socialist, emerged from apparently amicable meetings in conflict over one key issue: United States policy in Nicaragua.

headline: $60 Million Is Set For Venture Fund
abstract: The New York State Common Retirement Fund and the New York State Teachers Retirement System have agreed to invest $60 million in a joint venture capital fund to finance New York-based companies in early stages of growth or in special situations.   The fund, called the New York State Business Venture Partnership, was approved a year ago by both pension funds after legislation was passed allowing the pension systems to invest up to 5 percent of their total assets in investments that were more risky than normal but that might also encourage business expansion and new jobs in New York.

headline: Deloitte Haskins & Sells Picks a New Chairman
abstract: As a student at the University of Florida in the early 1960's, J. Michael Cook planned to major in math, until a guidance counselor suggested he switch to accounting, because it offered better career opportunities.   That advice seemed to have paid off yesterday, when Deloitte Haskins & Sells, the international accounting and consulting firm, named the 42-year-old Mr. Cook chairman and chief executive, effective July 1, 1986.   Mr. Cook will succeed Charles G. Steele, 59, who has been chairman since 1983. Mr. Steele will turn 61 next year, and the firm's mandatory retirement age for partners is 62.

headline: REAGAN, DECLARING 'THREAT,' FORBIDS NICARAGUAN TRADE AND CUTS AIR AND SEA LINKS
abstract: President Reagan ordered an embargo on trade with Nicaragua today, telling Congress that the policies and actions of the Sandinistas constituted a threat to United States security.   Mr. Reagan also banned Nicaraguan aircraft and ships from the United States.   The announcement came in the form of an executive order and an accompanying letter to Congress. Both were made public only hours after Mr. Reagan arrived in West Germany for the 11th annual economic conference of seven major industrial nations. The three-day meeting opens Thursday in Bonn.

headline: Discounts Reduced For Store Officials
abstract: A favorite perquisite for retailing executives, the employee discount, is being reduced.   The executives and other non-hourly employees who have enjoyed discounts of as much as 50 percent on merchandise sold by their stores are finding that the benefit is being cut by one-third to one-half so that it will remain untaxed and still conform with the requirements of the Deficit Reduction Act of 1984, which took effect last Jan. 1.   Other employees, however, who represent the bulk of store staffs and who have generally been entitled to smaller discounts, typically 10 to 20 percent, are continuing to receive them. In most cases, they and the store executives now receive the same discount, and the so-called two-tier discount policy is mostly being ended.

headline: TROOPS ARRIVE IN SIDON TO HALT FIGHTING
abstract: After a delay of two weeks, Lebanese Army reinforcements were sent from here to Sidon today in an effort to halt the fighting between Christian and Moslem gunmen.          The fighting has been raging around the port city in southern Lebanon for the last 28 days. Witnesses reached by telephone in Sidon said there were only a few people on the streets to welcome the unit of 400 troops, in 33 United States-supplied armored personnel carriers, since most of the residents were hiding in building basements and shelters.

headline: U.S. WILL RENEW ALL SOVIET ISSUES
abstract: The Reagan Administration has decided to review its policy toward the Soviet Union over the next two weeks in preparation for high-level meetings next month, officials said today.   They said that Secretary of State George P. Shultz had asked Ambassador Arthur A. Hartman to return from Moscow to take part in the review. The Administration will then decide on any new initiatives it wants Mr. Shultz to put to Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko when they meet in Vienna on May 14, the officials said.   The United States and the Soviet Union formally announced the Shultz- Gromyko meeting today, but it had been planned for some time. They will both be in Vienna for ceremonies marking 30th anniversary of the 1955 treaty that ended the occupation of Austria by the wartime Allies.

headline: Kanak Parties to Run In New Caledonia Race
abstract: Two Kanak separatist parties said today that they would take part in regional elections planned by France as a step toward independence for this South Pacific territory.

headline: I.B.M.-MCI LINK SEEN SPEEDING DEREGULATION
abstract: The proposed partnership between the International Business Machines Corporation and the MCI Communications Corporation could speed up the continuing deregulation of the telecommunications industry, according to Federal officials involved in telecommunications policy.   At a time when the Federal Communications Commission and members of Congress are looking for evidence that breaking up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company as a way to promote competition was a sound decision, the deal announced Tuesday brings welcome reassurance for pressing ahead on several pending issues, the officials said.   I.B.M., the nation's largest computer company, announced an agreement with MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance company, after A.T.&.T., in which I.B.M. could purchase up to 30 percent of MCI.      Terms of the Transaction    As part of the deal, MCI is buying Satellite Business Systems, a smaller long-distance competitor owned by I.B.M. and the Aetna Life and Casualty Company. The transaction is worth about $1 billion, with I.B.M. purchasing an 18 percent interest in MCI initially.

headline: Bhopal Case Rift Widens
abstract: The rift among lawyers representing victims of the Dec. 3 gas leak at the Union Carbide Corporation plant in Bhopal, India, continued to widen yesterday in response to a proposal filed by the counsel for the Government of India.    Michael Ciresi, who is representing the Government of India in its suit against Union Carbide, indicated to United States District Judge John F. Keenan that he was willing to work with the private lawyers who have been retained by individual victims, but he suggested that those lawyers should notify each of their clients that they have the option of being represented by the Government.

headline: REGAN SEEKING TO TAKE FOCUS OFF CEMETARY VISIT
abstract: The White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, is seeking to shift attention from President Reagan's planned visit to a German military cemetery next Sunday to a concentration camp site earlier that day, White House officials said today.   Mr. Regan, who has taken over direct control of every detail of the President's visit to the German military cemetery at Bitburg, has decided with other White House officials to try to focus Mr. Reagan's day almost entirely on the visit to the Bergen-Belsen death camp site, the officials said.   Mr. Reagan will speak both at Bergen-Belsen and the United States military base at Bitburg, near the cemetery. ''He will talk about the horror of the Holocaust and the necessity of rallying the world to never letting it happen again,'' a White House official said.

headline: GERSTNER REVITALIZED TRAVEL UNIT
abstract: For all of the publicized moves into stocks and bonds and cable television, what pays the rent at American Express is still credit cards, traveler's checks and travel.   The choice of Louis V. Gerstner Jr. as its president was a fresh reminder of the priceless franchise that American Express, one of the best-known commercial names in the world, enjoys in its traditional lines of business.   Mr. Gerstner's promotion to the second-ranking executive post stems from his highly successful stewardship of American Express's Travel Related Services Company, the division that handles the company's card memberships, traveler's checks and travel services.

headline: GINGERLY, PARAGUAY DEBATES LIFE AFTER STROESSNER
abstract: There is no evidence that Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, the 72-year-old President, is ill or is planning to step down, but what comes after his 31-year-old rule is suddenly the main topic of debate in Paraguay.   The Government has tried to limit discussion of the issue, arguing that the entire concept of ''post-Stroessnerism'' has been invented by opposition groups bent on agitation. ''There is no such thing as post-Stroessner,'' one official said.   But in a country where, in the words of a journalist, ''the news is always the same,'' change is now being viewed as inevitable.   ''We're definitely in a pre-transition period,'' a foreign diplomat said. ''Stroessner will stay in office as long as he wants to, but there is genuine widespread concern about what will happen afterward.''

headline: Textron Offers 2 Debt Issues
abstract: Textron Inc. is offering two debt issues totaling $250 million, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. A $150 million issue of 11 3/4 percent subordinated notes due in 1995 is offered at 99.41 to yield 11.851 percent, while $100 million of 12 3/4 percent subordinated debentures due in 2010 are offered at 99.80 to yield 12.775 percent.      Proceeds of the debt, rated   Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, will be used to repay outstanding commercial paper.

headline: SIMON BID REJECTED
abstract: Multimedia Inc., a major broadcasting and publishing company, said yesterday that an investor group that includes members of the founding families and senior management had increased its offer for the company to about $54 a share, or $900 million, from the $49.50 a share offered earlier this year. At the same time the company confirmed that it had rejected an offer of $60 a share, or a total of $1 billion, from Wesray Inc., a New Jersey investment company headed by former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon.     ''The fairness committee reviewed the first offer and decided that perhaps some sweetening of the offer was in order,'' said Donald J. Barhyte, chief financial officer and treasurer of the Greenville, S.C., company and a member of the investor group. In addition, he said, recent media deals including Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. and Metromedia as well as the bidding for Cox Communications Inc. had convinced the investors that a higher price would be in order.

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: Stock and commodity markets, banks and Government offices in the United States are closed today in observance of Memorial Day.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Baltimore Gas and Electric Co. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $100 million of floating-rate notes due 1995 through Paine Webber Inc.    * Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $75 million of notes due 1995 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co.    * Chevron Corp. has filed for a shelf offering of $1 billion of debt securities to be offered from time to time.

headline: Using Light To Compute
abstract: ANYONE who has raced to catch a flight at Logan Airport at rush hour can sympathize with the plight of an electron, trying to get from one computer chip to another.   The winding streets of downtown Boston all feed into a multilane funnel at the entrance to the Callahan Tunnel, the only direct route to Logan. By 4 P.M., the funnel is usually hopelessly clogged by traffic. Actually making it into one of the tunnel's two narrow lanes is often no help. There always seems to be an overly wide truck just ahead, hogging two lanes, and traffic at the airport on the other side seems to slow down everything.

headline: Singapore Output Off
abstract: Manufacturing output in Singapore fell 2.4 percent in the first quarter from the period a year earlier, the Ministry of Trade and Industry said today. The agency attributed the decline mainly to the depressed petroleum and transport-equipment markets. Oil-rig construction activities also fell.

headline: Farm Credit Rates Set
abstract: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation announced interest rates yesterday for three new bond issues totaling $2.613 billion.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 20, 1985:

headline: SPECIAL SUBGROUP OF HOSTAGES REPORTED
abstract: A Trans World Airlines official said today that the Beirut hijackers had specifically sought to create a separate group of hostages comprising United States military personnel, Greek nationals and passengers with Jewish-sounding names.   ''Our flight attendents said the hijackers wanted to take off male passengers who were affiliated with the U.S. military, who were Greek nationals and, or, those who had Jewish-sounding names,'' the airline official, Jerry W. Cosley, vice president for corporate communications, said in a telephone interview.   On Thursday, a spokesman for the Shiite Amal militia in Beirut said the hijackers had separated 6 to 10 hostages because they suspected them of having ''Zionist connections.'' He indicated that they had been placed under the control of the Party of God, a fundamentalist pro-Iranian Shiite group. It was the first confirmation from a Shiite official that such action had been taken.

headline: World Medical Group Cancels Plan to Meet in South Africa
abstract: The World Medical Association says it is canceling plans to hold its annual assembly in South Africa.

headline: REAGAN SAID TO GET SUMMIT REPLY
abstract: President Reagan said today that he had received a reply from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to his invitation for a summit meeting.    In an interview published in the Tuesday issue of The Washington Post, Mr. Reagan said that the Soviet leader had answered the invitation he extended via Vice President Bush last month, and that the United States and the Soviet Union were discussing the specifics of a meeting.    ''I wrote, and he answered, and we're in negotiations,'' the President said. He declined to elaborate on the contents of the letter from Mr. Gorbachev, but added that he was ''hopeful that we can have such a meeting.''

headline: REYNOLDS NABISCO BID IS REPORTED
abstract: R.J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's second-largest cigarette maker and operator of the vast Kentucky Fried Chicken chain, has offered to pay more than $5 billion in cash for Nabisco Brands Inc., Wall Street sources reported yesterday.   There was no certainty that the two would proceed. But Wall Street sources said that even if the deal fell through, several potential bidders might be waiting in the wings. They said that Philip Morris Inc., the nation's largest cigarette maker, had already retained Wall Street help and was watching the situation closely. Unilever and the Coca-Cola Company were viewed as other possible bidders.

headline: 4 POLICE OFFICERS KILLED IN ULSTER BY A BOMB PLANTED BY THE I.R.A.
abstract: Four police officers were killed near the Irish border today by a bomb that exploded near their armor-plated car as it sat parked near a derelict customs post. The Irish Republican Army took responsibility for the attack.   The dead, three men and a woman, were members of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. Their deaths brought the number of police officers killed in the province this year to 17.

headline: B.&B. GETS FAST-FOOD ACCOUNT
abstract: BENTON & BOWLES has become the agency for Rax Restaurants, the fast-food chain based in Columbus, Ohio, that claims to have pioneered the fast-food salad bar, the stuffed potato and the greenhouse ambiance. But more important, it plans to double its ad spending in the next 12 months, to $10 million.   Benton & Bowles fills a client category that has been vacant since Hardee's Food Service Systems vacated for the halls of Ogilvy & Mather in March, after what B.&B. calls a ''difference on strategic direction.'' Hardee's grew in the 10 years with the agency to $35 million in billings, from about $5 million.

headline: IN CHINA, 'CAPITALIST ROADERS' CAN NOW CRUISE IN CADILLACS
abstract: China, amid some ceremony, acquired a fleet of Cadillac limousines today.   At a formal handover, Chinese officials lined up to accept the 20 dark blue limousines, described in Cadillac brochures as ''the car of the stars,'' each equipped with a built-in television set, refrigerator and bar.   It was the kind of occasion that left Westerners with memories of Mao Zedong's China shaking their heads in disbelief. The ceremony was held only a short bicycle ride from the stadium where Mao's enemies were once paraded in duncecaps as ''capitalist roaders.''

headline: PEKING COUNCIL MEETS OVER SOCCER RIOT
abstract: Peking's municipal Communist Party committee met in emergency session today in the wake of the country's worst sports riot in years, a rampage that developed after Hong Kong eliminated the Chinese team from contention for the World Cup next year.   After Hong Kong won the game by 2-1, enraged supporters of the Chinese national squad hurled bottles at the Hong Kong players before surging into the streets around the 80,000-seat Workers' Stadium.   The rioters smashed at least a dozen buses, overturned several cars and menaced foreigners, throwing rocks through the windows of foreigners' cars and spitting on them.   It was the worst outbreak of violence in the capital since supporters of Zhou Enlai clashed with the police in Tian An Men Square in 1976 after Mr. Zhou's death.

headline: JAPAN OPENING UP TOBACCO MARKET
abstract: The president of Japan's former tobacco monopoly trooped over to the Ministry of Finance the other day bearing two blown-up stock certificates. He bowed, handed over the two million shares that represent his company's capital and Japan Tobacco Inc. was officially declared a private company.         The brief ceremony told much about the company born from the 81-year-old monopoly, and about the challenges facing foreign manufacturers in a newly liberalized tobacco market.

headline: KENNEDY AIRPORT TIGHTENS SECURITY
abstract: More stringent security measures have gone into effect at Kennedy International Airport, and passengers, aware of the hijackings and bombings that prompted the new procedures, are cooperating.   Few airlines will disclose specific measures, but at Trans World Airlines they include X-ray examination of all checked baggage, frequent searches of carry-on baggage, no curbside check-in for certain destinations, an increased police presence in the terminal and more vigilance on the part of customer service agents.   These measures, many of them urged last week by the Federal Aviation Administration and by Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole, have slowed check-ins, and travelers who inquire are urged to arrive at the airport earlier than usual.   ''They are pleased and extremely understanding,'' said R. M. Caesar, a T.W.A. customer service agent, as he checked in passengers for a flight to Athens, the origination point of the jet that was hijacked to Beirut on June 14.

headline: UNOCAL BAR TO PICKENS IS UPHELD
abstract: The Delaware Supreme Court said today that the Unocal Corporation could exclude a group of investors led by T. Boone Pickens in the company's offer to purchase 29 percent of its stock. The ruling was interpreted as giving managements of companies incorporated in Delaware a significant new tactic for warding off unwanted corporate raiders.   The decision by the three-judge panel, which cannot be appealed, overturned a decision last Monday by the Delaware Chancery Court. It also created the possibility that the market value of Unocal shares held by the Pickens group could fall next week by $300 million or more if Unocal proceeds with its buyback offer.

headline: 300 Youths Are Seized In Clash at Stonehenge
abstract: More than 300 youths, barred from holding a music festival at Stonehenge, were arrested today after a clash in which vehicles in a convoy were used to ram police vans.   Stonehenge, the 4,000-year-old monument of standing stones on Salisbury Plain about 80 miles west of London, was immediately closed to tourists.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Campbell Soup Names U.S. Division President
abstract: The Campbell Soup Company said that Herbert M. Baum, a marketing executive, had been named president of the company's American divisions.         Mr. Baum, a Campbell's employee for the past seven years, most recently as executive vice president of domestic operations, succeeds John M. Lindley. Mr. Lindley, who is 54, is taking early retirement. He has served as president of the division since 1982.

headline: 1,000 CHINESE IN POOL OF FUTURE LEADERS
abstract: In an effort to entrench the policies he has introduced, Deng Xiaoping, the country's pre-eminent leader, has had the Communist Party apparatus select 1,000 middle-aged officials as the core of China's future leadership.         A front-page article today in People's Daily, the main party organ, said the  officials had been designated over the last year. It said they had been chosen from ''different parts of China'' on the basis of recommendations by current leaders and by ''a vast number of ordinary people.''

headline: Florida Cypress
abstract: The board of Florida Cypress Gardens Inc. has entered into a $23 million merger agreement with the parent company of another popular tourist attraction, Sea World. Under the proposed deal, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., which owns Sea World, would acquire the outstanding shares of Florida Cypress. The stock was quoted at $7.50 bid in over-the- counter trading today, up $3, making it the biggest percentage gainer.

headline: U.S. Is Said to Plan Expulsion of Russian
abstract: The United States, displeased with the Soviet response to the killing of an American Army intelligence officer in East Germany, is likely to expel a Soviet diplomat, probably a military attache, within the next several days, a State Department official said today.   The official said that the United States has yet to receive a satisfactory response from the Soviet Union about procedures to prevent a recurrence of the incident in which Maj. Arthur D. Nicholson, Jr., a member of the American liaison team allowed to observe Soviet forces in East Germany, was shot to death by a Soviet sentry in East Germany on March 24 while preparing to take pictures in what the Russians said was a closed military installation.

headline: I.B.M., NAVY STILL IN CONTRACT FIGHT
abstract: The Navy and the International Business Machines Corporation remained locked  in a stubborn dispute last week over I.B.M.'s performance on a $1.7 billion contract to build an advanced computer system for submarines.         I.B.M. insists that work on the project is on schedule, meets the Pentagon's  technical specifications and will run less than $100 million over budget. The Navy contends that the work is behind schedule, falls short of specifications and could run as much as $800 million over budget.

headline: NEW TUNA BRAND WAVES FLAG
abstract: Watch out, Charlie the Tuna.   A new competitor has just hit the supermarket shelves - American Tuna, whose star-covered red, white and blue cans declare it to be the only national brand caught, processed and canned exclusively by workers in the continental United States.   American Tuna, the first new nationally marketed tuna brand name in 30 years, is being introduced accompanied by a $4 million star-spangled advertising campaign that clearly tries to play on building protectionist sentiment.      Battered Industry    Such flag-waving may be necessary, however, if American Tuna, a product of C.H.B Foods Inc., is going to succeed where other companies have failed. The domestic tuna industry has been battered for years by overproduction, high interest costs and what industry executives say is the Government's failure to stem a flood of cheap imports.

headline: Major Treasury Financing Planned
abstract: The hiatus in new Treasury notes and bonds is coming to an end this week, with the regular weekly offering of two-year notes on Wednesday. The auction is the first sale of Treasury notes since the last week of March, and precedes by one and a half weeks a major Treasury financing in the first week of May.    In advance of this Wednesday's auction, securities dealers offered the new notes on a when-issued basis late Friday, with a yield of 9.79 percent. That yield is down from 10.86 percent at the previous two-year note auction on March 20.

headline: More Losses At Regent Air LOS ANGELES, April 5 (AP)
abstract: The Regent Air Corporation   said today that it lost $4.4 million in its fiscal 1984 fourth   quarter, and $21.5 million for   all of 1984. The Los Angeles-   based carrier also said it expects to lose about $3.2 million   in this year's first quarter.

headline: EXPERTS SKEPTICAL OF REPORTS THAT MENGELE DIED IN 1975
abstract: Investigators from the United States, West Germany and Israel left hurriedly for Brazil yesterday to check into assertions that Josef Mengele, the fugitive Nazi death-camp doctor, may have drowned there six years ago and been buried in a cemetery outside Sao Paulo.   ''We're going with a healthy degree of skepticism,'' said Neal M. Sher, director of the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations for war crimes cases.   The report, stemming from West German and Brazilian authorities, also drew reactions of skepticism from other officials and independent experts in several countries. They cited recurrent reports that Dr. Mengele had been spotted in South America as recently as last year and had been in regular contact with relatives in West Germany.

headline: NIKE STRUGGLES TO HIT ITS STRIDE AGAIN
abstract: STRATEGIES FOR RECOVERY: RUNNER More than loyalty to a particular brand, there's loyalty to a specific shoe. One of the most common pieces of advice you see in running magazines is ''If it's not broke, don't fix it.''

headline: U.P.I. Plans More Layoffs
abstract: United Press International, which has filed for protection from its creditors under Federal bankruptcy statutes, will lay off more of its domestic editorial employees, the wire service said today. In a story made available to The Associated Press by U.P.I., the news service quoted Maxwell McCrohon, its editor-in-chief, as saying that ''there will be some further layoffs within a few days.''

headline: U.N. Security Council Assails South Africa
abstract: For the third time in three days, the Security Council condemned the South African Government today, this time for a recent military attack on neighboring Botswana.   Sixteen people, including a 6-year-old girl, were killed in the raid on Gaborone, Botswana's capital, on June 14.

headline: Ohio Utilities' Merger Enhances Two Careers
abstract: Back in 1948, when Robert M. Ginn was applying for his first job - in the finance department at the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company - the interviewer asked him about his career goals. ''Someday I'd like to make $10,000 a year,'' Mr. Ginn answered.   As Cleveland Electric's chairman, Mr. Ginn has more than met his goal. He now earns about $325,000, he said. And if the plans disclosed on Tuesday to merge his company with the Toledo Edison Company go through, Mr. Ginn, 61, will become president and chief executive officer of one of the 20 largest electric utilities in the United States.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;Signal Picks Chemist As Director of Research
abstract: The Signal Companies said that Mary L. Good had been named president and director of research at the Signal Research Center Inc., its basic research laboratory.         Mrs. Good, who is 53, gave up an endowed chair in the College of Engineering  at Louisiana State University to join Signal four years ago as vice president and director of research.

headline: PHILHARMONIC CANCELS STOP IN GREECE ON BASIS OF WARNING ABOUT AIRPORT
abstract: The New York Philharmonic, here on a European tour, said today that it had canceled performances in Greece, scheduled to begin Sunday, because of a State Department warning against flying into Athens.   The cancellation, along with what seems to be a growing number of American tourist cancellations, appeared to be a major blow to efforts by the Greek Government to counter the warning and maintain vital summer tourism.   The State Department issued the warning on travel to Greece June 18, four days after two Shiite Moslems boarded a Trans World Airlines plane in Athens and hijacked it. Fourty of the passengers and crew members are still being held hostage in Lebanon.   The Reagan Administration has charged that Greek airport security was lax. Greece has said the hijackers' weapons were brought aboard the aircraft in another country.

headline: Holiday Inns Vote
abstract: Holiday Inns Inc. said its shareholders had approved two anti-takeover amendments to its bylaws at its annual meeting and also voted to adopt a new name, the Holiday Corporation.
