In addition, the shareholders approved a reorganization under which Holiday Inns Inc. would become a wholly owned unit of the Holiday Corporation. The company said the new provisions included staggered terms for the 13-member board of directors and a requirement that every shareholder's shares be eligible for the same price in a takeover.

headline: SMALL STAFFS
abstract: To the Editor:   The article on trimming corporate staffs leaves one wondering how they got big in the first place.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: TUESDAY, APRIL 16, 1985

headline: Newsweek to Postpone 2d Issue on Technology
abstract: Newsweek is going to postpone the second annual publication of Newsweek Access, a special issue covering new technology that would have been sent free next November to executive subscribers. The announcement was made by Steve Price, the publisher, He said that while the first special issue last June was a distinct success, the signs of change in the high-technology marketplace indicate that Newsweek should wait before trying a repeat.   The second issue, which would have been written by both staff and outsiders, would have been sent to a list of some 950,000 subscribers.

headline: City Investing To Sell Unit The City Investing Company
abstract: said that it had agreed to sell its   General Development Corporation unit to an unidentified real   estate investment company for  $215 million in cash as part of   its liquidation program. The transaction brings to   more than $2.35 billion the   value of the operations sold by   City Investing since it approved the liquidation plan last   year.

headline: Control Data to Idle Plants for 2 Weeks
abstract: The Control Data Corporation, responding to declining orders, said yesterday that it was consolidating two of its disk drive assembly plants near Minneapolis and that it would idle 29 other facilities throughout the country for two-week periods, beginning next month. The company said the move would result in the temporary layoff of ''several thousand'' employees.

headline: ANXIOUS KIN OF HOSTAGE ARE CONSOLED BY REAGAN
abstract: President Reagan met unexpectedly today with the family of one of the American hostages in Beirut after promising that he would not ''cave in'' to the demands of terrorists and ''reward their grisly deeds.''   Mr. Reagan's five-minute meeting with the family of James Hoskins came in a room at the Indianapolis Convention Center after a speech by the President. White House officials said the family was close to tears as they left the meeting.   A White House spokesman, Albert R. Brashear, said Mr. Reagan ''praised'' the courage of the family and sought to reassure them that the Administration was seeking to free the hostages as soon as possible.

headline: PERSONAL INCOME UP BY 0.6%
abstract: The personal income of Americans rose six-tenths of 1 percent in April, following an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Commerce Department said today.   But private wages and salaries advanced at only about half the March pace and manufacturing payrolls actually declined.   Robert Ortner, chief economist at the Commerce Department, said that the April overall income gain would have been an even smaller four-tenths of 1 percent without a boost provided by Government subsidy payments to farmers and back wages paid to postal workers in a new contract.

headline: Arab Cooperation Urged
abstract: The third Arab Energy Conference ended in Algiers today with appeals for more intensive Arab cooperation in the energy sector and an end to restrictive practices by industrial states.

headline: India-Carbide Talks Planned
abstract: After a two-month lapse, negotiations are to resume Monday between Indian Government and Union Carbide officials on a possible out-of-court settlement to compensate victims of the poison gas leak in Bhopal, India, last Dec. 3.   Separately, Federal District Judge John F. Keenan postponed from June 18 until Aug. 7 the second pretrial conference on suits against the Union Carbide Corporation, because both the plaintiffs and defendants needed more time to prepare, sources close to the case said.

headline: TAX-EXEMPTS TOP THE LIST FOR AVID BOND SHOPPERS
abstract: INTEREST rates continue to slide, but with inflation remaining quiescent individuals are still pouring money into the bond markets. In the past year, yields on 30-year Treasury bonds have declined by more than a percentage point, to 11.75 percent. The drop in long-term tax-exempt municipal issues has not been so sharp - as of April 11, the Bond Buyer's 20-bond index stood at 9.39 percent, down from 9.97 percent a year earlier.   ''We are in a period of successively lower peaks and lower troughs for interest rates,'' said Steven J. Hueglin, a partner at Gabriel, Hueglin & Cashman, bond dealers and underwriters, ''but the ratio of yields from bonds compared with stocks strongly favors investments in the bond market.''   As long as inflation is subdued, analysts say, bonds will remain a highly attractive investment vehicle. With inflation below 5 percent a year, there is a real rate of return of roughly 5 percent on tax-free municipals.

headline: Police Kill 2 Blacks In South African Clashes
abstract: Two blacks were shot and killed by the police in separate incidents today, the day before a mass funeral for 19 people slain when the police fired into a crowd of black marchers last month.   Police headquarters in Pretoria reported scattered rioting Thursday night and today in several black townships of the eastern Cape Province.

headline: Franklin Library
abstract: BBDO Direct has become agency for Franklin Library, a division of the Franklin Mint that markets six series of books. It previously did its advertising in-house and expects to spend $5 million through BBDO Direct during the coming year. Franklin Mint is a subsidiary of American Protection Industries.

headline: Vote on Fuel Program
abstract: The House Energy and Commerce Committee voted today to abolish all but $500 million of what once was a $20 billion synthetic fuels program. The bill approved by the committee would abolish the Synthetic Fuels Corporation in 90 days. It now moves to the House Banking Committee.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Allegheny International Inc. has named William H. Vogt president of Springfield Instrument Co. of Hackensack, N.J., a unit of its North American consumer group.    * California First Bank, San Francisco, has elected Seishichi Itoh president and chief executive officer.

headline: JAPAN LIST SHOWS GROWING AFFLUENCE
abstract: To the chagrin of the wealthy and the delight of the curious, Japan's tax agency last week published its annual list of the nation's largest taxpayers.   The list, issued by the National Tax Administration Agency, offers a tantalizing glimpse of the very private world of the very wealthy here. Some of the names are familiar, such as Japan's leading industrialists, and some are new, and perhaps fleeting -the authors of a popular cartoon series, television personalities and athletes.   Because the list is based only on declared taxable income, and tax rates vary, it is difficult in some cases to calculate exactly how much total income a certain tax payment indicates.

headline: Scandinavia Feels Tremor
abstract: The strongest earth tremor felt in Sweden this century shook the southern part of the country and parts of Denmark today, the Danish Geodetic Institute said. The tremor, measured in Sweden at 4.2 on the Richter scale, occurred at 2 A.M. (9 P.M. Friday, New York time) and lasted 10 to 15 seconds.

headline: 28 CONSECRATED 'PRINCES OF THE CHURCH'
abstract: Pope John Paul II consecrated 28 cardinals of the Roman Catholic Church today in an outdoor ceremony grand in pageantry and resonant in tradition.   From his throne in front of St. Peter's Basilica, the 65-year-old Pope received the men, natives of 19 countries, one by one as they climbed the red-carpeted steps of the largest church in Christendom and knelt before him.   The Pope bestowed his blessing and gave to each the two red silk hats symbolic of high station in the church: a skullcap and the square-ridged crown called a biretta.   Giving a ring to each of the cardinals, the Pope declared, ''Receive the ring from the hand of Peter and know that with the love of the Prince of the Apostles, your love of the church is strengthened.'' Among the 28 men consecrated today were the archbishops of some of the largest Roman Catholic dioceses in the world, including John Cardinal O'Connor of New York and Bernard Cardinal Law of Boston.

headline: Chase Won't Sell Econometrics Unit
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said today that it had ended talks with McGraw-Hill Inc. over the proposed sale of its Chase Econometrics subsidiary, and it will retain and expand the economic forecasting firm.   The announcement comes two days after the Justice Department began to study whether the deal would violate antitrust laws, but Chase officials insisted the study was not an issue in the joint decision to terminate negotiations.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD ;   Parts of Pakistani City Sealed Off After Riots
abstract: Thousands of soldiers and policemen sealed off the western and central sections of Karachi today, allowing no one on the street after five days of rioting left 44 people dead and more than 250 hurt.

headline: OHIO PLANT FOR HONDA CAR ENGINE
abstract: The Honda Motor Company said today that it would begin to make automobile engines in Ohio late next year, becoming the first Japanese-owned car company to produce major components in this country.   Honda said it would expand its newly completed motorcycle engine plant in Shelby County, Ohio, to produce 60,000 engines a year for its Civic subcompact automobile. The investment, which Honda officials put at $40 million, continues the company's rapid expansion of its American manufacturing operations.

headline: HOW TO CHOOSE A WORD PROCESSOR
abstract: WORD processing has become as common ss the written word, or so it would seem from the amount of space devoted to this aspect of personal computing in magazines and newspapers. However, the attention probably has more to do with the fact that reporters use these programs in their work - and they assume that everyone else finds them equally indispensable - rather than with the widespred implementation of word processing software. My guess is that only a small percentage of the business community that might profit from word processing actually use that software.   Using a personal computer is still a new endeavor for many people, even in the corporate environment. a recent survey conducted by the Yankee Group for Infoworld magzine indicates that although the number of personal computers in use at large companies is impressive - 25,000 at the General Motors Corporation and 10,800 at the United Technologies Corporation, for example - the percentage of those companies' employees actually using pesonal computers is fairly low - 3.6 percent at G.M. and 5.6 percent at United Technologies.

headline: Internorth Terms
abstract: Internorth Inc. said that it had agreed to sell several of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation's pipelines and gathering facilities to meet Federal Trade Commission requirements on its previously announced $2.3 billion merger with Houston Natural. As a result of the agreement, Internorth said that it had accepted for payment the 58 percent of Houston Natural's outstanding shares that have been tendered under its $70-a-share offer. The offer expires today unless extended.

headline: Winans Case Summations Prosecution and defense lawyers in the securities fraud
abstract: trial of R. Foster Winans and   two co-defendants submitted   written summations yesterday   to the presiding judge, Charles   E. Stewart of Federal District   Court in Manhattan. Mr. Winans is the former   Wall Street Journal reporter   who has admitted that he   tipped off a stockbroker, Peter   N. Brant, about upcoming   ''Heard on the Street'' articles   and shared in profits based on   trading of stocks mentioned in   the articles. He has denied the   Government's charges of conspiracy, securities fraud and   mail and wire fraud.

headline: Chile Extends Siege
abstract: The military Government extended its six-month state of siege today for 90 more days, keeping opposition political activity banned throughout Chile.

headline: TAX SHIFT UNDER FIRE IN SENATE
abstract: The Senate began public scrutiny of President Reagan's tax revision proposals today, and the reception was much less enthusiastic than in the House of Representatives.   One Senator after another, questioning Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d at the opening tax hearing of the Senate Finance Committee, took issue with central elements of the Administration's tax plan.   Some expressed concern over such broad issues as the plan's effects on overall Government revenues and on the ability of American manufacturers to compete in international trade. Other Senators raised more narrow questions such as potential harm to the life insurance and timber industries and whether the proposed changes would lead to rent increases.

headline: PALEY SEES A 'TRAGEDY' IN A HOSTILE SHIFT AT CBS
abstract: Against a backdrop of vintage radio microphones and 57 years' worth of broadcasting artifacts, awards and memorabilia, William S. Paley, the 83-year-old founder and former chairman of CBS Inc., said yesterday that it would be a ''tragedy'' if either the management or the structure of the company were to be changed as a result of a hostile takeover bid.   ''CBS is strong; CBS is healthy,'' he said in a carefully prepared statement that he read aloud in a resonant voice to a visitor to his elegant office - its walls lined with paintings by Picasso, Giacometti, Rouault and Kline - on the 35th floor of CBS's headquarters on Sixth Avenue and 52d Street.   ''But that strength and health are the products of more than a half a century of careful, concerned nurturing by a great many very dedicated people,'' he said. ''To throw this away would be a tragedy. To risk its loss would be to trifle recklessly with the company's future and with the public interest.''

headline: ARGENTINE PRESIDENT RALLIES SUPPORT
abstract: President Raul Alfonsin succeeded today in attracting tens of thousands of Argentines to a rally he called ''in defense of democracy,'' but the size of the crowd belied a serious loss of support for him in the last month.   Mr. Alfonsin called on Argentines to attend the rally in the Plaza de Mayo after a nationally televised speech in which he accused unnamed ''traitors'' of planning a coup.   The call to the plaza has tremendous political overtones here, because, rather than being a symbol of democracy, such rallies are reminiscent of those staged by Juan Domingo Peron and the military rulers who followed him.   When Mr. Alfonsin's administration took office in December 1983, he promised to break from the past. His critics were also quick to point out this week that a well-attended rally would not solve the country's economic problems.

headline: UNOCAL BUYBACK RULING IS LIMITED, LAWYERS FEEL
abstract: Law experts said yesterday that a Delaware Supreme Court ruling on Friday, which allows the Unocal Corporation to exclude a group of investors led by T. Boone Pickens from a Unocal stock buyback offer, is not so sweeping as it might seem.   A number of takeover lawyers, reacting with surprise upon hearing of the ruling, had said it might give corporate boards of directors broad new power to fight off unwanted takeover attempts.   ''It is necessary to be careful about reading too much into it,'' Harvey J. Goldschmid, a corporate law professor at the Columbia University Law School, said yesterday. ''This is a limited decision in terms of its possible ramifications because of the set of circumstances that must be met.''

headline: United Cable Buying in Hartford
abstract: The United Cable Television Corporation has signed a letter of intent to purchase for $61.5 million the Hartford area cable system of Times Mirror Cable Television.

headline: Lomas Debentures
abstract: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation, the largest mortgage banking firm in the country, is offering $100 million of 9 percent convertrible subordinated debentures due in 2010 at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The debentures are convertible into Lomas & Nettleton common stock at $37.50 a share, up from yesterday's over-the-counter closing price of $30.875 a share.

headline: CAR BOMBER FAILS IN ATTEMPT TO KILL LEADER OF KUWAIT
abstract: A suicide driver rammed a bomb-laden car into the motorcade of the Kuwaiti leader today, killing himself, two bodyguards and a passer-by in an unsuccessful assassination attempt, Kuwaiti officials said.   A caller saying he represented the shadowy terrorist group known as Islamic Holy War took responsibility for the attack. The group has demanded the release of 17 convicted terrorists from Kuwaiti prisons in exchange for at least four Americans and two Frenchmen kidnapped in Lebanon.   Islamic Holy War has issued a crescendo of threats in recent weeks, including vows to attack American diplomats and a warning that it would open ''the largest military operation'' the United States ''has ever seen.''

headline: SUPPLIERS CITE FREEZE BY LERNER
abstract: Lerner Stores, the 800-store apparel shop chain that abruptly canceled all of its apparel orders 10 days ago, has frozen payments to suppliers for two weeks, according to apparel market sources.     The freeze on payments, which involve early disbursement of funds to obtain anticipated discounts, is expected to end late this week. But its disclosure was one of a number of developments that indicate that Lerner's cancellation of orders on April 8 has deeper ramifications.    The payments freeze shocked producers, lawyers and factors, who met Thursday night at the Tower Suite of the Time-Life Building to discuss strategy on the Lerner action.

headline: Hughes Trims Oil Rig Figure
abstract: The Hughes Tool Company, which originally predicted an increase in oil drilling activity this year, has lowered its 1985 estimate again.   The Houston-based manufacturer of oilfield equipment now says the number of active rigs in the United States this year will drop 8 percent from 1984.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Mesa Finance Chief Plays Unusual Role
abstract: David H. Batchelder is the chief financial officer at an oil company. But the company he works for, the Mesa Petroleum Company, is not just any oil company. And Mr. Batchelder, who is 35 years old, does not have an ordinary job description.

headline: New President Set For Merged T.W.A.
abstract: Richard D. Pearson, who only a year ago was appointed executive vice president and chief operating officer at Trans World Airlines, will succeed C. E. Meyer Jr. as president of the carrier when it completes its merger with the Texas Air Corporation late this year, the airline announced yesterday.   Mr. Meyer, who joined T.W.A. in 1968 as vice president and controller and became president and chief executive in 1976, will leave to become president and chief executive of the Hilton International Company. Hilton is a subsidiary of the Trans World Corporation, T.W.A.'s former parent.

headline: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS WARNS INVESTORS
abstract: Most shareholders in the Continental Illinois Corporation are likely to see their investment wiped out, the bank holding company said today.   Under last summer's $4.5 billion Federal plan to rescue the bank, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reserved the right to purchase the common shares outstanding at the time for one-thousandth of a cent each if losses on a portfolio of bad Continental loans the F.D.I.C. was assuming reached a certain level.   The bank said today that more than $800 million - the trigger amount -would likely be lost on the $3.5 billion portfolio being transferred to the insurance corporation. Before the huge run on the bank last May, common shareholders' equity in Continental Illinois totaled more than $1.7 billion. Today, based on the New York Stock Exchange closing price of $1 a share, it is worth only $40.3 million.

headline: Judge Denies Crown Motion
abstract: A Federal District judge in Nevada on Friday denied a motion by the Crown Zellerbach Corporation for a temporary restraining order barring Sir James Goldsmith from purchasing additional Crown shares following the withdrawal of his cash tender offer, a source close to Sir James said yesterday.         A spokesman for Crown, Lawrence Kurtz, confirmed that Judge Bruce R. Thompson of United States District Court in Reno denied the motion, pending a hearing previously scheduled for tomorrow on Crown's earlier request for an injunction to block Sir James's bid for the company.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: SATURDAY, MAY 25, 1985        The Economy    President Reagan criticized the Democratic budget plan that passed the House, saying it would place the nation's defense at risk by permitting no increase in the military budget. He also began seeking support for his forthcoming plan to simplify the Federal income tax, calling the current system ''needlessly complicated and unfair.'' [Page 1.]    Some taxpayers may have to file duplicate returns to get their refunds, the I.R.S. said. The processing of 1.5 million returns has been delayed because of problems registering them with a master computer file. As a consequence, several hundred thousand taxpayers may not receive their refunds until after June 1. [29.]

headline: SOVIET CALLS REAGAN'S EMBARGO 'PATHOLOGICAL'
abstract: The Soviet Government's press agency said today that President Reagan was venting a ''pathological hatred for the Sandinista revolution'' in imposing a trade embargo on Nicaragua.   ''To attain its hegemonistic ambitions, the Reagan Administration is not averse to the use of any, even the dirtiest, means,'' the Tass press agency said in a commentary.   In another commentary, on Wednesday, Tass noted, without comment, a statement by the Reagan Administration that Nicaragua had become a ''pillar for the Soviet presence.''   The two commentaries compared United States actions in Nicaragua with what it called interference in Chile, Grenada and Vietnam.

headline: THRIFT UNIT'S 'JUNK BONDS'
abstract: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills owned approximately $2 billion in high-yielding, low-grade securities at the end of March, considered one of the biggest holdings of ''junk bonds'' of any thrift institution in the nation.   Thomas Spiegel, a 39-year-old one-time broker who left Wall Street for a job as marketing director for the Starrett Housing Corporation's apartment construction projects in Iran during the 1970's, has been Columbia's president and chief executive officer since 1977.   Sales of low-grade bonds contributed about 18 percent to Columbia's record first-quarter profits of $32.8 million, or $1.66 a share. Columbia has $6.1 billion in assets, up from $1 billion at the end of 1982. Mr. Spiegel recently discussed the question of low-grade bonds as a proper investment for savings associations.

headline: Weinberger Holds Talks With Japanese Official
abstract: Defense Minister Koichi Kato of Japan discussed the defense of Pacific sea lanes around Japan and other issues today with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, the Pentagon said.   In addition to a five-year Japanese plan to increase its defense of sea lanes within 1,000 miles of its shores, the officials discussed the exchange of technology between Washington and Tokyo and Japan's request for information on American radar systems that look over the earth's horizon, the Pentagon said.

headline: U.S. TELLS TOURISTS ATHENS AIRPORT HAS HIGH RISK
abstract: The State Department, on direct orders from President Reagan, warned American travelers yesterday that there was a high risk of exposure to terrorism on flights using Athens International Airport. Athens was the boarding point of the men who hijacked a Trans World Airlines jet last Friday.   In Athens, the Greek Government immediately summoned the United States Ambassador to protest what it called an ''unjustified and unfriendly'' American action.  The Reagan Administration's warning was in reaction not only to the T.W.A. hijacking but also to what it regards as extensive evidence of inadequate security at the Athens terminal. The State Department said there was ''above-average potential for terrorist activities'' there.

headline: Fee Ruling on Ford Suit
abstract: A Federal judge in New York has ordered two lawyers, Roy M. Cohn and Allan M. Pollack, to return $230,000 in fees received from a Ford Motor Company shareholder suit against Ford's former chairman, Henry Ford 2d. The lawyers received the fees in 1980.

headline: Japan to Lower Tariffs
abstract: Japan announced today that it would cut tariffs on more than 1,800 products in the first stage of a program to improve access to its markets.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: May 6, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Body for 1985 Conference on Women's Decade - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee, Subcommittee on Petitions, Information and Assistance - 10:30 A.M.   Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Committee on the Implementation of the International Development Strategy for the Third Development Decade - 3 P.M.

headline: Baldwin Posts $54 Million Net
abstract: The Baldwin-United Corporation said that it had a 1984 profit of $54 million, compared with a loss of $1.36 billion in 1983.   The company, a seller of single-premium deferred annuities until it entered bankruptcy in 1983, said that its 1984 results include a nonrecurring gain of $128 million from the sale of its banking investments in Colorado and other assets, and a charge of $57 million related to receivables from deconsolidated subsidiaries. The company had a negative net worth of more than $900 million at the end of 1984, down from a negative net worth of nearly $1 billion a year earlier.

headline: Bloomingdale's Opens Catalogue to Outsiders
abstract: For the first time, Bloomingdale's will open its national catalogue pages to outside advertisers.

headline: Senate Votes Tax Changes
abstract: The Senate voted today to repeal strict record-keeping requirements for tax-deductible vehicles and home computers after endorsing new expense-account tax breaks for corporate executives and for workers who drive company cars on personal business.   The Senate action, approved by a 92-to-1 vote, would worsen the Federal deficit by about $5.5 billion over the next four years.

headline: U.N. CHIEF URGES ISRAEL TO FREE PRISONERS
abstract: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, called today for the ''early release'' by Israel of 735 Lebanese and Palestinian prisoners whose freedom has been demanded by terrorists holding 40 American hostages in Beirut.   The Secretary General did not link the release of the Moslem prisoners for the hostages.   In a statement read by a United Nations spokesman in New York, the Secretary General noted Israel's release Monday of 31 prisoners and said he ''would view the early release of the remaining prisoners and their return to their homes and families as a most essential and helpful step in the process of restoring peace and stability in the south'' of Lebanon.   Israel says the 31 prisoners were freed because they were found not to have committed any violent acts against the Israeli Army.

headline: Jersey Thrift Units 'Sound'
abstract: In New Jersey, where 24 small savings and loan associations have no insurance, state banking officials said yesterday that the institutions were ''extremely sound'' and in no danger of failing.   The average ''ratio of net worth to deposits is 24 percent,'' said William Sievewright, chief examiner in the savings and loan division of the state's Insurance Department.

headline: BOMB AT FRANKFURT AIRPORT KILLS 3 AND WOUNDS 42
abstract: A powerful bomb ripped through an international departure lounge of the Frankfurt Airport this afternoon, killing three people and wounding 42, according to the police. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.   The bombing came as world attention has been centered on the hijacking drama that started last Friday when Lebanese Shiite gunmen seized a T.W.A. airliner after takeoff from Athens. But various police spokesmen declined to link the two events.

headline: Guadeloupe Rebel Chief Escapes From Jail
abstract: The suspected leader of a group fighting for the independence of French overseas territories escaped from jail in Guadeloupe today, the public prosecutor said.   The escapee, Luc Reinette, was sentenced earlier this year to 23 years in jail for illegal possession of arms, an attack against a radio station and a bombing in the capital, Basse Terre, in which more than 20 people were hurt. Prosecutors say he is the leader of the Revolutionary Caribbean Alliance.

headline: China Restricts Banks
abstract: China is not ready to let foreign banks set up branches outside Peking and the southern special economic zones, the People's Bank of China president, Chen Muhua, said today.

headline: MITTERRAND'S GOALS: 'PRESERVING SKILLS,' 'PROTECTING EUROPE'
abstract: Fears of a scientific brain drain to American industry and of unrest at home largely explain President Francois Mitterrand's objection at the Bonn summit conference to setting a date for new trade talks and his rejection of Washington's invitation to join the ''Star Wars'' research program, according to French officials and other participants.   West European governments, these sources say, fear that the $26 billion missile defense research program will divert Europe's best scientists and skills to American industry, giving the United States an unassailable lead in ultramodern technologies with extensive civilian applications.   But by refusing for the moment to join the program, the French President hopes to increase support for the European space-science program that he has proposed, these sources say.   The program, called Eureka, would provide for joint European research in many of the nonmilitary areas covered by the ''Star Wars'' plan, including high-powered computers, artificial intelligence, lasers, sensors and advanced telecommunications.

headline: EVEN FOR THE SWISS, IT'S TIME FOR ANOTHER LOOK AT THE WAR
abstract: As their neighbors have been marking the 40th anniversary of the end of World War II, the neutral Swiss have been quietly undergoing a reassessment of their role during the conflict.   In recent months, several issues that were once considered taboo or rarely discussed have gained new attention, including the political leanings of the wartime military chief, Gen. Henri Guisan; the Swiss treatment of Jewish refugees, and even the national bank's purchase of gold seized during the war by the Nazis.   Photographs of a house destroyed by an accidental Allied bombing of Schaffhausen, the only Swiss town to be bombed during the war, have appeared in newspapers and on television. Other publications have reviewed the role of the Swiss Army and the condition of Jews in Switzerland.

headline: NEW BOARD FOR COAST THRIFT UNIT
abstract: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board yesterday announced the appointment of a new board of directors for the ailing Central Savings and Loan Association of San Diego, after efforts to find a buyer apparently failed.   Central Savings is one of California's 20 largest thrift institutions, with assets of $2.2 billion and 48 offices in the state.

headline: All the Tea in China: Price Soars by 400%
abstract: The price of tea in China has soared up to 400 percent this year because an abnormally cold and rainy spring seriously cut production, the Government reported today.   The official New China News Agency said tea bushes in Zhejiang and Anhui Provinces, the country's main producing regions, sprouted late because of the weather, and picking was delayed.

headline: British Petroleum Offers Eurobonds
abstract: BP Capital, a subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company, is offering $100 million of 10 1/2 percent Eurobonds due in 1994 and $182.46 million face amount of zero coupon Eurobonds due in 1995 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley International. Both issues are guaranteed by British Petroleum, and both have delayed-payment features.

headline: LIBERATION THEOLOGY: 2 SIDES POLARIZE
abstract: A leading Brazilian theologian who was ordered to withdraw from public life by the Vatican has remained secluded in a Franciscan monastery for the last month, refusing to take telephone calls and turning down invitations to ceremonies organized in his honor.   The theologian, the Rev. Leonardo Boff, is a proponent of teachings known as the theology of liberation. While he has quietly accepted the one-year punishment for what was termed his doctrinal errors and deviations, the growing controversy over the Vatican's move appears to be polarizing opinions in Brazil and elsewhere in the Roman Catholic world.   Some clergymen believe that, rather than restoring orthodoxy, the Vatican's move against Friar Boff may have fed a mood of rebelliousness in sectors of the church that have been critical of Pope John Paul II. The teachings invoke scriptural texts in support of a struggle for social justice and have a wide following among Christians in developing countries.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.          Monday    Construction SpendingFeb.      Tuesday    None      Wednesday    None      Thursday    None      Friday    UnemploymentMarch

headline: Portuguese President Plans To Dissolve the Parliament
abstract: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes of Portugal decided today to dissolve Parliament but plans to maintain the current Government for the moment, an official statement said.

headline: SALVADORAN PANEL UPHOLDS ELECTION
abstract: El Salvador's electoral commission tonight unanimously rejected a demand by leaders of rightist parties to nullify the results of national elections here, ending a bitter 24-hour struggle between the conservatives and President Jose Napoleon Duarte.   The decision not to consider the assertion by the rightist leaders that the Government and the army had manipulated the vote, came just four hours after the Salvadoran Army's high command called an extraordinary press conference to declare that it had been neutral in the contest and that all political factions should ''act honestly and consolidate democracy.''   Francisco Merino, vice-president of the Central Elections Council, which is the arbiter of all election disputes, said tonight that the agency had decided not to consider annulling the election, but that it would investigate complaints of irregularities in specific municipalities. The official count of the ballots will begin on Monday, he added, at the end of the traditional Easter week vacation here.

headline: CHIP-TESTING PROBLEMS ABOUND, PENTAGON SAYS
abstract: A Defense Department inquiry, prompted by the discovery last fall that several vendors of computer components had shipped improperly tested microchips  to makers of weapons systems, has concluded that irregularities in the testing of military equipment are pervasive in the electronics industry.          The inquiry has led to a crackdown on military suppliers in an effort to reverse practices that Pentagon officials say impede their ability to assure the reliability of computers, jet fighters, missiles and radar equipment. But Defense Department officials emphasize that they have no evidence that any of the parts in question have thus far led to any equipment failures.

headline: LABOR'S CLASH WITH TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Work Transformed: Automation & Labor in the Computer Age, by Harley Shaiken. Holt, Rinehart & Winston, N.Y., 306 pages, $17.95.       WHEN a President of the United States tried to break a miners' strike in the 1940's, John L. Lewis, the head of the United Mine Workers union, told him that ''you can't mine coal with bayonets.''    But when members of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization walked off the job in 1981, 75 percent of commercial flights were operating soon after, even with 75 percent of the controllers on the picket line. What ultimately doomed PATCO, according to the author of this book, was modern technology: A computerized procedure to regulate traffic flow and to space aircraft uniformly along air traffic routes, thereby maximizing the use of airspace, facilities and controllers.

headline: Dow, Up Again, Adds 1.10 Points
abstract: Wall Street stock prices closed slightly higher yesterday - the fifth trading day in a row that stocks gained. But trading activity was light, as investors continued to resist putting more money into equities.          With a lack of genuine buying interest, takeovers and other special situations continued to provide what little excitement there was on Wall Street.

headline: Patents;  Improving Color TV Picture
abstract: WASHINGTONRCA received a patent this week for a device that it says can provide a sharper, clearer and cleaner picture for its color television.

headline: Ruling on Unocal May Hurt Pickens
abstract: A legal ruling that could potentially derail T. Boone Pickens's takeover move against the Unocal Corporation was issued yesterday.   In a preliminary decision in Los Angeles, a Federal District Court judge said that Unocal would ''probably be able to prove at trial'' that the investor group led by Mr. Pickens had violated Federal securities laws last February when it said that it held about 7 percent of Unocal for investment purposes only. Judge A. Wallace Tashima said he believed Unocal would also prevail in its charge that the group had not adequately disclosed information about the impact on Unocal of the second stage of its acquisition plans.   The judge said he had not decided what preliminary relief, if any, would be required by his findings. A further hearing on the matter is set for today. Lawyers said that if the judge decides the case should go to trial, then he might issue an injunction against Mr. Pickens's tender offer for 36.5 percent of Unocal stock pending the outcome of the trial.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: May 13, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.          Special Committee Against Apartheid - 10:30 A.M.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: * Bank of Boston Corp.  has elected to its board J. Richard Bullock, president and chief executive officer of Wyman-Gordon Co., and Stephen J. Sweeney, president and chief executive officer of Boston Edison Co.     * GTE Corp., Stamford, Conn., a worldwide telecommunications, lighting products and precision materials company, has named Edward C. MacEwen vice president of corporate communications.

headline: GERMAN AWAITING MENGELE EVIDENCE
abstract: The West German prosecutor in the Josef Mengele case said yesterday that there was now ''a certain probability'' that the fugitive Nazi death camp doctor had lived and perhaps died in Sao Paulo, Brazil, but that he was awaiting the results of further investigation and tests.   The official, Hans-Eberhard Klein, said in a telephone interview that establishing Dr. Mengele's presence in Sao Paulo and his death there were two separate issues. He said that evidence so far seemed to show that Dr. Mengele had lived in the Brazilian city but added that he thought it was too early to verify accounts that Dr. Mengele drowned in February 1979 and was buried at a nearby cemetery.   The Brazilian police say the skeleton of a man in the cemetery at Embu could be that of Dr. Mengele, who vanished from the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp in December 1944.

headline: LEBANON CHRISTIANS CLOSE ISRAEL OFFICE
abstract: Lebanon's main Christian militia force announced today that it was closing its office in Jerusalem in a move designed to end 10 years of collaboration with Israel.   The militia, known as the Lebanese Forces, also said it was recalling its fighters from the Christian town of Jezzin and the border area in southern Lebanon and was moving them to Beirut. It asked for an urgent meeting of a multifactional security committee to discuss a cease-fire designed to end three weeks of heavy fighting in the Lebanese capital.

headline: High-Tech Trade Rules
abstract: The Commerce Department today announced final regulations that will govern export licenses authorizing multiple shipments of computers or other strategic, high-technology goods to friendly countries. Officials said they believe the rules were less restrictive than an earlier version, and thus more acceptable to business.

headline: REINVESTING DIVIDENDS
abstract: PLANS through which shareholders can automatically reinvest their dividends in a company's stock instead of receiving cash have been a fixture on the American business scene for more than 15 years. But a slowing growth rate for the plans has spurred companies to devise some changes recently that are intended to attract greater investor interest.   Currently 1,300 companies have dividend reinvestment plans, or D.R.P.'s, with more than six million participating stockholders.    The slowing growth rate in the plans, specialists in this field say, is the result of the merger trend among businesses; the decreased need for funds by utilities, particularly those that had been building nuclear plants, and the fact that most of the major corporations able and willing to institute a plan have already done so.

headline: Fleischmann Account To MacNamara, Clapp
abstract: MacNamara, Clapp & Klein is going to be doing the advertising for the 12 brands of the Fleischmann Distilling Company, part of Whitbread, North America.   The agency got its foot in the Whitbread door about a year ago, when it was assigned Florio Marsalla, a fortified Italian wine, from its Julius Wile Sons & Company division, now Buckingham Wile.

headline: Carlson Assumes Top Posts at BMC
abstract: Robert J. Carlson, who resigned last September as president of the United Technologies Corporation under circumstances that are still unclear, yesterday was named chairman, chief executive and president of BMC Industries.   BMC, which makes precision electronics equipment, posted revenues of $333 million last year, and the appointment came as something of a surprise to analysts, who said they had heard rumors that Mr. Carlson was considering offers from a number of very large multinational companies.   ''Those rumors were essentially correct,'' Mr. Carlson said in a telephone interview yesterday from St. Paul, where BMC is based.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: American Petrofina Inc., Dallas, has elected Kenneth W. Perry senior vice president and Brendan M. O'Connor treasurer.    * Amerimac Inc., a mortgage banking subsidiary of Amerifederal Savings Bank of Lawrenceville, N.J., has appointed Daniel J. Cunningham president.    * Avant-Garde Computing Inc. of Mount Laurel, N.J., which makes communications network management products, has named John J. O'Connors and William A. Angus 3d senior vice presidents.

headline: Car Sales Declined 8.6% In First 10 Days of May
abstract: Despite incentive programs, sales of new American-made automobiles fell 8.6 percent in the first 10 days of May, compared with that period last year, the manufacturers reported today.   The results were slightly below what most auto industry analysts had been expecting.   Total sales of 217,832 cars, down from 238,240 a year ago, brought the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate to 7.8 million units. Last year the rate was a very stong 8.7 million. There were nine selling days in the period both this year and last.

headline: DIGITAL'S BID FOR A COMEBACK
abstract: Not too many years ago, a small start-up computer company with only $70,000 in seed money stunned competitors with an inexpensive, versatile machine that introduced computers to thousands of new users.   But the company was not Apple, the place was not Silicon Valley, and the product was not the personal computer. Instead, the place was a suburb of Boston nearly 30 years ago, the runaway success was the minicomputer - a smaller, simpler, more economical machine than the expensive mainframes - and many thought that bigger, lumbering competitors would never catch up with the Digital Equipment Corporation.   They were wrong. Now, after a painful four years in which Digital saw profit margins shrivel and the personal computer revolution largely pass it by, the world's second-largest computer maker is attempting a powerful comeback. One of the most important pieces of its strategy will fall into place Tuesday, when the company introduces its Microvax II, a computer that puts one of Digital's most successful minicomputers on a chip.

headline: Golf Illustrated
abstract: Family Media, a magazine publisher, has acquired Golf Illustrated, a quarterly with single-copy circulation of around 40,000. And, since it already owns World Tennis, that brings its sports publications to two and makes it an appropriate time to start a new division called Family Sports Media. Now the company has eight titles.

headline: U.S. LABOR TIES WITH ISRAEL ARE STRAINED BY EL AL STRIKE
abstract: A small strike, barely noticed by most Americans, has created a severe strain in the long relationship between Israel and the American labor movement, to the point where the Israeli Prime Minister has now intervened to force a settlement.   The strike, by the machinists union against El Al, the Israeli state airline, enters its 15th month today. The airline has continued operating at Kennedy International Airport and at its Manhattan office despite the walkout.   The confrontation has triggered bitter charges of strikebreaking against the airline and threats that the labor movement will sell millions of dollars of Israel Bonds unless the strike is settled.

headline: Taiwan Trade Surplus
abstract: Taiwan's trade surplus narrowed to $347 million in March, from $700.8 million a year earlier, the Government said today. It added that while imports rose 6.9 percent from a year earlier, exports dropped 9.2 percent.

headline: Britain Refuses Asylum For Nigerian Fugitive
abstract: The Government refused today to grant asylum to a fugitive Nigerian politician who was the victim of a bungled kidnapping attempt hear last year.   A spokesman for the Home Office said the Nigerian, Umaru Dikko, could now begin appeal procedures and remain in Britain pending an outcome.

headline: Housing Starts Fell 14% in May
abstract: Housing starts fell a surprisingly sharp 14 percent last May, to an annual rate of 1.66 million units, the Commerce Department reported today.   Industry executives, however, said no one had expected the brisk April rate of nearly 2 million starts a year to be sustained. They also said the continuing slide in mortgage interest rates since the May figures were compiled bodes well for higher figures in the months ahead.

headline: POLE DENOUNCES POLICE IN SMUGGLED PRISON LETTER
abstract: In a letter smuggled out of his jail cell in Gdansk, the dissident Adam Michnik has denounced the Polish police, appealed for international monitoring of his coming trial and urged that the treatment of political prisoners be added to the agenda of the Geneva arms talks.   In the letter, titled ''A Lesson on Dialogue,'' the 38-year-old historian resumed the prison writings in which he challenged and ridiculed the Polish authorities from prison for more than two and a half years until he was freed in a general amnesty nine months ago.   After six months of freedom, Mr. Michnik was arrested again in February at a meeting convened by Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity trade union. Mr. Michnik and his fellow Solidarity activists, Bogdan Lis and Wladyslaw Frasyniuk, are awaiting trial on charges of inciting public unrest in connection with the meeting. At the meeting the men discussed a strike as a response to Government plans for price increases.

headline: Reliance Stake
abstract: Reliance Group Holdings Inc., the closely held insurance and financial conglomerate owned by Saul P. Steinberg, the New York businessman, and his family, disclosed that it owned 5.1 million shares, or 5 percent, of Vickers Ltd., the British company that is the parent of Rolls-Royce. A spokesman for Mr. Steinberg said the purchase of the shares was for investment purposes.

headline: Honeywell Sees Decline in Quarter
abstract: Honeywell Inc., citing weakness in industrial and computer markets, said that it expected its second-quarter earnings to ''decline sharply'' from the period last year.

headline: NATO COOL TO U.S. PROGRAM FOR MODERN CHEMICAL ARMS
abstract: Defense Ministers of the Atlantic alliance agreed today on a program to improve nonnuclear defenses and reduce reliance on nuclear arms, but avoided a United States proposal for production of new chemical weapons.   The 14 ministers agreed to correct deficiencies in conventional arms by narrowing priorities, improving long-term planning and making better use of existing resources.

headline: OFFICIALS OF P.L.O. MEET BEIRUT AIDES
abstract: Five leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization met with officials here today for talks that were said to have centered on Lebanese-Palestinian cooperation after Israel completes its troop withdrawal.   It was the first time since the P.L.O. and 12,000 of its guerrillas were evacuated from Beirut almost three years ago that senior guerrilla delegates had arrived here and held talks with Lebanese officials and other politicians.   The Palestinian delegation, which arrived in Beirut Tuesday from Damascus, represents a Syrian-backed faction opposed to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman and head of the mainstream Al Fatah faction.   The five-man guerrilla delegation is said to have come here with Syrian approval to try to bring 13 Palestinian refugee camps in Lebanon under control of a newly formed group, the Palestine National Salvation Front, and away from Arafat loyalists. 400,000 Palestinians in Lebanon Palestinians still residing in Lebanon are estimated to number 400,000, one third of them living in camps operated by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees.

headline: Murdock View On Castle Deal SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -
abstract: David H. Murdock, the West   Coast financier who would become the chief executive of   Castle & Cooke under a proposed merger, said today that   he would sell off some of Castle   & Cooke's real estate to help   improve its financial situation,   but that he would not strip the   company of all its valuable assets. ''I can state without equivocation I would like to build Castle & Cooke, not destroy it,''   Mr. Murdock said.

headline: Data Bank;   May 19, 1985
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: People
abstract: * Paula Bolouri, Philip Brushaber, Jud Chapin and Henry Lewczyk have been elected senior vice presidents at Bozell & Jacobs, Dallas.

headline: MURDOCH TO BUILD HOTEL IN PEKING
abstract: Rupert Murdoch, the publisher whose newspaper and magazine empire stretches from New York to London to his native Australia, will build an international hotel and news media center in Peking, a spokesman for Mr. Murdoch said yesterday.   The center, which is scheduled to be completed by 1987 at a cost of $40 million, will have 300 hotel rooms and 100 apartments for journalists and business executives, according to Howard J. Rubenstein, Mr. Murdoch's spokesman in New York.

headline: South Africa Issues Reports on 20 Victims
abstract: Most of those who died when police opened fire on a funeral procession near here a month ago were shot in the back or in the side, autopsy reports have revealed.    The reports were presented as evidence to the commission of inquiry looking into the shooting incident that claimed 20 deaths and wounded dozens in the black township of Langa on March 21.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: Durr-Fillauer Medical Inc.  has filed an offering of $30 million of convertible subordinated debentures, through underwriters led by E.F. Hutton.     *       First Interstate Bancorp filed an shelf offering of up to $500 million in debt securities, through Goldman, Sachs.     *       Manufacturers Hanover Mortgage Corp.  filed an offering of $100 million in mortgage pass-through certificates, through First Boston.

headline: Longtime Copywriter Helps Newcomers
abstract: Without a doubt, Whit Hobbs, longtime successful advertising copywriter (and proud of it), was one of the favorite speakers at the recent three-day annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. It was a good dose of nostalgia mixed with plugs for his recently finished book, ''I Love Advertising,'' subtitled ''Especially the Energetic, Talented People.

headline: SOVIET RESEARCH SHIP TRAPPED IN ANTARCTIC ICE
abstract: The Soviet Union has dispatched one of its giant icebreakers to Antarctica to free a research vessel trapped with 53 aboard in thickening and shifting winter ice.   The icebreaker Vladivostok is expected to reach the stranded Mikhail Somov sometime in early July. But the success of the mission, according to press reports, is far from certain.   The research vessel is mired in ice up to 12 feet thick, hundreds of miles from open sea. The polar night, with its bitter frosts, is rapidly setting in and icebergs are lurking nearby, the press reports say. Once the Vladivostok reaches the trapped ship, it may be able to do little more than stand guard over it until the polar spring.

headline: Blast Near Rhein-Main Base
abstract: A bomb exploded today in a safety shaft leading to an underground fuel pipeline near Rhein-Main Air Base, the police said. A spokesman said no one was hurt in the explosion, which occurred in the village of Morfelden-Walldorf, and there was little damage. A leftist group called the Revolutionary Cells took responsibility for the bombing in a telephone call to the village priest.

headline: GAS DEREGULATION'S IMPACT
abstract: The Jan. 1 deregulation of natural gas prices, which some observers predicted would cause price increases, has instead driven gas prices down, intensified competititon among gas transmission companies and contributed to a frenetic spate of takeover rumors and merger agreements in the once-staid pipeline industry.   In addition, pipeline company analysts and other industry observers said that the ''merger mania'' that has swept through the oil industry in recent years has now come into play, and with greater force, among gas transmission companies.      Series of Acquisitions    The result over the last two years has been a continuing series of acquisitions of medium-sized pipeline companies by larger ones, joint ventures between major pipeline companies on specific networks and, recently, two huge proposed mergers.

headline: NEW YORK MIDDLE CLASS FACING BIGGER TAX BITE
abstract: President Reagan in a speech in New Jersey last week reasserted his belief that his tax plan would not hurt taxpayers in ''high-tax'' states such as New York. But neither the President nor his lieutenants have ever denied that many New Yorkers would face a big tax increase.   And while Governor Cuomo has insistently denounced as unfair a key Reagan provision, the proposal to end the deduction for state and local taxes, the Governor has not contested that a great many New Yorkers - not all of them rich - would enjoy substantial tax cuts.   The dispute heated up this weekend, when Patrick J. Buchanan, the White House director of communications, described Mr. Cuomo as a ''glib, fast-talking lobbyist for a reactionary liberalism that would kill tax reform in its crib.'' The charge was made in a letter to The New York Times.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

headline: AT BUCHENWALD, CEREMONY OF BITTER MEMORY
abstract: Tens of thousands of people today commemorated the liberation of the Buchenwald concentration camp in a ceremony filled with bitter attacks on the United States and its allies.     In April 1945, about 40 hours before soldiers of the American Third Army reached Buchenwald, several hundred camp inmates who were organized in a resistance group overwhelmed their guards and took control of the camp. Former Buchenwald inmates boast that theirs was the only Nazi concentration camp to be liberated by the prisoners themselves.    There was no mention today of the thousands of Jews who died at Buchenwald, and there were harsh tirades against the United States and its allies.

headline: Article 049811 -- No Title
abstract: Trans World Airlines Inc. agreed in principle last night to be acquired by the Texas Air Corporation, parent of Continental Airlines and New York Air, for $793.5 million, according to sources close to the companies.   T.W.A. has been up for sale for several weeks as an alternative to a hostile takeover attempt by Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor.   Texas Air's offer amounts to $23 a share in cash and debt securities, exceeding a $22 package offered by Resorts International Inc., the sources said.   In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, T.W.A.'s stock closed at $19.625, down 25 cents.

headline: 7 KILLED AS HAND GRENADE ATTACKS HIT TOWNSHIPS NEAR JOHANNESBURG
abstract: Hand grenade attacks in black townships killed seven people today and explosions in Transkei, a so-called tribal homeland, set a huge fuel depot ablaze, knocked out a power station and cut off the capital's water supply, the police said.   The police said seven people were hurt in the black townships northeast of Johannesburg and that most of the casualties were men whose hands were blown off as they started to throw grenades into the homes of black policemen.   The police said another explosion in the area, possibly caused by a limpet mine, killed an eighth man who was apparently planting the explosives, and damaged an electricity substation.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *       BMW of North America Inc. , Montvale, N.J., has named Friedrich Hanau senior vice president.     *       The Coastal Corporation, Houston, a natural gas company, said Frederick M. Otto had resigned as a director and as senior executive vice president for refining and marketing operations.

headline: U.S. Said to Withhold Visa for Former Rebel
abstract: Two Democratic Congressmen said today that the Government was withholding a visa for a former Nicaraguan rebel leader to influence the debate in Congress over aid to the insurgents.   The former rebel leader, Jose Efren Martinez Mondragon, recently abandoned the insurgents' cause and requested asylum at the Mexican Embassy in Honduras.

headline: GORBACHEV AGAIN WARNS U.S. ON SPACE ARMS PLAN
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that if the United States developed space-based weapons, the price could be not only an end to the Geneva talks, but ''the scrapping of every prospect for an end to the arms race.''   Speaking at a dinner for the visiting Italian Prime Minister, Bettino Craxi, the Soviet leader said he did not sense ''an adequate readiness'' on the American side for what he called businesslike talks at the Geneva arms negotiations, which resume Thursday.   Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, who is also on a visit here, said, ''I would be surprised if any progress would be made at this next round of negotiations in Geneva.''   Mr. Brandt, who talked with Mr. Gorbachev on Monday for five hours, said at a news conference that he believed there could be progress only if the three subjects under negotiation were dealt with in their interrelationship.

headline: Chairman of A.M.C. To Join Textile Concern
abstract: W. Paul Tippett, chairman of the American Motors Corporation, said he will join Springs Industries, a Fort Mill, S.C., textile company, as president on July 15. He said he would retain the title of chairman at A.M.C. at least until a board meeting on July 8.   Mr. Tippett joined the auto maker as president in 1978 and was made chairman in 1982. Last September, he gave up the title of chief executive officer to Jose J. Dedeurwaerder, the company's president and chief operating officer. The move was seen as strengthening the ties between the troubled auto maker and its principal shareholder, Regie Nationale des Usines Renault of France. Mr. Dedeurwaerder had been an executive with Renault.

headline: Italy's President Says He Won't Run Again
abstract: President Sandro Pertini of Italy said today that he would not run for re-election this month, the Quirinal Palace said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Beefsteak Charlie's Inc. shareholders voted to change the company's name to Lifestyle Restaurants Inc.    * BellSouth Corp., Atlanta, said its board had approved a plan to offer to buy the stock of shareholders who own fewer than 100 shares.    * Chesapeake Corp., West Point, Va., said that it had entered into a definitive agreement with Philip Morris Inc. to acquire two Morris units, Wisconsin Tissue Mills Inc. and Plainwell Paper Co.

headline: Apple to Curtail Direct Sales to Corporations
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. plans to abandon most of its efforts to sell computers directly to large corporations, officials said this weekend.   Eight of the 60 people in Apple's national accounts sales force, which sold to the largest companies in the nation, have been assigned to selling computers to the educational market.

headline: Goodyear Off 22.5%; Johnson Rises
abstract: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, hurt by a general decline in the replacement tire market, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter fell 22.5 percent as revenues slipped 2 percent.     Goodyear, the country's largest tire producer, said that net income dropped to $86.7 million, or 81 cents a share, from $111.8 million, or $1.06 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenues dipped to $2.46 billion, from $2.51 billion.

headline: Metropolitan Life, Crossland Capital
abstract: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said that it had agreed to buy the Crossland Capital Corporation, which is based in Los Angeles, from the Crossland Savings Bank F.S.B. of Brooklyn for more than $200 million.

headline: Aleksandr Mikulin of Soviet; Designer of Aircraft Engines
abstract: Aleksandr A. Mikulin, a Soviet pioneer in aircraft engine design before the jet age, died May 13, according to Moscow newspapers received in the United States. He was 90 years old.

headline: Eckerd Sues Dart On Stock Purchase
abstract: The Jack Eckerd Corporation said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit seeking to stop the purchase of more of its stock by the Dart Group Corporation.   Reiterating that it was not for sale, Jack Eckerd said that it would oppose any substantial purchases of its shares by Dart Group ''as not in the best interests of Eckerd, its stockholders and employees.''

headline: Who Owns It?
abstract: To the Editor:   In your case study of Nike (May 19), you listed the Athletic Shoe Factory as one of the national chains owned by Kinney Shoe Corporation.

headline: SALVADORAN RIGHTIST PARTIES ASK FOR NEW VOTE
abstract: A coalition of right-wing parties that appeared to be the losers in national elections here demanded tonight that the vote be nullified because of improprieties, according to Mario Samayoa, president of the El Salvador's Central Elections Commission.    The Nationalist Republican Alliance and the National Conciliation Party filed the petition to nullify the vote.   Their demand, challenging the validity of the apparent upset victory on Sunday by the Christian Democratic Party of President Jose Napoleon Duarte, appears certain to trigger a major political confrontation.

headline: Pennsylvania Unit Revenue Offering
abstract: The Lehigh County Industrial Development Authority of Pennsylvania tentatively priced $55 million of 9 3/8 percent pollution control revenue bonds, due in 2015, for the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company. The underwriters are headed by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, JUNE 7, 1985        Companies    Retailers' sales results were mixed last month. Analysts saw a sign of a consumer slowdown, but noted that last year's period was particularly strong. Sears, Roebuck sales fell 1.7 percent and Penney declined 1.8 percent, but K Mart gained 12.5 percent. [D1.]    Kirk Kerkorian bid for the 30 percent of MGM Grand Hotels that he does not already own, offering $18 a share, or a total of $126 million. That price was considered generous by many Wall Street analysts, who said it reflects a brightening outlook for Nevada's gambling business. [D1.]

headline: Stocks Continue to Retreat
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average closed below 1,300 yesterday for the first time this week as profit takers again took the stock market lower in an orderly retreat.   The greatest volatility came in bank stocks, which dropped sharply on a rumor - later denied - that Argentina was planning to nationalize its banks. Analysts said investors have had big profits in these stocks over recent weeks, and did not want to wait around to see if the rumor proved to be true.   The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.05, to 1,296.71, for its second consecutive loss. The blue-chip indicator is now only about a point above the 1,295.83 close last Friday, before Wall Street had a chance to react to the discount rate cut.

headline: 2 Accounts Lost At Ally & Gargano
abstract: Ally & Gargano has lost two accounts, and no explanations were given.

headline: Xerox Announces Development Plan
abstract: The Xerox Corporation yesterday proposed a $8 billion to $10 billion dollar development on 2,267 acres it owns near Leesburg, Va., about 30 miles northwest of Washington, D.C. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., said that its unit, the Xerox Realty Corporation, had begun discussions with local government officials about the mixed-use development, which would include corporate offices, residential units, a conference center, hotels and recreational facilities. But, Thomas Abbott, a company spokesman, last night said no definite plans had been reached.

headline: Funds Assets Climb
abstract: Assets of money market mutual funds increased $2.72 billion in the week ended yesterday, to $218.84 billion, the Investment Company Institute said.

headline: NIKE STRUGGLES TO HIT ITS STRIDE AGAIN
abstract: STRATEGIES FOR RECOVERY: PROFESSOR I know of no more complicated administrative challenge than that faced by Phil Knight and his associates. It is absolutely the most complex senior manager circumstance that I've ever bumped into. The president of General Electric has a far simpler task even though G.E. is 50 times as large.

headline: AT U.N., WALTERS HOPES TO AVERT 'LYNCHING' OF U.S.
abstract: The new United States delegate, Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, says his top priority will be to increase support for American positions by refusing to tolerate unfair criticism of the United States, while at the same time paying attention to developing nations.   ''The United Nations has become a place where many countries seek to achieve a lynching of the United States by resolution,'' the retired general asserted in an interview this week. ''It is a most shamefully unfair attitude and one that arouses serious opposition from me.''   As for diplomatic tactics toward the developing nations, he said, ''You can try to enlighten them to the true motives of the United States; you can show them how it's to their advantage to vote with us and you can make plain that voting against us will have some cost in our bilateral relations.''

headline: UTILIZATION OF TRUSTS FOR LOWERING TAXES WOULD BE CURTAILED
abstract: President Reagan's tax proposal would curtail parents' use of their children as tax shelters, even for worthy purposes.   If adopted by Congress, the plan would end a popular tax-saving strategy employed by a growing number of middle- and upper-income Americans of using trusts to have investment income taxed to a child or other dependent in a low tax bracket instead of the high-bracket parent.   The new provision would generally apply to irrevocable trusts created after 1985.

headline: REAGAN IS GIVEN A LIST OF WORLD AIRPORTS DEEMED VULNERABLE TO HIJACKERS
abstract: The Reagan Administration has received a report from the Federal Aviation Administration listing airports around the world that may be vulnerable to hijackers because of lax security, Federal aviation officials said today.   The White House is considering restrictions on air traffic between the foreign airports cited and the United States. But the agencies involved said the list of airports would not be made public for now.   On June 18, President Reagan announced that he had ordered the Federal Aviation Administration to review security systems at airports around the world in response to the hijacking of Trans World Airlines Flight 847. The resulting report was delivered to the White House on Tuesday, according to Edmund Pinto, an F.A.A. spokesman.

headline: BUSINESS GAIN ON TAXES LIKELY IN REAGAN PLAN
abstract: The plan to revise the Federal income tax system that President Reagan intends to submit to Congress next week will probably be somewhat more favorable to business and less favorable to individuals than the proposal the Treasury Department presented last fall, Administration officials said today.   The Treasury's proposal last November would reduce total taxes paid by individuals by 8.5 percent and raise corporate taxes by more than 35 percent.   The officials said the President's plan, which is being designed to generate the same amount of revenue as the current tax law, would increase corporate taxes and reduce individuals' taxes, but not by so much as the November proposal.

headline: Afghan Refugee Dies in Fight
abstract: One person was killed and several were wounded in a gunfight between two groups of Afghan refugees in the North-West Frontier Province, on the Afghan border, official sources said today. They had no immediate information about the cause of the clash Saturday at a refugee camp.

headline: Progress on Sale Of Corestates Unit
abstract: The Corestates Financial Corporation announced it had reached definitive agreement for the sale of its Colonial Mortgage Service Company group to the General Motors Acceptance Corporation for $190 million.

headline: $140 Million Issue Of Georgia Bonds
abstract: The Burke County Development Authority, in Georgia, is offering $140 million of 30-year pollution control revenue bonds through underwriters led by Robinson Humphrey/American Express Inc., an Atlanta-based securities firm.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: A New Fed Battle The public wrist-slapping of Preston Martin, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board last week, may have severely damaged his chances for the No. 1 job at that august institution. In a highly unusual move, Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve's chairman, publicly chastised Mr. Martin for the vice chairman's remarks about how to handle third-world debt. Mr. Volcker, who was in Japan, went out of his way to criticize his colleague. Calling Mr. Martin's remarks ''incomprehensible,'' Mr. Volcker telephoned his complaints to the Fed in Washington, which released them to the press.   Money market participants said Mr. Volcker had been annoyed in the past by public remarks of Board members, but had kept his criticisms private. Mr. Martin, however, is viewed as a special case. He is widely believed to aspire to the Fed chairmanship, and, as a Reagan appointee, was considered a likely candidate for the No. 1 Fed job should Mr. Volcker step down during Mr. Reagan's tenure.

headline: TRADE GAP EASED A BIT IN MARCH
abstract: The United States had an $11 billion trade deficit in March, even with a lighter-than-usual influx of oil and automobiles, the Commerce Department said today.   The March deficit brought the first-quarter total to $32.8 billion, the report said. That is nearly 9 percent ahead of the 1984 pace that led to a record $123.3 billion total for the year.

headline: ISRAELI ENGINEER SAYS HE GOT SWITCHES USED IN ATOM ARMS
abstract: An electronics engineer at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem said tonight that he bought krytron switches from an American manufacturer for the school's Physics Department in 1976.   The engineer, Hanan Boasson, said he saw the items listed in an catalogue supplied by the Israeli agent for the American company, E E & G. He said he inquired about the price and then simply placed an order, which was then filled.

headline: China Imposes a BanOn Obscene Material
abstract: The Chinese Government announced today that it would ban the import or manufacture of a wide range of what it called obscene materials, including explicit films and magazines, sex aids and aphrodisiacs.   An edict published in People's Daily said the ban covered all audiovisual and printed matter that ''specifically portrays sexual behavior or publicizes pornographic and lascivious images.''   Smugglers or sellers of pornography risk fines or jail.

headline: Big Board President Is Named
abstract: Robert J. Birnbaum, president and chief operating officer of the American Stock Exchange, was named president and chief operating officer of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.     Mr. Birnbaum's appointment, which had been expected, is apparently the first time a senior official of one exchange has moved to a senior post at the other.    Some analysts in the financial community have speculated that the Birnbaum appointment would make a Big Board-American exchange merger more likely, because the New York exchange wants to expand in options trading, an area of strength for the much smaller American exchange.

headline: OFFICIALS IN IRELAND DISCUSS HOW TO APPROACH INQUIRY INTO AIR-INDIA DISASTER
abstract: Officials began discussions today on how to investigate the crash of an Air-India airliner that fell into the Atlantic on Sunday, taking 329 people to their deaths.   With 131 bodies recovered, an effort was pressed to find two cockpit monitoring devices. The Challenger, a British vessel that designed to recover objects from the seabed, is steaming toward the crash site.      Ocean Is 6,000 Feet Deep    On Monday, the Challenger met a helicopter carrying technicians and equipment that should improve the ship's ability to probe the 6,000-foot-deep ocean area presumed to be the resting place of the bulk of the jumbo jet.

headline: PATENTS;  Selectively Eliminating Parts of Broadcasts
abstract: A system for selective elimination of portions of television and radio programs was patented this week by Henry Von Kohorn of Greenwich, Conn., a retired engineering executive.

headline: ADVERTISING ;   Cinematographer Hired For Pentax Campaign
abstract: It takes a pretty strong (or heartless) person not to feel an emotional tug while watching those down-home Kodak commercials from J. Walter Thompson. Of course, given the sponsor, the demands for good photography are high.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *        Advanced Tobacco Products Inc., San Antonio, said it would begin test- marketing its Favor smokeless cigarette on May 1.     *       Austin Co., Cleveland, a unit of National Gypsum Co., said it won a contract from the Buick division of General Motors Corp. to construct a parts terminal at Flint, Mich., that may cost more than $25 million.

headline: GORBACHEV, RECEIVING O'NEILL, URGES U.S. TO END 'ICE AGE'
abstract: The Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, told a visiting Congressional group today that United States-Soviet relations had been suffering an ice age, and he urged Washington to show the political will to overcome it.    In remarks reported by the Tass press agency, he told Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House of Representatives, that the Soviet Union favored detente and that ''our nations can gain much from the development of broad and fruitful cooperation.''    Later, at a news conference, Mr. O'Neill said he and three other House members had met with Mr. Gorbachev in the Kremlin for three and three- quarter hours, more than twice the planned time, and had been impressed by his toughness, knowledge and persuasiveness.        Letter From Reagan Delivered    The Speaker, who is a Massachusetts Democrat, said the Americans had delivered a letter from President Reagan, though he declined to disclose the contents.

headline: People
abstract: * George Beech has joined Kenyon & Eckhardt/Detroit as executive vice president and general manager;       Bruce Andrews, a senior vice president, has been promoted to associate general manager there, and       Alan Levenstein has rejoined the agency in New York as executive vice president and chairman of the operations committee.     *        James R. Heekin has joined J. Walter Thompson as senior vice president.     *        David W. Basch has been appointed executive vice president and       Robert L. Hurley and       David Miln elected to the board at Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Inc.       Libby Daniell and       Myron Polenberg have been named senior vice presidents.

headline: HONDURAN ARMY KILLS AMERICAN
abstract: An American citizen was shot and killed by a Honduran Army patrol near the Salvadoran border, a United States Embassy spokesman said today. A Honduran military spokesman said the American was shot Wednesday when he tried to flee from a border patrol that had asked him for identification.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: FORMAL LINK OF STEPS BARRED
abstract: The Reagan Administration has told several friendly governments that if the 40 American hostages are freed unconditionally by the hijackers in Beirut, Israel will follow with the release of the 766 detainees, Administration officials said today.   But the Administration was also said to have told diplomats that the United States will maintain its principle of not bargaining, or negotiating, or giving in to terrorist demands. Thus, the officials said, it is trying to convey to the Lebanese Shiite leader Nabih Berri through the foreign governments that the hijackers' demands can be met, but only if there is no attempt at formal linkage.

headline: Heroin Arrests in Singapore
abstract: Narcotics officers have seized heroin worth $2.5 million at Changi Airport and have arrested a woman and two men, the Government-run radio said today. The woman was arrested at the airport Friday with five pounds of heroin strapped to her body as she was about to board a plane for the United States, and the men were arrested later, the radio said. Officials said all were Singaporeans.

headline: GORBACHEV CRITICAL OF SOVIET ECONOMY INT HE FIRST QUARTER
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, called today for discipline, efficiency and accountability in the economy.    In a speech to party officials and to economic managers, he was also critical of the first-quarter results, which he said had been hurt by complacency, poor organization and the lack of a sense of responsibility.

headline: Gannett Curbs
abstract: The Gannett Company is asking shareholders to approve two proposals it says would reduce the likelihood of a hostile takeover.

headline: ARCO SETS PACT TO SELL STATIONS
abstract: The Atlantic Richfield Company said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell more than 400 of its gasoline stations in eight states and the District of Columbia to the Shell Oil Company.
