Neither company would disclose the financial terms of the agreement, which they said had yet to be compeleted.

headline: Progress Is Reported On Channel Tunnel
abstract: Britain and France agreed today to hasten preparations for the long-awaited tunnel under the English Channel.   A spokesman for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said she had agreed in talks here with President Francois Mitterrand to speed up work on a treaty fixing the details for the tunnel - most likely a rail link.

headline: Burroughs Plants
abstract: The Burroughs Corporation, the Detroit-based computer company, announced it would close a plant here and an engineering facility in Orlando by Oct. 31. The two closings will involve transfers or layoffs of 600 employees in the Coral Springs encoding and imaging division and 150 workers in the Orlando engineering section beginning next month, company officials said. The closings are part of a yearlong consolidation.

headline: AIRLINER DISASTERS: HISTORY'S WORST
abstract: June 23, 1985: An Air-India Boeing 747 plunges into the sea off the Irish coast, apparently killing all on board, and an Indian official attributed the crash to an explosion. Sept. 1, 1983: A Korean Air Lines 747 is shot down by a Soviet fighter after flying through Soviet airspace near Sakhalin Island. All 269 people aboard are killed. Dec. 1, 1981: A chartered Yugoslavian Inex-Adria Airways DC-9 slams into a fog-shrouded mountain near Ajaccio, Corsica, killing all 178 people on board. Aug. 19, 1980: Fire bursts out aboard a Saudi Arabian Airlines L-1011 Lockheed TriStar jet as it waits to taxi at Riyadh airport. All 301 people aboard are killed. Nov. 28, 1979: An Air Zealand DC-10 carrying 257 people on a sightseeing flight from Auckland to the South Pole, strikes Mount Erebus in Antarctica. There are no survivors. May 25, 1979: In the worst domestic air disaster, a Los Angeles-bound American Airlines DC-10 crashes shortly after takeoff from O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, killing all 272 aboard and two men on the ground. Nov. 15, 1978: A chartered DC-8 jetliner carrying Indonesian Moslems home from a pilgrimage to Mecca, Saudi Arabia, crashes outside the airport at Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing 183 of 259 passengers. Jan. 1, 1978: An Air-India 747 bound for the Middle East sheikdom of Dubai with 213 persons aboard explodes in the air and plunges into the sea less than two minutes after takeoff from Bombay.

headline: EXPERT CALLS SPORTS VIOLENCE PART OF A CHAIN OF AGGRESSION
abstract: An expert on sports-related violence said yesterday that the riot by soccer fans in Brussels was the product of a ''vicious cycle of aggressive events that perpetuate themselves.''   Dr. Jeffrey H. Goldstein, a professor of psychology at Temple University in Philadelphia, said the final outbreak of aggression, such as what happened in Brussels, involved events that occurred much earlier.   ''The people watching an aggressive sport are likely to become more aggressive themselves, thus the sequence of events tends to perpetuate itself -the fans themselves feel aggressive, they sense or see aggression, and then they act aggressively,'' he said.

headline: BUNDESBANK TO LOOSEN RULES
abstract: The Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, has begun to move cautiously toward opening the country's financial markets, acceding reluctantly to growing international and market pressure to take such a step.    Various indications woven into public speeches in recent weeks that such a new stance was emerging were confirmed this week by bank officials in meetings with representatives of foreign banks, including the major United States banks that operate in Germany.   Under a comprehensive package of new capital market arrangements disclosed at the meetings, the central bank will allow foreign bank subsidiaries to act as lead managers for German mark-denominated bonds of a minimum denomination of 20 million marks, or about $9 million at the current rate of exchange.

headline: Midcon Increases Its Credit Line
abstract: The Midcon Corporation said that it had increased its credit line to $2.5 billion, from $900 million, saying that the money could be used for acquisitions. The action by Midcon, a natural gas pipeline company based in Lombard, Ill., stirred up new takeover speculation in that industry.

headline: GORBACHEV CALLS GENEVA ARMS TALKS FRUITLESS
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, gave a warm welcome today to Willy Brandt, the former West German Chancellor, and told him the Geneva arms talks had so far proved ''completely fruitless.''   After the highly publicized five-hour meeting with Mr. Brandt, a member of the West German delegation said at a news conference that Mr. Gorbachev had said he saw little hope for progress at the talks, which resume Thursday, unless the United States revises its policies.   Calling Mr. Gorbachev ''harder than some believe,'' the West German spokesman said the Soviet leader, echoing an assessment he made when the first round of talks ended on April 23, had called the discussions fruitless.   The West German spokesman, Egon Bahr, an arms expert in Mr. Brandt's opposition Social Democratic Party, said Mr. Gorbachev also said that contacts and preparations were under way for a summit meeting with President Reagan but that details had not been fixed.

headline: PAPANDREOU HOPES FOR BETTER TIES WITH THE U.S. IN HIS SECOND TERM
abstract: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, in his first news conference after his re-election Sunday, expressed hope today for improved relations with the United States.   Mr. Papandreou hedged in replying to two questions on issues regarding the United States that could become divisive during his second four-year term.   Asked whether he would demand the withdrawal of American military bases here when the present agreement makes this possible, the Prime Minister referred to his Government's formal interpretation of the 1983 accord given to Parliament. The interpretation stated that the accord was intended to lead to the removal of the bases but left the timing open.

headline: A Balanced Approach At F.C.&B.
abstract: THE annual report of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications includes a three-page essay entitled ''Analysis and Artistry.'' It deals with the information explosion and the proper utilization of the hemispheres of the brain, with the left handling analysis and the right, creativity.   ''At Foote, Cone & Belding,'' it says, ''we are developing systems and inventing processes to outlaw 'the tyranny of the left' and unleash the full imagination of the right. To bridge the gap - with projects that need analysis and artistry, relevance and surprise.''

headline: Florida Company Sold
abstract: The Senior Corporation said today it had been sold for $141 million to a corporation owned by the William Lyon Company, a California home builder, and the J.D.H. Realty Company.

headline: U.S. SUES ON PENTAGON LAUNDRY BILLS
abstract: The Justice Department sued two executives and their Florida company today on charges of defrauding the Pentagon on laundry contracts.   The defendants received about $15.7 million in ''excessive and inflated profits'' because of ''false or fraudulent activity,'' the department said. The suit seeks $47.2 million, three times the overcharge.

headline: PLAN WOULD END $1 TAX CHECKOFF FOR CAMPAIGNS
abstract: President Reagan's tax plan proposes that Congress end the current system of public financing for Presidential elections by repealing the $1 checkoff allowed on tax returns. If adopted, the step would radically alter the way Presidential campaigns have been paid for since 1976.   At the top of their returns, taxpayers can indicate whether they want $1 of their taxes to go into the Presidential Election Campaign Fund, which last year paid $40.4 million each to Mr. Reagan and his Democratic opponent, Walter F. Mondale, for the general election campaign. In exchange for public financing, candidates forgo private contributions in the general election.

headline: 14 South Africans Seized In Disinvestment Protest
abstract: The police arrested 14 blacks who gathered outside the United States Consulate today to protest foreign investment, witnesses said.

headline: PATENTS;  Inventor of the Year
abstract: Intellectual Property Owners Inc., an organization of patent, trademark and copyright owners, will hold a reception honoring its Inventor of the Year next Wednesday evening in Washington's Senate Caucus Room. Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, will introduce Dr. Jewell L. Osterholm of Thomas Jefferson University as Inventor of the Year and present a $2,500 award to him. He developed a system for the treatment of stroke.

headline: Time Magazine to Start Statue of Liberty Ads
abstract: The July 8 issue of Time magazine, out next week, will carry the first of 18 full-page ads in space donated by the publication that will promote contributions to the Statue of Liberty/ Ellis Island Foundation.   The magazine announced its plan in January, when it asked ad agencies to donate advertising for the space.

headline: MEESE SAYS U.S. CONCURS ON MENGELE
abstract: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that the Justice Department believed that a body recently exhumed in Brazil was that of the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele.   He said the department had accepted the conclusion of an international group of medical experts that had identified the remains.   ''Based on the information available from the forensic examination, these experts have concluded that the body exhumed by Brazilian authorities is in fact Josef Mengele,'' he said in a written statement. ''Representatives of the United States Government took part in the examination of the remains and concur in the conclusion.

headline: Mead Profits Rise 9.3%
abstract: The Mead Corporation, a paper products company based in Dayton, Ohio, announced yesterday that earnings in the first quarter rose 9.3 percent, to $23.6 million, or 76 cents a share, from $21.6 million, or 71 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1984. Sales edged up 2 percent, to $670.4 million, from $657.3 million.

headline: SUDANESE UNIONS CALL OFF STRIKE THAT LED TO COUP
abstract: Unions representing professional workers in the Sudan formally called off a five-day general strike tonight that helped touch off the overthrow of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry on Saturday.     The strike's end was announced in separate statements broadcast on the official Sudan radio by a representative of the unions and Gen. Siwar el- Dahab, the new military leader.   On Sunday, the labor unions were reported to have decided to continue the strike until the state security apparatus was dissolved and the Government was turned over to civilians.    (In Washington, Administration officials said military leaders in the Sudan had decided to oust Mr. Nimeiry to forestall a move by younger military officers. Page A7.)

headline: New Mexico Offering Tax Refunding Bonds
abstract: New Mexico offered $262.4 million of severance tax refunding revenue bonds in serial form yesterday through underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company. Underwriters offered the bonds with tentative yields ranging from 4.80 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6 3/4 percent in 1990, 7.20 percent in 1992 and 7.60 percent in 1994.   The bonds, rated Aaa by Moody's Investors Service and AA+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, are backed by taxes levied by New Mexico on mineral extraction and production processes within the state.

headline: WEILL'S DEPARTURE OF AMERICAN EXPRESS
abstract: The American Express Company announced yesterday that Sanford I. Weill had resigned as president and that it had named Louis V. Gerstner Jr., head of travel services, to succeed him.   Mr. Weill's resignation came after months of rumors that the strong-willed Wall Street executive was restless in the huge company and after he made at least two unreported attempts to buy the troubled Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, which he headed, from American Express.   Mr. Gerstner, 43 years old, will assume the No. 2 post Aug. 1, when Mr. Weill's resignation becomes effective. Mr. Weill will continue as a consultant to American Express until his employment contract expires in June of 1986.   The new president, described by associates as a consummate operations man, is credited with revitalizing the company's travel division, now American Express's biggest profit center. [Page D5.]  The company also announced that it planned a partial divestiture of Fireman's Fund. [Page D5.]  Mr. Weill, who is 52, made his mark by forging a string of brokerage houses into what today is the giant Shearson Lehman Brothers investment banking arm of American Express.

headline: Advertising;   A Way To 'Coat' TV Spots
abstract: DOG owners frequently get their pets to take pills by wrapping them in little coats of chopped meat. General Foods is discovering that a similar ploy works pretty well with TV commercials.   In order to combat the ''zapping'' craze and get consumers to watch General Foods video ads without jumping to another channel, the White Plains package goods giant has been wrapping its 30-second commercial messages in a bit of meatier programming, something informative and noncommercial that makes the pill easier to swallow.   It doesn't require much - about 60 or 90 seconds - making a total package of two minutes or less.

headline: EMIGRES CRITICIZE U. S. NAZI-HUNTERS
abstract: Baltic and Ukrainian emigre organizations have accused the Justice Department's Nazi-hunting unit of using fraudulent evidence from the Soviet Union in its efforts to deport people accused of taking part in Nazi war crimes.   Their statements at a news conference Friday underscored a growing controversy between Jewish groups and some Eastern European emigre groups over the operations of the Office of Special Investigations, a Justice Department unit set up to find Nazi war criminals in the United States and deport them.   The Eastern European emigre groups assailed the World Jewish Congress at the news conference Friday for a recent study, in which the Jewish group charged that the emigre groups' attack on the Justice Department unit was a result of anti-Semitism and was designed to shield people who took part in Nazi atrocities in Eastern Europe during World War II.   Anthony B. Mazeika, vice president of the Baltic American Freedom League, said the group sought ''solidarity with our Jewish brethren'' in pursuing war criminals by ''constitutionally correct'' procedures.

headline: GRIFFIN BELL RETAINED BY HUTTON
abstract: The E.F. Hutton Group Inc. has retained a former Attorney General of the United States, Griffin B. Bell, to determine which individuals had personal responsibility for the extensive check fraud scheme to which Hutton's brokerage subsidiary pleaded guilty on May 2, the company said yesterday.   The announcement, made at Hutton's annual meeting by its chairman, Robert Fomon, follows widespread outcries from members of Congress and others urging that officers and personnel responsible for the crime be punished. Hutton had said at the time it pleaded guilty that it would be conducting its own internal investigation.

headline: Bond-Warrant Link by Intel
abstract: The Intel Corporation is offering $215 million of units consisting of zero coupon bonds due in 1995 and warrants to buy common stock though underwriters led by L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin. The financing, which underwriters said was attracting both equity- and debt-oriented investors, was said to be the first of its kind.

headline: Comerica Seeking Michigan National
abstract: Comerica Inc., the second-largest bank holding company in Michigan, said that it had filed with the Federal Reserve Board for authority to take steps toward aquiring the troubled Michigan National Corporation.    Michigan National said it would resist Comerica's effort.

headline: German Sees the U.S. In Shift on 'Star Wars'
abstract: One of West Germany's most vigorous supporters of President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' plan says the United States is no longer interested in getting its European allies involved in the missile defense system.   The supporter, Lothar Spaeth, a Christian Democratic provincial leader, said in an interview published today in the newspaper Stuttgarter Zeitung that his recent talks in Washington had convinced him the United States had changed its mind about making the space-based system, formally called the Strategic Defense Initiative, a joint program.

headline: RESETTLES CHINESE STAGE A PEKING SIT-IN
abstract: Hundreds of men and women who resettled in the countryside during the Cultural Revolution broke a taboo on public protests today by occupying the steps of Peking's Communist Party headquarters and demanding permission to live in the capital.   Nearly 17 years after they set off for Shaanxi province proclaiming their support for Mao Zedong, the former Red Guards returned in a mood of truculence and disillusion. Although the policy of forcing young city dwellers to settle among the peasants was abandoned more than a decade ago, hundreds of thousands of people were never given the residence permits required to come home.   Resentment can be found wherever resettlement took place, but concerns about retribution have generally stifled public protests. Instead, those separated from their families and friends have generally concentrated their efforts on working the network of influential contacts, known as guanxi, that Chinese try to develop as a means of getting favors from the bureaucracy. 20,000 Reportedly Still in Shaanxi Those who joined the protest today were the losers in this game of maneuver. As they sat beneath large red-and-white banners proclaiming their cause, a member of the group said they represented about 20,000 people still ''exiled'' in Shaanxi, out of 400,000 originally sent there from the capital in 1968. Most were in their teens or early 20's at the time, and are now approaching middle age.

headline: Western Union Records Loss
abstract: The Western Union Corporation said today that it lost $15.3 million in the first quarter, in contrast to net income of $14.1 million, or 50 cents a share, a year ago.

headline: Market Place;   High Returns On Drug Issues
abstract: WHAT William J. Hayes calls his ''big bet'' on major drug stocks has paid off handsomely for the portfolio manager of the Fidelity Select Health Care mutual fund. So far this year, its total return of 45.2 percent ranks as the best performance among 818 mutual funds monitored by Lipper Analytical Services.   This compares with a total return - price appreciation plus dividends and interest reinvested - of 16.3 percent for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in the same period through June 6. The average return for all mutual funds was 13.4 percent.

headline: I. Goldberg & Partners Eager for Accounts
abstract: Only last month it was announced that Irwin Goldberg, executive vice president and co-creative director of Nadler & Larimer, would be vice chairman and executive creative director of the agency that had been reorganized into Calvillo, Shevack, Goldberg & Partners.   Now, with two executive associates from the old Nadler & Larimer operation he has departed that scene and has opened I. Goldberg & Partners at 235 East 34th Street with no accounts but a considerable amount of eagerness.

headline: Bolivian Troops Occupy A Provincial Capital
abstract: Troops occupied one of Bolivia's provincial capitals today after demonstrators there set fire to an official car and stoned the homes of city and provincial administrators during a strike rally, officials said.   They said soldiers moved into Sucre, the capital of Chuquisaca Province, where a mass rally was scheduled to discuss a four-day strike called by the authorities in the province, who have demanded greater local spending by the central Government.   Interior Minister Gustavo Sanchez said the disturbances were caused by groups that wanted to sabotage the talks between the provincial authorities and the central Government.

headline: ISRAELI COALITION SEEMS IMPERILED
abstract: The prisoner exchange carried out today provoked demonstrations and appeared to be growing into a controversy that could shake the coalition Government.   For many Israelis, the exchange was a bittersweet moment at best, and perhaps the first time in Israeli history that the nation as a whole did not celebrate the return of captured sons.   The Foreign Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, asked Prime Minister Shimon Peres to have the Cabinet consider an amnesty for the 19 Jewish suspects still on trial for anti-Arab violence and the eight others already convicted, the Israeli radio reported tonight.   Mr. Peres's office had no comment on the report, but he was not believed to favor interfering with the judicial process. The radio said Mr. Shamir was prepared to bring down the coalition Cabinet over the issue. Mr. Shamir belongs to the Likud bloc and Mr. Peres to the Labor Party. The two joined together after neither emerged as clear winner in the election last July.

headline: World Trade Council Tables Nicaraguan Embargo Protest
abstract: The United States today blocked an attempt by Nicaragua to have the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade here condemn the United States embargo against the Central American nation.   Although many nations supported the Nicaraguan case against the trade embargo that went into effect last month, the 90-nation council concluded its all-day meeting with a statement saying only that it would ''consult on how the matter could be dealt with at a subsequent meeting.''   Nicaragua had called for the council meeting to protest the Reagan Administration move and to win approval of negotiations to settle the dispute in the context of the tariff organization.

headline: Pope to Visit Australia
abstract: Pope John Paul II will visit Australia next year, Deputy Prime Minister Lionel Bowen of Australia said today. He said the Pope had accepted an invitation from Prime Minister Bob Hawke and the country's Roman Catholic bishops to visit in November 1986.

headline: Ambassador to Iraq Named
abstract: David G. Newton, a Foreign Service officer, has been nominated as the first United States Ambassador to Iraq since diplomatic relations between the two countries resumed, the White House announced today. Mr. Newton, 50 years old, a native of Boston, has been the charge d'affaires at the American Embassy in Baghdad for the last five months.
